HEADLINE: Sunny Forecast for Los Angeles Mayor

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 8

 BODY:
At a breakfast speech to a business group the other day, Mayor Richard J. Riordan, the affable Republican who took on the leadership of the nation's second-largest city four years ago, delivered a sunny summary of the state of his city: leadership in the fields of entertainment, biotechnology, international trade and apparel, and recovery from a devastating earthquake and riot.
"Today I stand here at Town Hall to declare, Los Angeles is on a roll," Mr. Riordan proclaimed. 
 Whether his sprawling, sun-drenched, smog-smudged city is really on a roll is a subject of perpetual debate among Angelenos, but there seems little doubt that Mr. Riordan himself is. A month before the nonpartisan city election in which he is seeking a second term, he has a 2-to-1 lead in the polls over his principal opponent, State Senator Tom Hayden, and a better than 10-to-1 advantage in fund-raising.
Last week, Mr. Riordan, a multimillionaire lawyer and businessman who had never run for office before winning City Hall in 1993, narrowly won the endorsement of the local branch of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., despite Mr. Hayden's celebrated support for the migrant workers of Cesar Chavez and three decades of association with liberal causes. On Thursday, the Mayor broadcast his first television commercial of the campaign, a feel-good hymn in which a narrator brags about "2,000 new cops," "30,000 new jobs" and "a good start from our great Mayor -- and he works for us for just $1 a year."
The commercial was made by Mr. Riordan's media team of Bill Carrick and Hank Morris, a pair of longtime Democrats who have worked for candidates from Senator Dianne Feinstein to the New York City Comptroller, Alan C. Hevesi, and their willingness to cross party lines to work for him is itself a sign of Mr. Riordan's broad, bipartisan appeal.
Mr. Hayden, the 1960's student protester who was once married to Jane Fonda and who has spent 15 years in the State Legislature, is running a grass-roots, shoestring campaign, but has been at some pains to get any traction. He has raised just about $200,000 (half of it from himself) to $2.4 million for Mr. Riordan, though he will eventually get more because he, unlike the Mayor, is taking part in the city's voluntary campaign finance system, which offers matching public money in exchange for limits on contributions and spending.
Mr. Hayden has also been hard pressed to make headway even among the minority groups, liberals and members of the entertainment industry who should be his natural base. Few give him much chance of holding Mr. Riordan below the majority vote needed to avoid a runoff.
"Tom shouldn't even be running," said Susan Estrich, a veteran Democrat who managed Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign in 1988 and is an old friend of Mr. Hayden's but is supporting Mr. Riordan.
"He's 57 years old and he's having an identity crisis," she said. "I sat with him for hours to say, 'Don't do this.' It was clearly a suicide mission. Even his close friends, I don't think, think he has a chance."
It is not that Mr. Riordan is such a dynamo at the age of 66, though he does like to glide along at the beach with in-line skates. In contrast to his Republican counterpart in New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Riordan is a phlegmatic, aw-shucks sort, a halting public speaker with a tendency to step on his own lines and an unusual willingness to defer a question to a nearby aide. At his speech on the city's economy on Wednesday, he repeatedly mangled the tag line of his text, which proclaimed Los Angeles as the "capital city of the future," instead referring to it as "the capital city of the world."
"He's not polished, and I think that's what people like about him," said Noelia Rodriguez, the City Hall press secretary who is on leave to serve as the Mayor's campaign communications director.
But after prevailing four years ago over a crowded field to succeed Tom Bradley, the city's first black mayor, who served for 20 years, Mr. Riordan has worked tirelessly to reassure a city shaken by the 1992 riots and the police brutality that helped provoke them, overseeing the expansion of the police force to its largest level in history and presiding over a 25 percent drop in crime. "It all comes back to safety," he said in his speech.
Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Center for Politics and Economics at the Claremont Graduate School, said the calculus was simple, especially in a city where the City Council, independent boards and the county government hold great sway and the mayor's powers are limited compared with cities like New York, Boston and Chicago.
"Riordan campaigned on two issues, jobs and public safety," Ms. Jeffe said, "and the perception among the electorate -- and I always make a distinction between the electorate and the rest of the city -- is that the economy is picking up and crime statistics are down. They're satisfied with the way things are going, so why get rid of a mayor?"
The Mayor, like Mr. Giuliani and President Clinton, has also adopted the prevailing bipartisan mantra of minimalist government mixed with activist volunteerism. Last week, for example, Mr. Riordan proposed a five-year freeze on city business taxes for businesses willing to relocate or stay in distressed urban areas, and set a goal of designating 15 new magnet schools for multimedia training, to be financed with $1 million from the private sector.
For his part, Mr. Hayden has the challenge of persuading voters who hope they have put the worst behind them that they are not as happy as they think. In his economic proposal, released a day ahead of Mr. Riordan's last week, Mr. Hayden chose to see the glass as half-full, emphasizing an increase in the number of local business failures and personal bankruptcies last year. And he proposed much more sweeping solutions, including a $250 million bond issue for multimedia schools to train the animators, technicians and computer graphics experts of the future.
Mr. Hayden's spokesman, Rocky Rushing, conceded a setback in losing the endorsement of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor, but said it reflected the conservative bent of older union leadership.
"We knew it would be a fight to get it," Mr. Rushing said. "What I think it says is that the old guard is still in place in terms of leaders' embracing the status quo. I think Tom has very good relations with the younger activists who are shaking things up."
Paradoxically, Mr. Riordan and Mr. Hayden have a fair amount in common. Both share Celtic, Catholic roots, though Mr. Riordan has been far more active among lay Catholics as a longtime philanthropist, while Mr. Hayden, whose alienation from the church dates to its hawkish stance on the Vietnam War, has only lately begun to rediscover and celebrate the faith of his forebears.
Both also live in the wealthy enclave of Brentwood, since Mr. Hayden rented out his house in the adjoining beach-front city of Santa Monica to run for mayor this year, a fact that has let the Riordan campaign suggest he is a flaky carpetbagger by referring to him as "Santa Monica Senator Tom Hayden."
Mr. Hayden counters that Mr. Riordan's assertion of 30,000 new jobs ignores the reality that most of them are in low-wage occupations and the result of an economic cycle.
"For Riordan to claim credit for them," the Hayden economic position paper says, "is like Jack Nicholson claiming he scores Laker baskets by cheering."

HEADLINE: Dan E. Sweat Dies at 63; Guided Atlanta

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Dan E. Sweat Jr., a self-styled Federal bagman and municipal whipping boy who spent 30 years whipping Atlanta into modern shape as its premier civic administrator, died on Feb. 28 at his home in Atlanta. He was 63 and had been suffering from stomach cancer.
On paper, Mr. Sweat was never more than a high-profile functionary -- administrative assistant to Atlanta mayors, point man for the city's powerful downtown business interests and, later, coordinator of Jimmy Carter's ambitious urban cure-all known as the Atlanta Project. 
 Yet Mr. Sweat proved so adept at negotiating the city's political thicket and so adroit at securing Federal money for the myriad projects he dreamed up, designed and implemented for his patrons that he put his own stamp on the city.
Among other things, Mr. Sweat, who once described his job as "hustling Federal money," was credited with rescuing the Chattahoochee River and preserving the city's water supply, transforming an abandoned downtown tract into an integrated, mixed-income residential communiy, and spearheading programs intended to bring the city's black and white leaders together.
Along the way, he recruited and trained so many administrators that there is hardly a civic agency in the city without one of his proteges at the helm or in a high position.
Over the years, Mr. Sweat became so closely identified with virtually every facet of Atlanta's drive to put its racist past behind it and become a modern, enlightened city that it was easy to forget that he was not an Atlanta native but a railroad machinist's son from Waycross, Ga.
Or, as Mr. Sweat liked to put it when he was in an aw-shucks mood, he was an "old boy from the Okefenokee" who arrived in Atlanta on a Greyhound bus in 1952, at the age of 18, and never stopped referring to his adopted city as "up here."
Originally aiming for a career in journalism, Mr. Sweat enrolled in night courses at Georgia State University and took a daytime job as a reporter for The Atlanta Journal, but because the school had no journalism major, he graduated with a degree in public administration.
After a three-year stint as a naval officer, he returned to his job at The Journal, but he soon left to become the spokesman for the DeKalb County Commission chairman, Charles Emmerich, a legendary local reformer who was so impressed with Mr. Sweat that he quickly made him his chief administrative assistant.
After Mr. Emmerich's defeat in 1964, Mr. Sweat became associate executive director of Economic Opportunity Atlanta, an agency formed to attract and distribute Federal antipoverty money. So much of that money came in during Mr. Sweat's tenure that he was soon hired away by Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. as Atlanta's chief administrative officer, a post he also held under Mr. Allen's successor, Sam Massell.
After a year as executive director of the Atlanta Regional Commission in 1972, Mr. Sweat began a 15-year-run as president of Central Atlanta Progress, an association of downtown business leaders.
Under Mr. Sweat's direction, the association attacked Atlanta's problems on a broad front, stimulating construction, reclaiming the downtown area as a residential district and working with community groups on an array of programs to establish and strengthen ties between black and white Atlanta.
For Mr. Sweat, a tireless administrator who often worked long hours, it was not always smooth sailing.
A sometimes brusque man who could be impatient with municipal bureaucracy, Mr. Sweat, who made a career cutting through red tape, was often a lightning rod for criticism and had some monumental battles with city officials, including the city's first black Mayor, Maynard H. Jackson Jr. He once went so far as to bar a City Hall doorway to keep Mr. Jackson from storming out of a meeting.
Mr. Sweat, who left the association in 1988 to run a local foundation, was hired in 1991 by Mr. Carter to run the Atlanta Project, which seeks to solve virtually every urban problem through cooperative efforts of business and community groups. He remained until 1995.
He is survived by his mother, Kathleen Sweat of Waverly, Ga.,; his wife, Tally; a daughter, Sally, of Waverly; two sons, Stephen, of Atlanta and Charles, of LaGrange, Ga.; five sisters, Elouise McCrary of Brunswick, Ga., Ruth Lopez of High Springs, Fla., and Merle Kimbrell, Linda Strickland and Vivian Ragan, all of Waverly, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Retirement Planning for Too Much of a Good Thing

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
THE notion that Congress might enact a tax break and that accountants would advise their clients to go easy on taking advantage of it would seem about as likely as children deciding on Christmas morning to go easy on opening their presents. Yet, it has happened -- the tax break part, that is.
The break, a complicated one, concerns tax-deferred retirement plans, an area in which Congress passed significant legislation in 1996. For three years, beginning this year, taxpayers older than 59 1/2 can take as much as they like out of I.R.A.'s, Keogh plans, employer-sponsored pension plans or 401(k) or 403(b) plans without having to pay the 15 percent excise tax that would normally be owed on 1997 distributions exceeding $160,000, or $800,000 for a lump-sum payout. 
 Years ago, Congress decided to defer taxes both on deposits into qualified retirement plans and on the income they earned until withdrawn. The point was to encourage retirement savings. But to make sure such generosity was not abused, Congress also decided on a series of penalties: for early withdrawal, for failing to take money out on time, for excess distributions and, finally, when estates were left with big balances, for excess accumulation.
With the stock market's boom, many people now have the problem of their dreams. Their retirement plans have grown so much that plan holders are likely to incur excess distribution penalties, or -- if the money stays in the accounts -- their estates may be gutted by a combination of estate taxes, which reach as high as 55 percent at the Federal level, income taxes and the 15 percent excess-accumulation excise tax.
"Some retirement plans have doubled in the past year," said Edward A. Slott, a partner in E. Slott & Company, an accounting firm in Rockville Centre, L.I. "A million dollars is not uncommon anymore. The average person's largest asset is often an I.R.A." Many people who quit a job or retire early roll over money from a corporate plan into an I.R.A.
SO Congress offered such taxpayers a three-year opportunity to withdraw big sums free of the excise tax. Yet accountants are counseling caution.
"It's a great temptation, but you still have to pay ordinary income tax" on any money withdrawn, said Stephen Pennacchio, a partner with KPMG Peat Marwick in New York. In doing numerous calculations for clients, he said he has found that "in most cases it is beneficial to leave the money in" for continued tax-deferred growth.
Avery E. Neumark, director of employee benefits and executive compensation for the New York accounting firm of Rosen Seymour Shapss Martin & Company, said he was "not rushing to have clients take money out."
"If you are going to do anything," he said, "wait until the third year" and let the account grow in the meantime.
Besides, he said, he saw "a very good possibility the excise tax won't be reinstated." Unless a person's individual circumstances warrant taking money out now, Mr. Neumark said he would prefer to see what happened in the next couple of years.
In deciding whether to make large withdrawals or to leave the money to grow tax-free and eventually pay the excise tax, considerations include account balances, a person's projected tax rate, projected inflation rate, the expected annual return on investment, life expectancy and what use will be made of the money withdrawn.
In general, the longer money remains in a plan and the higher the rate of return, the more likely that the advantage of tax-deferred growth, even with an eventual excise tax, will outweigh the benefit of pulling out money now to avoid the excise tax.
However, if the taxpayer is very elderly or terminally ill or if the plan is earning little, withdrawing money now makes sense, as it may for someone who has a specific use in mind for the money, like starting a new business.
Mr. Neumark, who is chairman of the employee benefits committee of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, cited calculations for a taxpayer with a combined Federal and state income tax rate of 45 percent, assuming that a deferred distribution would be subject to the excise tax that would be avoided now.
With only a 2 percent annual rate of return on the retirement plan, the taxpayer would be better off withdrawing the money now. With a 4 percent return, the money would have to stay in 20 years for tax-free growth to be the better deal; at 6 percent, it would take 12 years; at 8 percent, 10 years; at 10 percent, 8 years; at 12 percent, 7 years, and at 14 percent, 6 years.
STILL, people do not run their lives strictly by the numbers. Raymond G. Russolillo, director of financial education services for Coopers & Lybrand, cited an example of a client, age 70 1/2, who had not yet taken any distributions, so he was eligible for a lump-sum distribution with five-year forward averaging -- a tax benefit that is scheduled to expire after Dec. 31, 1999. (It allows taxpayers, using Form 4972, to stretch out the tax payments over five years.) The client chose to take the money out of his plan now, pay the income tax and avoid the excise tax.
Strictly from a tax standpoint, it would probably have been better to make his granddaughter the plan's beneficiary and minimize distributions. But the client wanted the money to go to his wife, and he wanted it now, "so his goals and objectives take precedence," Mr. Russolillo said.
People whose total assets exceed $600,000 and who want to be sure their money goes to their families or to favorite charities may want to make some withdrawals now and begin making gifts, said Mr. Slott, author of "Your Tax Questions Answered" (Plymouth Press, 1997). A person may give as much as $10,000 to each recipient annually with no gift or estate tax consequence.
Mr. Pennacchio agreed with that advice, noting that otherwise, "After estate tax, income tax and excise tax, the kids can get 10, 12, 14 cents on the dollar."
People who reached 70 1/2 last year must begin making at least minimum withdrawals from their I.R.A.'s by April 1 of this year, Mr. Neumark noted, "and if you don't, you must pay a 50 percent excise tax" on the amount that should have been withdrawn.
Thanks to another change, effective this year, he added, "you may be able to delay taking minimum distributions from your employer's pension plan at age 70 1/2 if you are still working," as are many people, especially entrepreneurs.
However, Joel S. Isaacson, who heads his own New York accounting and financial planning firm, cautioned that here, too, because of possible estate-tax problems resulting from excess accumulations, it would still make sense for many people to begin taking out money by 70 1/2.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about distributions from retirement plans referred incorrectly to the tax benefit known as five-year forward averaging. A lump-sum distribution is treated as if the income were received over five years, thus lowering the tax owed, but the tax is paid in one year, not five.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
With Bonds, Colleges Can Get Topsy-Turvy

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
FORGET everything you've ever heard about what makes a top school. When it comes to higher-education debt ratings -- admittedly a little more obscure a detail than, say, the size of the library, the success of the swim team or the proportion of Ph.D.'s on the faculty -- tiny Grinnell College is right up there with Harvard, Yale and Princeton.
Like those three famous institutions, Grinnell, a solid liberal arts college in Grinnell, Iowa, with an enrollment of 1,300, has a AAA rating from Moody's Investors Service for its bonds. "Their endowment and their assets are so large relative to their modest amount of debt," said John Nelson, an analyst with Moody's. "It's half a billion versus $10 million in debt." 
On the other side of the fence is Georgetown University, which, despite its great fame, has some credit strikes against it. "They have not historically been strong at raising funds," Mr. Nelson said. "Plus they run a teaching hospital, and they are in an urban area, and the hospital is in the District of Columbia. Those things are all weak credit factors." Thus, Georgetown has an A-1 rating from Moody's, in the middle of the investment-grade risk spectrum.
Looking at a college's bonds may never become the primary way for prospective freshmen and their parents to size up a school. But they, along with investors, may want to pay greater attention to these mostly tax-exempt debt offerings. Schools often use them to finance projects like new dormitories, or rewiring old ones for the information age.
"Deferred maintenance is the big issue," says Mary Peloquin-Dodd, a director at Standard & Poor's ratings group who follows nonprofit debt. "Our feeling is that over the last two years, colleges and universities have really tried to dig into their deferred maintenance, and it certainly has affected the market."
Last year, $9.1 billion in tax-exempt debt was issued by the nation's public and private universities, up from $6.8 billion in 1995, said Patrick Hannigan, the higher-education analyst at Morgan Stanley.
The number of schools in debt has risen, too. Statistics are sketchy, but perhaps as many as one-third of the nation's 3,600 colleges and universities have bonds or bank loans outstanding, up substantially from 10 years ago, Ms. Peloquin-Dodd said.
Higher education tends to get a warm reception in the bond market. "There is a general view that these places can withstand pressures and have managed to survive through some pretty serious turmoil," said Fred Prager, whose San Francisco firm, Prager, McCarthy & Sealy, underwrites many such offerings. "Higher-education credits trade as a class better than hospitals and can do better than general-obligation debt and housing and utility bonds."
This high regard means that investors in school bonds are willing to accept yields that are, for example, 10 to 20 basis points lower than that of otherwise similar hospital bonds. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
Nevertheless, as more colleges issue bonds, the number of risky offerings is growing. While nearly 30 colleges and universities join Grinnell in receiving the highest ratings from either Moody's or Standard & Poor's -- others include Stanford, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Rockefeller University and California Institute of Technology -- the two ratings services say more colleges are on the speculative-grade list than ever before. For Moody's, this means a rating below Baa3; for Standard & Poor's, BBB-.
Four schools rated by Standard & Poor's are in this "below investment grade" category: Odessa Junior College in Texas, Anderson University in Indiana, Wagner College on Staten Island and Seton Hill College in Pennsylvania. Moody's also has Odessa Junior College on its below-investment-grade list, along with three others: Bennington College in Vermont, Colby-Sawyer College in New Hampshire and the University of Hartford in Connecticut.
HOW did these places get sent to study hall, financially speaking? To rate bonds, Ms. Peloquin-Dodd said, she looks at not only a school's finances and debt, but also at its management and the prospective student interest in the school -- something that can fluctuate, often with dire results.
Consider Bennington College, which Moody's has rated below investment grade since 1995, and the University of Hartford, which saw Moody's lower its rating to below investment grade in January.
Because fewer high school students were moving through the college-bound pipeline, Bennington, like many other colleges, saw applications shrink. While the school tried to turn things around by dismissing a lot of faculty members, fewer students meant less income. "They spent down most of their endowment," Mr. Nelson said.
Michael Leary, a spokesman for Bennington, said the school was working on its problems. "We've continued to show an improvement in our enrollment," he said, with the freshman class growing from 78 in 1995 to 119 last year. Total enrollment is just 189, though, down from 500 before the restructuring.
At the University of Hartford, the nationwide drop in the number of high school students has forced the school, like others, to dangle full and partial scholarships before prospective students to fill seats.
So even though Hartford's class size has remained the same, its revenue is much lower, said Naomi Richman, another Moody's analyst. At the same time, widespread layoffs in two pillars of the local economy, the military and insurance industries, have undercut the continuing-education program, which has long subsidized the undergraduate school.
"So they had a double whammy," Ms. Richman said. "They have had an operating deficit for the last five years. We think they are likely to survive, but are much more vulnerable to any kind of a disruption."
David Isgur, a spokesman for the University of Hartford, said the school had already taken major steps to turn itself around by the time Moody's downgraded its bonds.
"The agency did say the outlook for the university is stable," Mr. Isgur said, "and we see this as a reflection of the success we have already had in significantly reducing our deficit." He added that the university expects to have a balanced budget by next year, and that admissions do not seem to have been affected by the rating.
But a lower rating does increase a school's borrowing costs. For each "notch" that a rating drops, said Mr. Prager, the yields that investors demand rise from 5 or 10 basis points to 40 or more, depending on market volatility and which notches are involved. Of course, lower ratings mean lower resale values and higher risk, too. But Mr. Nelson said that no college rated by Moody's had ever defaulted, although not all carry insurance to reimburse investors in the event of a default.
Whether their tastes run to AAA ratings or to something chancier, investors can go directly to their brokers to buy school bonds, which are typically offered in denominations as low as $5,000. Many mutual funds also invest in the bonds.
But don't expect schools to peddle the bonds to their own graduates. "There's a finite amount of alumni money out there, and you don't want to draw on it and have to pay it back when you can draw on it and not pay it back," Mr. Prager said.
Secondary schools, meanwhile, are learning from their cousins in higher education, issuing bonds of their own. "That's an emerging market," Ms. Peloquin-Dodd said.
In that group, Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., got the red-carpet treatment with a AA+ rating, the highest rating that Standard & Poor's bestows on such schools. Another New Hampshire school, Brewster Academy, had a bumpier ride and wound up with a Baa3 score from Moody's.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 16, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Downsized, but Not Out: A Mill Town's Tale

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: BIDDEFORD, Me.

 BODY:
FOR more than a century, outsiders controlled the economic destiny of the men and women who toiled in the textile mills of this coastal town south of Portland.
Whether those who held this power were faceless Boston bankers, Southern textile brokers or Wall Street portfolio managers didn't matter much to the millworkers. Owners came and went, and the only visible sign of each transition was a new company name printed on payroll checks. 
 So when word spread last July that Albert J. Dunlap had been hired as the chairman of the Sunbeam Corporation, owner of the Biddeford Textile Company, the 352 workers at the mill took the news calmly, expecting some manner of corporate shake-up but confident that their jobs were safe.
After all, they reassured one another, they helped produce Sunbeam's popular, and profitable, "Beauty With a Brain" line of electric blankets. True, the controls and wiring were manufactured in Mississippi and Mexico, but the fabric "shells" -- some four million of them last year -- were woven for Sunbeam exclusively on Biddeford Textile looms. Once finished, the electric blankets were shipped to department stores across the country and sold for up to $179.
But Mr. Dunlap didn't get his nickname "Chainsaw Al" for nothing. In November, he announced that the Biddeford plant would be either shut down or sold as part of his plan to slash Sunbeam's overall work force in half. When Robert B. Reich, then the nation's Labor Secretary, described the move as "treating employees as if they are disposable pieces of equipment," Mr. Dunlap brushed off the criticism and said his first obligation was to the shareholders who hired him to make the company profitable.
The mill hands reacted to the thunderbolt much as most people deal with death -- with disbelief, anger and depression. They have resisted, so far, only the last stage: acceptance.
Perhaps they should have seen it coming. It was no secret that Mr. Dunlap had joined Sunbeam after lopping off 11,200 workers, one-third of the work force, at the Scott Paper Company in a mere 28 months, earning $100 million for his trouble. And the Biddeford workers' blankets, though of high quality, are far from high technology. It would be far cheaper to make them in a third world country.
Moreover, plant closings are hardly unusual these days. About 10 times a week, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, a big factory shuts down somewhere in the United States, throwing an average of 190 people out of work with each closing. And those figures do not include the even larger number of mining and construction sites and service-company workplaces that are shuttered.
But these are ordinary folks -- on the flip side of the investing public's obsession with the surging Dow Jones industrial average and the performance of its mutual funds. Many live from paycheck to paycheck, contribute to a modest union pension, but have no 401(k) plans or stock options.
The Biddeford mill work force, including managers who worry as much about their own futures, now stands at under 300 because of winter layoffs. Few jobs in the local market come close to the $9 to $13 an hour that workers are paid to tend the thrumming weaving machines. Mill hands rely on a tradition of grit to see them through hard times, which in textiles in New England is almost a full-time job.

Unraveling of a Mill Town
That tradition goes back a long way. It is hard to imagine today, but this town was once a cradle of American industry, beginning in 1826 when the largest cotton mill in the country was built on an island where the Saco River plunged into spray-tossing cataracts. As production peaked earlier in this century, nearly 6,000 textile workers in different mills flooded the streets during shift changes.
Yankee farmhands were the first millworkers, subsequently replaced by Irish immigrants and French-Canadians who trekked from rural Quebec, sometimes by foot, as production expanded and more cheap labor was needed. In this century, as New England textile mills bled jobs to Southern states with nonunion labor, companies were sold, merged or went out of business.
With no money or political power to speak of, the mill hands relied on grit as their main weapon against anguish while waiting for Mr. Dunlap to decide whether to close or sell the mill. By year's end, few of them had any illusions about a boss who wrote a book called "Mean Business" and who relished his reputation as a tough guy with a mission from shareholders to clean up the mess left by his predecessors.
Yet grit alone would not be enough to prevail against the executive suites of Sunbeam's South Florida headquarters. In the end, however, millworkers may be saved from the scrap heap of modern corporate history through a union effort to negotiate an employee stock ownership plan with the help of a private investor and a mill manager who -- in their eyes -- is as much a hero as Mr. Dunlap is a villain.

Rumors, Hope and Anger
The workers' first reaction to Mr. Dunlap's November announcement was shocked disbelief and bafflement. "We've been working a lot of overtime this year, so no one guessed it would be this bad," muttered Rosaire Breault a few days before Thanksgiving, as he downed an early-morning $1 pint of beer at Pop's, a workers' hangout a block from the mill. "We've always been a profitable place for Sunbeam. They've always made a buck here."
Rumors were still flying about Sunbeam's intentions, and Mr. Breault was under the false impression that Mr. Dunlap had set a Jan. 1 deadline for deciding whether to jettison the Biddeford factory. Weary from working the overnight shift, he looked out the window in silence for a while as the first snowfall of the season dusted the parked cars outside.
"The thing nobody can figure out is, Why would Dunlap want to get rid of the only mill that makes shells for the electric blanket line he wants to keep?" he finally said. "It doesn't make sense."
Just down the street from Pop's, a similar incredulity reigned at the meeting hall of Local 1856 of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. A few members had gathered in an upstairs office, and they were in a combative mood.
They suspected that Sunbeam had a hidden agenda: It would either bust the union contract and cut wages and health plan benefits, or it would sell the mill to a buyer who would crate up its modern machines and relocate production closer to Sunbeam's Mississippi plant, where the shells are shipped to be fitted with electrical-heating components.
"Why else would they sell their only supplier?" asked Ray Tilton, president of the local and the third generation in his family to work in the mill. "It's like making an engine without a car to put it in."
"We're being sold because we're in the Northeast and a union shop," shot back Wally Szumita, another union official.
"There are a lot of half-empty textile mills in the South that would be happy to be Sunbeam's supplier," interjected Michael J. Cavanaugh, assistant manager of the union's regional board.
The conversation soon veered into wishful thinking. "They have no experience down there making blanket shells," declared Mr. Tilton, who works a second job driving a taxi at night. "We have all the skills and the experience. No one else could do what we do. Not those Rebels, anyway."
Mr. Szumita picked up the theme. "Not taking anything away from these Southerners," he rasped, "but you can't find a good work force down there like you can here. Here the millworker takes pride in his work and will work 60 hours a week, every week, if you ask him."
Others in the room nodded agreement. endorsing a long-held sentiment. However, manufacturing workers in the South today can often earn as much as Biddeford's unionized workers. But that fact is tough to accept in a union hall whose members fear more job losses.
"Compare our blankets with what they produce down there," he continued. "Theirs are like a rag. If you went down there and said you were a millworker from Maine. they'd hire you in a heartbeat," he said, snapping his fingers for punctuation.
Rita LaChance had listened to the exchange quietly. But when she spoke, the others fell silent.
It is an axiom of the mill that the closer a job places a worker to the loom, the higher he or she is in the pecking order, both for pay and respect. And Mrs. LaChance, a gray-haired grandmother with a commanding voice that seems made of polished steel, stands atop the hierarchy. She has worked in textile mills for 42 years and is the head weaver at Biddeford Textile, in charge of setting the patterns that tell the automated looms what to weave.
"Any company can weave our shells if they have our patterns," she said flatly, bringing the conversation down to earth.
Recently installed modern machinery at the mill could be shipped almost anywhere, she said, even to Mexico.
"I have the feeling, Ray," she said, softly now, as she looked at Mr. Tilton, "if they wanted to move us down South they could do it. That's what scares me."
"I don't know," replied Mr. Tilton, a little deflated but refusing to concede defeat. "We have all the experience. The tradition. Our families are here."
"They could retrain workers and get it done in six months," Mrs. LaChance said, pursing her lips with conviction.
"Family, traditions -- that means this much to Al Dunlap," said another person in the room, forming a zero with his thumb and forefinger.
"Well, if some new owner comes in here and tells us to renegotiate our contract and cut benefits or he'll move South," Mr. Szumita retorted, growing angrier, "we're going to tell him to take his company and get the hell out of town!"
Similar scenes unfolded throughout this town of 21,000 in the early days. But the mood of defiance was hard to maintain against a faraway autocrat who held all the cards. By mid-December, it was giving way to fear in the mill families' lives.

Specter of Minimum Wage
Already, some millworkers were being idled in seasonal layoffs and other cutbacks. The rest were picking up their weekly paychecks not knowing whether each payment would be their last. Then, the week before Christmas, the mill was idled for repairs to a smokestack. There was no work and no pay.
Suddenly, what bravado remained had an an air of desperation. "I ain't going to let Al Dunlap spoil Christmas," Norm Gagnon sang out a little too brightly on a cold morning as sunshine streamed into his new kitchen.
Last spring, Mr. Gagnon, 48, who had worked at the mill since 1974 as a carding-machine operator, and his wife Sharolyn, took out a $75,000 bank loan to remodel their home. That was a lot of money for a couple whose combined income at the time -- she made $11.99 an hour as a trouble-shooter in the spinning unit, he earned $10.44 -- totaled $900 a week. But, they figured, with overtime and with the extra money they made from their home photo-and-video sideline and her work as an Avon lady, they could afford to meet the repayments and pay the extra property taxes, totaling $300 a week.
"If we'd known what was coming we'd have never taken that loan," Mrs. Gagnon said. "But we're better off than most because we work at other jobs." Under a Christmas tree in the living room were piles of brightly wrapped gifts. "We saved $1,500 in our Christmas club," she added. "Not even Dunlap was going to take Christmas away from us."
She was wrong. Two days before Christmas, Mr. Gagnon was laid off with 37 other millworkers. The gift exchange with relatives the next day was a somber affair, and things have not improved. Now on $210-a-week unemployment, Mr. Gagnon has found little in the help-wanted ads that offers him much hope. "The only jobs listed were picking shrimp or working in a warehouse for six or seven bucks an hour," he reported.
The threat of losing their textile jobs -- and dropping down the economic ladder to within a couple of rungs of the minimum wage -- haunts the workforce. Millwork is hard, dusty, noisy and repetitive, requiring a high tolerance for boredom. But here, at least, it beats the alternatives.
"In most cities the mills would be considered employers of last resort, but in Biddeford it's the cream," said Charles Butler Jr., head of the local historical society. "Jobs pass down in families from one generation to the next because the wages and health benefits are good compared to anything else available in town."
Marge Perry, 39, a single mother who earns $12.37 an hour as a weaver, foresees a grim future if the Sunbeam plant closes. There is only one other textile plant in town, owned by West Point Stevens of West Point, Ga., but openings are scarce. About the only other job prospects are low-paying, menial work. "I'll have to work two jobs just to make what I do now," she said wearily.

Local Hero Plans a Rescue
But maybe the mill won't close, after all.
If there is a hero in this story, it is probably Rene Boisvert, Biddeford Textile's top executive who resigned in December rather than oversee the possible destruction of the company he had helped create.
As quiet as Mr. Dunlap is brash, Mr. Boisvert (his full name is pronounced RAIN-ee BO-vye) is the model boss who came up through the ranks. Though he refuses to give his age, he says he started out 43 years ago on the production line at the Biddeford mill, then owned by West Point-Pepperell (since renamed West Point Stevens). When West Point-Pepperell's blanket division was having problems, Mr. Boisvert helped arrange its sale to Sunbeam in 1971. It was then renamed Biddeford Textile, with Mr. Boisvert in charge.
After Sunbeam took over, ultimately becoming the only producer of electric blankets in the country, he never forgot his roots, making a practice of strolling on the production floor in his shirt sleeves and soliciting the workers' views on production improvements. His former charges talk about him in tones approaching reverence, and at first, his departure prompted despair.
"We feel Rene was the only one looking out for the workers," Mrs. Gagnon said. But instead of heading for the sunny South, Mr. Boisvert got into the thick of negotiations to find a way to salvage his mill.
The discussions, involving city and state officials, the union and Sunbeam, had begun almost as soon as Mr. Dunlap announced his intention to rid his company of the plant. Sunbeam assigned its investment bank, Chase Securities, a unit of Chase Manhattan, the task of seeking potential buyers. The union, for its part, engaged American Capital Strategies of Bethesda, Md., an investment bank that specializes in helping labor unions develop employee stock ownership plans to buy their companies, troubled or not. American Strategies helped Northwest Airlines employees with a limited buyout in 1993, for example.
As January came and went without any developments, the remaining management team appeared as much in the dark as the workers about the mill's fate. "Just like us, they don't know if they'll have a job when they show up for work tomorrow," said Ms. Perry, the weaver.
Adding to the somber tone was news in January that a profitable Sunbeam unit in McMinnville, Tenn., which had been spared the Dunlap ax in November, was being closed and the operation moved to Mexico, at a loss of 650 jobs.
As the talks in Biddeford progressed, details of a possible solution leaked out. An outside investor -- Michael Liberty, a Portland real-estate developer -- was willing to take a large stake in a new company that would buy the plant from Sunbeam for an unspecified sum. His two equity partners would be American Capital Strategies and the millworkers, who would make pay and benefits concessions in return for their stake.
Mr. Dunlap, professing enthusiasm for the proposed agreement, pledged to continue buying the blankets for several years. He also said he would welcome efforts by the new company to sell blankets to other buyers; already, it sells one-tenth of its annual production to airlines and prisons.
And running the show, as of old, would be Mr. Boisvert, who would take the title of president and chief executive of the new concern.
The prospect of Mr. Boisvert's return heartened the rank and file as nothing else had throughout the cold winter. "Rene is well-off enough to be playing golf in Florida this winter, but he really cares about the people who work at the mill and what happens to them," said a union member who requested anonymity, fearing that any comment on the record might be seized by Mr. Dunlap as an excuse to torpedo talks.
Late last month, the group signed a letter of intent with Sunbeam to buy the mill and was given exclusive rights to close the deal by later this month. Confidentiality agreements have kept all the principals and their agents from commenting on all aspects of the pact.
However, a Sunbeam official said the company was "confident" the sale to the workers could be achieved. John DeSimone, Sunbeam's director of investor relations, said Sunbeam had talked with other potential buyers, but that the Biddeford group "is our first choice of the organizations we would like to sell the company to." Mr. DeSimone also said that Sunbeam was prepared to offer the worker group a five-year guaranteed supply contract. Sunbeam's agreement to buy all its electric-blanket shells from the Biddeford mill would give the factory a secure base for growth. And growth seems possible for this mill, especially now that Sunbeam is the only producer of electric blankets in the United States. Though electric-blanket sales dipped in the early 1990's, corresponding with consumer concern about the possible link between cancer and the electromagnetic fields they generate, those fears have been allayed somewhat by a National Research Council study that found no evidence of such a hazard. The Biddeford mill, meanwhile, has been modernized and it doubled production of electric-blanket shells from two million in 1990 to four million last year.
Last Sunday, the outside investors held a series of closed meetings with union members in Biddeford's City Hall to lay out their plans. With the memory of another local employee-ownership experiment that had failed still fresh in the minds of participants, several workers asked pointed questions about their own prospects. They listened quietly but respectfully to the answers, with one exception -- every time Mr. Boisvert spoke, they applauded.
"We left the meeting feeling a little skeptical," reported Michael Boisvert (no relation to Rene), a 41-year old spinning-frame repairman who has worked at the mill since high school. "We can negotiate what we feel we can give back in wages or benefits, but you can't expect us to work all week and not eat. If they want more than we can give, they can forget about it."
He had a reason for some pessimism. His wife, Barbara, had been involved in a similar employee-buyout effort at a local company named John Roberts, which made men's apparel. That attempt to save jobs collapsed in 1994 after three years.
"The last two years were terrible, with the workers scared into making concessions like giving up 6 percent of their wages, all vacations and holidays, and they still had to shut down," Mrs. Boisvert said.
For all that disquieting precedent, Mr. Cavanaugh, the union official, said any parallel to Biddeford Textile would be a stretch. John Roberts was in bankruptcy proceedings when the buyout plan was started as a last-ditch attempt to save jobs, he said. By contrast, he said, the local Sunbeam plant "is very healthy, profitable and a leader in its industry."
Moreover, he added, invoking the name of the man of the hour, "This group, headed by Rene Boisvert, has leadership and management skills everyone respects."

Yanked by the Stock Market
The workers' optimism may be justified, according to Corey Rosen, executive director of the National Center for Employee Ownership, an advocacy group in Oakland, Calif. Prospects for employee buyouts of financially healthy companies generally are favorable, he said, if workers are not asked to make excessive concessions and if the former owner stays involved. "So much depends on keeping a good relationship with the former parent to maintain guarantees about buying the product," Mr. Rosen said.
Now, as the clock ticks toward the deadline for closing the deal, the tension in Biddeford is almost palpable. Last Tuesday, Sunbeam officials met with Mr. Boisvert and union representatives to begin final negotiations on the sale, while a union team began work on concession proposals that would be put to a vote by the rank and file.
Although the principals of the buying group remained tightlipped about final deals of an agreement, Mr. Boisvert seemed at pains to temper worker hostility toward the Sunbeam chief. "We appreciate the opportunity Mr. Dunlap has given the workers to buy Biddeford Textile," he said last Thursday during a break in the negotiations. "We have had a long and friendly relationship with Sunbeam and we hope to continue making shells for the company for some time to come."
If the deal goes through -- and most people expect it will -- the workers may need some time to get over their bitterness toward Mr. Dunlap, the man they blame for making their lives miserable. "He has caused me more stress than the cancer surgery I had four years ago," said Ms. Perry, the 39-year-old single mother. "But Chain Saw Al doesn't care who he steps on and squashes, as long as he gets paid his millions."
Mr. Dunlap brushes off such characterizations as misguided. "Everyone whose job is threatened sees me as the villain because I am the visible symbol of change," he said in an interview during the midwinter International Housewares Show in Chicago, where he met with representatives of major retailers under banners heralding the company's new slogan: "There's a New Sunbeam Shining -- Now There's a Bright Idea."
Mr. Dunlap remained unrepentant about the large-scale layoffs that Sunbeam has conducted nationwide. "At the end of the day, I feel I've rescued 6,000 jobs that would've been lost because Sunbeam had become a basket case and would've gone out of business this year unless drastic changes were made," the West Point-trained paratroop officer said with square-jawed command. Indeed, Sunbeam's stock has vaulted from about $12.50 a share to more than $30 since he took charge.
Whatever the outcome of the buyout attempt, the decision would not have many repercussions outside of Biddeford. It is a turn of events in an out-of-the-way place, but hardly one that will be noticed beyond the kitchens and parlors of the troubled workers.
The Republican Mayor of Biddeford, James M. Grattelo, a businessman who owns an amusement park in Portsmouth, N.H., said there might be another villain in this story: The millions of people who have hitched a ride on the biggest bull market run in American stock-market history. It is these shareholders and their mutual-fund managers who put unremitting pressure on companies to raise stock prices, whatever the human cost, he suggested.
"Al Dunlap's not stupid and he's not a monster," Mr. Grattelo said over lunch shortly after the November announcement. "I don't want to defend him but he didn't create the stock market. We did. Businessmen, investors, people all around the country. They hold mutual funds, they have 401(k)'s. They want profits."

HEADLINE: At the World Bank, Architecture as Diplomacy

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE new World Bank complex now approaching completion here is about as un-Washington -- and as un-banklike -- as a building gets.
In a city known for its classical influences, there is nary a cornice or pediment in sight. Moreover, there is a total absence of such traditional materials as marble and brass. And with the exception of granite curbstones mandated by the city -- and various wood veneers -- all the building materials are manmade. 
 But the reasons for these departures are far from apolitical.
"The World Bank is in the business of assisting third-world countries and the whole language of classicism is very much connected to the issue of colonialism," said William Pedersen of Kohn Pedersen Fox,the New York-based main architect for the project. "We did not want to get involved in that debate."
The complex, which occupies a square block along Pennsylvania Avenue two blocks west of the White House, comprises three buildings grouped around a 13-story atrium. One of the buildings and the atrium are new and two are what is left of the bank's original headquarters, a complex of six fairly nondescript office buildings erected over roughly 25 years beginning in the mid-40's.
The original buildings were linked on some floors, but not on others, and had separate climate-control systems. "It was a complete hodgepodge," said Tim Cullen, senior adviser for external affairs at the bank.
"The old buildings were very dark and there were a lot of problems with technology and with heating and cooling," said Sven Sandstrom, managing director of the bank. "They were hot in the summer and, given the darkness, had a very enclosed feeling. We also had asbestos problems, which made wiring and renovation very difficult."
In addition, by the mid 80's, the bank was bursting at the seams with personnel. The old complex held just under 4,000 staff members; another 4,000 were scattered in buildings the bank either owned or leased in the area. Clearly, something had to be done.
In 1989 the bank held a worldwide architectural competition and received 76 proposals from 26 countries. This was later narrowed to 8, with Kohn Pedersen Fox the eventual winner. One of the terms of the competition was that the two newest buildings in the original complex be retained temporarily for economic reasons. The winning proposal went a step further and incorporated them into the finished plan.
"They're serviceable buildings by good architects and we thought we'd be a step ahead of the game in terms of the bank's master plan if we used them," said Mr. Pedersen.
One of the retained buildings was designed by Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill who also designed Lever House in New York and many other office buildings in the 60's. The other is by Vincent Kling in association with Clas Riggs, now Clas Riggs Owens & Ramos. The older buildings, with their austere modern facades, appear to be embedded in the new and larger aluminum and glass structure.
BUT what really carried the day, said Mr. Sandstrom, was the way the design introduced natural light not only to the center of the building but also to two underground floors by way of the vaulted atrium. The atrium is 178 feet tall, considerably above the 130-foot limit in the district, but allowable because the extra height is not used for occupancy. It has a 28-foot waterfall, elevator banks, planters and a number of seating areas.
"It has the feeling of a main street where people get together, talk, eat lunch," said Mr. Sandstrom. "We've never had that before."
The complex includes two large conference rooms on the roof of the new building and a ground-floor auditorium. All are equipped with simultaneous translation facilities. There is also a gleaming basement cafeteria and a private dining room for which Kohn Pedersen Fox designed everything from the lighting fixtures to the china.
Surprisingly, the bank's top management resisted the urge to construct glitzy new offices for themselves and it remains ensconced in a 12th-floor suite in one of the old buildings. "We didn't see any point in moving the offices," said Mr. Sandstrom.
The complex, which has 2.1 million square feet of space, an increase of about 300,000 square feet, will house about 4,700 employees.
For all its familiarity with the intricacies of third-world economic development, the bank proved less adept when it came to the cost estimates and scheduling for its new headquarters. The original estimate was $211 million. That has been steadily revised upwards to $314 million.
"The overrun was mainly about bad planning," said Peter Copplestone, a construction manager who was brought in to oversee the project when costs started skyrocketing. "They were very optimistic about the concessions they were going to get from contractors."
Demolition of four existing buildings began in late 1989. Completion of the project is expected late this summer.
The complex is the first of several large downtown projects that are expected to roil the waters of the real estate market here in the next few years. The other projects include the 1.8 million-square-foot Ronald Reagan International Cultural and Trade Center, a 650,000-square-foot building for the International Finance Corporation and a 500,000-square-foot Secret Service building. Downtown Washington has about 32 million square feet of office space, making it the third largest office market in the country after Chicago and New York, the largest.
ACCORDING to the local office of Cushman and Wakefield, the national brokerage, the overall vacancy rate for the downtown business district is just over 13 percent. "It's been very stable for the last five years," said Elisa Hughes, an analyst with the firm. She added, however, that the new projects would bump that number up a point or two in the next few years.
Ms. Hughes. as well as others in the industry, say the city is finally on the upswing after a long period of fiscal and governmental turmoil that led many firms and associations to relocate to the suburbs.
"Anyone who doesn't have to be in the district would prefer not to be but if you have to be, you live with it," said Alfred Neely, senior vice president of development for Charles E. Smith Company, a development and property management concern here with interests both in the district and the suburbs.
One plus for the city, he added, is that suburban rental rates -- particularly in northern Virginia -- have been rising steadily and are now on par with the city.
The World Bank is among the entities that need to be in the city, according to Ernesto Henriod, director of construction for the bank.
"We are an international institution and need to be near government offices and embassies," he said. "We also get a lot of visitors from overseas so we need to be close to hotels and other services. Economically, it would have been a lot cheaper [in the late 80's] to go out to the suburbs, but from a functional standpoint it would have been wrong."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
It's Called Poor Health for a Reason

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. SHWEDER; Richard A. Shweder, a cultural anthropologist, is chairman of the Committee on Human Development at the University of Chicago.

 BODY:
FROM a cerebro-vascular, genito-urinary, gastro-intestinal, psycho-therapeutic or mortuary point of view, the rich and famous have never had it so good. Yes, their children are more prone to acne and allergies. Nevertheless, during the last half of the 20th century, people in the developed world with an elevated social status have been producing health, well-being and longevity at a faster rate than those with lower social standing.
Physical and mental health run parallel to social rank. In England, commoners die sooner than aristocrats. In the military, sergeants have more heart attacks than generals. Blue-collar workers -- and not only those working in mines, construction sites and chemical plants -- have more respiratory infections and hacking coughs than white-collar workers. Office clerks are more anxious and depressed than office managers. Lower-middle-class Americans are more mortal, morbid, symptomatic and disabled than upper-middle-class Americans. With each little step down on the educational, occupational and income ladders comes an increased risk of headaches, varicose veins, hypertension, sleepless nights, emotional distress, heart disease, schizophrenia and an early visit to the grave. 
 The funny thing is, no one knows why.
Of course, people who are socially well placed have not always been spared the ravages of disease. Mythic images of wounded elites come to mind: gout-endamaged royalty, wan and hysterical Victorian ladies, ascetic malnourished Brahman widows, Mandarins eating vitamin-deficient polished rice and bearing beriberi. In the 1920's and 30's, coronary heart disease was apparently a mark of social distinction among men in England. In the 1940's and 50's, the polio virus crippled those at the top in the United States. And even today there are a few afflictions, like breast cancer and malignant melanomas, that seem to prevail among citizens of high station.
On the whole, though, the upper- crust neuroses and illnesses have all but disappeared from Europe and the United States. During the last 50 years, Western men and women of higher status have lived longer and have been healthier and saner than the people they outclass.
The study of "social inequalities in health" is today one of the hottest areas in epidemiology, medical sociology and health psychology. Only last December, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation established a research network on socioeconomic status and health, under the direction of Nancy Adler, a psychologist at the University of California, San Francisco.
Much of the excitement dates from the 1980 publication of the "Black Report," when Sir Douglas Black (a former president of the Royal College of Physicians) and his medical, social science and public policy associates showed the statistical association between illness and social class in England and Wales. The Conservative Government detested the Black Report, viewing it as a trespass of social medicine into politics, an ideological tract produced by welfare-state advocates longing to redistribute wealth and level the social class system. Liberal egalitarians, just as predictably, took the study as proof that social hierarchy is a public health problem.
Politics aside, no one knows precisely why people with high status are more healthy and less crazy.
It is not primarily because they have better access to health care. Socioeconomic differences exist for diseases that are not amenable to treatment. In fact, since the advent of the British National Health Service in 1948, the gap in health between occupational statuses in England has widened. (Perhaps this confirms the dismal economic principle that publicly financed institutions -- hospitals, schools, highways and courts -- always benefit the well-to-do most.)
The health gap cannot be blamed mostly on hazardous work or living conditions, either. Social status differences in health persist even when members of different social classes are exposed to similar levels of pollutants and carcinogens in their environment.
Nor is poverty itself the prime reason. Consider, for example, the famous "Whitehall Studies," an investigation of the tidy, hierarchically graded world of relatively well-off white-collar British civil servants, conducted by the epidemiologist Michael Marmot and his public health colleagues at University College, London.
The Whitehall study showed that with each tiny descent in civil service rank, from senior executive officer down to executive officer, comes more angina, more diabetes and more rough cough with phlegm. In this securely employed population, the mortality gap between senior administrators and clerical workers is even greater than the health divide in the general population. Moreover, as comparisons between richer and poorer countries in Europe have shown time and again, greater national wealth does not readily translate into greater national health. A 45-year-old Greek male can expect to live longer than his English peer.
The health gap cannot be blamed primarily on life style differences, either. It's true that clean living (no smoking, alcohol or fatty foods and lots of exercise) is a high-status religious activity (though professional women probably drink more liquor than working-class women). Nevertheless, it turns out that most of the social inequality in coronary heart disease remains even after such life-style differences are taken into account.
Could the health gap exist because unhealthy people are downwardly mobile or because healthy women marry up? Those things do happen. Some people rise in status because they are vigorous and others are "selected" for demotion because they are disabled or out of their minds. But social migration isn't enough of a stampede to explain all the health effects.
Neo-conservatives believe that both health and high social rank are jointly produced and justly earned by hard-working, intelligent people who avoid reckless risks, educate themselves and take a long view of life. And liberal-minded egalitarians believe that health is a common good that ought to be provided and regulated by the government (just like highways, schools, courts and national defense). But neither side has explained how the health divide is actually produced.
Perhaps it is karma. Perhaps it is in the genes. Perhaps it is all of the reasons above. Perhaps it is a statistical artifact. Perhaps the safest thing one can say is that the socioeconomic health gradient is a "multiple complex synergistic non-linear incremental cumulative threshold-bound lag effect." Social scientists like to talk like that when they think they are looking at something important but don't really know what is going on.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Suspicions in the East, Confusions in the West

BYLINE: By ORVILLE SCHELL; Orville Schell is dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California, Berkeley.

 BODY:

THE COMING CONFLICT WITH CHINA
By Richard Bernstein and Ross H. Munro
Illustrated. 245 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23. 
 Even before Deng Xiaoping's death, the question of whether China's economically dynamic but politically unsettled state of affairs would ultimately pose a threat to the interests of the United States and other nations was so sensitive that most members of the foreign policy establishment chose to tiptoe cautiously around it. With Beijing alleging foreign plots bent on "containing" China's aspirations and denying Chinese "their rightful place in the world," few cared to offend Chinese Communist Party leaders with unflattering criticism.
The party has long mastered the art of controlling what its own people say and think. What is new is the way it has succeeded in controlling expressions of opinion from abroad as well. Its trump card in this global manipulation is, of course, its new ability to withdraw access to China's swelling market and to put pressure on foreign businessmen, politicians, diplomats, academics and even some journalists to be silent or even to polemicize China's brand of market Leninism.
But two former Beijing bureau chiefs -- Richard Bernstein (who reported on China for Time magazine and now is a book critic for The New York Times) and Ross H. Munro (Beijing correspondent for The Toronto Globe and Mail and now director of the Asia Program at the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia) -- have unrepentantly plunged harpoons into the tenderest interstices of the Chinese-American relationship. In "The Coming Conflict With China," they portray China as a growing economic and military threat that "during the past decade or so has set goals for itself that are directly contrary to American interests, the most important of those being to replace the United States as the pre-eminent power in Asia."
They are particularly concerned about how China's long repressed yearnings for hegemony and its "historic aggrievement" have made anti-Americanism "a matter of national dignity." One foreign affairs expert in Beijing notes that it has become "politically correct to describe the U.S. as a sinister superpower, a dangerous enemy, a superpower bully."
A new wave of paranoid official accusations charging the United States with plotting to "subjugate China" by "subverting the Chinese Government and strangling China's development" leads the authors to observe, "No other supposedly friendly country has attacked the United States more strenuously or with more rhetorical excess than China."
It is a great paradox that after suffering for a century as "the sick man of Asia" and then as the epicenter of a failed Marxist revolution and when now at last it is evincing signs of real economic success and global influence, China remains so lacking in self-confidence that its leaders need to conjure up phantom foreign enemies. So commonplace has overblown nationalist rhetoric become that Deng's insistence that even though "China and the United States are different in ideology, there is no conflict between their fundamental interests" already seems like a reverie.
China's new truculence is a reminder that those wellsprings of suspicion and hostility toward the outside world that grew out of the opium wars, fueled myriad xenophobic movements and gave rise to Mao's militant anti-imperialism have not vanished behind the signs of American fast-food restaurants. Instead there remains a deep and enduring ambivalence in China about the West and Japan that will be difficult to overcome even if the United States finally does arrive at a China policy that is coherent, consistent and wise.
One of the most worrisome aspects of present-day China is the way the party's unyielding commitment to "unifying the motherland" could lead to a conflict over Taiwan involving the United States and Japan. The authors go so far as to suggest that "Beijing's rulers will risk war with America not because it is in their country's interest but because it is in the interests of the governing clique." While they do not believe that war is unavoidable, they point to the fact that the United States is "a handy natural enemy" and that xenophobia is always a tempting way to unify a divided society.
While the authors support "engagement," they assiduously reject "that noble but naive American idea that better communications automatically lead to better relations" or that "making concessions to China and shrinking from imposing sanctions on it no matter how bad its behavior will encourage it to act with greater restraint and responsibility in the international community."
They are particularly critical of overseas businessmen. "China's efforts to impose its international agenda on foreign companies doing business in China has shaken up American businessmen," they write. "But it hasn't shaken them into leaving China. It has shaken them into doing China's bidding more eagerly than ever."
Crucial in this alliance between the leaders of a Communist Party and captains of capitalist industry is what the authors call "the new China lobby," that group of former United States Government officials turned private consultants who, while incanting the mantra that open markets equal open societies, "use their prestige and influence both publicly and privately to advance policies from which they profit mightily."
While its provocative assumptions about China's aggressiveness will doubtless doubtless play into Beijing's paranoia, and its critique of accommodation will be rejected by those who espouse unalloyed engagement as the best hedge against a rogue China, "The Coming Conflict With China" presents an important and cogent argument from the "tough love" school of Chinese-American relations.
It forces us to confront the fact that as this errant "people's republic" reinvents itself, it has given rise to a society that is both undemocratic and off balance and capable of becoming a destabilizing force instead of a constructive one. By laying out the dangers implicit in this new belligerence, Mr. Bernstein and Mr. Munro may offend many Chinese, but they may also help reset the goal posts for what one hopes will be a new and realistic debate over American policy in the post-Deng era.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Prisoners in Their Home, Facing the Twin Ravages of Plague and Power

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
The child is faceless. She has pulled her skirt up her over head, something that little girls are not, of course, unknown to do. But in this case, the image isn't playful. There is instead the sense that what is before us is only a body, a disquieting feeling confirmed by the first words she speaks, "What are you doing out of your grave?"
So begins Naomi Wallace's "One Flea Spare," which opened last night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater. It's an appropriate and unsettlingly effective prologue to a play in which flesh is not only mortal but also exploitable, marketable and ultimately interchangeable. 
 This moment, both tantalizingly ambiguous and joltingly specific, is also, unfortunately, the high point of this densely lyrical, self-conscious drama set in London in 1665, the year of the bubonic plague. Ms. Wallace, an American playwright who is also a poet and whose work has been widely praised in England, does indeed have a poet's precision in sustaining and developing metaphors (while giving a whole new resonance to the phrase "body politic"), as well as an ear for the music in plain language.
But while sensationally dramatic things do happen in "One Flea Spare," the work remains stiff, schematic and surprisingly unaffecting. Often one has the feeling of looking at, rather than listening to, a score for a chamber ensemble. The notes are clearly all in place, but you've yet to hear the music that would sweep you into experiential involvement.
Ms. Wallace mines the same historical material that Daniel Defoe used in his crypto-journalistic novel "A Journal of the Plague Year." The biological details of the course of the disease that paralyzed and transformed a city are unstintingly described, creating a climate in which illness and death are, if nothing else, democratic. In the lime pits where bodies are piled, as one character notes, "all faces looked the same."
But the rot that Ms. Wallace smells isn't just a product of disease. Her greater concern is with a more discriminating abuse of bodies: of the poor by the rich, of the powerless by the powerful. And the central conflict of the play, directed by Ron Daniels, is one of class, enacted by a quintet of Londoners who suddenly find themselves in a world in which the old, order-defining rules are under siege.
As in Sartre's "No Exit," this work confines characters of disparate stripes in a sealed environment and then watches the power shifts among them. The setting is the household of William and Darcy Snelgrave (Jon De Vries and Dianne Wiest), an affluent couple of the merchant class.
They have been prisoners in their own home for 28 days, dependent on their unscrupulous guard, Kabe (Paul Kandel), for news and groceries, when they are joined by two unwelcome interlopers in search of sanctuary: Bunce (Bill Camp), a rough-spoken sailor, and Morse (Mischa Barton, the appealing young actress from Tony Kushner's "Slavs!"), a mysteriously intuitive 12-year-old who says she is the daughter of neighbors of the Snelgraves.
The dissolution of the status quo, already shaken by the plague, is traced in a series of vignettes that often suggest theatrical exercises in a Marxist economics class, with more than a little assistance from D. H. Lawrence and Jean Genet.
The Snelgraves take a most prurient interest in Bunce, whom they make their provisional servant while trying to get some vicarious experience of the world beyond their cushioned, insular lives. William, who controls a dockyard, is fascinated by ocean travel, though he has no stomach for it, and "the foul and lecherous ways of the sea."
Darcy, who was horribly mutilated by a fire two years after her marriage at 15 and has had no physical contact with her husband in the succeeding decades, is predictably drawn to the lusty sailor. (She even says to him, a la Lady Chatterley, that while she hardly gives him a thought during the days, "every night I ravish you in my sleep.")
Well, sex, like death, is certainly a great leveler. And it probably wasn't a good idea for William to let Bunce try on his fancy shoes as a little experiment in class distinction. By the play's end, Bunce will be wearing more than William's shoes, and the master will find himself stripped and tied to a chair, with the eerily wise Morse playing arbitrator.
This sort of role reversal inevitably brings to mind "The Maids" of Genet. But "One Flea Spare" doesn't begin to have the far-reaching reverberations of that work. It's too firmly anchored in its conscientious set of symbols -- of unhealing wounds, sexual bartering and penetration, fire, water and decay -- for its characters to spring into autonomous life.
This may be partly the fault of the production. Aside from Mr. Camp, who brings to his part a canny sense of reawakened appetites blunted by years of oppression, the actors approach their roles as though they were uncomfortable pieces of furniture.
Ms. Wiest, heaven knows, is a marvelous actress, and she does some terrific things with her eyes and smile that speak volumes about the thwarted, restless spirit beneath Darcy's proper facade. But she is crippled by a plummy, aristocratic accent that at moments recalls Edith Evans at her loftiest.
Riccardo Hernandez's spare Vermeer-like set and Scott Zielinski's artful lighting are lovely and haunting. And the production achieves moments of eloquent, silent tableau, as when Bunce, on his knees, is hand fed by William. But you're also entirely too aware of the significance of the staging: who's standing, who's lying down, who's seated; who, in short, is in power.
"The movement of history," William observes, is "as inflexible as stone." That may be, but theater usually requires an immediate spontaneity and a sense of manifold possibilities to breathe freely. "One Flea Spare" is definitely carved in stone.
 
ONE FLEA SPARE
By Naomi Wallace; directed by Ron Daniels; sets by Riccardo Hernandez; costumes by Paul Tazewell; lighting by Scott Zielinski; sound by Stuart J. Allyn; original music by Michael Rasbury; production dramaturge, Mervin P. Antonio; production stage manager, C. A. Clark. Presented by the Joseph Papp Public Theater/New York Shakespeare Festival, George C. Wolfe, producer; Rosemarie Tichler, artistic producer. At 425 Lafayette Street, East Village.

WITH: Dianne Wiest (Mrs. Darcy Snelgrave), Mischa Barton (Morse), Bill Camp (Bunce), Jon De Vries (Mr. William Snelgrave) and Paul Kandel (Kabe).
