HEADLINE: No Change in Capital Gains

 BODY:
Since the beginning of the Bush Administration, Democrats have managed to contain the Republican obsession with cutting the tax on capital gains. But opposition to a cut among Congressional Democrats, and even in the White House, appears to be weakening, now that stock prices are soaring and millions of investors are facing a stiff tax bill when they sell investments. Small farmers and business owners are also begging the Democrats to go along. Both groups face tax burdens when they sell their family-owned enterprises at elevated prices.
The Democrats should hold their ground. A major achievement of the 1986 tax reform bill, still mostly intact, was to tax all types of income, including capital gains, at the same rate. It makes no sense to discard this hard-fought victory. It also makes no sense to cut taxes at a time when Congress and the White House are faced with the huge task of eliminating deficits totaling hundreds of billions of dollars over the next five years. The wise course would be to keep capital-gains taxes in place. But if the Democrats want to mollify small-business owners and farmers, they can easily do so without capitulating to the G.O.P.'s attempt to grant what would be a large and discriminatory tax break. 
 The Republicans offer two arguments. One is that capital gains are taxed too heavily. The second is that a much lower capital-gains rate would encourage a wave of new investment and growth. Neither argument is correct.
Under current law, wages and interest income are taxed in the year they are earned. But capital gains on investments escape taxes until they are sold. By postponing the tax, Washington lets investors keep money they would otherwise turn over to the Treasury -- giving them, in effect, an interest-free loan that weakens the claim that capital gains are overly taxed.
More important, an across-the-board cut, as the Republicans propose, will not deliver the economic punch they promise. If Congress cuts the tax in half, the after-tax profit on typical investments is likely to rise by no more than 7 percent. That is too little benefit to generate a substantial increase in saving and investment. As a fraction of national output, the additional investment would be minuscule, much less than 1 percent.
Venture capitalists would be the major beneficiary of the tax cut because their reward largely takes the form of capital gains. But even for them, the impact would be small because venture capitalists account for very little investment themselves. Nearly 90 percent of the money they invest comes from institutions like pension funds and universities, which are exempt from taxes and therefore indifferent to capital-gains tax rates.
Small farmers and business owners often have their wealth tied up in one place, their farm or business, and face large tax bills when they sell their operations. Exactly why the tax burden is seen as unfair to these groups is unclear. After all, everyone else pays taxes on appreciated assets. Indeed, the code already provides tax relief on the sale of family businesses. But if Congress wants to further ease their plight, it can do so with a targeted measure that does not create a massive loophole elsewhere in the tax code.
The budget can afford a hit limited to family businesses and small farms. It cannot afford a needless giveaway that drives up the deficit and creates a loophole Congress rightly closed 10 years ago.

HEADLINE: Unions, Bruised in Direct Battles With Companies, Try a Roundabout Tactic

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Frustrated that companies are beating unions in so many organizing drives, American labor leaders are making a fundamental shift in strategy away from a 60-year tradition of concentrating on workplace elections.
Instead, labor leaders say, they will focus on getting at least 51 percent of the employees at various companies to sign cards backing a union and then demand that the companies recognize the union. 
 This card-check strategy, as it is called, is likely to produce more clashes with management, labor leaders acknowledge. Unions are warning employers that if they do not accept unions on this basis, labor will mount campaigns to press management into recognizing unions even when management is demanding an election.
In Los Angeles, for example, the New Otani Hotel has been rocked by a campaign in which the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Internatonal Union, angry that management rejected a card check, has organized a boycott, sponsored demonstrations and even flown workers to Tokyo to confront and embarrass the hotel's Japanese owners.
The architects of this strategy, which include the leaders of several of the nation's most aggressive unions, say they hope to persuade most employers to recognize unions based on card checks, not only to avoid a pressure campaign but to avoid months and perhaps years of labor-management hostility in hard-fought representation elections.
"American companies say they can't compete without a cooperative environment," said John Wilhelm, secretary-treasurer of the hotel workers union, who has led successful card-check drives in Las Vegas, Nev., avoiding lengthy conflicts. "It's essentially impossible to go from this kind of warfare to a cooperative environment. That's why I tell companies they should accept card checks."
Labor leaders view card checks as a vital weapon in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new campaign to recruit millions of members to reverse the movement's two-decade slide in membership and clout. As the model for their card-check strategy, union leaders cite the organizing drive in which the hotel union has increased its membership in Las Vegas to 45,000 from 18,000 by using cards instead of elections. As another example, union officials point to the United Food and Commercial Workers, which added 68,000 new members last year through card checks.
"Unions have found that the system of representation elections is heavily weighted in favor of employers," said Andrew Stern, president of the Service Employees International Union, which has relied on card signings to unionize 30,000 janitors in its Justice for Janitors campaign. "These elections don't really give workers free choice. We're saying, 'If Americans can buy a house or a car by signing their name, if they can register to vote by signing their name, then they should be able to join a union by signing their name.' "
Many business executives reject labor's push for card checks, arguing that unions have adopted the strategy because they have done such a poor job selling themselves in elections. Noting that the National Labor Relations Act established a right to secret-ballot elections, company officials assert that elections are the fairest way to determine whether employees want a union.
"Card checks seek to circumvent the secret-ballot process in order to force the employer to recognize the union," said Jeffrey C. McGuiness, president of the Labor Policy Association, an employers' lobbying group. "Our problem with cards is they can be coerced. A large union organizer can stand next to a small person and say, 'It will be in your interest to sign this card.' "
Union officials say they have embraced card checks after concluding that representation elections are skewed against them. They note that employers often delay elections for a year or more through legal maneuvers. They cite studies by Prof. Paul Weiler of Harvard Law School showing that employers dismiss about 1 in 20 workers who campaign for a union. Union leaders further note that dismissed union supporters must often wait years for the courts to reinstate them, and that usually happens long after the dismissals have crippled the organizing drive.
Labor leaders also complain that management is free to spread its anti-union message to employees during their eight-hour shifts, while union organizers are barred from the workplace. In many cases, companies require workers to watch anti-union videos or sit through anti-union presentations by managers. In a recent survey of 525 organizing drives, Kate Bronfenbrenner, a Cornell University labor expert, found that half the companies threatened to close their plants if the union won.
"Even when employers don't fire workers, the deck is stacked heavily in favor of management," Mr. Wilhelm said. "Employers can indoctrinate workers during paid work time in a situation where the union has no access. To win recognition through an election, union supporters have to survive a period of propaganda, even terrorism."
Richard Bensinger, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s organizing director, says that if the rules for representation elections applied to political campaigns, President Clinton would have controlled all television stations and been able to make all voters watch his videos several hours a day. Meanwhile, Bob Dole would have had to stand at the Canadian border, handing out fliers to cars whizzing by.
Unions lose about half the representation elections at private-sector employers, but labor's success rate is 85 percent in the public sector, where many employers do not campaign against unions.
Charles Ecker, a spokesman for the New Otani Hotel, said it refused to accept card checks because it viewed them as unfair. Too often, he said, employees sign cards after hearing only the union's pitch -- and never hearing about the negative side of unionization. Elections are preferable, he argued, because workers get to hear both sides.
As for the pressure campaign the hotel faces for refusing to accept a card check, Mr. Ecker said: "It's a campaign of attrition. Nobody wins."
Under Federal law, a union may ask the National Labor Relations Board to supervise an election once 30 percent of a workplace's employees sign cards supporting union recognition. When more than 50 percent sign, the union can ask management for recognition without an election, but most employers demand a vote.
"It's nonsense for employers to say they oppose card checks because they want to give workers a free choice," Mr. Stern said. "This is really a matter of employers wanting to use all their inherent power and economic leverage to pressure employees to vote against the union."
Unions rarely ask for an election unless 70 percent of the workers have signed cards. Organizers say that if they do not have 70 percent support before an election, they are likely to lose because management's anti-union offensive usually changes the minds of many workers.
If there was a guru at last month's A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting in Los Angeles, it was Mr. Wilhelm, the hotel union strategist in Las Vegas who has earned a reputation as the leading card-check practitioner. Mr. Wilhelm, a Yale graduate who made a name for himself organizing Yale's clerical workers two decades ago, has persuaded many hotels to accept card checks by offering the union's cooperation.
He persuaded Mirage Resorts to accept card checks at its future Las Vegas hotels -- and to be neutral in organizing drives -- in exchange for the union's promise to help make the hotels more efficient. As an incentive, the union agreed to reduce the number of job classifications to 38 from 96, enabling management to have each employee do more tasks.
Mr. Wilhelm persuaded the 5,000-room MGM Grand in Las Vegas, the world's largest hotel, to accept a card check after an intense pressure campaign in which 500 union supporters sat in at the hotel and the union fought MGM's expansion to other states and issued a caustic report on MGM to investors.
Peter Pantaleo, an MGM lawyer, said, "I don't see management ever agreeing to a card check unless they are pressured or perceive a legitimate business justification."
Mr. Wilhelm has gone the election route only once in Las Vegas, and he says it underlined all the defects of elections. In May 1992, a union drive began at the Santa Fe Hotel and Casino, with 70 percent of the workers signing cards by September 1992. Insisting on an election, management rejected the union's request for card recognition. The election was not held until September 1993, and the union won by 300 to 241, but only after management had dismissed 9 union supporters, threatened to dismiss 14 others and cited 12 union supporters for trespassing. Five workers charged the hotel with illegal surveillance, and many complained that hotel security had pulled pro-union fliers out of their hands in the cafeteria.
The hotel challenged the election results, and it was not until October 1996 that a Federal appeals court upheld the union's victory and ordered the hotel into contract talks.

HEADLINE: Bonn Said to Expel U.S. Envoy Accused of Economic Spying

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, March 9

 BODY:
A United States diplomat is reported to have been expelled from Bonn, after being accused of committing economic espionage against Germany, one of Washington's staunchest allies.
The newsmagazine Der Spiegel, which released the report in advance of publication on Monday, said the expulsion, two years after a similar incident in France, was the first of its kind in Germany. 
 In Washington, a State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that German authorities had notified the United States that an American was to be expelled but that the person had not yet left. A spokeswoman for the United States Embassy in Bonn said, "We do not comment on intelligence matters." German officials here also refused to comment.
Der Spiegel said the expulsion had been carried out quietly without a formal diplomatic protest. But Willfried Penner, a member of the opposition Social Democratic Party who heads a key parliamentary committee, said "things will be different" if further instances of American espionage are uncovered.
The notion of American agents spying on Germany, which sees itself as a steadfast ally, is bound to complicate the question of how Washington now views a country that for decades during the cold war stood on Europe's front line against the Soviet bloc.
The affair coincides with what many German commentators view as Bonn's deepening sense of alienation from Washington. This was reflected, for example, in dismay over the recent American readiness to publicly accuse Germany of human rights abuses over its hostile attitude toward the Scientology movement.
Der Spiegel said that the unidentified American, apparently an operative of the Central Intelligence Agency under diplomatic cover, had tried to recruit a high-ranking official in the Economics Ministry with access to "high-tech projects." The nature of the projects was not disclosed.
According to Der Spiegel, the American agent's attempt to recruit the German official backfired when the German reported the approach to Bonn's counter-intelligence authorities.
Der Spiegel did not say when the expulsion took place.
The incident has highlighted the continued presence of American intelligence agents in Germany despite the end of the cold war, when this country was the most dangerous potential flashpoint in Europe and housed hundreds of thousands of American service personnel.
Since the fall of the Soviet Union the number of American soldiers stationed in Germany has been drastically reduced, to around 65,000, but the United States has rejected German requests for the dismantling of American intelligence-gathering operations here, saying they are necessary for the security of the North Atlantic alliance.
German officials quoted in Der Spiegel countered that economic espionage against an ally has nothing to do with NATO's security.
German intelligence officials, moreover, accuse their American counterparts of behaving as if nothing had changed since the cold war, when the divided Germany was an espionage center for East and West.
"The Americans still look upon us as their backyard where they can do anything they like," Der Spiegel quoted an unidentified German intelligence official as saying.
The expulsion was reported in recent days to the German parliamentary intelligence oversight committee, by which time the purported American spy had left the country, Der Spiegel said. It was reported to the committee by Bernd Schmidbauer, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's top intelligence aide, and Peter Frisch, head of the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, the domestic intelligence agency.
The Government's reluctance to publicly discuss the move today reflected a perception among officials here that some matters are best not aired. Last year, Bonn maintained a studious silence about the expulsion of two Iranian diplomats, even after word of their departure had been published in the American press.
Two years ago, France ordered five Americans -- four of them C.I.A. operatives working under diplomatic cover -- to leave France after they attempted to bribe French officials into betraying their country's position in world trade negotiations.

HEADLINE: Campaign Finance Complicates China Policy

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
When James Sasser, the American Ambassador to Beijing and a former Democratic Senator from Tennessee, went home to talk to the Economic Club of Memphis on Friday, local business executives wanted to know about China's unfair trade practices, its human rights problems and politics after Deng Xiaoping.
But reporters brought up something else: the so-called China connection to the campaign finance scandal. 
 Wherever the Ambassador spoke on his tour of various cities to tout 1997 as "a very important year" in relations with China, he found himself playing down accusations that either the Chinese Government or big campaign contributors with close ties to Beijing had influenced, or tried to influence, the Clinton Administration's China policy or the 1996 Presidential election campaign.
"I would be the most surprised person in the United States of America if we find there is any participation by the Chinese Government in campaign contributions," Mr. Sasser said in an interview in Memphis.
But domestic politics have a way of seeping into even the best-built foreign policies.
And although Mr. Sasser and other Administration officials deny that the scandal-charged atmosphere in Washington has in any way affected policy toward China, concerns are emerging inside and outside the Administration that the United States and China may now have less room to maneuver at a crucial time in their relationship.
Vice President Al Gore is to travel to China with his family this month, in the Administration's highest-level visit to that country so far. If all goes well, President Jiang Zemin will come to the United States this fall on an official state visit complete with a 21-gun salute and a formal White House dinner. That could be followed by President Clinton's first trip to Beijing next year.
But already, officials at the White House and the State Department are worried that Mr. Gore's visit could be overshadowed by questions about his involvement in campaign fund-raising or about whether fund-raising activities somehow compromised American policy toward China.
Officials who until a few weeks ago were billing Mr. Gore's trip as a major step toward finding a new way to talk to China are now playing down expectations of any substantive progress during the visit.
In fact, Mr. Gore is said to be concerned about the potential political repercussions in the United States of the toasts of friendship that he and his Chinese hosts will make and the official -- and unofficial -- photographs that will be taken, Administration officials familiar with China said.
The officials recall with dismay the ill-fated visit of Secretary of State Warren Christopher to Beijing in March 1994. That visit, initially planned as the culmination of six months of intensive high-level engagement with the Chinese, was poisoned by China's rounding up of political prisoners and by Chinese officials' public censure of Mr. Christopher as he sharply criticized their human rights policies and refused an invitation to an official banquet.
Although the atmosphere between Washington and Beijing has improved since then, it is impossible to predict what new reports about fund-raising may surface before or during Mr. Gore's trip.
Complicating policy toward China, the post of Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs is vacant. Winston Lord, who held the job for the last four years, made clear early last fall that he did not want to stay on. Next week, he is moving back to New York, where he intends to consult, study art and music and work on his tennis game.
The nomination of Stanley Roth, who handled Asia policy at the National Security Council and the Pentagon during Mr. Clinton's first term, is stymied at the White House. His confirmation hearings are several weeks, perhaps months, away.
In addition, Mr. Roth's name is on a few of the White House documents related to campaign finance practices that were released by the White House as part of the nomination of Anthony Lake, the former national security adviser, as Director of Central Intelligence. Mr. Roth's confirmation could be delayed even longer if Republican lawmakers try to link him to questionable fund-raising practices.
"The State Department is stretched thin in the East Asia division because of the absence of a successor to Win Lord," Mr. Sasser said. "It is imperative to get someone in place as soon as possible."
Although no evidence has come to light indicating that Chinese money affected Mr. Clinton's fundamental policy toward China, in the current supercharged political atmosphere, any accusations linking campaign contributions to Beijing could cause the Administration to be more cautious in making positive gestures toward China.
"The allegations about Asian fund-raising in general and connections with China in particular inevitably create an atmosphere in which people will interpret leadership on China policy as a payoff for Chinese contributions," said Kenneth Lieberthal, a China expert at the University of Michigan. "I think that would be a wrong interpretation, but politically that has to be a concern for the White House."
The accusations could also complicate lobbying by the Administration on behalf of American companies doing business in China.
"Clinton is going to have a hard time legitimately making demands on behalf of American companies to the Chinese Government, because of the perception that the normal boundaries between policy-making and fund-raising were not maintained," said Fareed Zakaria, managing editor of Foreign Affairs, who has written extensively about China.
But during his speaking tour, Mr. Sasser did his best to separate policy toward China and domestic politics.
He told a luncheon given by the National Committee on United States-China Relations in New York that he did not know much about the scandal but that America's policy of engagement would not "be deterred by any news story."
He told the Asia Society in Washington that China "was the worst lobbyist" in Washington and needed to do more, not less, to get its point of view across on Capitol Hill.
Still, even if the fund-raising scandal was not reflected in businessmen's questions to Mr. Sasser at the Economic Club luncheon in Memphis, much of the informal talk there was indeed about who was sleeping in the Lincoln bedroom and the political fallout for Mr. Gore, who like former Senator Sasser, is a product of Tennessee politics.
"There'll be a press conference in the front bedroom -- I mean dining room," announced Bruce Taylor, the head of a big construction company and one of the luncheon organizers.
For some businessmen, the fund-raising scandal is only of passing concern. "Since '91 we've become so accustomed to hearing things about Clinton and Gore that you've got to really come up with something new to grab our attention," said Calvin Anderson, an executive with Blue Cross/Blue Shield of Memphis, who worked for Mr. Sasser when he was in the Senate.
But other executives disagreed.
"The best thing Gore had going for him was that he was Mr. Clean," said Rudi Scheidt, who was involved in cotton exports to China when he was chairman of the Hohenberg Brothers Cotton Company. "So what does this all do to Mr. Clean?"

HEADLINE: Neglected Churches Are Given New Use In the Netherlands

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM

 BODY:
Every Friday afternoon, a courtyard along a busy Amsterdam street fills with Muslim men parking their bicycles and removing their shoes as they prepare for prayers. They may not see it this way, but the worshipers at the Fatih Camii Mosque are part of a fundamental change in the Netherlands.
The site where Allah is now loudly praised used to be a Roman Catholic church. It has been stripped of its crosses and paintings, and the spires on its two plump towers now carry a crescent moon. 
 But it is not Islam, brought here mainly by Moroccan and Turkish immigrants, that is troubling the Dutch priests and pastors. Rather it is a more far-reaching shift, the continuing decline of Christianity.
Dwindling church attendance by Catholics and mainstream Protestants has forced the clergy in much of Europe to confront the same, often painful question their counterparts in New York and other American cities have asked: What to do with the cavernous churches, the myriad chapels and sprawling monasteries that have become redundant and require small fortunes to keep up.
Disused churches can be found in Britain, France, Germany and elsewhere in northern Europe, and many are simply closed. German churches, though, are supported by tax revenues, and French churches long ago became municipal property, all of which help pay for maintenance.
But in the crowded Netherlands, where the churches own the buildings and space is precious, the response has been pragmatic and secular.
Cash-strapped church elders have sold off more than 250 places of worship in the last two decades, buildings where Catholics, Calvinists and Lutherans had prayed for a century or longer. Many have already been converted into libraries, shops, cultural centers and even apartments and discotheques.
Some changeovers signal another kind of transition. A handful of churches were bought by young evangelical sects, New Age groups and growing Muslim communities.
Jews have followed the trend, though on a smaller scale. One community sold a little-used 18th-century synagogue in The Hague, and it was recently dedicated as a mosque. Another synagogue, in Amsterdam, houses the Resistance Museum. A third is being turned into a store.
The Dutch Government's national heritage foundation often pays part of the conversion costs, particularly if it involves one of the 2,300 places of worship listed as protected. Protected or not, the churches are seen as part of the neighborhood, as a vital part of the urban landscape, said Jaap het Hart, director of the foundation.
"They do not want them demolished or changed," he said. "But as the country goes on secularizing, there is less and less money available to keep the buildings going."
In much of Western Europe, church attendance has been slipping since the 1960's, dropping particularly fast in the 1980's. Among the Dutch, the decline has been especially steep. While in 1960, 18 percent of the Dutch said they belonged to no church or religion, in 1995 that number had reached 40 percent, according to the national Bureau of Statistics.
The steepest drop has been among Protestants, who are split into various denominations. Catholics remain the single largest group, making up 33 percent.
The dismantling of the churches has produced anxiety and soul-searching among parishioners, even in a country that tends to be more practical than emotional. Religion may seem irrelevant to many people, but the power of its images and symbolism endures.
"People were offended at first and said things like: How dare you violate the church?" said Willem van Vliet, who in 1984 bought a large disused Protestant church in the heart of Hoorn, a town north of Amsterdam.
The century-old, neo-Renaissance building had been closed for 20 years, and the local "save the church" group had not managed to collect enough money for basic repairs. Mr. van Vliet and his partners paid $2.6 million for the hulking church and parsonage. The heritage foundation and the provincial government put up a similar amount for repairs and conversion work.
"We had a lot of sleepless nights," said Mr. van Vliet, recalling the overhaul of the slated roof, propping up four towers and worrying about painstaking tasks like restoring leaded glass windows, chimneys and ornamented pillars.
Today the church has five floors. Shops occupy the first two. In the soaring height of the nave, Mr. van Vliet built 18 apartments.
"I'm proud as can be," he said. "We were so criticized, and now we have a waiting list of 80 families wanting to live here."
One tenant, a young woman, said she was not religious but loved the idea of living in a church and sleeping under its slanted roof. For the neighborhood there is another kind of comfort: up in its tower, the old carillon still chimes the familiar tunes.
Tessel Pollmann, the author of a study of converted churches, said that not all projects had been an economic success and that some were struggling to survive. A few have become public libraries that have proved impractical and difficult to heat.
"It costs a lot more to turn a church into an apartment building than to put up a new one," Ms. Pollmann said. "There are architectural limits; it's expensive to maintain. But people keep doing it. Land is scarce, and everything is urbanized and intensely managed. And this is a rich country where people can afford to do impractical things."
Amsterdam, the nation's capital, has more than a dozen former churches with a new purpose. The Vondel Church, an elegant neo-Gothic structure named after a hallowed Dutch writer, houses several discreet offices with only tiny name plates on the door. But a few blocks away, the Holland Diving shop has painted the outside of an disused Protestant church black, hung up large signs, replaced the pews with racks of wet suits and flippers and built a swimming pool in the apse.
"The church elders knew of our plans, and they accepted it," said Lothar de Bruijn, the manager. "But when the pastor came to take away the organ, he had tears in his eyes."
As merchants have become brasher, opposition has grown. On the edge of Rotterdam, local residents who were furious when a Protestant church was turned into a carpet salesroom campaigned until the most objectionable billboards were taken down. A synagogue in Weesp that was recently sold was about to re-open as a giant outlet for discount jeans. Local citizens, considering this undignified, mobilized and stopped the project.
Selling property has sometimes put religious elders in an awkward position. When a Muslim group wanted to buy the big 18th-century synagogue on the Wagen street in The Hague to use it as a mosque, the Jewish community opted for a go-between: It first sold the building to the city, which then sold it to the Muslims.
Of the country's nearly 40 Orthodox synagogues, only about a dozen are in use. Almost three of four Jews who lived in the Netherlands before World War II died in the Holocaust. Today many do not practice the faith.
The Roman Catholic Church is clearly the most reluctant to sell. A Catholic church is considered to occupy consecrated ground, explained Leo Klok, the head of finance for the Archdiocese of Utrecht.
"We must protect the dignity of the building, and that can be difficult," Mr. Klok said. "We make agreements with the Government or a buyer, and they are not always met. So against our wishes a few churches have become offices, dance halls and shops."
More than 125 Catholic churches have been closed since 1973, but just as many smaller ones have been opened that allow for more versatile use as community centers. The old buildings have been much in demand as mosques, because their large size. But the archdiocese hesitates to sell them to Islamic groups, after a few "difficult" experiences, Mr. Klok said.
"Islam has many currents, and you end up dealing not with a religious group but with the government behind them," he said.
In Utrecht, for instance, the Emmaus Church was being transferred ostensibly to an Islamic foundation. "It turned out we were dealing with the Libyan Government," Mr. Klok said.
The Archbishop's office has calculated that in the coming years, as people leave rural areas for the cities, 90 more Catholic churches around the country will have to close, too great a number to sell easily, specialists say.
"We prefer that the churches are used by other Christians or for a cultural purpose -- or perhaps even as funeral parlors," Mr. Klok said. "If a dignified destination cannot be found, then we prefer them to be demolished."

HEADLINE: In America;
The Artful Dodger

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Bill Clinton is one of the great masters of the art of politics, which in its essence is the art of the con -- the ability to convincingly declare that day is night, that up is down, that what is so is not.
He was at it again on Saturday, during his radio address. Aware that the day is coming when large numbers of women and children will be thrown off welfare and into destitution because of legislation that he signed (the devil made him do it, or the Republicans -- whatever), Mr. Clinton announced that he was ordering Federal agencies to recruit and hire welfare recipients. 
 Said Mr. Clinton: "Government can help to move people from welfare to work by acting the way we want all employers to act -- demanding high performance from workers but going the extra mile to offer opportunity to those who have been on welfare and want to do something more with their lives."
Listeners could be forgiven for imagining one-time welfare recipients hurrying off each morning to their spiffy new Government jobs. It was the image Mr. Clinton intended to create. A small problem, which he managed not to address, is that the Federal Government has little more than a handful of jobs -- at best -- that can go to welfare recipients. The President has been assiduously downsizing the Government, a fact that he never hesitates to mention when it is politically advantageous.
As Robert Pear wrote in yesterday's Times: "Mr. Clinton's initiative faces formidable obstacles because the Federal Government is not hiring many people. The President boasts that he has reduced the number of civilian employees in the executive branch by 13 percent, to 1.9 million, the lowest level in 30 years, and he promises that the Federal work force 'will continue shrinking' as he tries to balance the budget by 2002."
Welfare recipients, for the most part, require low-skilled entry-level positions. Mr. Pear noted: "For permanent blue-collar jobs last year, the Federal Government hired 32 people in the Boston area, 27 in Dallas, 8 in Kansas City, 31 in New York and 17 in Seattle."
Current lists of Government job openings nationwide typically show few entry-level opportunities: 11 openings for nursing assistants, 6 for clerk typists, 9 for mail and file clerks.
Proponents of welfare "reform" adamantly refuse to address the fundamental issue of whether there are jobs available for those who are forcibly removed from the rolls.
A recent study out of Chicago showed what should be plain to anyone who looks at this matter in good faith: the so-called welfare problem is the result of a big problem in the labor market.
The study was conducted by researchers from the Center for Urban Economic Development at the University of Illinois at Chicago and the Chicago Urban League. It found that while overall unemployment rates in Illinois are at their lowest levels in more than 20 years, the jobless rate for those needing entry-level jobs was nearly twice that of other workers.
The study found that there are four workers in search of entry-level jobs for every entry-level opening in Illinois. In the urban centers of Chicago and East St. Louis, the gap is worse: six workers for every entry-level opening in Chicago and nine for every opening in East St. Louis.
In rural Illinois, the same story: six to nine workers for every entry-level opening.
And while an entry-level job is a step in the right direction, it's not as if it's the answer to the hideous constellation of problems associated with long-term poverty. As the Chicago study notes: "If welfare reform is to promote self-sufficiency, workers must be able to secure jobs that pay enough to allow families to cover household necessities and work-related expenses."
But jobs that pay a so-called "livable wage" are in extremely short supply at the entry level. The study found that, depending on the wage level designated as minimally adequate, "there are between 33 and 222 less-skilled job seekers for every entry-level, livable job in Illinois."
To move people from welfare to work there has to be enough work. Right now there is not nearly enough. Mr. Clinton knows that. But he goes on the radio and speaks as if he didn't. The art of the con.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
China, Part III

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At the recent Davos World Economic Forum I found myself seated at dinner next to the chairman of one of the world's largest energy companies, with major investments in Europe and China. He began by asking me: "What do you think about this Swiss-Jewish thing?" I told him the Swiss needed to be more forthcoming and he mumbled something about how the Swiss were no better or worse than anyone else in Europe. It was one of those conversations, though, where I knew if I had said, "Those Jews, they're just blackmailing the Swiss," this guy would have said, "Man, you're so right." Then he went on to China. What did I think of the U.S. human rights activism there? Before I could even answer, he unleashed a broadside against the U.S. for promoting human rights in China, and he added, for good measure, that one reason his oil business was doing so well there was because China didn't have all those pesky environmental rules.
The encounter ruined my dinner, but it was typical of the attitude of big business toward China today, which is craven, cynical and amoral. The most cynical say the job of business is business, and human rights in China is not their concern. Those slightly less cynical peddle the view that by doing business with China we are promoting free markets there, which will inevitably change the Chinese system into something close to democratic capitalism. Therefore we needn't press human rights, or rule of law, on China; it will happen naturally. 
 China's rapid economic growth definitely is prompting Beijing to introduce more rule of law in fields like copyright, administrative law and contracts. But there's nothing inevitable about this march ending with democracy and human rights in China and to pretend so is a cop-out. We've learned from what happened in the Soviet Union that the successor to Communism might not be democracy but "kleptocracy," where an economic elite rips off all the state assets. One reason that happened in Russia was that there was no rule-of-law foundation in place when the U.S.S.R. collapsed. We can't afford that in China.
Yes, the job of business is to make profits for shareholders, not to campaign for dissidents, like Wang Dan. But if business can't be persuaded to sacrifice profit for principles, it should be persuaded to not sacrifice the long term for the short term. In the short term, businesses can operate in China, without adequate rule of law there, by simply buying risk insurance or paying bribes. But this is a very shortsighted strategy.
As one diplomat in Hong Kong remarked to me: "How smart is it to be investing billions of dollars in a country which at any moment could surprise you with the worst thing you've ever seen on CNN -- all taking place in Tiananmen Square with your brand name in the background?"
Both Congress and the big pension funds need to encourage business to think long term. Congress should consider giving tax breaks to U.S. companies that promote rule-of-law practices in China. And fund managers should question any company that is too heavily invested in a country with inadequate rule of law.
U.S. business leaders better wake up. They do business with China in the context of a larger U.S.-China relationship -- and anyone who has been to Congress lately knows this larger relationship is in trouble. There is a sour mood in Congress these days about China -- a feeling that in the last few years the U.S. has so cravenly put profit ahead of principle with China that people are a little bit ashamed.
This mood could produce a violent reaction by Congress, if, for instance, China mishandles Hong Kong or is found to have massively meddled in the U.S. elections. If U.S. business wants to prevent such a lurch backward, it needs to start taking some responsibility for improving the overall framework of U.S.-China relations. That means taking some initiative to bridge the huge gap between the U.S. business community and the U.S. human rights community when it comes to China -- rather than always widening that gap. Business could start by looking for ways to promote rule of law in China, which helps commerce, human rights and the Chinese people.
I still believe in the mantra that human rights and business rights are just flip sides of the same coin -- the rule of law. And, in the long run, when there is no rule of law for Wang Dan there will be none for Microsoft, Mickey Mouse or Ronald McDonald.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: In a Pocket of Brooklyn Sewn by Welfare, an Unraveling

SERIES: WELFARE NEIGHBORHOOD: Change Comes to Southside

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Southside, a Latino and Hasidic section of Williamsburg, sits on one edge of Brooklyn, a neighborhood staring out at the lights of Manhattan. It is a neighborhood of dying industry and full-blown poverty, a neighborhood of churches and shuls, of immigrants and their children.
It is also a welfare neighborhood, and so it now feels a deep unease about the new welfare legislation and what it and similar local changes have done, and will mean. 
 Fear of the future is already reshaping life in Southside, where roughly half the 27,000 residents receive public assistance, money that not only supports families but also holds together the modest economy of bodegas, discount stores and travel agencies.
The effect can already be seen in tales of hardship and success and in the decisions of business people and institutions that function on welfare money.
Angel Feliciano, owner of the Latin Corner bodega, studies his bank statements -- more than two-thirds of his income comes from food stamps -- and frets about his store's prospects in a world of shrinking public assistance. Mr. Feliciano has decided that his bodega's future is perilous enough that he will not make his usual contribution to the neighborhood's Little League program. Mr. Feliciano said he believed that the city's aggressive efforts to trim the welfare rolls during the last two years had already helped reduce his monthly food stamp income to $1,600, from $2,100.
A former building superintendent, Hugo Contreras, 48, sent his three children back to the Dominican Republic after he was cut off from welfare for refusing his work assignment.
Miguel Pena, a 72-year-old Dominican immigrant in whom mental illness has been diagnosed, will lose his Federal disability benefits, known as Supplemental Security Income, within months because he is not a citizen. He, like many of the 80,000 legal immigrants similarly affected, has no other source of income.
The insular world of the neighborhood's Hasidim, one rich with children, will also feel the force of change. Rabbi David Niederman, a leader of the Satmar sect, estimates that 30 percent of the roughly 30,000 Hasidim in Williamsburg receive some form of public assistance. "As we don't believe in birth control, there is only one breadwinner in our families," he said. "Secular education for our men ends early. What jobs can they get? Doctors? Journalists?"
Meanwhile, working mothers wind up in tears daily at Nuestros Ninos, a city-financed day care center, after being told there is no space for their children, partly because the city has made welfare mothers its top priority for available slots.
So there is a palpable sense in Southside that its economy and people are on the cusp of a major transition as a result of the government's redefinition of what it will do for the poor. The complex currency of welfare reaches places obvious and not in Southside. It is spent on drugs, but also pays people's tithes to the dozens of Pentecostal churches; it buys fancy clothes, but also Catholic school tuition and Torah studies.
The forces starting to reshape Southside do not flow from one piece of legislation. Welfare reform is a series of changes in social policies, made at several levels of government. It is a patchwork of new laws and pending proposals, many of which will be phased in over weeks, months and years.
Of the 27,000 people in Southside, 6,200 have been receiving guaranteed cash and other assistance through the core Federal welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. The Federal Government has given control of this and other welfare programs to the states, and decreed that no person or family in neighborhoods like Southside will receive Federal money for longer than five years. Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed cutting the size of those Federal payments year by year as the five-year limit approaches for families. The results of the coming debate in the Legislature over his proposal will have direct consequences for the people of Southside.
In addition, 1,100 single childless adults in the neighborhood, ineligible for A.F.D.C., receive money through Home Relief, a state cash assistance program that Governor Pataki has proposed be eliminated. For the last year, New York City has been requiring both A.F.D.C. recipients and Home Relief recipients to work for their benefits.
Another 2,400 residents exist on Supplemental Security Income, which is Federal assistance for the elderly or disabled and is often used for medical care. The government has sent letters to hundreds of immigrants lacking citizenship saying they will be cut off from the program no later than this summer. Changes in Supplemental Security Income will also affect scores of children who will lose their monthly checks as a result of a toughening of Federal regulations for who qualifies as disabled.
An additional 3,700 people receive Medicaid as their only public subsidy. Food stamps will be eliminated for much of the welfare population: people who reach their welfare time limits, those who fail to meet the work requirements and immigrants who are not citizens.
The supporters of the welfare legislation have their own forecast for the future of a place like Southside: its residents will reclaim their independence, find work, give up the corrosive burden of welfare. And its economy, despite short-term damage, will emerge as an authentically healthy engine.
 
Ripple Effect
Economic Change, Dismal Decisions
It is hard to measure cause and effect so early on in the life of welfare reform, but the economic ripples are already being felt.
The administrators at a parochial elementary school, SS. Peter and Paul, worry about having to raise tuition if hardship forces parents to withdraw their children. Conversations in the boardroom of at least one bank that makes loans in Williamsburg have included talk of welfare reform's potential effects. Officials with a nonprofit economic development project acknowledge it may be more difficult to attract investors.
Moises Esdaille, the owner of the C-Town Supermarket on Havemeyer Street, closed his store last month after he was refused a loan by the Empire State Economic Development Corporation, the state agency that awards grants and loans to entrepreneurs and institutions across New York. More than 60 percent of Mr. Esdaille's business at the supermarket resulted from food stamps.
Mr. Esdaille, who admits he has had several financing problems, has been left to wonder how much the uncertain economic future of the neighborhood made his store appear a risk. "It was never said to me directly that they worried about what was going to happen to the neighborhood," said Mr. Esdaille, who laid off 15 workers. "But how could it not have been one reason?"
Randy Daniels, a senior vice president for economic revitalization at the Empire State Development Corporation, said concerns about Mr. Esdaille's debt and other problems were much much greater than any unease about the economic impact of welfare reform. Mr. Daniels, however, said, "We have to take note of anything that might have a positive or negative impact on a local economy, and so the impact of welfare reform will have to be taken note of in any decisions we make."
The store's supplier, Krasdale Foods Inc., which deals with small supermarkets across the city, was even more blunt about how the changes in welfare might affect its decisions in welfare neighborhoods.
"I think a lot of the store owners we deal with have bought into the idea that if welfare reform works, dealing with a neighborhood of working people that results is going to be good for them financially," said Ray Thek, a lawyer for Krasdale. "The question is what happens short term. It's absolutely true that we are going to be very conservative, even reticent, about what stores we get involved in."
People have been making painful decisions, great and modest, and preparing for difficult realities elsewhere in Southside.
An example of that has taken place at the Francis of Paola Preschool for disabled children in Williamsburg. The Federal Government, in addition to ending Supplemental Security Income benefits to legal immigrants lacking citizenship, will no longer extend hundreds of dollars in monthly benefits to children with learning delays or behavioral problems. School officials say that roughly one-fifth of the 280 students will lose their monthly checks of $500 to $800 in the coming months because they will not meet the new standards of disability.
As a result, school administrators are preparing the staff of 140 for layoffs.
"We know what might happen," said Carmen Pagan, a classroom aide and former recipient, "and so those who work here look at each other and think: 'I hope it's you that goes when the layoffs come.' You don't want to feel that in your heart. But you do."
 
Workfare Woes
Work Requirement Cuts Welfare Rolls
The greatest impact on Southside has resulted from the city's program to make people work for their benefits. The program, in place for two years, has helped reduce the city's welfare rolls, city officials say, to 900,000 from 1.1 million. More than 110,000 people have gone through the Work Experience Program, called WEP.
Scores of the 35,000 now participating in the workfare program come from Southside. Williamsburg Works, an agency with a limited staff on Union Avenue that tries to find work for welfare recipients, has been so overwhelmed with people sent by the city that it informed state and city officials that they would have to rethink their contract. One week, 35 welfare recipients involved in the city's mandatory work program showed up to look for jobs. No one got a job there.
The workfare program has produced casualties and successes. Mr. Contreras, who lives alone and gets by on odd jobs, said he refused his work assignment because he was frightened and humiliated by having to sweep streets for his welfare benefits. But Maggie Montalvo, a mother fearful of losing her benefits after 15 years on welfare, now meets her 20-hour-a-week work requirement by assisting teachers at her daughter's Head Start program. She is studying for a high school equivalency diploma.
"A lot of people are scared at first," Ms. Montalvo said. "They think their children will be deprived. But I needed help, a push. Half my life I stayed inside. I stayed inside, I thought, for my kids. Now I want to do something for me."
Others forced to work for their benefits remain mystified, uncertain why such a furor has been directed at women living on a sum that averages, for a family of three, $577 a month, plus $230 in food stamps.
Many of the women, a significant percentage in their 50's, are unsure what they are expected to do in the years to come. They do not consider their job prospects good, particularly in a neighborhood like Southside.
Antonia Medina, 58, arrived in Southside from Puerto Rico 30 years ago. A former factory worker, she has been required to clean McCarren Park, blocks north of Southside, for more than six months, receiving no guidance or training.
"Go to the factories, they are Dominicans, Mexicans, and they don't have papers," said Ms. Medina, who works 44 hours every two weeks for her $68.50 in cash benefits and roughly $150 in food stamps. "They take $3 an hour. I can't take that work. I didn't come here for welfare. But this WEP program is not a serious program to have people work."
Palmira Rodriguez, 55, suffers from asthma and was hospitalized during a trip to her city-mandated workfare job. But city officials insisted she could work, and cut her off from benefits. She had her benefits restored, but doctors hired by the city now say she can do office work. She is awaiting a hearing.
"I was an independent woman once," she said. "I worked at Bellevue Hospital. I don't wish to be on welfare. It's embarrassing. I feel like I am begging. But I am sick."
The work requirements have also strained the neighborhood's day care system. The city has directed the day care centers it finances to give first priority to welfare recipients.
So in January, the board of the Nuestros Ninos Child Development Center decided not to expand its operation, fearing that expanding to meet the demand caused by work requirements for welfare mothers might compromise its quality of care. So there is virtually no room for the children of the parents who stream through the door daily.
"It's not fair to make people who work wait longer," said Maria Rodriguez, 27, a legal secretary with two children and no subsidized day care options. "Everybody should have the same rights."
 
Don't Sell It Short
A Neighborhood With Resources
In the end, Southside may be up to the challenges. Many working people in Southside say they think that many recipients cheat the government and could be working.
"I know what goes on here," said Lena Manino, owner of Aldo's Coffee Shop in the heart of Southside. "Those are my taxes. Yes, there are people who need help. But out of 10 people on welfare in this neighborhood, maybe two deserve it."
The neighborhood, too, is not without resources. Physically rehabilitated from the days of arson and abandonment in the 1970's -- the number of reported felony crimes has fallen 42 percent during the last three years -- the neighborhood has churches, an alternative high school, an array of addiction treatment centers. Parts of the neighborhood fall within the boundaries of a major city and state plan to build affordable housing. And there is a legacy of political organizing among the Puerto Ricans.
But any positive remaking of the neighborhood will be difficult. Southside reflects discouraging national demographic realities: more Latinos are now officially defined as poor than are members of any other group, and their incomes are declining further; only 5 percent have college degrees; nearly 90 percent do not speak English as their primary language.
Roughly 15 percent of the neighborhood's children are born to teen-age mothers; scores of its households include the welfare-supported granddaughters of welfare-dependent grandmothers; much of its work force consists of illegal immigrants. There is also virtually no medical infrastructure in Southside. The distant Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center is the site of nearly all care. Drug use remains a plague. Domestic violence, which studies have shown often shackles women to welfare, is widespread.
Manufacturing, once the thumping economic heart of the area, is a faint presence. Many remaining factories flout laws governing wages and legal employment.
"I have worked for 10 years, put money away for my kids, seen the neighborhood improve," said Mike Vasquez, a building superintendent raised by a mother on welfare. "Maybe the neighborhood now goes down the drain. Welfare has been a kind of security for the neighborhood."
Residents say the welfare measures could widen the fractures already coursing through the neighborhood.
Divides of distrust have long separated the old-line Puerto Rican households from those of the more recent Latino arrivals, with many Puerto Ricans saying that Dominicans and Mexicans have helped destroy the job market, taking jobs for substandard wages.
Another chasm has separated the Latinos and the Hasidim, groups that are as suspicious of each other about welfare and the real need for it as they always have been about housing, police protection and political clout.
The Rev. Matthew Foley, pastor of Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in Southside for 37 years, said: "There were families on welfare in great numbers when I came, and there are even greater numbers of them now. For some it was a moral question. For others it was a practical question. Mainly it was a question of surviving and finding a way to do that. Now we will see if there is another way."

Welfare Neighborhood
The nation's welfare system is being reshaped with an array of policy changes at the local, state and Federal levels. Some people have forecast disaster for the poor; others see the end of decades of dependence and dishonesty. In the coming months, this series will examine how the changes come together in one Brooklyn neighborhood, Southside in Williamsburg. It will measure consequences and opinions. This is the first visit.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Palestinians Say Pullback By Israel Is Not Enough
The Palestinians rejected Israel's decision to withdraw from 9 percent more of the land it occupies, giving Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu an unexpected new crisis. After a three-hour meeting, the Palestinian negotiator said the territory to be turned over was insufficient. Foreign Minister David Levy reiterated Israel's position that the peace accords left it to Israel to decide on the size of the pullback, and he indicated that the matter was not closed. A8
 
Offer From Albanian Leader
 President Sali Berisha of Albania proposed a plan for a transitional government and national elections, but the offer appeared to be too little and too late to placate the rebels centered in the southern port of Vlore. Rebel leaders said they still wanted the resignation of Mr. Berisha, a hard-line leader widely blamed for failing to curb fraudulent financial schemes that have cost Albanians some $1.5 billion in savings. A3
 
Bonn Is Said to Expel American
A United States diplomat was expelled from Germany after being accused of committing economic espionage against that country, the news magazine Der Spiegel reported. A State Department official said that Germany had notified the United States that an American was to be expelled, but that the person had not yet left. German officials refused to comment. A6
 
Refugees Scatter in Zaire
United Nations officials began searching for tens of thousands of refugees who had scattered into the jungles in eastern Zaire. On their first return after evacuating the region nine days ago, relief officials found several hundred bone-thin people in the ruins of the Tingi Tingi camp, which was overrun by rebels last week. They said more than 100,000 others had either melted into the bush or pushed on to a Government-held town about 80 miles away. A5
 
Ex-Leader Charged in Ecuador
Ecuador's Supreme Court charged former President Abdala Bucaram and four top aides with corruption and embezzlement in a case involving $88 million. After being voted out by Congress last month, Mr. Bucaram and his aides left the presidential palace with 11 burlap sacks stuffed with money, investigators say. Mr. Bucaram's secretary, Oscar Celleri, was arrested carrying $3.4 million in a border town near Peru on Friday. Mr. Bucaram denies any wrongdoing. (AP)
 
Kabul University Reopens
Kabul University reopened its doors for the first time since the Taliban religious army took control of the Afghan capital in September. Many of the buildings were ruined by bomb and rocket attacks, and much of the campus, littered with land mines, is off-limits. The Taliban have banned women from the school as both students and teachers. Before the school was closed, women made up about 60 percent of the teachers and half the student body. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A10-12, B7-8
 
Showdown Looms Over H.M.O. Changes
A showdown is shaping up between Congress and the managed-care industry as both sides weigh the likelihood of legislation to set standards for the quality of care offered by health maintenance organizations. Lawmakers say they are responding to constituents' frustrations with H.M.O.'s. Managed-care companies denounce the prospect of new Federal regulation but find themselves in an awkward position because they also say they want to protect consumers. A1
 
Rap Artist Is Fatally Shot
The Notorious B.I.G., a gangsta rap artist who turned his drug-dealing past on the streets of Brooklyn into a platinum-selling recording career, was killed in Los Angeles in an apparent drive-by shooting. The victim, whose real name was Christopher G. Wallace, was the second big-name rapper to be slain in the last six months. Mr. Wallace, 24, was a fierce rival of Tupac Shakur, who died in September, six days after being shot in a drive-by attack in Las Vegas. A10
 
Rain and Prayer Along the Ohio
Residents along the Ohio River had to contend with more rain in their devastated towns. In Falmouth, Ky., about 100 residents gathered in a single church for worship because most of the rural area's other eight churches had been too badly damaged by the Licking River's floodwaters to be used. A10
 
Labor Shifts Organizing System
American labor leaders are shifting their tactics for organizing workers. They are frequently dropping a 60-year tradition of concentrating on workplace elections to focus on getting at least 51 percent of the employees at a company to sign cards backing a union and then demand that the company recognize it. One result is likely to be more clashes with managers, who often reject recognition requests based on signed cards and demand secret-ballot elections instead. B7
 
Feinstein Alerted on Donations
Senator Dianne Feinstein of California said the F.B.I. had warned her that the Chinese Government might try to funnel illegal contributions to her campaign and other Congressional campaigns through middlemen. But she said the information had not influenced her position or her vote on any issue. B8
 
Dodd Sees No Reform
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, who was general chairman of the Democratic National Committee at the height of the Clinton re-election drive, said the current reports of abuses in political fund-raising had not stirred up the degree of public outrage needed to force changes. "Reform will not be passed," he said. He called the current fund-raising system "contaminating," but said he was hard at work raising money for his 1998 re-election race anyway. B8
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Trenton Poised to Enshrine Ticket Brokers' Freedom
The New Jersey Legislature is close to passing a bill that would let ticket brokers charge concertgoers and sports fans as much as they could. The state is in the midst of an 18-month experiment with deregulation of ticket brokers; the bill would make that experiment permanent even before its time expires. Whether the experiment has caused ticket prices to go down or up is not likely to be clear before lawmakers act. B1

Funeral for 2 Killed by Tree
Several hundred people attended a wake and funeral in Queens for two young sisters who were killed when a tree blew down onto their school van. The other two children killed in the accident will be buried today. B1
 
Security Plans in Bayonne
New security measures are to begin this morning at Bayonne High School in New Jersey, where a student was fatally stabbed in a hallway last week. The school's 40 doors will remain locked at all times, except for three that will be open in the morning until 9 A.M. Visitors will be allowed in only at the main entrance, which will be monitored by a video camera. And everyone will be required to wear identification badges throughout the day. B4
 
A Renewed Plea on Abortion
John Cardinal O'Connor joined the nation's other Roman Catholic leaders in urging President Clinton to change his mind and sign a bill that would make certain late-term abortions illegal. The Cardinal's opposition to the procedure, known by its opponents as "partial birth" abortion, was not new. But it was given new impetus by an abortion-rights supporter's admission that he had lied last year when he said the procedure was used only rarely. B3

They have joined together to help finance an experimental ratings system that they hope will either become a full-fledged competitor to Nielsen or force it to change its methods and answer their complaints. HEADLINE: As More Sharks Wind Up on Plates, Need for Protection Rises

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONE of mankind's largest and least regulated harvests of creatures from the wild is ravaging many of the world's shark species, but nascent international efforts to protect the species are hampered by a deep ignorance, not only about how many are killed but also about how they live and what they need to survive.
"Little effort has been made to collect even the most basic kinds of information, such as numbers of sharks caught and discarded, necessary for meeting even minimal standards of management of fisheries affecting sharks," says a report on the species to be issued this week by the Center for Marine Conservation, an environmental advocacy group based in Washington. 
 The report says little is known about the life history and other characteristics of most shark species, like growth rates, reproductive potential, distribution, movements and interactions with other species.
Other recent studies echo the complaint. Now that demand and prices for shark are rising worldwide, they say, the low priority placed on shark research and management is a relic of the past.
Long relegated to second-class status, shark fishing is expanding worldwide, rising in prominence as other fish for the table become scarcer and as a worldwide trade in shark fins and other exotic shark products grows rapidly.
The reports of landings, the amount of fish brought to shore, of sharks and related species, like skates and rays, together called elasmobranchs, grew from about 220,000 tons in 1947 to more than 800,000 tons in 1994, according to sketchy data collected by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. The actual total catch is thought to be at least twice that much because there is substantial underreporting of how many sharks are caught incidentally by people who are fishing for other species in commercial, recreational and subsistence fishing.
The United States is one of the few countries to have imposed major controls on shark fishing. Its recent proposals to tighten restrictions even further this year are being welcomed by conservation groups but have provoked dissent from the fishing industry.
The proposed rule would reduce the annual quota for large coastal sharks taken in Eastern United States waters by 50 percent, to a little more than 1,400 tons, while also imposing a quota of 1,940 tons on small coastal sharks, about a third less than the current catch. Five species would be put off-limits altogether.
But in comments to the National Marine Fisheries Service, which is expected to issue a final rule within weeks, the fishing industry has argued that the tightening is premature because populations of these sharks may have already stabilized or even begun to recover since quotas and other controls were first imposed in 1993.
"Patience is truly a virtue," said John J. Hoey, a shark scientist at the National Fisheries Institute, an industry group, "and so is honestly describing the difficult position we are in, in terms of scientifically evaluating what has happened and what else needs to be done to enhance management and our understanding of current conditions."
The debate over the American shark controls would surely be amplified if any strong measures were proposed to control fishing for these species worldwide.
According to documents drafted by the United States for consideration by the various world bodies studying the issue, only 10 of the countries that report shark landings make any attempt to manage their fisheries, and only four countries have detailed management plans for shark fishing. Few international bodies are competent to manage shark fishing, and none are actively doing so, the documents say.
But several world bodies are encouraging member countries to at least collect more information, a vital first step toward regulating the industry.
How to build international rules to control shark fishing has been closely examined by the world's fishing nations for only the past three years, following the adoption of a resolution by the Conference on International Trade in Endangered Species, calling for some kind of global action.
Next week in Rome, the Committee on Fisheries of the Food and Agriculture Organization is expected to take up the subject, and at the next full meeting of the conference on endangered species, in Harare, Zimbabwe, in June, there may be debate on adding some sharks and their products to the list of protected species whose parts are restricted in international trade.
But any formal steps to devise international measures to protect sharks could be years away.
"We have to do the homework first," said Erhard Rucke, F.A.O.'s senior fisheries officer in Rome. "We are in rather bad shape with regard to information on a global basis."
Conservation groups warn, meanwhile, that the quirks of human appetite and the economics of the fish trade seem to be conspiring against sharks.
Their slow growth, long lives, extended gestation and low birth rates -- classic characteristics of big predators -- make the species especially vulnerable to human predation.
There are a number of factors driving people to increase shark fishing.
The most prominent is the surge in demand for shark fin, which is dried and processed into the gelatinous main ingredient of the famous Chinese soup. Global trade for this product, centered in Hong Kong, is booming.
In the United States, dealer prices for wet fins range, depending on the species, size and quality, from a few dollars up to more than $100 per pound, and dried fins can go for twice as much. That has helped stimulate the shark fishing industry, especially in Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico waters, although simply chopping off the fins and discarding the shark's body, a common practice around the world, is now discouraged by United States regulations.
Shark meat itself is increasingly sold, as traditional species are depleted and fishermen shift to new ones. In Taiwan, the value of shark meat exports is greater than the value of fin exports, even though the price per pound of meat is far less.
Other shark products include liver oil, skin and the increasingly widely traded cartilage, believed by some to have medicinal value despite the lack of credible evidence for its reputed anticancer powers.
Retail prices for shark cartilage are high -- sometimes more than $100 for a bottle of capsules. But dried cartilage goes for $1 a pound wholesale and wet cartilage for even less, giving fisherman scant incentive to harvest this product for its own sake.
Whatever the market, untrammeled fishing for sharks is almost certain to push some populations to the edge of extinction, conservation experts say.
The Center for Marine Conservation report says: "Traditional strategies for managing fisheries are predicated on the reproductive biology of fishes that release large numbers of eggs, few of which need survive to adulthood in order to maintain abundance. Sharks, on the other hand, produce few young, many of which survive to adulthood."
