SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 1842 words

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Robert C. Gallo;
For Besieged Scientist, New Start in New Lab

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
As he exercises command from a splendid new battlement in medical science's slogging campaign against AIDS, Dr. Robert C. Gallo seems at least as resilient as his quarry.
"You grow when you're challenged or when you're hurt, don't you?" the 59-year-old virologist asked in dark recollection of a nightmare time in his often brilliant but once bedimmed career as one of the country's leading AIDS researchers. 
 "If everything is perfect and going along harmonious, I don't think you have any chance to grow as a human," he observed. He spoke as a survivor of some hard years of notoriety that might have sent lesser scientists into eclipse: first, an international dispute challenging his co-discovery of the AIDS virus, then a bruising professional misconduct inquiry that followed.
Ultimately cleared, Dr. Gallo has not just landed on his feet. He has engineered one of the dream assignments of medical research as director of the new Institute of Human Virology here at the University of Maryland city campus.
The institute, intended to concentrate on AIDS but to work beyond it on an array of viral diseases, was tailored for Dr. Gallo by university and Government sponsors after a multistate competition for his services. It is being hailed by envious peers as a flagship venture.
The institute is an unusual enterprise because it combines in a single $52 million building the basic research that is Dr. Gallo's forte plus full epidemiological and clinical divisions, a drug marketing company to try to keep the financing pump primed from discoveries and even an in-house animal testing division to speed the tight path mapped here between single-site experimentation and therapy.
"It's a state-of-the-art place, but that's not necessarily all," said Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, a longtime colleague and AIDS researcher who is director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. "The Baltimore institute is already a very important component of the AIDS effort in this country because Bob Gallo, a brilliant scientist, is the main driving force there."
Fiercely dedicated, at times intemperate and often controversial, Dr. Gallo is a virtuoso in basic medical research, a complex world where ego can be as big an X-factor as any virus. He came here six months ago after 30 years as one of the most celebrated scientists at the National Cancer Institute. There, he and his research teams were responsible for significant success in registering scores of discovery patents and reaping tens of millions of dollars for the Government in royalties.
Most notable is the widely used blood-screening test for the AIDS virus, whose royalties he shares with a French team at the Pasteur Institute. A dispute over shared laboratory samples and primacy in discovery caused an international uproar a decade ago that had to be settled by a co-discovery agreement signed by the Presidents of France and the United States.
Afterward, Dr. Gallo labored to pursue fresh research while enduring four years of detailed scientific and Congressional inquiries into misconduct charges of falsifying research information and using French AIDS research to pave the way for his own claims. Confrontation and record-combing became his routine. Investigators at the Department of Health and Human Services found that there had been "minor misconduct," but the charges were dropped after an appeals panel found that they had not been proved. Dr. Gallo describes the experience as nothing less than harrowing and said it would have been unendurable but for the support of colleagues at the National Institutes of Health.
"Something like that does tend to make you a better person," he speculated warily, speaking with far less elan than he shows at his laboratory blackboard in diagramming the mysteries of AIDS. "Humbled?" he responded, rising to a question. "No. Empathetic is a better word: I'm more understanding of other peoples' hurts and problems.
"Humbled? No. You get too humble, you lose all your confidence, and then you can't think about science," he explained, suddenly sober at that prospect. "Actually, I became more determined -- determined that I lost years of research that I have to make up for. I always think, what if we were operating full blast in those years? We were at 50 percent, one arm tied behind our back, my colleagues being put through hell, too."
As he moves handsomely beyond that past, the gleaming new institute, reborn from the skeleton of an old shoe factory, seems not only a measure of Dr. Gallo's avowed indomitability but a device for him to try to catch up with some of that lost science. It offers one-stop shopping for his restless mind and ambition.
"The major reason for being here is to bring from lab to clinic, better and faster, the advances we believe in," he said of the institute, which has a staff of 90 and a budget of $30 million, which is expected to grow to 300 people and $100 million in five years. "This is a day-and-night difference," he said of the national institutes, which he speaks of fondly but commutes past daily in his fresh perch in the outside world. "Here, we have much more ease in bringing from lab to clinic, and certainly far more exchange of ideas."
Situated around an atrium and occupying four of the six floors in the university's Medical Biotechnology Center, the institute is attracting a galaxy of respected scientists, with more than 700 applications pending, Dr. Gallo said. Beyond weekly interdisciplinary conferences, the center was laid out for casually routing its central laboratory specialists down common corridors and open stairwells in a kind of Brownian-motion hope of sparking fresh notions.
Parallel with his research effort, epidemiology is in the charge of Dr. William A. Blattner, former chief of viral epidemiology at the National Cancer Institute. The clinic operation, which is already treating 4,000 AIDS patients who live nearby, is run by Dr. Robert R. Redfield, who is credited as the first investigator to demonstrate the heterosexual spread of the virus that causes AIDS. Dr. Joseph L. Bryant directs the animal testing program, where transgenics is emphasized, with mice scampering under the burden of transplanted human Kaposi sarcomas, the purplish skin cancers that are common among AIDS sufferers.
"This is the new paradigm of how things can happen," said Dr. Edmund C. Tramont, a virologist who directs the university's Medical Biotechnology Center, which includes the institute. He has also enlisted as Dr. Gallo's subordinate in charge of the institute's vaccine division.
"How do you take advantage of an artist?" Dr. Tramont asks in explaining the research, clinical and entrepreneurial inducements arrayed to attract Dr. Gallo here. These include $12 million a year in state and city financing to promote economic development in Baltimore's already thriving medical science industries. Plus an entrepreneurial venture named Omega Bio therapies that is intended to capitalize on useful discoveries.
However dogged by controversy, Dr. Gallo is clearly bolstered by loyalty and his continued strength as a researcher. Even before his role in isolating the AIDS virus, he had shown a pioneer's flair in virology in 1980, when his team discovered the first virus demonstrated to be a direct cause of cancer -- the beginning of the retrovirus studies that are now a critical focus in AIDS research.
As the author of more than 1,000 scientific papers and other publications, Dr. Gallo is probably the most cited scientific investigator in the literature of AIDS. Even critics who contend that he is too prize-driven and egocentric concede that his research has continued unabated.
Dr. Gallo's institute has a decidedly post-AIDS outlook. He anticipates a time when a variety of therapies will prove AIDS "clinically curable" in most cases and the institute will focus more on a wide spectrum of other virological problems and suspicions that already interest him and his colleagues. These include tumor and leukemia viruses, the possible role of hepatitis in cancers, questions about the role of papilloma virus in cervical cancer and even the theory that disorders like multiple sclerosis might have viral origins.
"There's no reason not to think of AIDS as a controllable disease in time," Dr. Gallo said, noting the success of combination therapies.
"If you can control the virus replication for the life of an individual, you likely will have a clinically curable disease," he said, drawing a parallel with insulin and diabetes.
But true success will remain elusive, he said, so long as a significant minority of sufferers do not tolerate current drugs well "and 99 percent of the people of the world who are H.I.V.-infected cannot afford them."
"So how can we then say, 'Fine, we've done it'? We have to think of alternatives that are less expensive and less toxic," Dr. Gallo said.
"We know more about this disease than we know about any other cause of any other human disease in the history of medicine," he said. "But that hasn't necessarily translated into a quick fix for many reasons because of the complexity."
But persistence in the face of complexity is Dr. Gallo's strength.
"He's incredibly resilient," said Dr. Fauci, his old colleague at the health institutes. "If you look at the stress and the strain Bob went through over those several years when he was literally under a microscope virtually every day, every week, I think it would have worn down and perhaps broken a lesser spirit. His new center is a breath of fresh air for him, on fresh ground, and he can concentrate on what he loves and what he's very good at. And that is science."
From his new station, Dr. Gallo hesitates to look back triumphantly. "I got trapped in a bad period," he said. Young researchers on his old team, many of them with him now, inspired him through that period, he insists. "Nobody was anything other than positive, supportive, angry, fighting, mad, the whole business."
At this memory, his signature self-confidence seems muted.
"I look upon it as a period of extreme ignorance combined with cruelty and witch-hunting," said Dr. Gallo, who noted that among the valued researchers he quickly hired here was Dr. Mikulas Popovic, a virologist who had been investigated and cleared along with Dr. Gallo.
"One might anticipate that from all this evidence, after all the sound and fury, there would be at least a residue of palpable wrongdoing," the appeals panel of scientists finally concluded. "This is not the case."
Still, those days echo for Dr. Gallo. "I don't believe that every human being in this country would ever believe the truth or ever know the truth," he said. "And I'm not sure it's worth trying to tell them."
Ultimately, his explanation of how he prevailed is elemental. "The answer was, I had a functional lab," Dr. Gallo declared. He nodded firmly amid the shiny new setting for his resilient ambition, a scientist well in command of a functional laboratory and then some.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Doubts on Monetary Union Buoy Mark Against the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday as fresh doubts that European monetary union would start on time buoyed the German currency.
A German economic adviser and a central bank official both suggested that the country might fail to meet some of the criteria for the single currency, the Euro, which is scheduled for introduction in 1999. 
 The Euro would effectively merge the mark, the strongest European currency, with some weaker ones. Signs that monetary union might be delayed typically bolster the mark.
"The mark is the best place to be" if monetary union does not happen, said Roger Chapin, foreign exchange manager at the Banc One Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. "That is the major factor weighing on the dollar right now."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.7020 marks, from 1.7145 on Friday. It eased to 121.63 yen from 121.82. The British pound edged up to $1.6033, from a five-week low of $1.6013 on Friday.
Concern over European monetary union increased after a weekend newspaper report. Herbert Hax, chairman of the Government council of economic advisers, said Germany was unlikely to meet some of the criteria for joining, an article in Bild am Sonntag reported.
A Bundesbank council member, Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, echoed that concern in a speech yesterday, saying he doubted that Germany could meet its goal of cutting its budget deficit to 2.9 percent of the gross domestic product this year, given the absence of a self-sustaining recovery and as high unemployment eroded tax revenue.
Last week, the Bonn Government said that joblessness had increased in February to its highest level in more than 60 years.
Another report, in the newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung and quoting the Kiel Institute of World Economics, said the German deficit would reach 3.5 percent of output this year, and that debt would come to 61.5 percent of output.
To qualify for the single currency, countries must lower their deficits to about 3 percent of their G.D.P. and reduce debt toward 60 percent. They must also meet criteria on inflation, long-term interest rates and currency stability.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
N.F.L. Meets in Desert, And Everyone's Thirsty

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

DATELINE: PALM DESERT, Calif.

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch stood at the entrance of the little nighttime pool bash that his Fox Sports division threw yesterday for the National Football League.
At one point, the man who writes annual checks to the N.F.L. of $395 million but can't get his cable news channel shown in New York City chatted with some of the potentates who share in the manna: H. Wayne Huizenga, the Dolphins owner, and Leon Hess, the Jets owner and hitherto unknown stand-up comic. They're each getting nearly $10 million a year in Murdoch money, so neither had to ask, as Fox's Terry Bradshaw did, as his boss left the party, "Mr. Murdoch, would you give me a dollar?" 
 Here at the N.F.L.'s annual meetings, the next TV contract is not on the agenda. But in a way it is. Television money nourishes the league. The current deal ends after the coming season. Everybody seemingly has an opinion on how much money will be showered on the N.F.L. in the new deal, on who shall be in and who shall be out, and who needs to pay through a larger nose than anyone has ever envisioned. And all this conjecture is taking place in the desert, two hours from a very large city without an N.F.L. team.
By the fall, the TV deal will be the most important thing on the agenda, when Fox, NBC, ABC, ESPN and TNT vie to keep what they have and CBS fights to take something back for itself. In 1993, Fox proved that a needy, covetous outsider could change league economics by overpaying beyond the limits of anyone's optimistic hopes -- in that instance, $1.58 billion for four years, or 49 percent more than CBS had paid from 1990 to 1993 to televise National Football Conference games.
But Fox's expensive game of leapfrog was a surprise. CBS Sports' hunger is now a given and is providing the league with more leverage than William Perry on a teeter-totter, despite TV ratings weakness, the absence of an N.F.L. franchise in Los Angeles and the impending departure of the Oilers from Houston. Al Davis, the Oakland Raiders chieftain, created some nervous chuckles recently when he suggested that the league may double its current $4.4 billion TV take.
But Jeff Lurie, the Philadelphia Eagles owner, did not chortle at the notion as he nursed a beverage courtesy of the munificent Murdoch.
"Doubling? I wouldn't say no," Lurie said. "ABC is going to have to step way up."
"Doubling? How about tripling?" asked Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner. (We think he was kidding.) Suddenly, he turned lawyerly. "We're expecting an increase."
"Oh yeah, we'll get a boost," said Robert K. Kraft, the New England Patriots owner and the newest member of the broadcast committee.
And yes, it will come partly from the hide of ABC, which escaped in the current deal with a mere 2.2 percent increase from $900 million to $920 million, to renew "Monday Night Football." "M.N.F." regularly ranks among prime time's top 10, a three-hour block of time that generally slays its competition. The N.F.L. had already wrapped up its ABC and ESPN deals by the time Fox trumped CBS and NBC jacked up its fee by 15 percent to keep the A.F.C.
Thus, an imbalance in the annual-fee department exists among the three broadcast networks: Fox at $395 million, ABC at $230 million and NBC at $217 million.
Hoo ha, just look at the potential for growth that the N.F.L. sees: ABC and NBC won't climb up to Fox levels, but they can be pushed higher and higher.
And, if one does not want to be pushed too high, well, maybe CBS would. This will be a game defined by how much of a premium networks place on being in the N.F.L.
"It's our priority to be in at the best price possible," said Chase Carey, the president of Fox Television. A lower one? Hardly. Carey discounts ratings weakness at the three networks as one of miscalculation by Nielsen Media Research, and views the N.F.L.'s continuing appeal as the most distinctive product in sports television.
"Its value is driven by its uniqueness," Carey said. "It's a great franchise." Not the words of someone who thinks he can drive his price down to his rivals' levels.
He added: "The packages are not in balance. The fees are not proportional to the ad dollars. No one's complaining about it, but as you look at the next round, we hope there will be more parity in the rights fees near us, which will make everybody sell harder."
TNT and ESPN will pay more to split Sunday night on cable, too, assuming both stay in the picture. Together, they pay more annually than ABC does individually, which is another element of the imbalance. Speculation has centered on CBS eyeing the Sunday night package, but why? Sunday is a strong night for CBS's prime-time programs; why sacrifice it to the unevenness of the matchups endured by ESPN and TNT, which may yield decent cable ratings but would fall short of decent numbers for CBS?
"It's very important for us to retain it," said Harvey Schiller, the president of Turner Sports, standing within 50 feet of Murdoch but across the pool from Tagliabue. "The N.F.L. made TNT as a network. As it made Fox and made 'Monday Night.' "
And, it would remake CBS if CBS is allowed in the sandbox, which will happen only if the N.F.L. does not make a deal with its incumbents during an exclusive negotiating period that ends Oct. 1. The incumbents may look at what ante the league tells them to pay, and say, okey-dokey. But the N.F.L. would seem to be too smart to blow the leverage offered by CBS and not check out its cash wad.
It should be a giggle.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Decline Ahead of Data On Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities slipped yesterday, with few investors willing to buy ahead of economic data to be reported this week, for fear that if the news is too robust, the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to avert inflation.
While most market participants expect the Fed to wait until May to tighten credit, some are beginning to suspect that it will come this month. 
 "Chairman Greenspan is inching closer to a pre-emptive strike," said Sung Won Sohn, senior vice president and chief executive of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "The tight labor market and above-trend economic growth have raised the probability of tighter monetary policy, but hikes in interest rates will be limited," he added, because the inflation picture looks good, and the dollar's appreciation is equivalent to monetary tightening.
The 30-year bond was down 2/32, to a price of 97 19/32 to yield 6.81 percent, unchanged from Friday's close. With a lack of new data to influence the market's direction, trading was mostly on technical factors.
"Given the market's renewed inflation anxieties," Anthony Chan, a vice president and the chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, "financial market investors are likely to focus this week on Friday's release of the Producer Price Index, with Thursday's retail sales report for February as the second most important number for the week." He added, "Investors will also be holding their breaths in anticipation of the Fed's beige book report, another part of the puzzle."
"Nonetheless," Mr. Chan said, "our view suggests that the employment report on Friday failed to provide the smoking gun needed to put to rest any or all doubts about a possible Fed tightening at the March 25 policy meeting. So we are sticking with our view that a May rate hike has a better chance, barring any negative surprises from either the P.P.I. on Friday or the Consumer Price Index next week."
Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said investors could draw two conclusions about the market outlook if the Fed tightened on March 25: that yields will move higher and that the yield spread between the short end of the market and the long end will narrow. "A typical spread for the two-year note versus the Federal funds rate is 50 basis points when Fed policy is viewed to be on hold indefinitely," he said. "At present the spread is about 82 basis points." (A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.)
"Bulls might argue that this spread already incorporates a 25-basis-point tightening, so the market is well priced for the policy outlook," Mr. Jones added. "However, we can guarantee that if the Fed tightens there will be an immediate consensus that another 25-basis-point tightening will be seen at the May 20 meeting. With the first tightening, the spread will narrow to 57 basis points if the two-year remains steady. If another is expected, the spread will be in the 75-basis-point-to- 100-basis-point range."
Interest rates declined slightly at yesterday's Treasury bill auction, as the results were in line with expectations. The rate for a three-month bill declined four basis points, to 5.06 percent, and the six-month bill fell one basis point, to 5.18 percent, as investors showed a little more demand for the shorter maturity.

HEADLINE: Nothing 'Foreign' About Us

BYLINE: By Richard A. Goldstein; Richard A. Goldstein is president and chief executive of Unilever United States Inc. and chairman of the Organization for International Investment.

 BODY:
Reacting to the controversy over fund-raising from so-called foreign sources, the Democratic National Committee has decided to stop accepting political contributions from American subsidiaries of companies based abroad and from groups of their American employees.
The D.N.C.'s new policy is unfair. These companies are important to the economy of the United States. And they are American companies; some, like Unilever, have been doing business here for more than 100 years. Their workers are American citizens, voters and taxpayers. The companies pay American taxes. Their political contributions are just as legal as those of other American companies and their employees. 
 If the D.N.C. is concerned about foreign influence, the law already prohibits political donations from foreign nationals, including foreign parent companies. Federal election rules bar any foreign participation, direct or indirect, in the political action committees of American subsidiaries. And all corporate political contributions must come from revenue generated in the United States.
The fact is, subsidiaries of foreign corporations provide millions of good-paying jobs for American workers. According to recent government figures cited in a new report from the Organization for International Investment, 4.9 million people are employed by the American subsidiaries of foreign companies, an increase of almost 140 percent since 1980. While the number of jobs at all businesses rose by almost 9 percent between 1988 and 1994, employment generated by international investment increased by more than 26 percent in the same period.
Moreover, people who work at the American subsidiaries of companies based elsewhere enjoy higher wages. The average monthly wage at these subsidiaries is nearly 26 percent higher than the average wage at all businesses in the United States.
These companies contribute more than jobs. United States subsidiaries of foreign businesses paid a record-high $8.2 billion in Federal taxes in 1993, according to the latest available figures. Subsidiaries invested $15.6 billion in American research and development in 1994, and put $68 billion into new plants and equipment in the United States. Nearly $14 billion in earnings were reinvested in 1995. And United States subsidiaries gave more than $430 million to charities in 1993, a 22 percent increase over the previous year.
Increasingly, the investors in these companies are Americans. In 1995, American investors held $411 billion in shares of companies based abroad, a 27 percent increase over 1994.
Yet feeling the heat of a political fight, the D.N.C. adopted a policy that implies that United States subsidiaries and their American employees are somehow second-class citizens when it comes to contributing to the Democratic Party. Fortunately, the Democratic Congressional and Senatorial campaign committees have rejected the idea, as has the Republican National Committee.
At a time when politicians and policy makers, experts and economists struggle over how to sustain economic growth and create jobs, the contribution of American subsidiaries of foreign companies is worth remembering.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Canadian Retailer Imperiled as U.S. Rivals Move In

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 10

 BODY:
The near col lapse of the T. Eaton Company the stately department store chain that filed for protection from creditors last month -- has heightened fears that even Canada's most powerful companies are threatened by aggressive American retailers.
Sales at Eaton's 87 stores have declined about $375 million over the last five years, and the company has lost nearly $190 million since 1988. It owes its 4,000 Canadian suppliers around $115 million, and the banks more than $120 million. (All numbers are in United States dollars.) 
 Just as Eaton's was weakening, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. entered Canada, in two years grabbing a dominant share of the market, and specialty retailers like Home Depot Inc. have also made successful debuts north of the border.
The impact of Eaton's decline is amplified because the company is so important to Canada. Timothy Eaton, the Irish immigrant who founded the company in Toronto 128 years ago, is a towering figure here, so revered that one Protestant church in Toronto bears not a saint's name but his.
Its stores are downtown anchors from coast to coast. The company employs 5,600 full-time and 9,700 part-time workers and had sales last year exceeding $1.18 billion.
According to court papers, Eaton's technically defaulted on Feb. 27, when its $8 million twice-a-week payroll exceeded its credit line.
Two Canadian banks had recently reduced that credit line to $160 million from $200 million because of worries over Eaton's performance.
Justice Lloyd Houlden granted Eaton's protection from creditors until June 30 by applying the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act, which offers many of the same protections as Chapter 11 does in the United States.
Eaton's secured a $410 million short-term loan from GE Capital Canada and has until June to come up with a satisfactory plan for paying its debts, slicing unprofitable divisions and returning to competitiveness.
Not everyone is sure the company will survive. But in court papers, Eaton's gave a hint of its future.
Eaton's "cannot compete with mass merchandisers," said an affidavit presented by John R. Anderson, Eaton's chief financial officer. "Its market niche is in the middle to upper range."
Mr. Anderson said the company would have to get rid of its least profitable stores.
Analysts said that from one-third to one-half of the stores could be liquidated.
Richard D. B. Talbot, managing director of Thomas Consultants International of Markham, thinks the company will probably be sold to or merged with another retailer, most likely one from the United States.
George Eaton, great-grandson of the founder and now the president, encouraged such speculation in his news conference. "We are not looking for a buyer right now," he said, "but if one showed up, I think it would be irresponsible of us not to talk."
Executives from the Hudson's Bay Company, based in Toronto, have recently said the company is looking to acquire other stores, and have expressed interest in both Eaton's and Kmart of Canada.
Many analysts said the best match for Eaton's would be retailers like the J. C. Penney Company or Nordstrom Inc.
Neither company is publicly acknowledging that its expansion plans include either Eaton's or Canada. Duncan Muir, a spokesman for J. C. Penney in Plano, Tex., said its most recent expansions had been in Chile and Mexico.
 Paula Stanley, a spokeswoman for Nordstrom, said the company plans to open 11 stores in the next three years -- in Atlanta, Hawaii and other parts of the United States. It has no outlets outside the country.
"Canada," Ms. Stanley said, "is not currently on our schedule."
Analysts say that like many traditional Canadian businesses, Eaton's was too slow to respond to the encroachment of aggressive retailers like Wal-Mart. The advantages of free trade helped Wal-Mart decide to enter Canada but company executives say the primary reason was the chance to buy 122 Woolco stores from the Woolworth Corporation and gain an immediate presence.
Since 1994, Wal-Mart has converted all the Woolco stores to Wal-Marts and opened 14 stores. It now commands 24 percent of the department store market, twice Eaton's share.
Wal-Mart is playing down its impact. "There is no question that Canada's retail environment has become far more competitive," said Edward Gould, a spokesman for Wal-Mart Canada. "But it's not just Wal-Mart. Price Club, Toys 'R' Us, Home Depot and other category-specific stores also have entered the market."
Eaton's has also been battered by increasing competition from Canadian specialty stores that have cut into its sales in furniture, appliances and housewares. And Canada's tepid economy has made consumers inveterate penny pinchers. Even company executives acknowledge that Eaton's misread the move away from traditional department stores toward discounters.
"Eaton's was already fairly groggy after having gone six or seven rounds with Canadian competitors," said Len Kubas, a Toronto retail analyst. "The Americans came in with a left-right combination and finished the job."
Eaton's is not the only Canadian retailer to have taken blows recently. Hudson's Bay has been under competitive pressure the last few years. It seems to have made a turnaround lately but its discount marketing chain, Zeller's, keeps losing ground to Wal-Mart.
Even Canadian subsidiaries of some American companies are on the ropes. Kmart Canada Ltd. ended 1996 with a loss and recently announced that it would merge many of its Kmart Canada operations into its United States operations and cut 150 jobs in Canada.
But Eaton's difficulties have been startling in part because the privately held, family-run company has for so long been considered the embodiment of Canadian retailing, a company with such prestige that it could arrange, on its name alone, unsecured loans of hundreds of millions of dollars.
For many here, a recent news conference by Mr. Eaton was a sad and almost unimaginable event. At one point he admitted to reporters that his great-grandfather, whose bronze statue is patted for luck by customers in many of the larger stores, "would have been disappointed."

HEADLINE: New Agreement on Scofflaw Diplomats

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration and the State Department announced an agreement yesterday that officials hoped would ease a longstanding irritation for motorists and the police alike: foreign diplomats parking illegally and claiming immunity to the fines.
The agreement would, for the first time, put teeth into the city's efforts to collect thousands of dollars in fines by denying registrations and diplomatic license plates to consulates and missions that fail to pay tickets within a year. 
 The city could also remove diplomatic plates from cars that it tows for safety violations, such as parking in front of a fire hydrant. The plates would be turned over to the State Department and returned to the diplomats only after they had paid the city or successfully contested the ticket.
The plan, to take effect April 1, is similar to one announced during the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins, but then dropped when Rudolph W. Giuliani took office two months later for reasons that officials have disputed. It is similar to an enforcement program that has been used with considerable success in Washington since the beginning of 1995.
 At a news briefing with Ambassador Bill Richardson, the United States Representative to the United Nations, Mr. Giuliani took pains to stress that most members of the diplomatic community -- which contributes roughly $3.2 billion to the city's economy each year -- abide by the city's laws and pay tickets. "There are some that don't," he added. "And this allows us a process to separate one from the other."
But, in remarks that reflected the careful dance city officials have engaged in over the issue, the Mayor also appeared eager to assure New Yorkers that he would no longer stand for diplomats hiding behind immunity. "The agreement helps protect the citizens of New York City against diplomats who choose to vagrantly abuse those privileges," he said.
While reluctant to say it in so many words, Mr. Giuliani conceded that more than $5 million in outstanding fines accumulated last year alone by consulates and missions would probably have to be written off because the program will affect only tickets handed out after April. "There is no way to enforce collection of those tickets," he said, speaking of those from years past. "There was no procedure in place."
Thomas E. Burns, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, said that in a one-time provision under the new agreement, the city would pursue more than 500 diplomats who have ignored past safety violations, mostly for parking in front of a fire hydrant. If those diplomats get another ticket for the same offense and do not pay it within 30 days, they would be asked to surrender their diplomatic plates until they paid for all the past tickets.
But for less serious tickets over the years, Mr. Burns said, "it's a new program and so it starts with a clean slate."
The city's Department of Finance now drops outstanding fines after they have languished in the system for a year, said Richard LoConte, a spokesman for the department, who added that the total amount owed the city was not calculated because it has become merely a "paper number." To arrive at an estimate, officials use an average of $40 per ticket, multiplied by the number of tickets issued last year: 134,281 or $5,371,240.
After years of mounting unpaid fines, the issue came to the fore again last December, when police officers scuffled with two envoys, one from Russia and the other from Belarus. The officers ticketed their car in front of a fire hydrant and tried to prevent one diplomat from driving because they suspected he was drunk.
The diplomat, whose elbow was dislocated in the fight, later denied being drunk, and accused the officers of ignoring his identification and license plates, and manhandling him. When the envoys' missions demanded apologies from city officials, Mr. Giuliani not only did not offer one, but also accused the diplomats of lying and used the issue to highlight the more than $100,000 in unpaid fines owed by Russia and Belarus.
Sergey Lavrov, the Permanent Representative of the Russian Federation to the United Nations, said yesterday that the new rules would only make it harder for Russian diplomats to obey the laws because it would probably force many to drive without proper registration in order to do their jobs. Last year, the Russian mission topped the list of parking scofflaws, with 31,388 tickets. Its closest competitors had about a sixth as many tickets.
Although the agreement provides guarantees that diplomats can use two parking spaces in front of their missions and one in front of consulates, and sets up a phone line for diplomats to report cars parked illegally in their spaces, Mr. Lavrov said the agreement "doesn't address the real problems that we experience."
"I'm not in favor of special privileges," Mr. Lavrov said. "But sometimes your job involves special treatment, if you will." He pointed out that journalists and many elected and appointed officials have reserved parking.
"Two parking paces per mission is not nearly enough for us," he said. At the American Embassy in Moscow, Americans can park legally around the block, he added.

HEADLINE: Bosnian Serb Area Destitute and Vulnerable

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: LUKAVICA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, March 7

 BODY:
The collection of warehouses that make up a sprawling factory less than a mile from the Bosnian capital stand as a bleak harbinger of the Bosnian Serbs' future.
The Famos factory, once owned by the Yugoslav Government, employed 3,500 people making truck and bus engines and car parts before the Bosnian war began five years ago. 
 At the end of the war in 1995 this factory was seen by the Bosnian Serbs as the prize that would help regenerate their economy. It was to be the industrial centerpiece around which they would build a new Serbian-controlled capital skirting the edges of the existing Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, which is under the control of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government.
The factory had been in the Sarajevo suburb of Ilidza, but its 2,000 machines were dismantled and moved to Lukavica last year, to an area controlled by the Bosnian Serbs. The move took place before Ilidza was turned over to the Government as part of the peace agreement reached in late 1995 in Dayton, Ohio.
Under the agreement, Bosnia was to include two distinct political entities -- one controlled by a coalition of Muslims and Croats and the other by Serbs, their self-styled Republic of Srpska -- with a national structure to coordinate the two.
But the Bosnian Serb entity has refused to honor many of the Dayton terms. As a result, it has been cut off from international aid and remains isolated. The steady political and economic decline of Srpska, along with the refusal to honor the Dayton agreement, has left many Western diplomats warning that the enclave will pose an easy, and increasingly tempting target, to the Bosnian Muslim army once NATO peacekeepers leave next year, although such an attack would set off another war.
The failure of the Famos factory, owned by the Bosnian Serb leadership, is one of the most visible symbols of the looming breakdown of its political entity. In the last year the factory has produced only 20 engines and 50 clutches, which were sold to the state-run bus company in neighboring Serbia. The Bosnian Serbs have been unable to sign any contracts with foreign companies or to lure outside investment.
The rest of the Bosnian Serb structure is faring no better. Its military is still largely run by Gen. Ratko Mladic, who has been indicted by the United Nations commission at The Hague for war crimes, although he was publicly removed from his position last year. But the Bosnian Serb army, no longer financed by Serbia, has dwindled from 40,000 to about 12,000 soldiers. Thousands of demobilized soldiers are unable to support themselves, and much of the military's equipment is rusting from lack of maintenance and spare parts.
Although Radovan Karadzic, the former leader who has also been indicted for war crimes, was forced to resign under international pressure, he still wields enormous influence. And the current political leadership is openly feuding. Last month, citing "security concerns," Biljana Plavsic, the Bosnian Serbs' largely ceremonial President, refused to travel from her office in the northwestern city of Banja Luka to Pale, the wartime Serb stronghold near Sarajevo, to meet with other Bosnian Serb leaders and Assistant Secretary of State John Kornblum.
The areas of Bosnia controlled by the Serbs have frequent power outages, the hospitals lack medicine and schools are often without books.
There has also been a huge exodus, to Serbia and neighboring European nations, especially by the young, professionals and skilled labor. Like Famos, most factories sit nearly idle. The unemployment rate is 90 percent. Of the 800,000 Bosnian Serbs, 300,000 were displaced from their homes by the war.
The implications of a collapse of the Bosnian Serb entity are enormous. Under the Dayton agreement, tens of thousands of Muslims displaced from their homes by the Serbs have a right to return home. In fact, the Serbs have allowed none to go back.
NATO strategists say that the Bosnian Government increasingly sees the Serb zone as an easy military objective. These commanders say that if the peacekeeping forces withdraw it will be difficult to hold the Muslim-led Government back.
"At least this war would probably be swift," said a senior Western diplomat. "And frankly there would be little sympathy for the Bosnian Serbs given their role in the war, their refusal to cooperate with the joint Government institutions and their refusal to let displaced people go home. War, in fact, might be the best solution."
But that presupposes that Serbia would not intervene, as it did in the last war. The despair and malaise that now infect the areas of Bosnia controlled by the Serbs are palpable in nearly every forlorn, shabby village. On a recent day, Milena Jevric, nearly toothless and clutching a plastic container filled with her daily soup ration, walked in shoes several sizes too large up a muddy road in the village of Brezovice, about 20 miles northeast of Pale.
A widow, she owned a small shop in a Sarajevo suburb before it was turned over to the Muslim-led Government last year. Everyone on her street fled, fearful of Muslim reprisals, and she followed.
Mrs. Jevric now lives with her brother in the basement of an unfinished structure. She sleeps on a dirt floor and has no stove, heat or running water.
"As a girl I lived like this, after the Second World War -- and as an old woman I live like this again," she said. "We have no more savings. We are destitute. Most of the young people are leaving. The country is dying. I just struggle to eat."
The Bosnian Serb leadership in Pale, in a move to establish a link with Serbia, signed an agreement with the Serbian Government in Belgrade that included a promise of military cooperation.
The agreement, which Muslim leaders and Western diplomats said violated the Dayton accords, also spelled out cooperation in areas such as foreign trade, border traffic, citizenship and customs.
But while the economic cooperation outlined in the agreement is mostly smoke and mirrors, especially given the dismal state of the economy in Serbia, it is a huge blow for the joint Bosnian Government.
It defiantly resurrects the apparent effort by President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to integrate the Bosnian Serb enclave into Serbia, which set off the Bosnian war in the spring of 1992.
The Bosnian Serb leadership, however, defends the agreement. "We have bonded ourselves to Belgrade with this agreement," said Momcilo Krajisnik, the Bosnian Serb member of the tripartite Presidency. "We are Serbs and we will never be ruled by the Muslims."
The continued presence in the center of power of hard-liners like Dr. Karadzic and his close ally Mr. Krajisnik bode ill for any real cooperation with the Bosnian Muslims and Croats.
The resolve of the Bosnian Serbs to retain the ethnic exclusivity of their enclave, where tens of thousands of Muslims died in the most brutal ethnic violence of the war, was driven home last Sunday. A mob of about 150 Serbs burned 11 prefabricated homes belonging to Muslims trying to resettle their old village in Serbian-held territory.
"Most of my friends have left the Republic of Srpska," said Bojan Brckalo, 19, as he sat with two friends recently in a Pale coffee shop. "But this does not mean that those of us who remain will allow the Muslims to seize our state. If the Muslims try to enter we will fight. This is Serb land."

HEADLINE: Newmont Wins Santa Fe, With Further Gold Deals Expected

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Outbidding the rival Homestake Mining Company, the Newmont Mining Corporation announced an agreement yesterday to acquire the Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corporation for $2.43 billion in stock, securing a position as the top gold-mining company in North America.
But few analysts expect the dust to settle in this rapidly consolidating industry before another takeover effort is begun, possibly for the Battle Mountain Gold Company in Houston, or the Getchell Gold Corporation in Englewood, Colo. Barrick Gold, for one, is hunting for acquisitions and may even consider breaking up the Newmont-Santa Fe combination, said Todd A. Hinrichs, an analyst with Everen Securities. 
 "We're seeing consolidation across the gold-mining industry," Mr. Hinrichs said. "It's a fight among the large producers to maintain their growth potential and their position at the top of the heap."
The merger of Newmont and Santa Fe, a 1994 spinoff from the Santa Fe Pacific Rail Corporation, would create a mining company with estimated gold production in 1998 of 4 million ounces and 55 million ounces of proven reserves, according to the company. The combined company would overtake Barrick as the largest North American gold miner.
The winning bid by Newmont came 94 days after it started its takeover effort and 91 days after Santa Fe announced a friendly merger with Homestake. Under the merger agreement, each Santa Fe share will be exchanged for 0.43 share of Newmont common stock, a 30 percent increase since the bidding battle started in December. Based on Newmont's closing price of $43 yesterday, the deal is valued at $18.49 a share, or $2.43 billion. The transaction would be on a tax-free, pooling-of-interests basis.
The prize in the contest was Santa Fe's enormous land holdings in Nevada, which sit next to Newmont's own mining operations.
"It was a good match-up from Day 1," said Lawrence Glaser, analyst with Muzinich & Company. "There's more synergies between Newmont and Santa Fe than there were between Homestake and Santa Fe."
The two companies own complementary technologies that would make it less expensive to mine gold. Newmont said it expected to generate savings of $70 million to $80 million, nearly double the amount first identified in December, through cuts of overlapping staff, purchasing economies and new technology.
But the victory by Newmont comes with a price and may put pressure on it to increase the number of layoffs. The transaction will be dilutive, or break-even, in the first year, although the company said the combination would add 11 percent to earnings in 1998 at current gold prices. As a result, Santa Fe shares gained 50 cents yesterday. to close at $17.875, while Newmont Mining closed at $43, down $1.125. Homestake, which closed at $16, up $1, conceded defeat and collected a $65 million breakup fee from Santa Fe.
"We told them we were not willing to pay any more," Jack Thompson, president of Homestake, said. "If you pay too much, it negates the value of a combination."
If the deal is approved by shareholders, Santa Fe would close its headquarters in Albuquerque, N.M. But it is unclear what would happen to Patrick M. James, Santa Fe's chairman, who would have become president and chief operating officer of the Homestake combination. Newmont declined to comment on Mr. James's future role other than to say the company was hiring a management consulting firm to assist in selecting "the best of the best" of the two companies. Five directors of Santa Fe will join the Newmont board.
The struggle to gain size and increase earnings in the gold industry is not over. Barrick is the "big barracuda" in the mining industry at this point, according to analysts, and the company most likely to make the next acquisition. At the time the Santa Fe bidding war began, Barrick seemed to have outmaneuvered two rivals, Placer Dome Inc. and Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold, in gaining control of the giant Busang discovery in Indonesia. But the Indonesian Government approved a plan last month that gave Freeport-McMoran a major interest in Busang, leaving Barrick empty-handed. In addition, Santa Fe is now $65 million richer, and it did not rule out making an acquisition.

HEADLINE: Hanoi Agrees to Pay Saigon's Debts to U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The Vietnamese Government, increasingly anxious to strike a broad trade accord with Washington, has agreed to repay to the United States millions of dollars in debts incurred by the former South Vietnam for roads, power stations and grain shipments during the Vietnam War, Administration officials said today.
The agreement, struck on Saturday in Hanoi, ends several years of negotiations with Vietnam over its assumption of debts, now worth about $140 million, incurred by the Saigon Government before it fell to North Vietnamese forces in 1975. 
 Many of those debts were incurred to bolster the South's war effort, including the country's main railroad and water system, and a major power plant for Saigon, the former South Vietnamese capital, now called Ho Chi Minh City.
But the repayment does not include the vast sums -- roughly estimated at $1 billion -- in direct military assistance that Washington transferred to the South during the war. In fact, in the negotiations conducted by Treasury and State Department officials, Vietnam balked at repaying $12 million in outstanding loans for the "Food for Peace" program, arguing that through a series of complex transactions the United States used money that was ostensibly earmarked for grain purchases to help finance the war.
Today Administration officials said that the accord was a sign of how far the dialogue between the United States and Vietnam has moved beyond the single issue of identifying the remains of prisoners of war, and toward questions of how the Communist Government will be integrated in the world economy.
"The Vietnamese leaders have a clear economic agenda," one senior Administration official said today. "And they knew that resolving this debt issue was one of the hurdles they had to get past before they get the trading rights they want."
Under the terms of the accord, Vietnam will have 20 years to pay back the loans that were issued to the South.
The Vietnamese were also motivated by the impending visit of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who is scheduled to travel to Vietnam in early April.
Since President Clinton normalized relations with Hanoi in July 1995, the two countries have been negotiating over the many ways in which the Vietnamese economy must change before the Administration is ready to grant most-favored-nation trading status to Hanoi. Most-favored nations are granted the ordinary trading rights -- including low tariffs on imported goods -- that the United States gives to almost all its trading partners.
That issue was high on the agenda when Warren Christopher, then Secretary of State, visited Vietnam in August 1995 to raise the American flag at a new embassy in Hanoi. Mr. Christopher was looking to celebrate the end of a raw chapter in American history; the Vietnamese were more interested in talking to members of his delegation about trade status, getting the country into the World Trade Organization, and economic reform issues.
But the talks since then have been painfully slow. Vietnam has many of the same trade barriers that American officials complain about in China: foreigners are not permitted to trade directly with customers in Vietnam (though many strike deals on the side); the country maintains strict import quotas and licensing requirements for companies that want to trade there, and it prohibits many kinds of foreign investment. "There is a long list of specific regulations and policies which make doing business difficult in Vietnam," Joan E. Spero said in a speech last year, when she was serving as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
Like China, Vietnam has been hesitant to make the kinds of concessions that would open its state-dominated firms to foreign competition. But over the last several months, it has been working with the United States to draft the specific language of a trade accord, one of the prerequisites for most-favored-nation status. Haggling over the wording of that accord, one official said today, "could take up much of the rest of the year."
Before most-favored-nation status could be granted, President Clinton would also have to waive a legal provision, called the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, that concerns freedom of emigration. A similar waiver concerning China sets off an annual human rights debate in Congress, and the arguments would probably be equally heated in Vietnam's case.
The first payment is due next month, shortly after Mr. Rubin's visit to Hanoi, which comes at a time when American companies are exploring large investments in Vietnam, though they have been hesitant because of many of the country's trading barriers. But Conoco Inc. is reportedly nearing an agreement to win rights to one of Vietnam's most promising offshore oil sites, as part of a consortium with Vietnam's state-owned oil company and South Korean and French interests.

HEADLINE: The New Horizon for Arms Cuts

 BODY:
President Clinton's meeting with President Boris Yeltsin of Russia in Helsinki later this month is a crucial opportunity to revive the lost momentum of nuclear weapons reduction. A welcome new bargaining decision recently announced by the Administration should make it easier to do so.
Washington, essentially, has agreed to look ahead to the terms of the next arms reduction treaty to insure that the last one is belatedly approved by Russia and put into force. The proposal, if accepted by Moscow, can lead to significant cuts in the nuclear arsenals of both countries. 
 The last treaty reducing the number of nuclear weapons was signed during the Bush Administration but remains unratified by the Russian parliament. It would reduce the level of long-range nuclear warheads to between 3,000 and 3,500 for each side, one-third the level of a decade ago. The accord would also outlaw land-based multiple warhead missiles, which are particularly dangerous because they are considered the most tempting targets in a nuclear crisis.
Since Russia has more of these megaweapons than the United States, the destruction of them would leave Moscow well below the overall warhead ceiling. To maintain nuclear equality with the United States, Russia might feel compelled to initiate an expensive program of building single warhead missiles. By proposing to begin negotiations at once on a new arms reduction treaty, with ceilings of 2,000 to 2,500 long-range warheads for each side, the Administration offers a good way around this problem. Levels that low would mean no new Russian missiles would have to be built. Washington should go even further by offering to sign a new agreement if doing so would assure Russian ratification of the last one. The Bush Administration set an appropriate precedent by signing the last treaty before the previous one was ratified.
The missile-building issue is not the only problem holding up Russian ratification. The collapse of Moscow's conventional forces has made many Russian legislators more reluctant to reduce nuclear weapons. Western plans to expand NATO closer to Russia's borders and America's programs to develop ballistic missile defense systems also increase Moscow's feelings of insecurity. But in reality Russia's security will be strengthened by continued nuclear missile reductions and its economy will be spared a taxing drain.
American and European security will benefit as well. The future dangers that inspire Washington's plans for ballistic missile defense and NATO expansion are hypothetical. No rogue regime is near developing reliable long-range missiles. Russia's weakened and demoralized land armies will not threaten central and eastern Europe anytime soon. But the thousands of nuclear warheads still sitting atop Russia's long-range missiles could once again become a danger to the American people if a less responsible Russian government comes to power.
The faster Washington and Moscow can move ahead with actual reductions in nuclear arms, the safer both countries will be. Working with the new American proposal, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin have a chance to make real progress in Helsinki.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Niagara Mohawk to Buy Out Costly Power Contracts
Seeking to avert collapse, Niagara Mohawk Power, which serves 1.5 million customers in upstate New York, agreed to a $4 billion buyout of long-term contracts with most of its independent power producers.
Niagara Mohawk is the first utility to rid itself of such contracts in one move. The contracts, dating from the late 1980's and early 1990's, have forced utilities in New York State to pay as much as triple the wholesale power price and raised consumers' costs. [Page B8.]
 
Stocks Soar, Despite Greenspan
Stock prices soared, with technology issues rebounding from recent losses and blue chips climbing, as cash continued flowing into equities, despite Alan Greenspan's warnings of irrational exuberance in the market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 78.50 points to close at a record 7,079.39, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq 100 index gained 13.81 points to close at 854.84. [D8.] 

Treasury security prices slipped with investors hesitant to take positions ahead of this week's economic reports, lest they lead to higher rates. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 6.81 percent. [D20.]
 
Nationwide Insurance Settles Suit
Nationwide Insurance, the country's fifth-largest insurer, agreed to invest $13 million in minority communities and to end a series of practices that a Justice Department suit said discriminated against blacks and poor people and furthered the deterioration of inner-city neighborhoods. Some contended the settlement did not go far enough. [D2.]
 
G.E. in $875 Million Acquisitions
General Electric agreed to buy Greenwich Air Services and UNC Inc. for $875 million in cash and stock. Analysts said the move would effectively double G.E.'s share of the $28 billion market for servicing jet engines. [D3.]
 
Japan Pushes Ahead With Digital TV
Seeking to catch up to the United States and Europe, the Japanese Government announced that it would hasten the introduction of digital television by years, using a superior transmission system. [D6.]
 
G.M. Streamlines Its Management
General Motors moved to streamline its sprawling operations, putting all North American car making under a single executive, Donald E. Hackworth. Richard G. LeFauve, who built its Saturn division, is to develop companywide management and engineering practices. [D4.]
 
Dean Witter and Morgan Advance
Dean Witter, Discover and Morgan Stanley have resolved a thorny issue in their pending merger, agreeing to keep Morgan Stanley's general counsel, Jonathan M. Clark. [D8.]
 
Merrill Officer's Pay Up 40%
Daniel P. Tully, Merrill Lynch's top officer, received a 40 percent raise last year. His compensation exceeded $10 million. [D4.]
 
Putting Holders Ahead of Lawyers
In line with the nation's new securities law, a new settlement in a class action involving California Micro Devices provides much more for holders than the original settlement, in part by bringing in more defendants, including its former auditors, Coopers & Lybrand.
Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
 
Six Companies Shun Nomura
At least six Japanese asset management companies suspended business with Nomura Securities because of its announcement last week that two of its directors had made unauthorized stock trades. [D6.]
 
Thailand Plans Financial Rescue
The Thai Cabinet is to vote today on a Government plan to end the country's financial turmoil by setting up a company to lend $3.86 billion to property developers. [D6.]
 
Vietnam Agrees to Repay Debt
The Vietnamese Government, increasingly eager to strike a broad trade accord with the United States, agreed to repay millions of dollars in debts incurred by the former South Vietnam during the Vietnam War. [A8.]

Uganda Seeks Famine Relief
Uganda issued an urgent call for international relief to avert a famine in its drought-hit eastern region that would affect 2.1 million people. An agriculture official in the northern town of Kumi said people in eight of the 18 sub-counties in his district were on the brink of starvation. In the hardest hit areas, people eat just three times a week. Uganda's weather office said rains expected in March were unlikely to arrive until April. (Reuters)
 
Taiwanese Airliner Hijacked
An unemployed journalist doused himself with gasoline in a Taiwanese airliner and hijacked it to China, where he requested political asylum, complaining of repression at home. It was the latest of 13 Taiwan Strait hijackings in the 1990's, but the first in which a plane was forced to fly to the Chinese mainland rather than away from it. The suspect, Liu Shan-chung, 45, was arrested moments after the plane touched down at China's southeastern port of Xiamen.

HEADLINE: Hanoi Agrees to Pay Saigon's Debt to U.S.

 BODY:
Vietnam has agreed to pay to the United States millions of dollars in debts incurred by the former South Vietnam for roads, power stations and grain shipments during the Vietnam War, Administration officials said yesterday.
The Vietnamese Government is increasingly anxious to strike a trade agreement with the United States. Administration officials said the accord was a sign of how far the dialogue between the United States and Vietnam has moved beyond identifying the remains of prisoners of war and toward questions of how the Communist Government will be integrated in the world economy. 
 The agreement ends several years of negotiations with Vietnam over debts, now worth about $140 million, incurred by the Saigon Government before it fell to North Vietnamese forces in 1975. But the repayment does not include vast sums in direct military assistance to the South.
Article, page A8.

HEADLINE: China Doesn't Deserve Trade Club Membership

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Asia's Giant, After Detours, Takes Familiar Growth Path" (front page, March 4), on China's economic growth strategy, raises an interesting irony for students of Marxist economics. The world's sole Communist superpower is now the number one exporter of surplus, low-cost wage labor to the capitalist system, thereby postponing the inevitable collapse of the capitalist system that Marx prophesied. It gives new credence to the adage that if you live long enough, strange things occur.
 
MICHAEL BANKS
Boulder, Colo., March 5, 1997

HEADLINE: Utility Seeks to End Costly Pacts With Power Suppliers

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
In an effort to fend off financial collapse, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to spend about $4 billion to buy out costly long-term contracts with most of its independent power producers.
The buyout by Niagara Mohawk, which has 1.5 million customers in upstate New York, is the first time that a utility has sought to rid itself of such contracts in one swoop. 
 The contracts, dating from the late 1980's and early 1990's, have forced Niagara Mohawk and other utilities in New York State to pay as much as triple the wholesale price for power and have been a major reason that state residents pay some of the highest rates in the country. They have also complicated the state's efforts to deregulate the utility industry and eventually allow customers choice.
"They had to resolve this in order to save the company," Barry Abramson, the utility analyst for Prudential Securities, said. "The alternative was either immediate bankruptcy or a slow death from these contracts."
The hope is that the agreement will allow the utility to lower rates eventually and make it competitive when the State Public Service Commission deregulates the state's utilities, possibly beginning in early 1998.
The agreement could also serve as a model for other utilities, like the Consolidated Edison Company, which have been buying their way out of such high-cost contracts, but in a much more gradual way.
William E. Davis, the chairman and chief executive of Niagara Mohawk, said that if the agreement was approved by stockholders and state regulators, the company would save about $5 billion over the next 15 years. "This will create a base from which the company can improve its financial performance going forward, as opposed to continuing to decline toward bankruptcy," he said.
Under the agreement, the utility would end or restructure 44 long-term power contracts with 19 independent power producers. Some of those contracts have 30 years to run.
The utility is paying 6 to 10 cents per kilowatt-hour to buy power under the contracts, when it could buy power for 2 to 3 cents per kilowatt-hour in the wholesale market. It estimated that this year its customers would pay about $600 million more than the wholesale cost or the cost of electricity generated by the utility.
As part of the buyout, Niagara Mohawk would pay $400 million in cash, take on $3.2 billion in debt and issue 46 million shares of stock to the independent power producers. The new shares would be about 25 percent of the company's outstanding common stock. They would also make the independent power producers major shareholders and give them an incentive to look out for Niagara Mohawk's financial health.
Carol Murphy, the director of the Independent Power Producers of New York, an industry trade group, said many of its members decided to make a settlement because they realized they would suffer if the utility were forced into bankruptcy.
"This way," she said, "they can get their debt paid off and be in a much better position to sell power" once deregulation occurs.
For current shareholders, however, the agreement would dilute the value of their stock. Many stockholders are retired people who bought the stock because it was thought to be less volatile than other stocks and paid good dividends. But because of the loss of some of its major industrial customers, Niagara Mohawk suspended paying dividends in January 1996.
"There is not much there for the shareholders, " Penelope Adelmann, the utility analyst for Gruntal & Company, said. She added that earnings would continue to be under pressure, and that the costly settlement would make it difficult for the utility to resume dividend payments.
Niagara Mohawk's stock was battered yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $9.375, down 87.5 cents.
New York State forced many of the utilities into the high-cost, long-term contracts under a 1978 Federal law that sought to encourage private investors to build small, efficient plants to reduce demand for oil to generate power. In the 1980's, regulators feared that demand for electricity would outrun supply and that its cost would soar. Instead, there is now a surplus of low-cost power.
Mr. Davis, Niagara Mohawk's chairman, said some of the initial savings from the agreement would be passed on to larger industrial customers in lower rates, while smaller commercial customers and residential users would see some modest rate cuts.
Larger customers would get bigger savings because the utility has lost some industrial customers who have built their own small generating plants or have been able to make alternative deals with low-cost competitors. This has put the utility, which serves 1.5 million customers, in a financial squeeze.
The company has proposed a radical restructuring, under which its nuclear plants at Nine Mile Point on Lake Ontario would be taken over or refinanced by New York State in order to cut the utility's costs.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Unlikely to Be Issue at Hearing on Nominee

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Senate hearings on Anthony Lake's nomination as Director of Central Intelligence, set to start on Tuesday, might become a debate over campaign financing and foreign policy failings instead of a discussion of the future of United States intelligence.
The good news for Mr. Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser from 1993 through 1996, is that he will finally have a hearing, and that he probably has the votes for confirmation. 
 The bad news is not so different from the good news. The hearing is likely to be politically brutal, and Mr. Lake will probably be bloodied when it is done. His margin of victory in confirmation might be the narrowest ever accorded a Director of Central Intelligence.
His prize will be the Central Intelligence Agency -- now suffering self-inflicted wounds from two treasonous officers, botched economic espionage operations against allies and an abiding midlife crisis as its 50th birthday approaches -- and the rest of the intelligence services.
What might be lost in the political scuffle are serious questions and answers about where the $30-billion-a-year intelligence establishment is headed.
On the eve of the hearings, which are scheduled to run for six days this week and next, Senator Richard C. Shelby, the Alabama Republican who heads the Intelligence Committee, is still looking for a show-stopping allegation that could cripple or kill the nomination.
Mr. Shelby still wants the White House to hand over raw files from the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Mr. Lake. Several conservative Republicans have warned that they might block the nomination in the full Senate unless the White House lets them see the reports. Mr. Shelby has warned that Mr. Lake could face "a firestorm" over the files on the Senate floor.
Behind closed doors, the Intelligence Committee staff, at Mr. Shelby's direction, has been researching some major foreign policy issues under Mr. Lake's control. These include what Mr. Lake knew about Chinese missile sales to Pakistan, his failure to tell Congress about President Clinton's tacit approval of Iran's arms shipments to Bosnia's Muslims in 1994, and whether he played down human rights abuses in Haiti under the government the White House helped install in 1994.
But publicly, Mr. Shelby has been questioning Mr. Lake's ethics and integrity. By postponing the hearings twice, he has held Mr. Lake at arm's length with one hand while rhetorically pummeling him with the other. The Senator's latest set of questions -- what role if any Mr. Lake and his National Security Council staff played in campaign fund-raising -- now appear likely to dominate the hearings.
"He's going to try and use Tony to get to the President on fund-raising," an Administration official said.
Mr. Shelby said on the Senate floor last week that he wanted to examine "the extent to which Mr. Lake knew of the ties the White House was building with questionable fund-raisers and foreign contributors and what effect this might have had on Administration foreign policy."
The intelligence committee's staff questioned four members of the National Security Council staff today about their work for Mr. Lake -- and their contacts with or knowledge of Asian fund-raisers. Those questioned included Sandra Kristoff, the head of the council's Asia directorate, and Robert Suettinger, a China expert.
Ms. Kristoff had meetings with Pauline Kanchanalak, a Thai businesswoman whose $253,000 in contributions to the Democratic Party were returned and are the subject of a Federal investigation. Mr. Suettinger wrote a memorandum last year describing Johnny Chung, another Democratic Party fund-raiser under investigation, as a "hustler."
But barring some devastating disclosure or some insurmountable procedural hurdle erected by Mr. Lake's opponents in the Senate, support from moderate Republicans is likely to put Mr. Lake at the helm of United States intelligence.
Some of the 10 Republicans on the Senate Intelligence Committee are likely to spend a good deal of time at the hearing attacking Mr. Lake politically, professionally and personally. The nine Democrats, led by the vice chairman, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, will spend much of their time defending him on those three fronts.
Two moderate Republicans on the committee -- Senators Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and John H. Chafee of Rhode Island -- are likely to provide a margin of victory for Mr. Lake. They will be bolstered by the committee's former vice chairman, Warren B. Rudman, a former Republican senator from New Hampshire, who said in an interview that he planned to endorse Mr. Lake before the committee on Tuesday.
"I've had extensive dealings with Lake," said Mr. Rudman, who has served as the acting chairman of President Clinton's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board. "I have very high regard for him. I think he's first rate."
