HEADLINE: The Next Course for the Restaurateur;
What's Better Than a Successful Restaurant? Two or Three or Four

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Jean-Georges Vongerichten, one of New York's better-known chefs and restaurateurs, is building a collection of restaurants the way a baseball owner puts together a team of pitchers -- each one has distinctively different qualities, all designed to give the customer, and the competition, a little something different each day of the week.
Later this month, Mr. Vongerichten, who is 39 and a native of France, will open his fourth restaurant, Jean-Georges, inside the new Trump International Hotel at Columbus Circle. 
 "This one is to go after the high-end customer, more precision cooking," he said. "Each one will have a different appeal. The people who go to one will go to another later in the week. I don't want them to go to someone else. It's competition. You create three or four concepts, so they'll go to each one."
In a city where restaurant owners have often enjoyed success and fame by focusing all of their attention on a single restaurant, about a dozen owners are building groups of one-of-a-kind, high-concept restaurants, creating powerful and profitable cartels for themselves and trying to attract a broader clientele by having, for example, a bistro with modest prices, a trendy place that people can go to for unusual and flashier food and a high-end, more sedate and exclusive restaurant.
While restaurant success may still be epitomized by owners like Sirio Maccioni, who for more than 20 years focused all of his attention on turning Le Cirque into one of the city's most acclaimed restaurants, the New York restaurant business is being redefined by people more like Mr. Vongerichten.
Fueled by a strong economy, a fast-growing market for dining out and smaller profit margins, owners like Mr. Vongerichten are creating restaurant concepts that help them appeal to a wider variety of diners. The demand for high-quality places to eat has grown significantly in recent years, as more tourists have flocked to the city, and the area's already large population of diners has become more sophisticated about cuisine and wine.
"Dining in New York is better than it ever was," said Charles Palmer, a chef and owner of the tony restaurant Aureole, as well as Alva and the Lenox Room. "People know much more about food and wine these days."
In 1995, New Yorkers ate out an average of 3.8 times a week, a 21 percent increase over the previous year, according to the Zagat survey of the city's restaurants.
"New York has a large tourist market, and people like to go out two, three times a week," said Andrew Zarnett, a restaurant industry analyst at Ladenburg Thalmann, a New York brokerage firm. "Competition is big here, but if you have a different concept, people will be there."
But one of the difficulties with the high-concept, one-of-a-kind restaurants is that they can lose their luster after a year or two, Mr. Zarnett said. Unless an owner has a superb location, it can become difficult to maintain large profit margins once the buzz dies down, and that can also encourage an owner to create a new concept.
"You can't make money with one restaurant anymore," Mr. Vongerichten said in a recent interview. "Twenty years ago, a place like Lutece would make a 30 percent profit. Taxes were lower, there was less competition. They were booked three months in advance." By opening a variety of restaurants, he said, owners can increase their profits through volume.
"There is more competition now," he said. "More people are going out also. They need more diversity. To make the same money as the people who were in New York before us, we have to open three or four restaurants."
From Sheldon Fireman, the owner of Cafe Concepts, which has five restaurants including Trattoria dell'Arte and the Red Eye Grill, to Alan Stillman, whose New York Restaurant Group operates six restaurants, including Smith & Wollensky and the Manhattan Ocean Club, there is growing evidence that New York's restaurant business is no longer the sole province of single-restaurant owners.
Also among those who have built restaurant groups over the last decade are Drew Nieporent, who owns Montrachet, TriBeCa Grill, Leyla, Zeppole, the Grill at Reebok, Nobu and City Wine and Bar; Steve Hanson, an owner of Isabella's, Coconut Grill, Park Avalon and Blue Water Grill; and Pino Luongo, who in addition to owning Le Madri, Il Toscanaccio and Coco Pazzo Teatro is now in the midst of an expansion of his Coco Pazzo restaurant around the country.
Blending his expertise as a chef with the financial backing of his investment partners, Philip Suarez and Robert Geraldi, Mr. Vongerichten has spent the last six years developing some of the city's most highly rated restaurants.
His first, Jo Jo, which opened in 1991, during a recession, was created to serve "simple food, at $40 to $45 per person," he said. His next, the Lipstick Cafe, which he opened the following year, caters mostly to a "salad and sandwich" crowd. And Vong, the French-accented Thai restaurant that Mr. Vongerichten opened in 1993, is "more international, more exotic."
Unlike restaurant chains, these groups offer different food and decor in each restaurant, but the consistency in quality and service allows owners to transfer the success of an established restaurant to a new one.
"If they're good, they feed off each other," said Jerry Kretchmer, who is a partner in Gotham Bar and Grill, Mesa Grill, Bolo, Judson Grill and Mesa City. "People in one restaurant often ask us to make reservations in another one for them. So there's clearly some feeling of continuity."
Mr. Palmer said that the people who dine at Aureole are willing to go to other restaurants that he is associated with because they are comfortable with his reputation. Next month, Mr. Palmer will open a restaurant called Astra in the Decoration and Design Building at 979 Third Avenue, where simple fare like soups and sandwiches will be served.
And as an owner, Mr. Palmer said, he benefits by having a group of associated restaurants. "The association is good," he said. "We always have the advantage of more buying power. We share a portion of clientele, and we can rely on each other for support."
But while some customers might take comfort in the level of consistency that restaurant groups offer, owners are keenly aware that customers like the romance of unique restaurants. Many owners, consequently, are adamant about distinguishing between their restaurants, and they scoff whenever their businesses are described as "theme restaurants."
Restaurant groups are not new to New York or, for that matter, to most other major cities. In the 1950's, Restaurant Associates, a group based in New York, pioneered the approach, as it grew to own more than 100 restaurants. Many were in New York City, including Mama Leone's, the Sea Grill, and Trattoria in the former Pan Am building. In 1990, Restaurant Associates was sold to a Japanese food-service firm.
Another large group in New York is Ark Restaurants, which is operated by Michael Weinstein and is a publicly traded company. Ark owns more than 20 properties in the city, ranging from Bryant Park Grill to Lutece.
But New York has had few owners who have run more than one or two restaurants at a time. While other cities saw individual owners grow to the point of near dominance in the market, New York restaurants maintained their pure independence.
"The restaurant market has increased so dramatically in the last decade," said Max Pine, an investment banker who for 17 years was president of Restaurant Associates. "With the growth of the industry, where you might have found only one company in each city that had three or more restaurants, now you're finding that there are more companies doing it."
Richard Melman, who built a dining juggernaut in Chicago with his Lettuce Entertain You Enterprises, said he believes that New York owners are finally changing their approach.
"For many years, New York was like Europe," he said. "The thing to do was to do one good restaurant and work it. Be a Sirio at Le Cirque, or an Elaine, and work it."
He said some New York owners have told him in private conversations that they are "going to start thinking bigger."
Mr. Vongerichten said that he has learned "little tips" from Mr. Melman. For example, he gives his top chefs a piece of the equity in the restaurants where they cook, and he never takes workers from one restaurant to a new one because it could diminish the overall quality of his work force.
Because he is the chief chef at all of his restaurants, one of the challenges, Mr. Vongerichten said, is not spreading himself too thin.
"I'm connected with all my restaurants," he said, as he whipped a tiny cellular telephone from his pocket. "I want to know everything going on. Who's there. Who's coming. If they're comping a glass of wine to someone, I'm reachable 24 hours."
In a city with more than 1,800 restaurants, the number of people building restaurant groups is still relatively small in New York. And as Mr. Stillman pointed out, it is so difficult to operate more than one restaurant that the number of people who can successfully build large groups could remain limited.
"Like any multiple-oriented retail industry, going from one to two is the highest risk you take," he said. "It changes your whole modus operandi."
Still, while every restaurant owner may not be expected to open multiple businesses, it is clear that many more are trying their hand at building a successful group.
Even Mr. Maccioni is about to become the operator of two restaurants. Last year, he opened Osteria del Circo, and in April, he will open Le Cirque 2000, the widely anticipated, revamped version of his famed restaurant.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 11 about restaurant owners in New York City creating groups of restaurants that, though commonly owned, are each one of a kind referred incorrectly to the ownership of Restaurant Associates, a New York-based company. While it was sold to a Japanese company, Kyotaru, in 1990, it was bought back by an American investment group led by its own management in July 1996.

HEADLINE: What's as Green as Ireland And Smoky as a Peat Fire?

BYLINE: By MOIRA HODGSON 

 BODY:
ST. PATRICK'S DAY: it brings to mind shamrocks and, at least for New Yorkers who crowd Fifth Avenue, beer or ale. But seaweed?
Well, why not? Seaweed is as much an Irish specialty as it is a Japanese one. Thanks to a professor at University College, Galway, seaweed has its own home page -- http:// seaweed.ucg.ie -- on the World Wide Web. 
 Figures on the Web give seaweed production in Ireland (34,600 tons were harvested in 1994, the most recent numbers available). And seaweed is even finding its way onto Manhattan menus. Instead of being served as a decoration under an order of half a dozen oysters on the half-shell, it may well be in the dressing. Brad Steelman, the chef at the Water Club in Manhattan, mixes it in a mignonette he makes with sake, mirin (a sweet cooking sake) and rice wine vinegar.
Rick Moonen, the chef at the Manhattan restaurant Oceana, broils it and adds it to salads or soup. "It's like a smoky bacon," he said. Which pretty much describes the taste of most forms of seaweed.
But too often seaweed still provokes the sort of reaction that J. M. Barrie, the author of "Peter Pan," is said to have had when seated at dinner next to George Bernard Shaw. The Irish Shaw was almost as famous a vegetarian as a playwright. Barrie looked down at Shaw's plateful of murky greens and said, "Have you just eaten that or are you about to?"
These days the word used by vegetarians (and by companies that harvest the stuff) is not seaweed but "sea vegetables," said Ken Bergeron, a restaurant consultant and the author of "Professional Vegetarian Cooking," due next year from Van Nostrand Reinhold.
Mr. Bergeron won a gold medal at the Culinary Olympics in Frankfurt in 1991 and 1993 for a vegetarian menu that included seaweed-stuffed squash, seaweed-corn pancakes with roasted tomato, dulse (a kind of seaweed) and garlic sauce, and oyster mushrooms fried in a coating of bread crumbs and powdered seaweed.
"I was looking for those seafood flavors without the fish," he said. "The seaweed made the mushrooms taste like oysters. I called it 'cuisine mirage.' The judges were really surprised when they saw the presentation and read the menus and saw there were no animal products."
James O'Shea, an Irish-born chef who runs the West Street Grill in Litchfield, Conn., has been experimenting with seaweed for years. "You may think that seaweed is something only used in Japanese or Korean cooking," he said, "but in Ireland we've eaten it since the 12th century."
One day recently Mr. O'Shea was stuffing a fillet of Irish salmon with cod roe and rolling it in a crust made with smoked dulse flakes. "Smell it, and you are right back on the coast in Kenmare," he said.
In Ireland seaweed is a major industry and has been for more than a century. "Right in front of us were three islands, and the outlying areas were covered in seaweed, with mussels clinging onto the rocks," Mr. O'Shea said. "All the people in the area used the seaweed as fertilizer, and my father covered his rhubarb patches with it."
More than 500 varieties of seaweed grow wild in Ireland, where it is used in cosmetics, soaps, toothpaste, as an additive in peat and as a source of iodine. The Web site estimates that the Irish seaweed industry contributes about $4.67 million to the Irish economy and employs 320 part-time and 120 full-time harvesters.
For a while after World War II, cereals made from seaweed meal were popular in Ireland. But that was a relatively new way to serve it. The earliest recorded reference to seaweed in Ireland involved dulse, which is known in Ireland as dilisk and has leathery flattened fronds that are used in breads and soups.
A stanza of a poem thought to have been written in the 12th century referred to a monk gathering the stuff. During the potato famine of 1845-49, after virtually depleting supplies of shellfish that lived on seaweed, people ate as much of it as they could gather (it is rich in vegetable protein, vitamin B12, carotene, chlorophyll and fiber).
Later in the 19th century carrageen -- popularly known as "Irish moss," even though it is is not a moss at all, but a dark purplish-red seaweed that grows in pools and on rocks -- was used as a remedy for chest ailments and as a jelling agent for puddings.
Nowadays, Irish chefs are becoming increasingly inventive with carrageen, adding it to everything from salsas to cheesecake. It is even being extolled as a condiment. Mr. O'Shea's sister, Bernadette, who has a restaurant called Truffles in Sligo, bakes it in the oven and grinds it to a fine powder. "I put it in soups, saffron aioli or on top of mixed greens," she said over the telephone from Ireland. "It should be on the shelf in every kitchen."
Perhaps. But the display of seaweeds in Mr. O'Shea's kitchen was not exactly appetizing. One looked like a piece of dust-covered bark, another like withered petals of a purple flower, yet another like a tangle of dried black spaghettini. He pointed to a pale gray stringy heap and joked, "Leftover nylons from World War II." But he said it is really kombu, which is like dulse and has a very mild taste.
The next step after dipping the salmon fillet into dulse granules mixed with flour was to roll it in beaten egg and then in smoked dulse flakes. "I like to use seaweed in flakes and granules not just for the ocean flavor it imparts to seafood," he said, "but because it both keeps it moist and absorbs much less oil than a regular batter. I tried it with crab cakes that were falling apart on me, but it held them together beautifully."
He placed the salmon in the hot oil and seared it on all sides. The seaweed crust turned from purple to deep green. "It looks like a water-washed beach stone," Mr. O'Shea said. "And the taste will take you right back to the beach."
Indeed, the seaweed crust on the salmon acted like a skin and kept the fish beautifully moist inside. It was not in the least greasy, and its smoked seaweed flavor complimented the richness of the fish. With it Mr. O'Shea served cabbage stir-fried with scallions (which the Irish call "spring onions"), tossed with hijiki, the seaweed that looked like black spaghettini, which he had soaked for half an hour until it was soft.
He stirred in a dash of a paste he made with ginger and chili and tossed everything together. The hijiki added a subtle, nutlike aroma that went very well with the cabbage and the salmon.
Mr. O'Shea is not alone among Western chefs to be intrigued by seaweed and its possibilities. Recently, it has shown up on menus as an ingredient in pancakes, salads, stuffings, puddings and even club sandwiches, as well as in a wide range of seafood dishes from oysters to lobster ravioli.
"Super-fresh fish has the flavor of the sea," said Ed Brown, executive chef of the Sea Grill in Manhattan, who uses it in seafood salad, among other things. "And that's what seaweed tastes like. Even the varieties that come salted and dried have that quality."
Mr. O'Shea's next project involves shad roe, a dish that appears every spring on the Irish table, with thick slices of smoked Irish bacon and mashed potatoes. "I'm going to do it in a seaweed crust instead," he said. "That will prevent it from bursting and will be much better for you than all that bacon."
 
Oysters With Seaweed And Cucumber Mignonette
(Adapted from Brad Steelman, the Water Club)
 
Total time: 50 minutes soaking and marinating, 20 minutes hands on

 2 tablespoons hijiki seaweed
 3 ounces rice wine vinegar
 2 ounces sake
 1 ounce mirin (cooking sake)
 1 tablespoon fresh ginger, peeled and minced
 1/2 teaspoon freshly cracked pepper
 2 tablespoons cucumber, peeled and minced
 24 oysters
 3 tablespoons wasabi-cured flying fish roe (optional).
 
 1. Soak the hijiki in warm water for 30 minutes or until it is soft. Drain and chop coarsely. Mix it with the vinegar, sake, mirin, ginger and pepper. Refrigerate for 20 minutes, or until ready to serve.
 2. Shuck the oysters and arrange them on ice on four plates. Add the cucumber to the sauce. Top the oysters with the sauce and a small dollop of flying fish roe.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 265 calories, 7 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 330 milligrams sodium, 30 grams protein, 16 grams carbohydrate.
 NOTE: Mr. Steelman, executive chef at the Water Club, says he prefers to use kumamoto oysters for this dish. They are small and buttery, with a light brine.
 
Salmon in Seaweed Crust Stuffed With Smoked Cod
(Adapted from James O'Shea, the West Street Grill)
Total time: 15 minutes

 4 5-ounce fillets of salmon, at room temperature for one hour
 2 ounces smoked cod roe, skinned
 1 cup flour
 1 tablespoon coarse sea salt
 1 teaspoon Cayenne pepper
 1 tablespoon smoked dulse granules
 1 1/2 to 2 ounces dulse flakes, for coating
 1 egg, beaten
 1/4 cup olive oil
 Sprigs of chervil for garnishing.
 
 1. Make an incision in the side of each salmon fillet. Stuff each one with 2 to 3 tablespoons of cod roe.
 2. Combine the flour with the salt, cayenne and dulse granules. Dredge the fillet in the flour mixture and pat off excess. Dip lightly in beaten egg and then lightly coat with dulse flakes, covering all sides; do not make the crust too thick.
 3. Heat the oil in a 12-inch stainless-steel skillet. Saute the fillets on all sides for a total of 5 minutes for rare, 8 minutes for well done (rare to medium rare is preferred for texture and color). Garnish with chervil and serve.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 380 calories, 20 grams fat, 130 milligrams cholesterol, 1,130 milligrams sodium, 30 grams protein, 18 grams carbohydrate.
 NOTE: Smoked cod roe is available by mail order from Petrossian,
182 West 58th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; (212) 245-2217, (800) 828-9241. Smoked dulse granules are available from Maine Seacoast Vegetables, Franklin, Me. 04634, (207) 565-2907.
 
Seafood Salad With Three Seaweeds And Chinese Black Beans
(Adapted from Ed Brown, the Sea Grill)
Total time: 20 minutes

 1 1/2 teaspoons olive oil
 2 cloves garlic, peeledand sliced
 2 teaspoons ginger, peeled and chopped
 2 scallions, white part only, cut in 1-inch julienne
 1/8 teaspoon red pepper flakes, rinsed
 1 teaspoon Chinese black beans (available in Oriental and health food stores)
 1 1/4 cups fish stock
 12 medium shrimp, peeled and butterflied
 12 medium sea scallops
 2 teaspoons miso paste
 1 tablespoon rice vinegar
 1 tablespoon soy sauce, low sodium
 1 cup seaweed salad, prepared (see note)
 3/4 cup goma kombu (seasoned seaweed, see note)
 4 tablespoons nori, cut in julienne (sold in sheets in Oriental and health-food stores)
 
 1. Heat the olive oil in a medium-size casserole over medium heat. Saute the garlic, ginger, scallions, red pepper flakes and black beans in the oil without browning.
 2. Add the stock, bring to boil and simmer for 1 minute. Add the seafood, return to the boil and simmer for approximately 3 minutes. Remove and reserve the shrimp, but cook the scallops about 1 1/2 minutes longer or until they are just cooked. Remove and reserve the scallops.
 3. Return the cooking liquid to the boil and reduce by approximately one-third. Remove and bring to room temperature. Add the miso paste, vinegar and soy sauce. Adjust seasoning to taste.
 4. To assemble: Form a small circle with one-quarter of the prepared sesame seaweed salad, then place 2 scallops on top, then one-quarter of the goma kombu; arrange 3 shrimp on top in a pinwheel and top with the third scallop. Divide the sauce over the 4 plates equally; garnish with a tablespoon of the julienned nori paper on top.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 170 calories, 5 grams fat, 50 milligrams cholesterol, 1,060 milligrams sodium, 17 grams protein, 14 grams carbohydrate.
 NOTE: This salad may also be garnished with soybeans, garlic chives, bud chives, julienned red pepper or thin-sliced red onions.
 Goma kombu is a dark marinated seaweed flavored with mirin and soy, sold fresh and ready to use. It costs $2.45 a container and is sold at Sam Bok, 127 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. (212) 221-0845. Sesame seaweed salad is available there at $8.95 a pound.

HEADLINE: Productivity in 1996 Up 0.7%, Biggest Rise in 4 Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Productivity, the main measurement of how quickly American living standards can rise, increased seven-tenths of 1 percent last year. It was the largest rise in four years but still below the standard set in the 1950's and 1960's.
The gain, reported today by the Labor Department, was more than double the 1995 advance of three-tenths of 1 percent and not far short of the typical annual gains seen since the mid-1970's. In the 1960's average annual gains exceeded 3 percent. 
 Productivity is a measure of output per hour of work. Its sluggish growth since the 1970's is viewed as the root of many economic problems, notably slow income growth.
However, in recent years, many economists contend, productivity improvements have actually been better than depicted in reports by the Government, which has had difficulty measuring output in services.
"Although we cannot quite measure output properly, we know there's more of it," said Samuel Kahan, an economist with A.S.K. Financial Research Ltd. in Chicago. "We have changes in technology that are improving our output in all areas."
"The primary force is computers," he said. "It ranges from banking, where you don't have to see a teller -- you can go to an A.T.M. or bank by computer -- to how a person writes a report or to how you have inventory control."
He estimated that actual productivity gains could be as much as one percentage point greater than reported by the Labor Department. "This may be one explanation of why we've had fabulous price behavior even though economic growth seems to be pushing its limits," he said.
Today's report was a downward revision from a month ago, when the annual gain was reported as eight-tenths of 1 percent.
In the fourth quarter, the Labor Department said, productivity grew at a 1.1 percent annual rate, half the 2.2 percent originally reported.
The decline occurred because hours worked increased more than had been thought and output increased less. Besides showing a more modest gain in productivity for the quarter, the revision also meant a steeper rise in unit labor costs, which take account of both hourly wages and productivity. Unit costs rose at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the quarter, not the 1.4 percent increase originally reported. Nevertheless, the revision was not enough to change the gain in unit labor costs for all of 1996: 2.9 percent, the same as in 1995.
An acceleration in unit labor costs can be a sign of inflationary pressure that could eventually push up prices.
With unemployment near a seven-year low at 5.3 percent in February, some economists expect wage pressures will cause unit labor costs to rise more steeply this year. Other economists, however, share the view of Janet L. Yellen, a former Federal Reserve governor who recently became head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. On Friday she described the job market as "extremely strong" but without "any evidence of inflationary pressures."
In today's revised report, the gains in manufacturing productivity were a bit higher -- 3.9 percent in 1996 and an annual rate of 4.4 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with the previously reported 3.8 percent for both the year and the quarter.
"This report has one central message: that the rapid gains in manufacturing productivity are significantly determined by the influence of rapid improvements in technology," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "U.S. Productivity" tracks index of output per hour of all people in nonfarm businesses, seasonally adjusted, from the third quarter of 1992 through the end of 1996. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Higher; Gains Trimmed Later in Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday, deriving a bit of strength from safe-haven buying after President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia sought to revamp his Cabinet and a Japanese nuclear plant caught fire.
But the dollar's gains partly eroded as the day progressed, with little in the way of economic news to guide the foreign-exchange market. Traders said the dollar was unlikely to move significantly in either direction pending the release of additional data on United States economic growth this week. 
 "At the end of the day we were a little bit higher, but it was really a kind of sideways trading day for the dollar," said Jim Phoenix, director of foreign exchange at CIBC-Wood Gundy in New York.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.7044 marks, up from 1.7020 marks on Monday, and at 121.81 yen, up from 121.63 yen. The pound rose to $1.6072 from $1.6033.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 122 yen on news of a fire and explosion at a Japanese nuclear waste-handling plant in Tokai, about 70 miles northeast of Tokyo.
Traders bought dollars defensively on the uncertainty about the extent of damage, acting on the knowledge that Japan is heavily dependent on nuclear energy. But as it became clear that the fire was not serious and there was no radioactive leak, the dollar backtracked.
Likewise, the dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7040 marks on news that Mr. Yeltsin had ordered Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin to make new Cabinet appointments. Traders often buy dollars and sell marks on political uncertainty in Russia, Germany's biggest trading partner.
"The dollar popped up as the markets were caught by surprise on the Yeltsin news," said Stephen Flanagan, senior currency trader at the New York branch of Credit Agricole.
But the dollar lost much of the gain as the market subsequently interpreted Mr. Yeltsin's move as a decisive effort to reassert authority over the drifting Russian Government.
"The dollar just seemed to back off a bit, as there wasn't much of a push behind it," said Robert Katz, a currency trader at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York. "There was nothing to reinvigorate the dollar bulls and draw people off the sidelines."

HEADLINE: President's Plan to Rein In Medicaid Costs Draws Bipartisan Fire

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Governors and members of Congress from both parties today denounced President Clinton's proposal to impose firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending, and the governors offered a number of alternative ways to save money.
At separate hearings in the Senate and the House, Mr. Clinton's proposal for annual per-capita limits on Medicaid spending won support from only one lawmaker: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a conservative Republican, who said such restraints would help balance the Federal budget. 
 Federal spending on Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for 37 million low-income people, grew by more than 20 percent a year in the early 1990's. Although the growth has slowed since then, Mr. Clinton says the Government must take steps to prevent another explosion of costs.
But critics say his plan would simply shift costs to the states.
Gov. Bob Miller of Nevada, a Democrat who is chairman of the National Governors' Association, said the Clinton proposal would "help the Federal Government balance the budget on the backs of the states." While the President's proposal would limit Federal spending, Mr. Miller noted, it would not limit state Medicaid spending, and the states would still be required to provide all the benefits guaranteed under current law.
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a Republican, said the limits would discourage states from expanding health insurance coverage of children, a goal that Mr. Clinton has espoused. Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, echoed that concern, saying the proposal "could inadvertently increase the number of uninsured children."
The New York Senators, Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, also spoke forcefully against the President's plan.
The hearings today were held by the Senate Finance Committee and the House Commerce Subcommittee on Health and Environment. Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said after his hearing that Medicaid caps were still "on the table."
"We certainly don't rule it out at this stage," Mr. Roth said.
The precise amount to be squeezed from Medicaid will be determined in negotiations over the Federal budget as a whole, although it is unclear whether President Clinton and Congress -- or Republicans and Democrats within Congress -- will reach a broad budget agreement this year limiting Medicaid and other benefits.
The governors noted that they had already reined in the growth of Medicaid, with the result that the Congressional Budget Office recently lowered its projections of Federal Medicaid spending from 1997 through 2002 by $86 billion, or 11 percent.
The governors said they could save $8 billion more if Congress allowed them to make greater use of managed care and to exclude doctors and hospitals that charge unusually high fees. Mr. Clinton, in contrast, has proposed $22 billion in savings, although he would spend $13 billion of that amount on new health benefits, for children and others.
Since its creation in 1965, Medicaid has been an open-ended program, providing health insurance to poor people who meet eligibility criteria set by Federal and state laws.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, though, average Federal spending on a Medicaid recipient could rise no faster than the nation's per-capita economic output. The total of Federal Medicaid spending would still increase automatically with the eligible population, but state officials say they would have difficulty maintaining existing benefits.
If the Federal Government reached its spending limit, Mr. Miller said, "states would essentially have to choose between cutting back on payment rates for health care providers, eliminating optional benefits provided to recipients, ending coverage for optional beneficiaries or coming up with additional state funds to absorb 100 percent of the cost of services."
Representative Michael Bilirakis, the Florida Republican who is chairman of the Commerce subcommittee, said he was disappointed that the governors had not proposed greater savings. Senator Gramm said Congress was certain to demand more, and he praised Mr. Clinton's proposal as "real honest-to-God reform that will save money."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, as investors continued to worry that coming economic data might be strong enough to prompt the Fed to raise short-term rates.
The 30-year bond dropped 14/32, to a price of 97 6/32, pushing its yield up to 6.85 percent, from 6.81 percent on Monday. 
 Analysts also noted yesterday that concern was raised by an announcement by Fidelity's Magellan Fund that it had cut its bond position to eight-tenths of 1 percent in January from 3.8 percent at the end of last year and 18 percent when it changed managers about eight months ago.
Bonds came off their lows in the afternoon, when Robert McTeer, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said the Fed was on guard against inflation that might arise from tight labor markets but was not yet ready to raise rates.
"The labor markets are so tight there is a danger wage pressure will exceed productivity gains, and then higher wages could spill over into product prices," Mr. McTeer told a reporter before speaking to a group of community leaders at the San Antonio branch of the Dallas Fed.
"On the other hand, commodity prices are low, including gold, and are well behaved," Mr. McTeer said. "So we are in the same place we've been for a year. We're on guard, but there's nothing to tip us over into tightening."
The central bank's Federal Open Market Committee meets two weeks from now, on March 25, to consider whether to raise the overnight bank lending rate. Mr. McTeer is not a voting member of the committee; he was replaced by Jack Guynn, president of the Atlanta Fed, at the beginning of the year.
Patrick R. Ledford, senior fixed-income portfolio manager at Citibank Global Asset Management, said Mr. McTeer's comments raised investor hopes that the Fed would remain on hold at the March 25 Federal Open Market Committee meeting. But he believes the die was cast last week.
"After the Greenspan comments a week ago, you can't expect bonds to rally on good inflation data," Mr. Ledford said. "His comment diminished the significance of good data." Mr. Ledford's reference was to the comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman.
If the Fed does raise rates, he added, it will be the pre-emptive kind the chairman warned about. "But we haven't seen any signs of higher inflation, though the risk of a Fed tightening is very real. We're constructive longer term from a fundamental standpoint, but tactically we're concerned like everyone on the Street."
Among the reasons he cites for the Fed to remain on hold are moderate growth, low inflation, a strong currency and attractive higher rates relative to foreign rates.
David Shabelman, market analyst at MMS International, San Francisco, said Mr. McTeer's comments led to a short-cover rally, as investors betting that the market would go down, were forced to buy securities to hold down losses.
Short positions occur when some market participants sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, thereby pocketing the difference. But if prices begin to rise instead of fall, as was the case after Mr. McTeer spoke, these participants have to cover their short positions by buying back the securities in order to limit their losses.
The afternoon release of the Redbook survey of retail sales, which showed a 1.1 percent gain for the period ended last Saturday, was fairly strong and weighed on the market. "It only served to confirm the morning Mitsubishi report of a strong 1.3 percent rise in retail sales," Mr. Shabelman said. "As the weekly retails sales continue to show strength, investors are growing wary."
The market is still bearish, he continued, so selling continues on any upticks on strength. "Our most recent survey is showing less than a fifty-fifty chance of a March tightening, which I believe the market consensus is. About 90 percent of the people surveyed think the Fed will act by May. So the data the market is to receive over the next couple of weeks is critical for those trying to get a jump on Fed intentions."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Tradition triumphs: an obvious choice is the clear favorite in planning where to be on Dec. 31, 1999.

DATELINE: Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
THE countdown has been under way for months for New Year's Eve 1999, with the Pyramids, the Eiffel Tower and the international date line among destinations being promoted as "the place" to welcome in the year 2000. But a recent survey in the United States found that among those who say they are planning a special trip that New Year's, the overwhelming favorite destination is (the envelope please) -- New York/Times Square, the choice of 45.8 percent of the respondents.
The fifth annual YP&B/Yankelovich Partners survey of pleasure travelers found these other destinations on the top 10 wish list for that special eve: Las Vegas (13.2 percent), New Orleans (8.5), a cruise (8.2), Alaska (6.3), Los Angeles (6.3), Colorado (5.8), Brazil (5.3), Jamaica (5.2) and Hawaii (5.1). 

Busy Summer for Hong Kong
Airline seats and hotel rooms for travelers to Hong Kong are still scarce to nonexistent for the days leading up to July 1, when the colony reverts from British to Chinese rule. But plenty of seats and rooms are available in most of the weeks and months after the change of government, although tourist officials warn that Hong Kong will be crowded again Sept. 23-25, when some 10,000 visitors are expected for the annual meeting of the boards of governors of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Otherwise, Japan Airlines reports that its flights into Hong Kong are sold out from June 26 through July 4, while its departing flights are sold out June 29 through July 8. Other than that, a spokesman for J.A.L. said, as of now there are plenty of seats. United and Northwest also have seats available after the change-over, although advance bookings are somewhat stronger than expected for the rest of the summer.
Marriott's two Hong Kong properties, the J. W. Marriott (600 rooms) and the Ritz-Carlton (216) both report strong bookings through the third quarter, but say there are still rooms available. The Excelsior (874 rooms) and the Mandarin Oriental (480) have rooms available from about mid-July through the rest of the summer, which is Hong Kong's slowest tourist season. But unless the change in government makes visitors wary, business travelers and tourists are expected to flock back to Hong Kong in the fall, which vies with spring as the busiest season.

They Came From . . .
If you think Hong Kong will be crowded in early July, don't try to get a hotel room in Roswell, N.M., over the Fourth of July holiday. The city's permanent population of about 50,000 is expected to double over that three-day weekend -- the 50th anniversary of what many believe was the crash of a U.F.O. on a nearby ranch. While apparently no one saw the purported crash, it has spawned all sorts of theories, a television movie, network television features and an International U.F.O. Museum and Research Center at Roswell that in three and a half years has attracted 180,000 visitors, coming from all 50 states and 54 other countries.
A new brochure from the Roswell Convention and Visitors Bureau -- its margins covered with drawings of U.F.O.'s and comets hurtling toward earth -- shows a photograph of the purported crash site with three mysterious lights in the background, glimpsed through the window of a pickup truck. The tag line reads: "Roswell. Some of our most famous visitors . . . came from out of state."

Automatic Bills and Coins
More and more New York hotels are installing automated currency conversion machines in their lobbies. The machine in the Ramada Milford Plaza, a Broadway hotel where half the guests are foreigners, dispenses American bills and coins in exchange for Brazilian reals, British pounds, Canadian dollars, Dutch guilders, French francs, German marks, Israeli shekels, Italian lire, Japanese yen and Swiss francs. The exchange is at the daily interbank rate.
The 10 currencies accepted at the machine in the Novotel New York are the same as at the Milford Plaza except that it does not take shekels or reals but does take Spanish pesetas and Swedish kronor.

HEADLINE: A Disney Import Seeks Tonic for Club Med Losses

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 7

 BODY:
Philippe Bourguignon, the former head of Euro Disney, got a first-hand feel for Club Mediterranee since taking over as its new chief executive earlier this month, visiting two Club Med villages, and meeting in London with sales and marketing executives.
In February, Club Med's shareholders, led by the Agnelli family of Italy, whose primary holding company controls roughly 13 percent of Club Med shares, hired Mr. Bourguignon. They had lost patience with Serge Trigano, Club Med's chief executive since 1993 and a son of Gilbert Trigano, who helped develop the concept of vacation villages in the 1950's. With Mr. Bourguignon's arrival, the younger Mr. Trigano was given a largely ceremonial post as chairman. In October, Mr. Trigano came under fire after predicting a large profit for 1996, then reversing himself and instead announcing a $130 million loss -- the club's third loss in six years. 
 By last year, the number of Club Med guests had fallen to 1.4 million, compared with 1.8 million in 1989, the peak year for customers and revenue. All through the summer Club Med's share price sagged, reaching a low of 304.8 francs in November.
It may have seemed like a crisis brought about by European yuppies tiring of sunny holidays in artificial Polynesian villages resembling the ones Gauguin painted. But the challenges facing Mr. Bourguignon, 49, are more those of wide economic sluggishness, high unemployment and lack of the disposable income that enabled generations of Europeans to make Club Med -- "the antidote to civilization," as it trumpeted itself -- into a thriving vacation business.
With unemployment in France exceeding 12 percent, more than double the rate in the United States, Club Med's business is flagging in the country where it was founded almost a half-century ago, and which generates roughly a third of its business.
In Germany, another key market, poor salesmanship and an onslaught of clever imitators is hurting business. And in the United States, which in 1989 supplied 220,000 club guests, business is stagnant, hampered by ineffective marketing and club management that some Club Med executives feel became increasingly aloof and perhaps too French for American tastes.
All this has produced a wide gap between high fixed investment and costs and low returns at the company, only growing wider in the current economic climate.
"There is a failure to match supply and demand, and a cost control and organization that are simply not adequate," said Nigel Reed, an analyst with Paribas Capital Markets in London, who lowered Club Med shares from a buy rating to "fair value, no action" after the stock price reacted to the management shake-up by climbing to 451 francs.
[In Paris on Tuesday, Club Med shares closed unchanged at 433 francs. American depository receipts of Club Med, each representing one-fifth of a share, closed at $14.875, down 62.5 cents, on the Nasdaq bulletin board.]
Even before the management shift, Mr. Trigano had begun making efforts to get a grip on the vacation group's problems. After commissioning a study by Bain & Company, the Boston-based consultants, Club Med late last year announced a turnaround plan that involved closing or getting rid of 7 of its 114 properties, and upgrading the others in a $144 million refurbishing program.
To revive business from Americans, it hired Andrew Jordan, a former Coca-Cola marketing executive. Pricing policy has been overhauled to make Club Med vacations more affordable, and the renovation of existing villages has begun.
The injection of new blood with Mr. Bourguignon's arrival is expected to accelerate the process of turning the company around.
But he will have to press further to reduce operating costs, analysts say, and tackle the cultural differences that trouble Americans. Still, his success at resolving such problems at Euro Disney prompted Fraser Ramzan, an analyst with Lehman Brothers Securities in London, to give Club Med stock an outperform rating, meaning he expects the share price to outperform the market over the next year by 5 to 15 percent.
One reason analysts like Mr. Bourguignon is that he is no stranger to the group he took over. In years past, he vacationed at Club Med villages in Morocco with his wife and two children. While at Euro Disney, he kept abreast of Club Med doings through the occasional recruitment of club executives, including Michel Perchet, who now directs the cast members (like the people in the Mickey Mouse costumes) at Disneyland Paris, the theme park east of the French capital.
Indeed, as word of Club Med's travails spread last fall, Mr. Bourguignon even suggested that Disney acquire the group, though the idea was rejected by executives of the Walt Disney Company in California.
Many of the problems he faces at Club Med are similar to those he resolved at Disneyland Paris. In 1988, Mr. Bourguignon was hired by Disney from the French hotel group Accor. After the theme park -- then called Euro Disneyland -- had suffered heavy losses from 1992 through 1994, he was appointed chief executive and made responsible for returning it to profitability. He cut costs and prices drastically, recast the marketing concept and made subtle cultural adjustments to the way the park was run to make it more palatable to European tastes.
By last year, Mr. Bourguignon's methods had increased the number of visitors to 11.7 million, from 10.7 million in the previous fiscal year, driving up net income 77 percent, to $35.5 million.
Yet analysts say that in some ways the problems he faces at Club Med are far more complex than those he resolved at Disney. While Disneyland Paris represents a single site sought out by visitors, often with their own transportation, the problems at Club Med involve bringing guests from dozens of countries to sites scattered around the world. He has not yet said how he will tackle them, preferring to take time first to get to know the company and its employees firsthand.
Analysts also note that the group makes an attractive acquisition target. "It has an excellent brand name, villages around the globe in fabulous locations, and a product appreciated by countless millions of customers," Mr. Reed of Paribas said. "It's a prime takeover candidate."

HEADLINE: So Much Hot Air

BYLINE: By Gregg Easterbrook; Gregg Easterbrook, a contributing editor of The Atlantic Monthly, is the author of "A Moment on the Earth: The Coming Age of Environmental Optimism."

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
Bookkeeping gimmicks employed to simulate big reductions. Promises of a decisive decrease, but not until somebody else is in office. Borrowing against future generations. Sound like the old Reagan-era budget schemes? Actually, these statements describe the Clinton Administration's plan for curbing emissions of gases that may cause the greenhouse effect.
Not only is the Administration surprisingly irresolute on reducing emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases, but it is also missing a golden opportunity to advocate a reform that would help the environment and increase industrial efficiency: a tax on the burning of fossil fuels that would be offset by cuts in other corporate taxes. 
 A treaty signed by more than 150 countries in 1992 in Rio de Janiero committed them to reducing emissions that may cause artificial global warming. Two international summits in Kyoto, Japan, later this year will supposedly bring the agreement into force. But many countries hope to wriggle out of their commitments, and the United States is doing some of the most uninhibited wriggling.
In its proposal, recently submitted to the United Nations, the Administration has set laudable long-term goals for reducing worldwide emissions. The catch is that the plan would not have teeth until 2010 -- long after President Clinton has left office (even a two-term Gore Presidency could have ended).
For public relations purposes, the Administration is insisting that its proposal is "binding." But the plan is backed up by little more than an honor system. It is as if the White House said there will be a "binding" law against speeding, but that no tickets would be issued until 2010.
The Clinton proposal would even allow governments to appear to be making greenhouse progress by "borrowing" credits from future years -- claiming a decrease today through nothing more than a pledge to cut emissions in the distant future.
During the 1992 Presidential campaign, Al Gore repeatedly excoriated President George Bush for failing to support binding reductions in greenhouse gases by 2000. Now, apparently not wanting to upset industry, the Administration says that short-term greenhouse gas reductions would unnecessarily burden manufacturers. It has defined "short term" as anything before the year 2010.
If Vice President Gore really believed, as he once said, that the possibility of global warming is "the worst crisis our country has ever faced," why is the White House plan so meek?
The Administration plan does have a couple of good initiatives among its weaknesses. One is that companies would, as an alternative to cutting their own emissions, be able to buy greenhouse gas "credits" from other factories that cut their emissions to even lower levels than required. The model for this plan is a 1990 law that allows the trading of permits for emissions that produce acid rain. This has helped cut acid rain faster than expected and at about one-tenth the cost projected by the Bush Administration.
The White House plan would also allow corporations to gain credits for greenhouse gas emissions by helping to reduce pollution in fast-growing countries like China. American companies could then forgo expensive renovations of their relatively efficient factories in the United States by, say, paying for the modernization of hugely inefficient Chinese power plants. This would help cut overall global emissions while sending Western money and technology to other countries.
Still, the Clinton plan overlooks a far more effective incentive to reduce greenhouse gases: imposing a tax on the burning of fossil fuels. At the same time, other corporate taxes could be reduced. You can be a skeptic about whether dangerous global warming has been proved -- I certainly am -- and still support these carbon taxes.
Moderate taxes on the greenhouse emissions of power plants, factories and automobiles would create an incentive for improved energy efficiency, which is in the national interest regardless of whether the global temperature is rising, falling or doing nothing at all. A 1992 Bush Administration study found that greenhouse gases could be cut by up to 11 percent with no cost to the economy, considering the value of fuel savings.
A levy on the consumption of fossil fuels is attractive because it shifts the tax burden toward pollution, a negative, and away from capital and labor, which are positives. That is why more than 2,000 economists from across the political spectrum, including six Nobel laureates, signed a statement last month calling for carbon taxes as part of a system of tradeable permits for greenhouse emissions.
Carbon taxes would reward the efficient use of natural resources and cut greenhouse gas emissions without harming industry. Surely a President who cannot run again -- and a Vice President who believes global warming to be a serious threat -- could support such progressive goals.

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: Mexico Without Illusions

 BODY:
Congress and the Clinton Administration appear headed for a collision over Mexico. Just weeks before President Clinton is scheduled to visit Mexico, Congress is moving to override the Administration's disingenuous certification that its Government is fully cooperating in the fight against illegal drugs. A successful override would invite a diplomatic confrontation with Mexico. But the crisis would be worth enduring if it led Washington to a more realistic appreciation of Mexico's problems and of President Ernesto Zedillo's failure to address them with sufficient resolve.
The Administration invited a Congressional rebuff when it pretended all was well with Mexican drug enforcement. It acted immediately after a series of embarrassing incidents made plain that pervasive corruption in Mexico's police, military and ruling party has blunted drug enforcement and led Mexican officials to withhold vital information from American authorities. 
 Only days before the certification decision came word that Mexico's recently appointed drug enforcement chief had been arrested for corruption, and that news of his downfall had been kept secret for nearly two weeks.
Largely because of this breakdown of enforcement and cooperation, well over half the cocaine entering the United States now passes through Mexico. Mexico has become the principal conduit for South American cocaine as well as a supplier of homegrown marijuana and heroin.
Mexico already resents the idea of a Washington report card on its law enforcement efforts. The insult would be far greater if Mexico received a failing grade, even if the Administration, as it surely would, waived the economic penalties that decertification could bring. The annual drug certification review is not a useful process. But as long as it is required by law, Washington does best to tell the American people, and itself, the truth.
In Mexico's case, that truth is cause for considerable concern. The drug enforcement problems are symptomatic of a deeper crisis in Mexican political life.
The old regime, represented by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has used patronage networks and, on occasion, electoral fraud to monopolize Mexico's presidency and dominate its politics for nearly seven decades. It is now in deep disarray, unable to reform itself and unwilling to give way to a more democratic and accountable system. President Zedillo is a weak but decent leader, apparently too beholden to the PRI establishment to reform it.
He has failed, for example, to move aggressively to clean up the notoriously drug-corrupted Federal Judicial Police. Mr. Zedillo has instead relied on regular army generals who are themselves proving vulnerable to bribery and other abuses. New reports link army drug fighters to a series of mysterious kidnapping incidents. Mr. Zedillo has failed to challenge federal and state politicians whose failure to halt drug trafficking in their areas of jurisdiction suggests either active complicity or incompetence.
With a long common border and a wide array of common interests, the United States has compelling reasons to maintain constructive relations with Mexico. But such relations can only be based on an honest assessment of Mexican conditions, including the obvious problems now afflicting its drug enforcement programs.
Unless President Zedillo attacks these problems boldly by initiating a thorough housecleaning of corrupt officials, Congress should override Mexico's certification.

LENGTH: 1502 words

HEADLINE: 6 Years in the Plus Column for the U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The economic expansion of the 1990's, six years old this month, is displaying a resilience uncharacteristic of earlier periods of such sustained growth.
The pace of the economy -- surging in some months, faltering a bit in others -- has reached an annual growth rate of 4 percent in recent months, well above average. Unemployment has held below 5.5 percent for the better part of a year, an experience that in the 1970's and 1980's helped cause wages and prices to escalate. 
 Consumer spending remains strong, much of it on credit. Industrial production is on the upswing, advancing at nearly a 5 percent annual rate. And home construction and auto sales, two pillars of the economy, were strong last year, although they have tapered off slightly in recent weeks.
"The strength will last until the summer," predicted Edward Hyman, president and chief economist of the ISI Group, a Wall Street firm, offering a view that is fairly common among economic forecasters. Many expect that the economy will strengthen again by the fall, after the summer breather.
But so far none of this renewed strength has led to the shortages and inflation that prompted the Federal Reserve to bring down past expansions by raising interest rates high enough to starve the economy for credit. What makes this expansion different is that even in its strongest moments, including the surge this winter, inflation has remained quiescent, leaving the Fed with little provocation to act.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has acknowledged that this is a less inflationary expansion, in part because the Fed notched up interest rates in 1994. But he suggested in recent testimony that the Fed's policy makers might raise interest rates soon anyway, as a "pre-emptive strike" against some future inflation and, perhaps, to cool down the stock market. He noted, however, that any rate increase would most likely be modest.
There are several reasons the expansion of the 1990's has unfolded in a different fashion from those of the past.
Cheap and abundant imports have played a role. So have falling prices for computers, whose booming sales have helped to fuel growth, and health care costs are rising less rapidly.
Wages have remained remarkably restrained. That is, in part, a result of a sudden influx of people into the labor force -- some of them older workers, some immigrants, some women -- while the growing use of temporary and contract workers has relieved pressure to grant raises. And millions of Americans have helped the process in their willingness to trade job security for modest improvements in their wages.
The United States has had three long expansions in the last 35 years. In the 1960's, the economy grew without a recession for more than eight years. The expansion of the 1980's lasted nearly eight years. But six years into the 1980's expansion, when unemployment was as low as it is today, wages were already moving up steadily and prices were rising more than 4 percent a year to cover the higher wages. Even in the 1960's, the healthiest expansion on record, inflation started to rise after five years of growth.
But none of that is happening today, "mainly because tight labor markets don't lead so quickly to higher wages," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Still, there is bound to be a recession at the end of the rainbow. "The Fed controls the business cycle," Mr. Roach said. "And in the end, it will raise rates enough to bring on a recession." Or the Fed will raise rates, trying to hold back the economy, and then an outside shock -- an oil crisis or a stock market crash -- will cause the next recession.
That happened last time. With interest rates rising, the Persian Gulf crisis burst over the economy, bringing on the recession that started in July 1990.
Compress the American economy into a line on a chart and the last six years look like a gently undulating roller coaster, rising until late 1994, falling in 1995, rising again late last year, perhaps to level off once more later this year. The annual growth rate, in the best of these times, has approached 4 percent, and in the worst it has fallen to just above 1 percent. The average over the six years has been 2.6 percent, which is what many economists consider the limit of growth in this country that can be sustained without generating inflationary pressures.
But they are not as certain of this as they once were. The limits have clearly shifted in the 1990's, and corporate America offers endless anecdotal evidence of the change.
Larger-than-usual wage increases are evident among pockets of workers, but the pressure is not spreading. The Principal Financial Group, an insurance company in Des Moines, for example, is desperately short of computer programmers and systems analysts. Nearly 1,200 of its 8,000 workers in Des Moines hold these jobs. To lure enough new ones -- to a city where unemployment is less than 3 percent -- Principal starts college graduates who have the right skills at $34,000, plus relocation costs. That compares with $28,000 (and no extras for relocation) for college graduates without those skills. Raises for the programmers and systems analysts are 8 to 10 percent a year, or twice the raises for college-trained regular employees.
But none of the regulars are agitating for pay equity, as they might have done a decade or two ago, says Thomas Gaard, a senior vice president. The pay pressure remains in an enclosed group. "People understand there are market issues here," Mr. Gaard said. "There is all the analogy to sports stars."
Nationwide, nearly 13 million people, 10 percent of the work force, are temporary and contract workers, and companies often use them to cut labor costs. Consider Norrell Services Inc., a temporary-help agency based in Atlanta. It takes over telephone marketing operations at big companies, running the operations and supplying contract workers.
"These are housewives coming into the work force, college students, people who have jobs and want a second one," Bruce Reek, a Norrell executive, said. "They are maybe making $8 an hour on their job, and they add this one at $6.50." But as part of its standard deal with its client companies, Norrell agrees to achieve annual improvements in output per worker, and thus bill clients for fewer workers. Even if the efficiencies are not achieved, Mr. Reek said, the billing must be lowered as if they were.
Cheap and abundant imports give consumers and corporations easy alternatives to domestic production. Everywhere in the industrial and developing world, foreign businesses count on the United States to absorb their excess production, particularly Europe and Japan, where weak economies have depressed local demand.
The Eaton Corporation of Cleveland, a maker of auto parts and controls for household appliances, never knows when a client might defect, says Stephen R. Hardis, its chairman. "The appliance companies are selling to consumers on the basis of price, and you can lose their business any day," he said. "There are Europeans with extra capacity, and people in Asia trying to get a toehold, or domestic producers who lost business and are hungry."
Labor markets might seem tight, but they actually are not, according to the yardstick of Warren L. Batts, chairman of the Tupperware Corporation in Deerfield, Ill., which has 100,000 women selling its household wares on commission. "When the economy is really booming, when jobs are going unfilled all over the place," he said, Tupperware has difficulty recruiting these women. "But as long as the economy is growing at a modest rate, direct selling is an opportunity, and that is where we are now."
Other factors, peculiar to this expansion, have helped to hold down inflation. Medical insurance premiums paid by corporations have risen at a much slower pace, helping to contain overall labor costs. And one-quarter of the economic growth last year came from the production and sale of computers, whose prices were falling, according to David Wyss, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm. "Part of those sales were in the new hardware you had to buy to run Windows 95," he said. "Those sales are slowing now."
And help came last year from an unexpected quarter. The American labor force -- the total number of people employed or actively looking for work -- normally grows at just over 1 percent a year. An extra injection of workers means more output, and a more robust expansion without labor shortages. That happened last year, when the labor force grew by nearly 2 percent.
Immigrants accounted for some of the rise. In addition, the participation in the labor force of Americans between 55 and 64, particularly men, stopped falling. Indeed, it began to rise again in 1995. And women between 25 and 54, whose participation had risen until the early 1990's, then leveled off, are going to work in growing numbers again, drawn in, experts say, by the strong economy.

HEADLINE: MONEY AND POLITICS;
Excerpts From Clinton's Remarks on Political Reform

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's remarks today before the Conference on Free Television and Political Reform at the National Press Club, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:
We have to do some things to improve the way our political system works at election time, and the way it communicates, or its leaders communicate, to people all year-round. This should not be surprising to anyone. The Founding Fathers understood that we were an experiment. We're still around after all these years because we have relished the idea that we are an experiment, that America is a work in progress, that we're constantly in the making. We always have to change. 
 A lot of good things have happened to expand participation in the political system from the time we were a new nation, when only white male property owners can vote. And we have to make some more changes now. But if you look at the changes which have been made in the last 200 years, we should be hopeful.
Television has the power to expand the franchise or to shrink the franchise. Indeed, that is true of all means of communications and all media. We know that television is a profound and powerful force. We know that we don't fully understand all of its implications, even what you said, Walter, we don't really know what the connection is between television and a diminished voter turnout. It could be because there's a poll on television every night that tells people about the election, so some people think that there's no point in their voting, because the person they're for is going to win anyway or the person they're for can't win anyway. We need to think about that. . . .
It is now a commonplace, everybody will tell you, that campaigns cost too much and it takes too much time to raise the money, and the more money you raise from the larger number of people, the more questions will be raised about that. Major party committees spent over three times as much in this last election cycle as four years before, and that doesn't count the third-party expenditures, both the genuinely independent third-party committees and those that weren't really independent, although they claim to be. Spending in Congressional campaigns has risen sixfold in the last two decades. That's over three times the rate of inflation.
The biggest reason for this is the rise in the cost of television. But of course, there is also now more money being spent on mail, on telephoning, on radio, and other print advertising as well. In 1972 candidates spent $25 million for political ads; in 1996, $400 million. Presidential campaigns now routinely spend two-thirds or more of their money on paid ads; Senate candidates, 42 percent of their money on television; House races, about a third. Interestingly enough, that's often because there is no single television market which just overlaps the House district, and often the cost is prohibitive, particularly in the urban districts. But you get the drift. It's the same everywhere.
We are the only major democracy in the world where candidates have to raise larger and larger sums of money simply to communicate with voters through the medium that matters most. Every other major democracy offers candidates or parties free air time to speak to voters. And we can plainly do better, building on the big first step urged by this group in 1996.
We have an obligation to restore our campaign finance system to a system that has the broad confidence of the American people, but also of the American press that comments on it. In order to do that, television has to be part of the solution.
I have said before, and I will say again, everybody who has been involved in this system has to take responsibility for it and for changing it. Those of us in public life know better than anybody else what the demands of prevailing in the present system are, and those who control the airwaves understand it well also.
First and most fundamentally, I came here to support Senator McCain.
We have to take advantage of this year to pass campaign finance reform. The campaign finance laws are two decades out of date. They have been overtaken by events, by dramatic changes in the nature and costs of campaigns and the flood of money that has followed them. The money has been raised and spent in ways that simply could not have been imagined when the people who fashioned the last campaign finance law in Congress did it. . . .
What we have to argue is, yes, we really need to be up here doing the public's business. We need to be balancing the budget, improving education, reforming welfare, expanding health care coverage to children who don't have it, passing juvenile justice reform, the kinds of things that I'm passionately interested in.
But having the right kind of campaign finance reform system and having the right kind of straight talk on television, and having issues be more -- elections be more issue oriented, and having the debates of both sides heard clearly by all people, and increasing voter interest and voter turnout, all these things will increase the likelihood that this laundry list of good things will be done and will be done in better fashion than would otherwise be the case.
I think it is very important that those of you who care about this make this connection because that's how to build broad and deep support for this endeavor.
It seems to me that we do have an historic opportunity to pass campaign finance reform, and I think the public owes a lot of gratitude to Senator McCain and Senator Feingold and Congressman Shays and Congressman Meehan and all of their supporters for the legislation they have offered. It is real and tough. It would level the playing field and reduce the role of big money in politics. It would set voluntary limits on campaign spending and ban soft money, all corporate contributions and the very large individual ones. It would restrict the role of political action committees and lobbyists and make needed reforms within the confines of the Constitution as defined by existing Supreme Court case law.
In all these ways, it would set ceilings on money and politics. And just as important, it would also provide a floor -- and I think that is very important -- it would also provide a floor. You actually have some members in Congress who come from districts with a very low per-capita income, for example, who are very afraid of campaign finance reform because they're afraid among their own constituents they'll never be able to raise enough money in their district to compete the first time a multimillionaire runs against them.
So the law has to give a floor, and McCain-Feingold does that by giving candidates free air time to talk directly to the voters if they observe the spending limits of the law. And we need to emphasize that any ceiling law should have a floor to guarantee that people have their say and are heard. It gives candidates deeply discounted rates for the purchase of time if they observe the limits of the law. . . .
In my State of the Union Address, I asked Congress to pass the McCain-Feingold bill by July 4th, the day we celebrate the birth of our democracy. I pledge to you that I will continue to work with members of both parties to do this. I will be mustering more support out in the country, and that will be announced over the next few weeks, for this endeavor.
We have to use the present intense interest in this, as well as the controversy over fund-raising in the last election and all the publicity on it, as a spur to action. We cannot let it become what it is in danger of becoming, which is an excuse for inaction. And that again is something that I challenge all of you on. Do not let the controversy become an excuse to do nothing and to wallow around in it. Use it as a spur to changing the system because, until you change the system, you will continue to have controversies over the amount -- the sheer amount of money that is raised in these elections. . . .
I believe broadcasters who receive digital licenses should provide free air time for candidates, and I believe the F.C.C. should act to require free air time for candidates.
The telecommunications revolution can help to transform our system so that, once again, voters have the loudest voice in our democracy. Free time for candidates can help free our democracy from the grip of big money. I hope all of you will support that.
There are many ways that this could be done. Many of you here have put forward innovative plans. I believe that free time should be available to all qualified Federal candidates. I believe it should give candidates a chance to talk directly to the voters, without gimmicks or intermediaries.
Because campaign finance reform is so important, I believe it should be available especially to candidates who limit their own spending. It is clear under the Supreme Court decision that this can be done, and I believe that is how it should be done.
Candidates should be able to talk to voters based on the strength of their ideas, not the size of their pocketbooks. And all voters should know that no candidate is kept from running simply because he or she cannot raise enormous amounts of funds.
Last month the Vice President announced that we would create an independent advisory committee of experts, industry representatives, public-interest advocates, and others to recommend what steps to take. Before I came over here today, I signed an executive order creating that committee. The balanced panel I will appoint will advise me on ways we can move forward and make a judgment as to what the new public-interest obligations of broadcasters might be. But today, let us simply agree on the basic premise. In 1997, for broadcasters, serving the public should mean enhancing our democracy. . .
We know, we know, when we work to expand our democracy, when you give people a greater voice and advocates of all political views a firm platform upon which to stand, we are moving forward as a nation. By passing campaign finance reform, by renewing the compact between broadcasters and the public to better serve in this new era, we can do that again.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Economic Plan for Capital

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
President Clinton today unveiled details of his redevelopment plan for the nation's capital, a strategy focused on tax breaks for businesses, rather than individuals.
The major tax components of the Administration plan include $95 million in tax credits for investors and lenders to District of Columbia businesses, a 40 percent tax credit on the first $10,000 of wages in the first year of employment and a deduction of up to $20,000 a year for certain equipment costs for small businesses. 
 As part of the Administration's overall plan to revitalize the District, announced in January, the economic package includes the creation of an Economic Development Corporation to coordinate projects, issue bonds and keep track of $285 million in new Federal money for tax credits and tax incentives.
That money, Mr. Clinton said, would stop erosion of Washington's tax base and create programs that could be models for other distressed cities.
"Our challenge," Mr. Clinton said, "is to revitalize the city as the nation's capital, to improve the prospects of self-government to succeed, and to make it a place where people really want to live, to work, to do business."
The Administration plan does not cut the Federal income tax for the District's residents, a recovery strategy favored by many Congressional Republicans and the District's non-voting delegate to Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton, a Democrat. Ms. Norton has introduced legislation that would cap Federal income tax for city residents at 15 percent, and some Republican lawmakers have predicted that a tax cut will probably be in the recovery package that clears Congress.
The proposals that Mr. Clinton outlined today will not necessarily be part of that final package.
While praising the President's efforts as "adding value" to efforts to solve District problems, Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, the Virginia Republican who heads the District subcommittee of the House Government Reform and Oversight Committee, said the tax breaks would prove beneficial only if the city also succeeded in driving down crime rates, improving public schools and simplifying business regulations.
Peter Hans, a spokesman for Senator Lauch Faircloth, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that oversees the District, said that Mr. Faircloth had not seen the details of Mr. Clinton's proposal but that he favored "management reform first for the District before throwing good money after bad."
