HEADLINE: Global Banks Offer a First: Forgiveness On Some Debt

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
In an effort to reduce the debt burden troubling some of the world's poorest nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund will act soon to forgive some of the loans they have made to Uganda.
Uganda will be the first of about 20 countries that may be released from the obligation to repay, which forces developing countries into austerity measures that they say not only impede their efforts to rise out of poverty but also cause resentment among their citizens. 
 The bank's board approved Uganda's participation in the program on Monday, and the fund's board is expected to take similar action on Wednesday. Both institutions said they expected a final agreement to be negotiated with Uganda by next month to cut as much as $300 million from the nation's international debts of $3.4 billion.
The bank and the fund adopted the program in broad terms last fall, opening it only to nations that have achieved strong records of economic improvement despite suffering from crippling poverty.
The program's goal is to make economic growth more sustainable while bringing under control the fiscal cycle that sees international lenders pour more and more money into third-world economies and immediately take much of it back out again to pay for old loans.
The program's focus is on Africa, although some South American and Asian countries are also likely to get some relief. The bank and the fund will begin considering applications from Bolivia, Burkina Faso and possibly the Ivory Coast within the next few weeks, with approval likely by May or June, officials said.
Other countries will come up for consideration over the next year as the bank and the fund gain more experience and coordinate their efforts with other institutions like the African Development Bank and with individual creditor nations that are negotiating debt relief packages. Countries like Zaire that are undergoing civil war or other chaotic situations will not be considered until they achieve political and economic stability, officials said.
"The debt initiative is a cornerstone of our efforts on Africa," said David Lipton, the Clinton Administration's Assistant Treasury Secretary for International Affairs. "If we are helping them to reform, we have to be sure they aren't doomed by debt burdens."
Mr. Lipton said the United States was developing other international efforts to help Africa economically, and hoped to have them ready for the meeting in June of leaders of seven leading industrial nations in Denver. He declined to say what they were.
Independent poverty-relief organizations have long pressed the bank and the fund to write off some of their debts to poor nations. But the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which together play a dominant role in the economic affairs of most developing nations, insisted for years on strict fiscal rectitude, requiring countries to meet all of their financial responsibilities, including burdensome debt payments, in order to qualify for more aid.
But with poverty proving intractable in Africa and some other parts of the world the bank and the fund have significantly changed their approaches in the last several years.
They are now giving more weight to assuring a nation's long-term economic viability, in part through increased expenditures on education, health and other social needs.
Uganda was selected as the first beneficiary because it has undertaken stringent economic reforms prescribed by the bank and the fund, but nonetheless faces long-term financial problems, officials said.
Since coming to power 11 years ago after a civil war, President Yoweri Museveni has brought inflation and the Government's budget deficit under control, and restored economic growth based largely on exports of coffee. As the economy has stabilized, the Government has turned to improving social conditions, and by indicators like infant mortality has had some success, World Bank officials said.
Richard Kabonero, the economic affairs counsel at the Ugandan Embassy in Washington, said the savings from the debt relief program had been pledged to help finance a push to make primary education available to all families in Uganda and to improve health care.
"The debt relief initiative is extremely important to Uganda, and it could not have come at a better time," Mr. Kabonero said.
Last year, Uganda's total debt payments were $154 million, of which more than half went to international financial institutions, primarily the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, according to the fund.
The debt payments nearly equaled the nation's spending last year on education and health of $175 million, the fund said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Expands Protection For Contract Farm Labor

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Officials of the Labor Department announced new rules yesterday to increase protection for hundreds of thousands of farm workers by making it harder for farmers to avoid liability for violations of laws on wages and sanitation committed by contractors who supervise the farmers' employees.
The Government adopted the rules, which are opposed by growers, after farm workers groups complained that contractors who hire and manage workers for thousands of farms are often shadowy operators who fail to pay minimum wages or provide clean drinking water. 
 Farm workers groups assert that contractors have long had scant incentive to obey the law because they have often escaped financial penalties by arguing that they have no assets.
These groups also assert that farmers had little reason to make their contractors comply with the law because farmers often avoided responsibility by persuading courts that they were not the employers.
Federal officials estimated that 700,000 to a million of the nation's 2.5 million farm laborers, many migrant or seasonal employees, work for contractors. Contractors often recruit workers, hire and fire them, check alien work permits and drive workers to the fields.
Under the new rules, farmers who use labor contractors will more often be defined as joint employers, meaning that workers who have not been paid the minimum wage by contractors can demand payment from the farmers, who have deeper pockets than contractors.
"Contractors are directly responsible for many of the abuses the laborers endure," Marc Grossman, a spokesman for the United Farm Workers, said. "Growers basically use labor contractors as a legal fiction to avoid their legal and moral responsibilities."
By making farmers liable more often for contractors' violations, Labor Department officials say they hope to pressure farmers to do more to insure that contractors comply with laws on minimum wages, overtime, child labor and providing drinking water and toilets.
"We think these rules will improve the level of compliance in terms of farm workers' rights," John R. Fraser, acting administrator of the Labor Department's wage and hour division, said. "Farm workers in this country are among the most vulnerable, the most exploitable, the worst- paid workers."
The United Farm Workers had sought strict liability that would automatically make growers jointly liable for violations by their labor contractors. Although the new rules do not create strict liability -- they instead call for deciding joint liability case by case -- farm workers groups applauded the regulations.
But farm employers denounced them. "We don't see any instances where these rules will not hold a grower automatically liable," Sharon Hughes, executive vice president of the National Council of Agricultural Employers, said. "They're basically saying the grower is the guarantor of the wages that independent contractors pay their employees."
Bryan Little, director of government relations for the American Farm Bureau Federation, said the rules would not make it economically viable for farmers to use contractors, even though farmers often need them to recruit workers.
"Every other industry seems to have the ability to use labor contractors, but the Department of Labor doesn't think we should," he said.
The rules establish new criteria for government agencies and courts to weigh in determining whether farmers should be held jointly liable.
The old regulations provided for a control test: does the contractor or farmer hire and supervise workers? Under that test, courts usually found that farmers were not liable.
The new rules establish a more expansive control test, telling agencies and courts to also look at who writes the paychecks, controls wage levels and pays Social Security and workers' compensation. Other factors the new rules say must be weighed are whether a contractor's workers are "integral" to a farmer's operations and whether a contractor's employees work for one farmer or many farmers.
The new rules take effect in 30 days.

HEADLINE: U.S. Negotiating With Germany To Avoid C.I.A. Man's Expulsion

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
American and German officials are negotiating over the fate of an American intelligence officer whom Germany has scheduled for expulsion, officials of both countries said today.
The officer has not yet been expelled, as originally reported by the German newsmagazine Der Spiegel, and if the discussions go well, he may be allowed to return from vacation to finish his regular tour of duty, the officials said. They said his tour was to end soon in any case. 
 American officials said the American officer of the Central Intelligence Agency was not engaged in industrial or economic espionage or espionage aimed at Germany, as Der Spiegel reported, but was gathering information about third countries, which they did not identify.
Germany has numerous business and diplomatic contacts with countries about which Washington seeks information and wants to ostracize diplomatically, like Iran, Iraq and Libya.
American officials said the German Government had made no formal complaint to the American Government about the intelligence officer or his activities, but was using him to send "a blunt post-cold-war message" about keeping Bonn informed of American intelligence operations within its borders and reducing the numbers of American intelligence officers in Germany.
One German official reached by telephone today said that "this does not seem to be the first such case" of German complaints about American intelligence officers and that "the number of people doing such work for the United States in Germany remains very high," especially now that the Soviet Union has collapsed and Germany is reunited.
German officials said the role of Germany as an American outpost and ideological frontier, where East and West spied on each other and no one felt compelled to inform the German authorities, was now outdated.
The Americans have reduced the number of intelligence officers in the last few years, but not as much as Bonn would like. And the Germans have asked for more sharing of information, a request the Americans have responded to only in part. American officials said the C.I.A. was doing business in Germany much as it has done since 1945, while Bonn was demanding recognition of its new status as a closely allied democratic country that is a bedrock of the new Europe.
The officer was doing his regular "cover job" at the embassy in a normal way, and some say he is being used as an example by the Germans because he was near the end of his tour. The officer, who was not identified, was said to be out of the country on vacation when Der Spiegel released the text of its article on Saturday.
If the negotiations do not go well, an American official said, the officer will not return and his belongings will be packed for him.
Some officials cautioned that the C.I.A. was eager not to embarrass itself any further, especially while rancorous hearings are going on before the Senate Intelligence Committee on the nomination of Anthony Lake as Director of Central Intelligence.
While the third countries the intelligence officer was studying were not identified, Germany is regarded as a center for American intelligence-gathering on the so-called "rogue states" of the Middle East and North Africa.
The Germans are among the main proponents within the European Union of "constructive engagement" with Iran, while Washington has argued strenuously that it is a supporter of terrorism beyond its borders and is trying to develop weapons of mass destruction, and thus should be isolated.
German companies were prime suppliers of goods used by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to build up his armed forces and stocks of chemical and biological weapons before the gulf war, American officials point out.

HEADLINE: Rep. Flake Breaks With Party to Back School Vouchers

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Representative Floyd H. Flake of Queens is breaking with fellow Democrats to add his name as a sponsor of a Republican bill that would provide vouchers for children to attend private schools if they choose.
Mr. Flake's decision to co-sponsor the American Community Renewal Act, along with Representatives J. C. Watts of Oklahoma and James M. Talent of Missouri, is the culmination of a yearlong courtship by Republican officials. Mr. Flake decided to co-sponsor the bill after discussions two weeks ago with Republican leaders, including Speaker Newt Gingrich and the majority leader, Dick Armey, Mr. Flake's aides said. 
 In adding his name as a sponsor of the bill, which would also provide tax incentives to inner-city neighborhoods, Mr. Flake is taking a position that placed him squarely at odds with a number of his Democratic colleagues, including his fellow members of the Congressional Black Caucus, who have ardently opposed using public money to help students attend private schools.
Mr. Flake, a six-term incumbent, is also the pastor of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church, a sprawling congregation that operates a private school and whose development arm has built large housing complexes in St. Albans, Queens.
Mr. Flake has long been critical of black elected officials and religious leaders, complaining that many of them are too dependent on government-financed social programs.
"The Congressman supports the bill because the poorer communities of America need a new model for rehabilitation, economically and educationally," said Dwayne Andrews, a spokesman for Mr. Flake.
"And the tax-based incentives and the school-choice help to enable communities to revitalize themselves," Mr. Andrews said. "Students in poorer communities should be able to get the same quality education that students in better-off communities do."
Mr. Flake could not be reached for comment yesterday. He was attending a funeral for one of the four children killed last week when a tree fell on their school bus on the way to the Allen Christian School, which is associated with Mr. Flake's church.
In his years in Congress, Mr. Flake has been successful at funneling Federal money to his district. His admirers and critics agree that much of Mr. Flake's success results from his willingness to befriend powerful Republicans. Prominent among his Republican allies is Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who once encouraged him to run for mayor.
Congresswoman Maxine Waters, a California Democrat who is head of the Congressional Black Caucus, said that Mr. Flake's position would create no strain within the caucus.
"We are not monolithic," she said. "We have divergent views on a lot of issues, from the balanced budget amendment to freedom of choice. This is simply an area where Floyd Flake has made a decision about what is in the interest of the people he represents."
The proposed measure represents an effort by House Republicans to pass an agenda aimed at solving some of the problems of large, urban areas, where the party has traditionally had little support. It includes a number of tax incentives, like the elimination of capital gains taxes for the sale of businesses held for more than five years.

HEADLINE: Friends Helped Labor Nominee Move Up, Then Almost Brought Her Down

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Nobody doesn't like Alexis Herman.
Ask childhood friends about President Clinton's choice to be the next Secretary of Labor, and they recall how the tough-minded black youngster from Mobile, Ala., faced down a Catholic prelate over racial discrimination. An admirer remembers when she lent her good dresses in the 1970's to black women interviewing for office jobs. Democrats marvel over her management of the party's 1992 convention, the one that helped pump up Bill Clinton's support in polls by 20 percentage points. 
 She has been known to give presents to co-workers after tough workweeks. One man who has known her for years says she briefly considered becoming a nun.
"People who like her really like her," says Lamond Godwin, who grew up across the street from Ms. Herman in the 1950's. "Most of the people she meets who become her friends remain her friends forever."
Which, lately, is her biggest problem.
The Senate Labor Committee investigated Ms. Herman for two and a half months before scheduling a hearing on her nomination for next Tuesday. The delay had less to do with her resume, a Horatio Alger story of pluck and hard work, than with the friends -- powerful, sometimes controversial Democrats -- she made on the way up.
Ms. Herman's confirmation now seems likely, but questions about those relationships had threatened her nomination and angered her supporters.
"Alexis is not somebody who's along for the ride," said Ricki Seidman, a White House aide during Ms. Herman's recent tenure as the Presidential liaison to business and the public. "She's a highly principled person."
Few dispute that. But the story of Ms. Herman's rise to influence, so intertwined with powerful friends, suggests how delicate the balance between politics and principle can be.
 
Religion and Politics Side by Side
Associates of Ms. Herman, 49, whom the White House declined to make available for an interview with her confirmation hearings coming up, describe a woman who learned early that skin color need not determine success.
Alexis M. Herman grew up in Mobile when white resistance to integration was peaking and Southern blacks were awakening to their political power. Her mother was a reading teacher. Her father, a mortician, was one of the first blacks elected to Alabama's Democratic Party organization, as a wardsman. Friends recall watching national political conventions in the Herman living room, her father providing commentary.
Religion most shaped Ms. Herman's youth. Her Roman Catholic parents shunned segregated state education and enrolled her in parochial schools -- still segregated, but employing white priests and nuns whose tutoring was colorblind.
"The nuns and the priests kept us from becoming racists," Mr. Godwin said. "The best people we knew were white -- people we spent the whole day with, who were the best examples of moral behavior. We had the Klan bombing churches, but we had these people on our side. It made it easy to understand that the problem was not us; the problem was the Klan."
It also enabled Ms. Herman to challenge racism. She once sneaked away from classmates at a school event, the annual Christ the King parade, to demand that a church official explain why black students never performed the celebration's symbolic highlight, crowning the Virgin Mary.
Ms. Herman's father once took her high school class on an unusual field trip: to a meeting of the Alabama Citizens Council, the front for the Ku Klux Klan.
"They started throwing things at us, popcorn boxes, cans, whatever," said Paulette Lewis, a classmate and still a close friend. " This is the kind of upbringing we had."
Most Pure Heart of Mary High School, where Ms. Herman was a class officer, produced extraordinary alumni in Ms. Herman's era: a Marine general and ambassador; an adviser to President Ronald Reagan; doctors; investment bankers like Mr. Godwin, a managing director of Smith Barney Inc.
Ms. Herman graduated from a Catholic university -- Xavier University of Louisiana, in New Orleans -- and returned to Mobile. She joined Catholic Charities in nearby Pascagoula, Miss., lobbying the city shipyard to give apprenticeships to unskilled black laborers.
 
Forging Friendships With the Influential
She was good at it, blessed with self-confidence and an ability to bridge gaps between blacks and whites. Mr. Godwin, then working on minority-employment programs for the Southern Regional Council, touted her to Ray Marshall, a member of the council's executive committee. Mr. Marshall brought her to Atlanta to work on a project to persuade corporations to hire college-educated black women for office jobs that had been filled exclusively by whites.
"I was amazed," Mr. Marshall said recently. "She did a better job than I would have."
Using a Federal grant, Mr. Marshall expanded Ms. Herman's project and merged it with a New York City nonprofit group, the Recruitment and Training Program. Working there was another Southerner, who had impressed Mr. Marshall on a project to integrate the construction industry. His name was Ernest G. Green.
Mr. Green was already well known. When Federal troops forcibly integrated schools in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957, Mr. Green was among the first black students escorted into Central High. His coolness had made him something of a civil rights icon. He and Ms. Herman became fast friends.
Mr. Marshall and Mr. Godwin, meanwhile, had moved on to run a task force on the rural South whose directors included Georgia's Governor, Jimmy Carter. "We were having dinner at the initial meeting of the task force," Mr. Godwin said, "and Governor Carter said he was thinking about running for President. This was 1974. At the time, we all thought it was far-fetched."
But President Carter chose Mr. Marshall as his Secretary of Labor. Mr. Marshall named Mr. Green an assistant secretary, Mr. Godwin his head of national employment programs and Ms. Herman director of the women's bureau.
Mr. Godwin, who sketched out Ms. Herman's life in politics, said the three administered billions of dollars in grants much like those they had once received, and although Ms. Herman did not dispense money, she became a top adviser to Mr. Green and Mr. Marshall.
They also became political figures, if minor ones. Ms. Herman had worked on the Atlanta mayoral campaigns of Maynard H. Jackson and Andrew Young. She was also an early supporter of Marion S. Barry Jr., and came to know Ronald H. Brown, a National Urban League executive and Democratic Party figure.
At a 1980 testimonial dinner in Mobile, she met another rising political figure: the Rev. Jesse Jackson, then the head of Operation PUSH, the group that targeted companies with poor minority-employment practices.
After Mr. Carter lost the 1980 election, Mr. Green and Mr. Herman formed a firm that advised businesses on marketing and minority-hiring issues.
Within months, Republican critics accused Mr. Green of shoveling almost 300 Federal contracts and grants to cronies in the last months of Mr. Carter's term, including contracts to the Recruitment and Training Program and Operation PUSH. They also accused Green-Herman & Associates, the new consulting firm, of cashing in by obtaining subcontracts from some of those same cronies.
The Labor Department, the Senate and a United State Attorney's office all investigated. Though some Federal employees testified to irregularities, others called the complaints trumped up. No charges were filed. Mr. Godwin and Mr. Marshall, who now holds an endowed chair in economics and public affairs at the University of Texas, call the affair a political smear.
In fact, friends of Ms. Herman and Mr. Green now say, Green-Herman & Associates did benefit later from Jesse Jackson, who sometimes recommended their consulting firm to companies targeted by Operation PUSH. But that, they say, reflected not favor-trading but Mr. Jackson's growing friendship with the two and his confidence in their firm.
 
Building a Machine As Fortunes Rise
Ms. Herman's political and financial fortunes rose in tandem. In 1982, she supported Mr. Barry's re-election campaign for mayor of Washington. In 1984, she worked for Mr. Jackson's Presidential campaign. About the same time, the developer of a Pennsylvania Avenue tract near the Capitol made Ms. Herman a partner, giving her 3.3 percent of an office-and-condominium complex for little or no money.
Then and now, such sweetheart deals are a common way of satisfying the affirmative-action demands of government boards that hand out contracts. Ms. Herman later sold part of her share and recently valued the remainder at $500,000 to $1 million.
Mr. Green sold his interest in the consulting firm to Ms. Herman in the mid-1980's and entered investment banking. In 1988, Ms. Herman joined Mr. Jackson's second Presidential campaign and found herself working with Mr. Brown, by now a prominent lawyer and lobbyist who was organizing Mr. Jackson's convention.
George Bush's triumph in 1988 left the Democratic alliance in tatters. Mr. Brown sought the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee, and won. Ms. Herman became his deputy and, in 1992, the organizer of the party's national convention.
Together, they built an impressive financial and political machine. Just as in Pascagoula and Atlanta, Ms. Herman's deftness at organizing blacks, whites, rich and poor around a common purpose stood out.
She and Mr. Brown also came under attack for what U.S. News and World Report called the lavish use of perks like limousines, private jets and a Central Park apartment rented during planning for the 1992 convention, held in New York City.
To some others' dismay, Ms. Herman continued to run her consulting firm while running Democratic politics. In one case, her firm was paid $600,000 to advise the winning bidder for a $750 million Federal office project near the White House, a plum fought over at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue. Critics later complained that she acted as a political fixer in the competition, an accusation the White House has denied.
When Mr. Clinton became President, Mr. Brown became Commerce Secretary. Ms. Herman went to the White House as head of the office of public liaison -- in effect, the grass-roots organizer of support for Administration policies.
The job was ostensibly nonpolitical, but by its nature, it has almost inevitably taken on a political cast. This time, that was doubly true: the office helped draft Mr. Clinton's plans to win over ethnic groups in his 1996 campaign. Ms. Herman's deputy ran a group that targeted Asian-Americans. Another aide worked on wooing the Jewish vote.
Among other campaign duties, Ms. Herman supervised the strategy to win black voters. Her second in command was an old friend, Mr. Green, who by then was a friend of the President's, too -- and one of the Democratic Party's biggest soft-money fund-raisers. He also promoted business deals, including ventures with another Arkansan and Presidential friend, Charles Yah Ling Trie.
All those roles converged in the 1996 campaign. Mr. Green appeared at some of the now-infamous White House coffees with major party donors. In February 1996, he and Mr. Trie arrange for attendance at one coffee by one of their business prospects, Wan Jung, an executive in an arms-export business identified as a weapons smuggling front for the Chinese military.
Ms. Herman also attended some coffees; her office invited a Federal banking regulator to one such session, attended by big donors from the banking industry.
Ms. Herman has insisted that she played no part in that invitation, and that her work for Mr. Clinton's re-election was properly performed on personal time.
Senate investigators have since reviewed that and the rest of Ms. Herman's past. After long thought, they seem agreed that nothing there bars her confirmation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alexis M. Herman, the nominee for Secretary of Labor, is known for being well liked by enduring friends. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: At Top School for Gifted, I.Q. Test Is Still the First Measure

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
The I.Q. test, the tool that the New York City Schools Chancellor wants public schools to abandon as the primary measure of a child's eligibility for gifted and talented programs, remains firmly in place at the city's most acclaimed school for academically gifted students.
Hunter College Elementary School, which is publicly financed but administered by Hunter College, a part of the City University system, rather than the Board of Education, relies on the I.Q. test to screen out the majority of its huge pool of 4- and 5-year-old applicants. Those with the highest I.Q.'s are then evaluated based on factors like problem-solving and creative thinking. 
 Hunter administrators readily acknowledge that I.Q. tests cannot adequately measure the "giftedness" of every child, but they say that given the school's focus on academic excellence and the tough competition for its 48 spaces each year -- only one out of 25 applicants gets in -- they need an empirical way to winnow the applicant pool. The I.Q. test has proven a reliable first standard at Hunter despite its acknowledged limitations, officials say.
"I've said to myself, 'Is there a better method?' " said Polly Smith Breland, director of admissions. "I don't think there is a better method right now."
Over the last two decades, research has shown the I.Q. test to be a good gauge for some children, but not all. Many students from poor or immigrant backgrounds do not score as high as children from middle-class backgrounds and native speakers of English. Children are more likely to do well when their parents read to them frequently, expose them to large vocabularies and take them to stimulating places like museums.
As a model for gifted programs across the country and a center of research on teaching gifted students, what happens at Hunter can have reverberations nationally. Hunter's continuing use of I.Q. testing even though administrators recognize its flaws underlines the complexity of assessing children for gifted programs, with their limited spaces and promise of challenging, high-caliber instruction, which, in turn, can lead to greater college and career opportunities.
These concerns are especially sharp in urban school districts, where public schools try to insure equal opportunities for immigrants and underprivileged children, while not neglecting the needs of middle-class families. Citing such concerns two weeks ago, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said he wanted to reduce the reliance on I.Q., or intelligence quotient, scores in choosing students for gifted programs. Many public schools now use the I.Q. test as Hunter does -- as a first hurdle children have to clear before they can be evaluated in other ways.
"I think there are lots of children, children of color, children whose first language is not English, who don't necessarily get access to this," Dr. Crew said. "I think that there have been any number of those kinds of tests that have never really, in my judgment, been the determinant of true giftedness."
Hunter officials say they are sensitive to the issue of which students they might be excluding. The school, long a national model for other gifted programs, tries to choose an ethnically diverse group from the children who score high on the I.Q. test -- This year the minimum was 132 points.
Officials say they are also trying to broaden the range of children who apply, to increase the odds that more children from disadvantaged backgrounds will qualify for admission; the school charges no tuition.
Still, the school stands by the I.Q. test -- it uses the Stanford-Binet 4. Hunter officials say there are few ways of quantifying the skills of very young children, who lack the report cards, teacher evaluations and test results of older students. They add that many parents can accept rejection based on a test score more readily than rejection based on more subjective evaluations.
Administrators note that unlike some other gifted programs, which may test for leadership qualities, artistic talent or spatial skills, Hunter's curriculum is based on academic excellence only.
"We believe that there are a lot more gifted children than we can admit," said Dr. Rena F. Subotnik, a Hunter College professor and a consultant to the elementary and high schools. "Our school is a school for academically gifted kids. Throwing all different kinds of talents together isn't always the best thing to do."
Even strong critics of the I.Q. test are not demanding that Hunter change. They say Hunter's system may be valid and even necessary, given the small number of spaces, the type of program and the extraordinary competition.
Rather, some say the flood of applicants to Hunter reflects a scarcity of opportunities for many of the city's gifted and talented children in the public school system. And they say that unlike Hunter, the public school system should be obligated to serve the needs of children with many kinds of talents.
"I think there is a space and place for something like Hunter," said Dr. Joseph S. Renzulli, the director of the federally funded National Research Center on the Gifted and Talented who believes in screening for characteristics like creativity and a child's motivation on specific tasks. "But we need to have a place for high-end learning in every school."
Dr. Crew said he wants more gifted programs and wants districts to use multiple measures of giftedness, measures he has not yet specified, but which could include I.Q.
Hunter College elementary and high school programs, located on the Upper East Side, offer everything from intensive chess to a mathematics laboratory. Five-year-olds can research independent projects on subjects like Italian Renaissance art and pharmacology.
Children are admitted to the elementary school only in nursery school and kindergarten, and only if they live in Manhattan. The high school automatically accepts Hunter elementary school children but fills the remaining 200 spaces through a competitive admissions process for sixth graders in all five boroughs who do well on citywide math and reading tests and Hunter's entrance exam.
The I.Q. test is used only to screen elementary school applicants, who must first score in the 97th or 98th percentile on the national I.Q. rating system. In the most recent round, 1,183 applicants took the I.Q. test and 305 made the 98th percentile I.Q. cut-off, a score of about 132.
The finalists are invited to Round 2, where, in groups of eight, they are evaluated on how they solve problems, think creatively, learn tasks and respond to complex directions.
In picking the final 48 students, Hunter officials say they strive for diversity. They say they do not use a formula, except to make sure that they choose an equal number of boys and girls, and the selection committee does not see the applicants' names.
Officials say that once they decide which applicants performed the best in Round 2, they try to choose children from different racial and ethnic backgrounds. They say they may sometimes select a child who is several months younger than the others because they are impressed by the child's precociousness.
And they may also factor in whether the child has a physical disability or whether the child comes from a poor household, as measured by whether the family's income was low enough to qualify for a waiver of Hunter's $165 test and application fee.
Of those chosen for next September's classes, 26 are white, 9 are black, 4 are Asian, 5 are Hispanic and 4 are listed by their parents as "other." Only one is from a low-income family. This year, 67 of the 1,183 applicants received a waiver for the application and test fees, and of them, only two made the I.Q. cut-off.
Dr. Anthony D. Miserandino, the director of both the Hunter elementary school and the high school, said: "Clearly, people who have income are going to be able to expose children to more opportunities, whether it is a trip to the museum or a computer in your home. To the degree to which economics and the educational background of parents are tied to race, you're going to see outcomes that reflect that."
Ms. Smith Breland, the director of admissions, who is black and attended Hunter College High School in the 1960's, said Hunter's admissions pool necessarily reflects the "problems around race and ethnicity in this city."
"I don't think you can divorce those problems and how children are raised in this city from how children are going to do," she said.
One of Dr. Crew's concerns is that students from poor families, many of them immigrants, are unaware of gifted and talented programs. Hunter officials say they have been trying to expand their pool of applicants by advertising on radio and visiting or sending fliers to churches, libraries, day care centers and Head Start programs in low-income Manhattan neighborhoods. Last fall, they held weekend classes for children and parents from an East Harlem day care center.
Ms. Smith Breland said that when she or her staff recruit, they try to suggest low-cost ways people can enrich their children's education.
"We tell them that 'When your child asks a lot of questions, that's not just annoying, it's good,' " Ms. Smith Breland said. "Or when you talk to your child, point out the colors in the room and different shapes. That may not help them for Hunter right away, but maybe three or four years from now."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
King and Israeli Leader Exchange Forceful Letters
King Hussein of Jordan wrote Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu a personal and forceful letter saying that he could not continue as the Israeli's partner and friend. The King accused Mr. Netanyahu of decisions amounting to continued deliberate humiliation of the Palestinians. In a sharp reply, Mr. Netanyahu countered that he was reviving, not killing, the peace efforts. A1 

Mr. Netanyahu sought a reprieve from the political fire at home in Moscow, where he was making his first state visit to Russia. The trip focused on improving economic ties and courting Russia's newly assertive Jewish community. A8
 
Reducing Poor Nations' Debts
The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund will soon forgive some loans made to about 20 of the poorest nations, beginning with Uganda, in an effort to reduce the debt burden plaguing them. The agencies said they expected to slash as much as $300 million from Uganda's international debts of $3.4 billion. Uganda is the first country to be considered for the program. A5
 
Rebels Gain in Albania
More towns in southern Albania fell to anti-government rebels. In Kucove, about 60 miles south of the capital, Tirana, armed local people captured an air base and more than a dozen MIG fighter jets. As the turmoil sped closer to Tirana, the Embassy of Italy -- an ally of Albania's President -- evacuated nonessential staff, as did France and Germany. A10
 
French AIDS Charges Fizzle
France's top prosecutor recommended dropping charges against a former Prime Minister and two other officials in the infection of 1,300 French hemophiliacs with AIDS-tainted blood products in 1985. The prosecutor cited a lack of evidence. The scandal broke in 1990 with revelations that health officials had used blood supplies known to be contaminated with the AIDS virus rather than purchase American technology to treat or test the blood. (AP)
 
Iraq Aid Plan Delayed
A draft United Nations report said humanitarian aid to Iraqis was unlikely to be distributed within the six months allotted under an agreement allowing Iraq to sell some of its oil despite the sanctions against it. The report cited delays in getting food and other supplies to Iraq. (Reuters)
 
U.S. Calls for Solution in Zaire
The United States renewed a call for a political solution to Zaire's civil war, but continued to rule out an American role in a proposed military intervention force. The State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said that American officials would continue to discuss a multinational force, but that the United States believed the political course being pursued at the moment was the right one. (Reuters)

Five female recruits said Army investigators had coerced them into accusing male noncommissioned officers at Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland of sexual misconduct. At least 50 female recruits have made charges that include, among other things, 27 rapes; 5 sergeants face courts-martial as a result. A14

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Optimism in New York, But Race and Class Affect Views

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
New Yorkers are more upbeat about their city than they have been in nearly a decade, with their views of crime, the economy and the future suggesting that many have discarded the grim self-image that gripped them just four years ago, according to the latest New York Times poll.
But the poll presents New York as a city divided by race, ethnicity and economic class. While black and Hispanic residents are also more optimistic than they were four years ago, they are notably less satisfied than whites with the state of the city. 
 The Times poll, conducted at the start of this month, points to a relative hopefulness that appears to be taking hold in parts of New York at the start of this mayoral election year.
In one measure of how sharply attitudes have changed, half the people surveyed said that even if they had the option to move away, they would not leave New York.
That was the highest percentage that response to that question received in more than a decade, though again, whites were more willing to remain in New York than were other groups.
From a political perspective, the Times poll contains much good news for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, though it pointed to some possible vulnerabilities in his pursuit of a second term. Most New Yorkers tend to think the city's economy is doing well now relative to four years ago, though economic indicators show that the recovery is centered mostly on Wall Street, and they feel safer on their streets than they did when David N. Dinkins was Mayor.
Many are inclined to credit Mr. Giuliani with at least some of these improvements, and not to blame him for some of the city's problems.
On the other hand, the level of dissatisfaction with Mr. Giuliani among blacks and, to a lesser extent, among women and Hispanic residents, could pose a problem for the Mayor, especially if he faces a strong Democratic opponent. The two leading candidates vying for the Democratic nomination are a woman and a Hispanic politician: Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, and Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President.
The Times poll was conducted from March 1 through March 6. There were 1,397 adult New Yorkers, living in the five boroughs, who were questioned by telephone. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
When similar questions were posed to New Yorkers by The Times and WCBS-TV in October 1993, about a month before Mr. Giuliani defeated Mr. Dinkins in the last mayoral election, the city's mood appeared to be much more pessimistic than that found in this poll. Then, and by sizable margins, people described New York as less safe, more economically debilitated and more racially polarized than it had been when Mr. Dinkins took office in 1989.
By contrast, in this latest poll, 43 percent called the city safer than it was four years ago. In 1993, only 13 percent said they thought the city was safer than it had been in 1989. In this poll, 59 percent described the city economy as good, compared with 32 percent in 1993. And 35 percent described race relations as good, compared with 24 percent four years ago.
Still, New Yorkers have reservations about the city and its Mayor. Voters are increasingly worried about the state of the schools, with one in five voters saying that education should be the top priority of the next Mayor. One in four voters said that crime should be the next Mayor's top priority.
Even more New Yorkers, 31 percent, cited crime as their chief complaint about living in the city. The drop in crime rates notwithstanding, the results suggest that the issue remains a burning one, though not as critical as in 1985, when half the respondents cited crime as the worst thing about living in New York.
And while there are more New Yorkers who present themselves as optimistic about the city's long-term future than there were at the end of Mr. Dinkins's term, they are still outnumbered by New Yorkers who are pessimistic.
Further, the Times Poll indicates that Mr. Giuliani governs a city stratified by race, class and sex. The upbeat view of the city and its Mayor is driven by respondents who, like Mr. Giuliani, are white, male and upper-middle or upper class. Women and lower-income respondents were far less likely to say that the economy had improved, or that New York was safer, or that Mr. Giuliani was doing a good job.
That disparity is even more stark when it comes to race and ethnic background. Whites disagreed with black and Hispanic respondents on nearly every question in the poll, from questions about Mr. Giuliani's performance to the caliber of New York City drinking water. (Whites rated it better.) The one exception was in attitudes towards crime, with 39 percent of whites, 32 percent of blacks and 21 percent of Hispanic respondents agreeing that reducing crime was the best thing Mr. Giuliani had done as Mayor.
By any measure, this public mood seems likely to have a significant effect on shaping the mayoral election, and the initial indications are that Mr. Giuliani will be the beneficiary. Of those questioned, 54 percent approved of the way Mr. Giuliani was handling his job, and 52 percent described his first term as "mainly a success." By contrast, Mr. Dinkins never achieved a job approval rating above 47 percent.
And while 46 percent said Mr. Giuliani had "performed his job as Mayor well enough to deserve re-election," 48 percent said it was "time to give a new person a chance," indicating -- theoretically, at least -- that an opponent could win next November. But even here, Mr. Giuliani remained relatively strong: when the same question was asked about Mr. Dinkins in the middle of his term in 1991, only 25 percent of the people surveyed said he deserved re-election.
One particularly striking measure of Mr. Giuliani's standing came when people were asked to name the worst thing Mr. Giuliani had done. Nearly half were unable to provide an answer, or responded by saying "nothing."
That said, there were a few glimmers of hope -- if dim ones -- for the four Democrats hoping to run against Mr. Giuliani: Ms. Messinger, Mr. Ferrer, the Rev. Al Sharpton and Sal F. Albanese, a City Councilman from Brooklyn. The Times poll suggests that while voters approve of Mr. Giuliani's job performance, they do not like him very much, and are almost equally apt to describe him as "abrasive" as "tough."
In expressing concern about education, 60 percent faulted Mr. Giuliani for not paying enough attention to the issue. Mr. Giuliani's opponents -- who presumably have been looking at their own polls -- have already begun to emphasize education, as, indeed, has the Mayor lately.
In addition, women are not as satisfied with the condition of the city, particularly when it comes to crime, or with Mr. Giuliani; 49 percent approved of how he was handling his job, compared with 59 percent of men. That disparity might prove significant if Democrats nominate Ms. Messinger.
Similarly, Mr. Giuliani also appears to have some problems with Hispanic voters. Mr. Giuliani defeated Mr. Dinkins in 1993 with 38 percent of the Hispanic vote, and just 42 percent of Hispanic residents questioned for the poll said they approved of the way Mr. Giuliani was handling his job. Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, is of Puerto Rican descent, and has already begun a quiet campaign appealing directly to Hispanic voters, including a series of radio advertisements that are to be broadcast on Spanish-language radio stations in New York starting this week.
And Mr. Giuliani's standing with blacks remains low, as it always has been; 34 percent approved the way he had handled his job. That suggests that any Democratic candidate would benefit by encouraging black turnout in November. Mr. Sharpton is black, but is widely viewed as unlikely to win the nomination.
Beyond its implications for the mayoral race, there were two overriding themes to the poll. The first was the improved feelings New Yorkers have about their city. The second was the latest evidence of political polarization among difference races and ethnic groups.
The two areas that most accounted for New Yorkers' improved feelings about the city were crime and the economy. In terms of the economy, 59 percent of New Yorkers now rate it as good.
And in another sign of a favorable mood about New York, the percentage of New Yorkers who reported that they or a member of their family had been a victim of a crime over the last year fell from 27 percent when Mr. Dinkins was Mayor, to 17 percent now.
All this has combined to produce the upbeat view of the city that emerges from the poll results. Thirty-four percent of respondents said life in New York was generally better, with 33 percent saying worse and 29 percent saying the same. By comparison, four years ago, only 10 percent said the state of the city was better than it had been when Mr. Dinkins took office, with 60 percent saying worse.
The disparity in racial and ethnic views is particularly evident regarding the economy and crime. While 67 percent of whites in the poll said the economy was good, only 55 percent of blacks and 47 percent of Hispanic residents shared that opinion, an indication that whatever economic prosperity there is in New York is concentrated in certain pockets. Similarly, while 54 percent of whites said the city was safer today than it was under Mr. Dinkins, only 30 percent of blacks and 37 percent of Hispanic respondents agreed.
But on no subject is the racial disparity greater than on Mr. Giuliani himself. His relatively high standing in the city is largely a function of his popularity among whites: 71 percent of them in the poll approved of his handling of the job as Mayor, compared with just 34 percent of blacks and 42 percent of Hispanic residents. Similarly, 69 percent of whites called Mr. Giuliani's term as a success, compared with 33 percent among blacks and 37 percent among Hispanic residents.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews with 1,397 adults, conducted March 1 through March 6 in all parts of New York City. Interviews were in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a list of all city exchanges. They were chosen to assure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. The telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated at random to be the respondent for the survey.
The results were weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points either way from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Yorkers.
For smaller groups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus 4 percentage points for whites, 5 percentage points for blacks and 5 percentage points for Hispanic New Yorkers.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;
Confirmation Hearings Start With Confrontational Tone

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
The opening hours of the long-awaited hearing about state secrets and political money fell well short of a full-fledged "Borking" -- the political character combat that habitues anticipate.
Still, after the introductions and felicities, after the Red Sox jokes and the prepared opening statements, it only took five brief questions before the chairman of the Senate intelligence committee was somewhat gleefully asking Anthony Lake, the nominee for Director of Central Intelligence, about security warnings to the Clinton Administration that China might have been trying to funnel money last year to Federal candidates, the President included. 
 In an instant, attention was being fully paid in Room 216 of the Senate Hart Office Building, the arena of the now departed Whitewater hearings of the 1995-96 political cycle. Even questions about the nation's readiness to anticipate nuclear attack were secondary to the main question of China money possibly being directed at polluting the American campaign pot.
"This was your watch, was it not?" asked Senator Richard C. Shelby, the committee chairman.
He smiled tightly as he warmed to the task and sought to press Mr. Lake on his duties as the President's national security adviser last year, when the F.B.I. warnings about China reached White House security underlings but somehow not President Clinton.
"Why were you not informed of such a dynamite piece of news?" Senator Shelby demanded, finally reaching an easy synch with the season's dominant capital topic, suspicions and allegations of high scandal in big-money campaign financing.
Mr. Lake, a man whose career in security and intelligence is intimately linked to anticipating tough questions, was hardly taken aback. He hewed to a mood of courtly openness and replied that he, like the President, had never been told by subordinates of the F.B.I.'s concern which, nevertheless, had managed to reach several other political candidates in Congress directly.
"I should have been informed, and the President should have been informed," Mr. Lake answered as the hearing took off on a two-week schedule that one Democrat warned might be a ritual "bludgeoning" and "trial by ordeal." But Senator Shelby insisted that it would be a full and fair airing of the nomination.
Even when he was a Democrat, Senator Shelby, of Alabama, never was one to shy from taking on the Clinton Administration. "The tax man cometh," he had complained with an easy needle of one early Clinton budgetary plan, in 1993. When Vice President Al Gore was dispatched to bring the Senator aboard, Mr. Shelby had television cameras waiting and aced him with further sound-bite denunciations of Clinton economics.
With that, the Senator's Rubicon was only an election away, and he switched parties on the day after the Republicans took control of both houses of Congress in 1994. The Administration knew then that an ambitious new antagonist was in the majority with his seniority intact and his appetite for confrontation keen.
As the hearing opening, the Senator held the gavel and stayed attentive to nuance as he surveyed a large audience for the hearing. His reference in his prepared statement to the "business of spying" was altered in delivery to "the business of intelligence operations." The spoken mantra of the opening round was not about politicians' endless need of money but rather the nation's higher need of unvarnished truth, unvarnished facts, unvarnished intelligence, with the adjective invoked every 15 minutes on average by assorted speakers.
The Democrats had Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska on guard as vice chairman, and he sought to bring some early lightness to the proceedings. "Are Louis Freeh and the President going to strip to the waist and duke it out?" he asked, referring to the F.B.I. Director. He smiled in referring to the contradictory accounts of the China warning offered by the White House and the F.B.I. His larger point was about the need for getting past the headline moment and focusing on national policy.
No one seemed more willing to move on than Mr. Lake, who first had to stress for Senator Shelby that he had not subsequently questioned national security aides about the confusion over the F.B.I. warning because he did not want to create any "impression of my trying to influence them."
Senator Shelby looked pleased that the topic was fully on the table, and he promised to return to it in detail. The proceeding moved on to other questions, including where Mr. Lake rated himself on a "comfort scale" of 1 ("passive") to 10 ("hysterical") about the dangers of nuclear weapons spreading to third-world rogue nations.
The intelligence specialist thought a moment and managed to drive thoughts of China money briefly from the room.
"Nine," he tersely replied. Then, before the hearing adjourned, Mr. Lake added that the probability was considerably less.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Downstate Media Move

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Web Genesis, a new media company based in Ithaca, N.Y., is moving to New York City.
The move, to West 21st Street in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, means the transfer of 20 employees. The company also plans to hire up to 10 more employees by year's end, said Todd Krizelman, chief executive officer of Web Genesis. 
 The move follows IBM's recent decision to move part of its Internet operation from its Armonk headquarters in Westchester County. Like IBM, Web Genesis decided that the move was too good to pass up because of business opportunities.
"The concept of telecommuting, it only goes so far," said Mr. Krizelman, who credited the New York City Economic Development Corporation with acting as a "concierge" in making the move even more enticing. "We want to be closer to advertisers, and we want closer access to talent."
Web Genesis operates an on-line site called "The Globe," which functions as a community forum, with chat rooms, personal ads, discussion groups and other services. The site claims more than 525,000 registered users each month, a high number in the business. DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
On His Farm He Grew Some Pot, Ee-eye Ee-eye-o

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Wherever he looks, Peter Jennings, our guide to tonight's all-American garden tour, finds marijuana plants being tended with diligence, affection and hope. He provides tips along the way on proper cultivation (plenty of light, not too much water), but, as the program's title, "Pot of Gold," hints, his interest is less in horticulture than in the economics of what he says may be America's biggest cash crop.
In the Pacific Northwest, he is told, for an investment of less than $2,000, the indoor gardener can make $200,000 a year tax free. Twenty-something entrepreneurs have joined together in this cottage, or ranch house, industry. One of them comments that whoever it was who said money doesn't grow on trees didn't know "what trees to look at." We also meet the area's Johnny Potseed, who is on a mission to subvert laws against marijuana. 
 A Midwestern couple who describe themselves as Rush Limbaugh Republicans ("We're kind of Main Street U.S.A., apple pie, mom and pop. . . . We're not hippies.") are doing their growing in their basement, using seeds selected at an Amsterdam marijuana trade fair, the Cannabis Cup. (Mr. Jennings reports that you can save yourself a trip and order on the Internet.) So far the non-hippies haven't made any money; maybe fans of Mr. Limbaugh are green-thumb-challenged.
And in Georgia, the program focuses on a county of farmers who are trying to beat hard times by producing a crop known for high times. Unlike corn, a grower explains, marijuana has a seller's market. The local sheriff seems to have been elected on a no-see, no-smell platform. "And how tough were you on marijuana growers after you were elected sheriff?" inquires Mr. Jennings. The sheriff answers, "Uh."
Although the heads of growers are either cut off by the camera or concealed in shadows to avoid implicating the guilty, none seem to be hopheads. They are just out to make a dishonest dollar. One young woman says, "It's not hurting anyone, you know." And neither Mr. Jennings nor the program take an admonitory tone.
It would be surprising if tonight's lighthearted contribution to ABC's month of anti-drug programming did not attract new recruits to a small-risk, profit-promising line of work that gives folks a chance to get their hands dirty.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
New ideas go beyond handouts in the war on African poverty.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH much of the third world busily freeing markets and imitating the export-led growth policies of the Asian tigers like Taiwan and Hong Kong, economic development is the order of the day everywhere. Everywhere, that is, but sub-Saharan Africa, where population growth has outpaced output for two decades and most people live on the edge of subsistence.
Are Africans fated to remain poor? Not according to specialists at the Harvard Institute for International Development, who are pressing Washington to create a "new partnership for growth" with African countries. Instead of handouts-as-usual, they would offer market access, foreign debt concessions and technology transfers. 
 This idea is not being tossed into a political vacuum. With the support of the Clinton Administration, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have begun to offer debt write-offs as carrots to domestic reforms. And an influential group of lawmakers has introduced legislation in Congress to break the cycle of the traditional guilt-induced aid followed by indifference.
While hardly anyone thinks a change in foreign aid policy could cure all that ails Africa, there are promising precedents for the tough-love approach. "Nobody anticipated East Asia's success before it happened," notes Nick Eberstadt, a researcher at the American Enterprise Institute. He argues that economic planners in Taiwan and South Korea pulled up their socks only after a termination of conventional foreign aid was threatened.
It's hard to exaggerate the wretched state of the economy south of the Sahara and north of the Republic of South Africa. According to United Nations calculations, personal consumption levels are roughly one-twentieth that of the industrial countries. Poor nutrition and a lack of clean water have transformed much of Africa into a sink of disease, with one child in six dying before the age of 5. Meanwhile, explosive population growth and soil depletion are driving once-self-sufficient farmers into urban mega-slums, which offer little hope of housing, education or employment.
It is also hard to exaggerate the failure of four decades of development aid. While the West has poured tens of billions of dollars into assistance -- and saved a lot of lives during famines -- a combination of geopolitics and post-colonial sensibilities have limited the leverage of the donors. "There has never been any effective pressure for African governments to make policy choices," argues Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard group, "which would have led to the mobilization of domestic resources for development."
This doesn't mean the region is beyond economic redemption. East Asia looked as hopeless in the 1950's. And development specialists cautiously estimate that the continent is capable of sustaining 5 percent growth in per capita income for several decades. "Africa could even catch up with Asia if it did everything right," Robert Rotberg, the institute's coordinator for southern Africa, concluded.
"Everything right" is a tall order. Mr. Rotberg and others would be delighted with significant progress on the basics: prudent budget policies, investment in education and infrastructure, deregulation of domestic markets and foreign trade, a warm welcome to foreign investors. To get from here to there, the Harvard group wants Western donors to offer wide-open import markets, foreign debt write-offs, subsidies for private foreign investment and very temporary injections of cash to help balance budgets -- all of which would be conditioned on no-nonsense domestic reforms designed to let markets work.
The Rwandas and Zaires of Africa are plainly not ready for economic prime time. But some deeply impoverished countries with politically legitimate governments may be in a position to respond to incentives: Experts offer Uganda, Ghana, Mali, Malawi and Mozambique as prospects.
There are stirrings of political support where it counts. This week the World Bank and the I.M.F. announced plans to cut Uganda's debt by $300 million. And two House Democrats, Jim McDermott of Washington and Charles B. Rangel of New York, along with Philip M. Crane of Illinois, a senior Republican, have introduced legislation to rewrite the rules for trade and investment policy with Africa along the Harvard group's lines.
"I believe it is time for a major shift in attitude, policy and commitment," Representative McDermott told a House subcommittee last August.
Sound familiar? Africa's economic predicament periodically draws sympathy in the West, but never for long. One difference this time, perhaps, is that no one is asking for serious money to sustain the initiative. More important, Europe -- Africa's major benefactor -- is less likely to undermine demands for domestic reform with what amounts to guilt money for past sins. "The colonial and post-colonial periods are behind us," said a report on aid issued by the European Commission last November.
But a war on African poverty would require overcoming the weary sense of hopelessness that surrounds attitudes toward Africa. "The essential question," argues Albert Fishlow, a development specialist at the Council on Foreign Relations, is, "do we take Africa seriously?"

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Says Higher Pay Mostly Eludes Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Despite a persistently low unemployment rate, American workers have generally been unable to win significantly higher pay, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of economic conditions suggested today.
And where companies have granted hefty raises, they have managed to offset the extra cost with better productivity, thereby keeping the cost of their products in check. 
 This implies that the Federal Reserve, which is to conduct an eagerly awaited policy meeting on March 25, may be able to avoid raising interest rates to slow the economy.
But that is not certain, for Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has warned that he might not necessarily wait for incontrovertible evidence that inflation was gaining momentum and could make a "pre-emptive" strike against it. The state of the job market, Government officials and private economists agree, is crucial since it accounts for the bulk of costs in the economy.
"Tight labor markets still dominate in almost all parts of the country," said the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis in its summary of the anecdotal findings, which cover late January, February and the first few days of March. But "wage gains generally remain moderate" and price pressures appear "temperate."
Still, there were glaring exceptions, such as a report from the Minneapolis Fed that an electronics company there is offering $5,000 signing bonuses and starting pay of nearly $40,000 to undergraduate seniors with majors in engineering. Building contractors in the Chicago district, meanwhile, were said to be recruiting scarce workers at the construction sites of competitors.
The securities markets found little comfort in the survey, part of the Fed's preparation for a meeting of the Open Market Committee. Stocks started an afternoon slide following its release at 2 P.M.
The committee moved in August to a stance biased toward tightening monetary policy and is believed to have maintained it through its most recently scheduled meeting on Feb. 4 and 5.
But the Fed's options still appeared to remain open since many employers seem unwilling to engage in a bidding war for workers, presumably because they believe that they cannot raise prices to recover the extra cost.
"Some firms cite low unemployment rates as making it difficult to expand their operations," the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta found. Similarly, the Fed's Chicago district reported that "several contacts indicated that the tight labor markets may be restraining the region's economic expansion."
This suggests that to some significant, although unquantifiable, extent the private sector is restraining the economy and thereby making it less likely the Fed will be forced to do so with higher rates.
The survey's summary found most districts enjoying "strong" conditions in residential real estate, that commercial real estate markets "continue to strengthen" and that consumer spending was higher than in the first two months of last year.
The economy of the New York district, including part of New Jersey and southern Connecticut, was cited for higher consumer spending, along with Boston and Atlanta. The commercial real estate market tightened further as the asking price for rents in midtown Manhattan began to edge up, and the market for single-family houses "appears to be gaining momentum," with prices across the state up about 5 percent from the level a year earlier. Manhattan co-ops and condominiums, however, have been flat.
The Boston district, which covers virtually all of New England, was one of the strongest, with wages rising about 4 percent a year. Temporary workers were especially scarce, the Fed found, with demand outstripping supply "across all industries and occupations" and wages rising at a rate of 8 to 10 percent.
Massachusetts, southern Connecticut and southern New Hampshire were described as very strong, and Maine and Vermont were "both starting to pick up."
However, the Fed cited a lessening of wage pressures in the Dallas and Kansas City districts. A mini-boom in southwest Pennsylvania has pushed the jobless rate there a half- point below the national average of 5.3 percent.
Over all, the Fed said, regional economies "generally continue to expand at a relatively moderate pace." This echoed the late January description of growth as being "moderate in most parts of the country."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Hard Work for Men in Hard Hats

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

PAYBACK
By Thomas Kelly
273 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.
 Perhaps the most powerful character in Thomas Kelly's bloody-fisted first novel, "Payback," is the tunnel that his hero, Billy Adare, is helping to build. This is Water Tunnel Three, being blasted through the ancient bedrock of Manhattan, 800 feet beneath the city. "The largest public works project in American history," explains the narrative, "when finished, it would stretch for 60 miles" and "would deliver two billion gallons of pristine mountain water a day to a metropolis surrounded by saltwater."
Back from college, back in the Bronx, back to work for the summer of 1987 before beginning law school, Billy wonders if he can return to the hard work of being a sandhog like his father, who was "the first of 23 men killed building Water Tunnel Three, a body count that made it the most dangerous job in America." 
 "Billy and the gang climbed up on the jumbo drilling platform, with its three levels, three drills to a level. The drills were run by compressed air, weighed over a hundred pounds each. Billy wrestled his drill into position. By the time he was set up, he was slathered in grease. The light was dim, the air worse than usual. Billy felt like he was breathing wet wool. He stood a hair under six feet tall, and his hard hat scraped the raw rock ceiling above his head. He hunched slightly and, with Frankie holding his drill bit to the rock face, let rip. The other sandhogs started drilling, taking up where the swing shift had left off. The howl engulfed them."
Powerful characters are threatening above ground, too. Billy's union lacks a contract. Joe Harkness, the tunnel's contractor, wants to break the union and thinks he can, given the anti-union climate created by President Ronald Reagan. Harkness has hired "a broker for illicit and unseemly business," who has made a deal with the Mafia. The Mafia has decided to pass the job on to the Irish gang that runs "the lucrative construction rackets on the West Side."
This gang is run by one Jack Tierney, whom a New York City police detective describes in colorful terms. Once, when Tierney was insulted by a man known as Screwdriver, "he lured Screwdriver somewhere and made him a pair of concrete shoes." The detective goes on: "Nice touch, right? A nod to the old days. But while Jack might be old-fashioned, a traditionalist at times, he's also a modernist. They say he put Screwdriver in those concrete shoes but before he dropped him in the river he fitted him with scuba gear. Taped the regulator over his mouth. Tied his hands behind his back, then tossed him in. Gave Screwdriver plenty of time to think what a bad idea calling Jackie Tierney names was. I wonder what was going through Screwdriver's mind, he's down there watching the carp swim by, maybe a snapping turtle or two."
One of Jack Tierney's lieutenants is Paddy Adare, a 32-year-old washed-up boxer who is Billy's older brother. So the battle lines are drawn. And Billy is caught in the middle, torn between his family and past and his ambition to escape to law school.
Many forces work to pull Billy back to his roots, as he hangs out over the summer with the friends he grew up with and falls into old habits of self-destructive loyalty, like getting drawn into bar fights or accepting tainted money from Paddy. Also, much repels him about the world he would escape to, as he recalls how out of place he felt at the "prestigious liberal arts school" he attended "upstate," and how put off he was by rebellious rich students who "hated all that made their life good."
The author of "Payback" seems to identify with Billy, perhaps because Mr. Kelly spent 10 years as a construction worker, including 3 as a sandhog in the Bronx, and went on to earn a bachelor's degree in political economy from Fordham University and a master's in public administration from Harvard. Whatever the reason, Mr. Kelly includes slightly more detail about growing up poor and Irish than is absolutely necessary to his hyperthyroid plot. Among his digressions is a telling scene in which he has trouble persuading the Columbia law school registrar's office to accept his tuition payment in cash.
Yet such overdetailing is counterbalanced by the pace and violence of a plot in which men crush their opponents with a brutality that makes even the film "Donnie Brasco" seem tame; in which a man thrown from a car "doing 70 up the West Side Highway" is described as having "bounced along" like a "Spaldeen," and where, when Billy peers over the edge of a roof, "far below, the life of the city surged like the blood of a great snarling beast, unimpeded by his concerns."
Considering what a Hobbesian world Mr. Kelly has drawn, with people caught in brutal dead-end lives of hard labor and sudden death, his plot resolves itself with remarkable neatness and a surprisingly positive outcome for the good guys. But you tend to overlook his unearned optimism because the reader of "Payback" ends up having an altogether entertaining time.
