HEADLINE: In Separate Studies, Costs Of Hospitals Are Debated

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Investor-owned hospitals have significantly higher administrative costs than nonprofit hospitals, in part because they are less efficient, two health care researchers said today.
At the same time, a Federal advisory panel said in a separate study that hospitals of all types had radically reduced the growth of their total costs. 
 Taken together, the studies suggest that hospital costs have leveled off, but that administrative costs account for a growing share of the total.
In the first study, published today in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Steffie Woolhandler and Dr. David U. Himmelstein said they had analyzed Government data and found "higher administrative costs at for-profit hospitals." Specifically, they said, "we found that for-profit hospitals spend 23 percent more on administration than do comparable private not-for-profit hospitals and 34 percent more than public institutions."
The American Hospital Association and the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents investor-owned hospitals, rejected the findings. They said that the authors had for years been strident critics of America's health care industry and had favored a Government-financed system of universal health insurance like Canada's.
Dr. Himmelstein said that for-profit hospitals tended to spend more on marketing, lobbying and executive compensation. Some investor-owned hospital chains "pay enormous salaries, bonuses and stock options to their executives," he said.
Dr. Woolhandler said that a typical for-profit hospital had administrative costs averaging $2,289 for each hospital stay in 1994, compared with administrative costs of $1,861 for a comparable private nonprofit hospital and $1,708 for a public hospital of the same size.
The authors, who are associate professors at Harvard Medical School, said their research belied the conventional wisdom that for-profit hospitals were more efficient. These hospitals "save money by laying off nurses, then hire consultants and bureaucrats to figure out how to maximize revenues and avoid unprofitable patients," Dr. Woolhandler asserted.
Thomas A. Scully, president of the Federation of American Health Systems, said that Dr. Woolhandler and Dr. Himmelstein had "a transparent political agenda: to discredit anything related to the market or competition in health care."
In response, Dr. Himmelstein said that he favored a Canadian-style system because "the health care industry in the United States wastes enormous resources and deprives people of the care they need."
About 15 percent of the nation's 5,200 community hospitals are for-profit entities. Some nonprofit hospitals behave in similar ways and try to earn a surplus each year. Hundreds of nonprofit hospitals have become profit-making enterprises in the last 15 years. Deborah J. Chollet, associate director of the Alpha Center, a health policy research institute here, said that most of the ownership status changes had occurred in California, Florida, Georgia and Texas.
New data from the Federal panel, the Prospective Payment Assessment Commission, which advises Congress on Medicare payments to hospitals, show remarkable reductions in the growth of hospital operating costs in the last three years. Such costs, which rose faster than the Consumer Price Index for many years, are now rising less than consumer prices in general, the panel said.
Dr. Donald A. Young, executive director of the commission, said today: "I don't find anything inherently wrong with administrative costs if an organization is efficient. Some of the best corporations in America also have high administrative costs. That, in part, is why they are good businesses. You need good administrators to manage a large, complex organization."
In an editorial in The New England Journal today, Stuart H. Altman, a professor of national health policy at Brandeis University, said that "better administration" may have increased hospitals' efficiency. "Since 1994," he said, "the annual rate of increase in hospital expenses per admission has been consistently below the level of inflation."
Richard H. Wade, a spokesman for the American Hospital Association, conceded that the health care system was "laden with wasteful administrative costs," in part because there were hundreds of different health insurance companies and health plans. But he said that many administrative costs were for medical records, auditing and other activities that increased the quality of care for consumers.
Hospital mergers and acquisitions generate "enormous costs up front," Mr. Wade said, but in the long run, investors hope that such transactions will increase the efficiency of the health care system.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond's Price Falls On Rate Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were flat to lower yesterday, as investors continued to be cautious for fear that new economic data could prove unduly strong, leading the Fed to raise short-term interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating.
Nervousness ahead of the Fed's release of its beige book report yesterday caused prices to sag, with only a brief rebound when the report, prepared by the St. Louis Fed, turned out to be very similar to recent reports on business activity. 
 The labor markets remain tight in nearly all the 12 Federal Reserve districts, with wage gains showing no signs of breaking out of the 3 to 4 percent range mentioned in the last several reports. It showed price pressures at retailers and manufacturers have been temperate, thanks to competition.
Today the market will focus on the monthly retail sales report to get a sense of how fast the economy is growing, and tomorrow market participants will be weighing Government reports on February industrial production and producer prices.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 12/32, to 96 26/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.88 percent, from 6.85 percent on Tuesday.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said after last week's employment report for February that the market ought to be ready for clear sailing ahead, but that does not seem to be the case.
"We seem to be taking the posture of waiting for the other shoe, or shoes to drop, whatever they may be -- whether another jump in equities, incipient signs of inflation, or a Fed rate hike," Mr. Delaney said.
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management, a Washington company that manages about $6 billion in bonds, said the significance of yesterday's beige book report was that the Federal Open Market Committee would use it when it meets on March 25.
"I think in general it would be difficult for the Fed if it were looking for some pretext, or rationale, from the text of the report to raise rates," Mr. Carpenter said. "What stands out was the choice of words to describe the tempo of economic activity, like moderate, temperate, and mixed. All of these words connote the lack of excesses and imbalances and would appear to provide little justification of an increase in the federal funds rate at the F.O.M.C. meeting.
"What was significant is that wage gains of 3 to 4 percent, which are moderate, did not appear to be accelerating from prior months. But the real statement in the report is that intense competition at the retail levels and big advances in productivity are negating any and all increase in input prices, leaving the overall inflation rate at a low ebb. There is no reason to believe that advances in technology and productivity and the overall current level of competition in retail markets is going to disappear anytime soon. So in terms of the F.O.M.C. meeting, it really puts off to the future the day of reckoning for Fed monetary policy."
Still, he added, bond yields cannot go significantly lower ahead of the meeting, as long as most market participants remain cautious.
"The risk on the retail number is to the upside, since all we've had has been this uncharacteristically warm February weather," Mr. Carpenter said. "And there is always the chance with the volatile retail number that the prior month number, which came out lower than expected, may get revised up at the same time the February number is published, indicating firm retail sales for that month. Investors may look past Friday's Producer Price Index to see if it will be confirmed by the Consumer Price Index. Industrial production is expected to be up half of 1 percent after the zero gain in January."

HEADLINE: Doubts Haunt Philadelphia in Trial of 2 Men Charged in a Jogger's Murder

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, March 12

 BODY:
There were 432 homicides in Philadelphia in 1995, but just one that brought a teary tribute from the Mayor at the victim's memorial service.
That was the slaying of Kimberly Ernest, a 26-year-old paralegal who was attacked on her early morning jog through Center City in a crime that chilled that area's genteel row house blocks. 
 Throughout the city, talk of "the jogger murder" was instant, animated and practically ceaseless. Tensions eased only when, within a month of the crime, the police had confessions from two minor-league criminals who had apparently conducted a small crime wave in Center City around the time of the murder.
But however satisfying the confessions, they now turn out to be the only significant evidence against the men in their trial, which has gripped this city for the last few months.
The defendants contend that they were beaten and their statements fabricated by detectives, the elite in a department that since 1995 has seen more than 270 cases dismissed and six police officers imprisoned for extortion, planting evidence and lying in court. And as testimony concluded today, the city that demanded answers after the killing is caught between concerns that the guilty may go free and suspicions that the real killer is still out there.
"The lack of evidence is highly disturbing," said Stuart Seidman, a businessman, stating the common wisdom around Center City these days. "With all the corruption trials going on in the Philadelphia police, you'd think the cops wouldn't be dumb enough to blow this one. It's classic Philadelphia."
Ms. Ernest, a Chicago doctor's daughter, was killed about dawn on Nov. 2, 1995. She was found, in a bra, socks and running shoes, in a deep stairwell outside an office on Pine Street, near Rittenhouse Square.
An autopsy found that Ms. Ernest died of strangulation and blunt-force injuries to the head. There was evidence of rape: fresh vaginal tears, though no semen in the vagina, and traces of semen, though no sign of trauma, in the rectum.
In the next few weeks, the stairwell became a shrine, with flowers, candles and handwritten eulogies arrayed against the gate on the brick sidewalk. People gathered there to protest violence against women.
"This case is different," said Sgt. Paul Musi, who worked on the case. "For some reason, Philadelphia embraces this girl."
Fear and speculation dissipated with the arrests of Herbert Haak 3d, 25, a sometime computer repairman with a long list of burglary and theft convictions, and Richard Wise, an unemployed 19-year-old with a record of assaults. Mr. Haak lived with his fiancee in an apartment a few blocks from the crime scene, and Mr. Wise had been staying in an attached garage.
Mr. Haak called the police six days after the slaying. He was in jail in suburban Bucks County, where he had been detained after a court hearing on a burglary charge held within hours of Ms. Ernest's death. Mr. Haak told detectives that Mr. Wise was threatening to kill his fiancee; he also said Mr. Wise was involved in the Ernest killing.
The police picked up Mr. Wise for questioning, administering a polygraph test, which they said he failed. But having no other evidence, they released him.
A few weeks later, detectives heard from Mr. Haak's stepfather, John Hall, who implicated Mr. Haak along with Mr. Wise. Both men were arrested after giving confessions that told the following story:
Herbert Haak and Richard Wise, who had met as neighbors in Philadelphia's working-class Fishtown neighborhood, had a routine of breaking into cars and harassing people in the predawn hours around Center City. On Nov. 2, Mr. Haak was acting as lookout and Mr. Wise was approaching a parked car with a crowbar when Ms. Ernest, running down Pine Street, spotted him and threatened to call the police.
Mr. Wise hit her with the crowbar, but Ms. Ernest, 5 feet 10 inches tall and athletic, fought back. The men pushed her into their car, which was parked nearby, where Mr. Wise beat her into unconsciousness in the back seat and pulled off her pants while Mr. Haak drove, searching for a place to throw her out. They returned to Pine Street and dragged her into the stairwell. Mr. Wise tried to rape her but, he told the police, "I was just having a tough time trying to do it."
The wrenching story seemed to promise resolution. But investigators were soon brought up short. DNA from the semen in Ms. Ernest's body did not match either defendant. An examination of Mr. Haak's 1987 Bonneville yielded nothing, and while Mr. Haak's statement said they were driving a stolen car -- Mr. Wise said they were in the Bonneville -- the police could find no such car. There was no blood, no fingerprints, no crowbar, no witnesses. Ms. Ernest's pants were never found.
The trial, which began on Feb. 19 in Philadelphia Common Pleas Court, has produced a knot of ambiguous evidence. Mr. Haak's stepfather refused to testify, as did his mother, Phyllis, who had told police that Mr. Wise threatened to kill her if she revealed anything "about what we did to that girl."
It is not clear that Mr. Hall's testimony would have helped prosecutors; a habitual car thief, he is known as a jailhouse informer. The defense contends that to settle scores with his stepson he fed the police a story that detectives, under pressure to solve the case, used to fashion confessions.
At the trial, Mr. Wise never took the stand. Mr. Haak, however, testified to being beaten during his interrogation, and a prison social worker and a public defender said they saw red marks on his face and chest the next day. But three prison medical workers who saw him after the interrogation noted no signs of injury.
Mr. Haak also testified that detectives forced him to sign blank pages and that the confession must have been typed in later. But under cross-examination he was caught in many inconsistencies and acknowledged lying to a jury in a previous case. And in rebuttal testimony on Tuesday, a police documents expert displayed for jurors a magnified photo of a page of Mr. Haak's confession showing that a stroke of the defendant's signature had been placed on top of a typewritten line.
As to why he implicated Mr. Wise, Mr. Haak told the court that it was a ploy to get him out of his apartment and away from his fiancee.
Asked whether a false accusation of murder was not an overreaction, he replied: "I was trying to get police to go pick him up, so I was telling them anything I could think of."
One of Mr. Haak's fellow inmates testified that he had talked about "the wild man who lived in his garage" and who had "whacked" and raped the jogger; a former cellmate said Mr. Haak boasted that the car he and Mr. Wise had driven would never be found "because it was under water." But the jury also heard from inmates who questioned the cellmate's credibility.
Most confounding is the mystery sperm. The assistant medical examiner said it could have been a day or two old and the result of consensual sex. But he also said it could have been left by the killer, which would exclude both defendants.
Today, another prosecution expert said he believed that the sperm had resulted from vaginal intercourse more than a day before the assault.
Several of Ms. Ernest's friends and former lovers testified to her active sex life, but no one has acknowledged having sex with her in the days just before her death.
"They shouldn't be convicted on the evidence the police have," said Frank Bender, a sculptor who lives near Pine Street.
Still, Mr. Bender added, "I thought from the beginning they had the right guys."

HEADLINE: An Office Revival Is Taking Shape;
But This Time, Developers Are Keeping Things Simple

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
They're back. The nation's real estate developers, after their crazed overbuilding in the 1980's helped ruin hundreds of banks and savings and loans, are starting to put up speculative office buildings again, breaking ground before they know who will fill most of their floors.
The developers swear on a stack of blueprints that they will not repeat their past excesses. Instead of building sky-scraping, marble-clad, sculpture-bedecked urban spires, they are mostly constructing squat boxes, often varying in little but trim, in outlying suburbs. In other words, McOffices. 
 "Underneath, it's the same building," one Atlanta developer, Don Childress, said without apology of the four six-story buildings he has started since he resumed office construction a year ago.
Economic growth and new hiring are feeding the resurgence in building, but there are other reasons, too. Cost-conscious tenants like the thrifty image these surroundings convey. Though bent on squeezing more employees into less space, they often need newer buildings with more parking and the heavier utility service that technological advances demand.
"The glamour, the grandiose styles, the palaces -- they're gone," said Douglas A. Tibbetts, president of the real estate arm of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, which a decade ago backed the nation's flashiest developers. "Today, people need something that looks efficient."
The resumption of office construction, though still modest, represents a turning point in a commercial real estate market that saw the worth of some buildings fall by half since the late 80's. The value of all commercial real estate now stands at $3.2 trillion.
Office building came to a virtual standstill for several years, with a low of only 1.6 million square feet -- the equivalent of less than two 50-story buildings -- completed in the entire nation in 1994. In 1986, developers finished more space than that every five days, with most of that fifth day left for topping-out parties. In all, 139.9 million square feet of office space was completed that year, as much as if the nation's developers had built another Houston, with all its suburbs, from scratch.
Last year, new office space was back up to 6.6 million square feet, and Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services firm, estimates that 13 million will be completed this year, the most since 1992.
More than three-quarters of the new buildings under construction at the end of 1996 were speculative, accounting for most of the gain, the firm reports. For much of the 90's, speculative construction essentially ceased.
The return of building on speculation, beginning about a year and a half ago, is concentrated in -- but not confined to -- the South and Southwest. Suburban Atlanta, Phoenix and Dallas are among the hottest markets. New speculative buildings are also going up, though, in North Jersey and the suburbs of Chicago and Washington.
About the only exceptions to the Edge City trend are a few towers planned in urban centers like Times Square in Manhattan.
Often, the new offices are going up in metropolitan areas where the downtowns still languish and entire office towers remain shuttered and vacant. In Dallas, the downtown vacancy rate is more than 35 percent, the highest in the nation. But in the sprawling Dallas suburbs of Plano and Irving -- out where companies like E.D.S., Exxon and J. C. Penney are based -- many of the nation's largest developers and financial institutions are vying to fill the demand for more space. Tenants see the suburbs providing newer quarters, with more parking and shorter commutes.
Nationally, rental rates have been rising as suburban vacancy rates have dropped from 21.4 percent in early 1992 to 12.9 percent at the end of last year, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Downtown office space has filled up, too, but more slowly, with vacancies falling from nearly 20 percent to 14.8 percent over the same period.
And investors' cash is again flowing into real estate, some of it seeking havens that seem safer than a sky-scraping stock market. "We are flush with capital," said Arthur J. Mirante 2d, Cushman & Wakefield's chief executive, speaking of the national trend. "But everyone remembers what happened in the 80's."
Back then, lenders pressed developers to take their money and build whatever they wanted, requiring them to put up only 5 percent of the costs, or sometimes nothing. Citicorp aimed to back the nation's top 10 developers, while Equitable financed such major builders as John C. Portman of Atlanta, the Crow family of Dallas and Donald J. Trump.
Today, lenders demand that developers put up 20 percent of the costs. They want to see stable or rising population and employment figures and marketing studies with evidence of rental rates high enough to support new construction. They check out the reliability of contractors and architects. And then they might only do business with developers who did not default before.
Wall Street has given hordes of individual investors the chance to buy in with real estate investment trusts, or REIT's. Some insurers are still selling off their real estate, but pension funds and REIT's are taking their places.
Few real estate analysts or economists see any signs that another crash is imminent. Many of the savings and loans and other rash lenders are gone, and there is no prospect of the sort of tax code changes that punctured real estate values in the late 80's. Those changes undid many of the tax shelter features that had caused investors to flock to real estate earlier in the decade.
According to Donald Ratajczak, director of the Georgia State University's Economic Forecasting Center, the long real estate cycle that bottomed out in 1992 is still on the upswing, so that any downturns at this stage will be short.
Even so, telecommuting and corporate cost-cutting continue to constrain demand for new space. Besides, many areas still have plenty of space left over from the last binge. Some Houston buildings that were completely mothballed are only now being unlocked and leased.
Developing offices remains a lot like playing a casino's baccarat tables, which offers plenty of cachet but the highest stakes and risks. Homes, apartments, shopping centers and warehouses have all come back first.
To limit their risks, most developers and lenders shun overbearing high-rises that take two or three years to finish, then another few years to fully lease. Instead, they are often doing suburban structures so simple to finance and build that they might as well be inflatable. If a decade ago construction cranes towered to the upper reaches of urban skylines, this time most of them are all but hidden among suburban trees.
Back in the 80's, Mr. Childress, a former Trammell Crow partner who founded Childress Klein Properties in Atlanta, won architectural plaudits for a Peachtree Street high-rise that featured travertine marble outside, bronze sconces and chandeliers in the lobby.
His latest buildings, each of the same size and shape, take no more than nine months to build, so that he and his lenders, primarily the First Union and Wachovia banks, are not gambling on the market's long-term strength.
The only stone on the facade of his Windward I building in the fringe suburb of Alpharetta, Ga., is a few narrow bands of granite around the entrance, with glass and precast concrete elsewhere. Windward II next door dispensed with the stone altogether.
Both were started without any takers for a majority of the space, but now only a single floor in just one building is left.
Even the few taller buildings that are going up reflect lower-rise ambitions.
In the late 1980's, Equitable Real Estate Investment Management designed Monarch Tower, in Atlanta's Buckhead neighborhood, as a 30-story octagonal showpiece. Over the top, in more ways than one, was an illuminated dome, flanked by four smaller domes at the corners, made entirely of gleaming stainless steel, a building material even more expensive than brass.
Finally, a few years ago, Equitable executives realized that reality had overtaken their costly plans. A different Monarch Tower was started in June 1995 and opened to its first tenants at the beginning of this year -- the first speculative project of the new wave, says Equitable, the nation's largest real estate investor.
Instead of a 30-story octagon, the building became a 24-story box, the only flourish being 12-foot ceilings on the top floor at the request of an aluminum company's executives.
Grant A. Grimes, the building's developer, flogs the new design the way Home Depot flogs do-it-yourself kitchen cabinets. Striding into the compact lobby, he points to some surfaces with a stucco finish and others that are nothing but whitewashed drywall.
"In the 80's, the lobby would have huge volumes of space, massive amounts of stone -- marble, marble, marble," he said, waving his arms. "They wanted that prestige. They wanted it to look horribly expensive."
He lowered his arms and his voice to continue. "In the 90's, they want it to look professional, but they don't want it to look so opulent that when they bring a client in, they say, 'I can't afford you.' "
When construction began, only half the space was leased, including several floors for some Equitable operations. Now, it is more than 90 percent taken, a year ahead of schedule. Equitable plans another building just across the street.
But Equitable remains cautious in a broader sense than design. The parent company -- having, like other insurers, sold off billions in real estate -- has not put its own money in the newer projects. Though the company plans to keep much of the real estate it still has, it is discussing the sale of its real estate development, management and finance operations to the Lend Lease Corporation of Sydney, Australia.
Some developers are even now wondering when to expect the next bust. Atlanta already faces something of an apartment glut, and developers have filed zoning requests to build millions more square feet of office space in the Buckhead area.
"I'm absolutely a believer in the business cycle," Mr. Childress said, recalling that he made no profits from 1990 through mid-1993. "When things get too good, they will be overbuilt. You have a few cows go, and then the herd starts running. It's happened all my life, so why would it change now?"

HEADLINE: MONEY AND POLITICS: THE PERCEPTION;
Why a Capital Uproar Is a Hinterland Beep

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 12

 BODY:
"It's one of the great puzzlements of the year," Robert Teeter said. "How can people be so indifferent to all this seamy stuff? I don't know, but they are. Scandal is on everyone's mind in Washington and on nobody's -- or almost nobody's -- in Michigan."
Mr. Teeter, a Republican campaign consultant of long experience, who managed President George Bush's unsuccessful campaign for re-election in 1992, has a theory about this seeming disconnection between Washington and the hinterland. He sees it as a manifestation of a larger phenomenon: the decreasing importance of politics in the lives of the American people and their waning interest in it. 
 "Every person has only so much attention to give," Mr. Teeter said, "and politics and government takes up only a fraction of what it did 25 years ago. Look at the declining television coverage. Look at the declining voting rate. Economics and economic news is what moves the country now, not politics."
Mr. Teeter was one of about a dozen Michiganders asked this week to reflect on the uproar in Washington over campaign fund-raising and its failure to find much of an echo in the rest of the country. President Clinton, whose Administration and party stand at the center of the furor, has lost little of his popularity in recent weeks, according to public-opinion surveys.
Everyone interviewed agreed that the reaction here has been a shrug.
Why Michigan? It is one of those Middle Western states that has been pivotal in national elections for decades. It has a strong industrial and strong trade-union tradition, bountiful farms and sprawling suburbs, a troubled big city (Detroit) and healthier small ones. It has a a Republican governor, a Republican senator and a Democratic senator, a House delegation dominated by Democrats and a Legislature where each party controls one house.
In short, it is a lot like the United States as a whole. Bill Clinton took it by 300,000 votes in 1992 and increased his margin to 500,000 in 1996.
One obvious reason why people here and elsewhere around the country have responded so little to the accusations of impropriety and excess in fund-raising is episodic news coverage. Local television news programs carried little or nothing on the story early this week, for example. The Detroit Free Press buried the story on page 5 on Tuesday and at the bottom of page 1 today.
"Maybe this is another case of us talking to us, as people say, instead of addressing their concerns," said Robert H. Giles, editor and publisher of The Detroit News, which has reported on the fund-raising matter fairly extensively. "But just because the story doesn't resonate doesn't mean we should start ignoring it. I worry that the public is lowering the bar of expectations so much that the next bunch that gets into the White House will think it can get away with even more."
Of course, politicians are paying attention. As ever, the controversy has spawned jokes. Alluding to the hundreds of overnight guests in the Clinton White House, many of them big contributors, Gov. John Engler of Michigan told a Republican dinner in suburban Macomb County the other night, "We're the party of Lincoln; they've now become the party of the Lincoln Bedroom."
Douglas Fraser, the former president of the United Automobile Workers, said a few of his labor friends were concerned that the furor "will weaken the Presidency and with it Clinton's ability to do things that they want him to do."
But even that kind of self interest, he suggested, tends to be overwhelmed by cynicism about politicians -- "why don't they get down to work?" -- and about journalists -- "why don't they stop carping at everyone?"
As for himself, Mr. Fraser said, he views the problems in the Clinton Administration as merely an extreme form of what has gone on for years: "Politicians get panicky when they're behind," he said. "They cut corners, they promise you and put the squeeze on."
The one phrase used again and again by the old hands here is "people think that they all do it."
"It's a reflection of the success of the Republicans, in a way," said Prof. David Rohde, a political scientist at Michigan State University in East Lansing. "They've been trying to convince voters for years that government is the problem -- Reagan's phrase -- and that you can't trust politicians. Now people believe it, by and large. How can you expect people to be incensed when they view all this as simply more of the same?
"If we lived in a different world, where people considered politics a noble profession, and they thought most politicians were genuine public servants, then people would be outraged by scandals like the ones we're seeing and call for the heads of the bad guys. But not now, not in this world."
The 1996 campaign provided a foretaste of this reaction when Mr. Clinton's Republican opponent, former Senator Bob Dole, tried to make character a central issue. Polls showed that people rated Mr. Dole more highly than Mr. Clinton in that department, but most of them made their decisions based on economic considerations.
Lee C. Bollinger, the president of the University of Michigan, said that even on college campuses, "social idealism is dead or dormant, and a vast majority see the United States as king of the hill, at least for a while." This a comfortable time to live for most people, he said, and they view this "as a time to make money, pad their 401k's, not worry about the poor."
Mr. Bollinger added: "In my mind, the absence of a taste for scandal is directly linked to the lack of a social agenda. If you have no idealistic vision of your country, there is no reason to be disturbed by leaders who fall short of high ethical standards."
In that way, said Charles Eisend rath, a Michigan professor who used be a foreign correspondent, the United States may be starting to resemble France. Long accustomed to the peccadilloes of their own politicians, the French could not understand what all the fuss was in the Watergate affair and thought Americans a little nutty to bring down Richard M. Nixon, a President they considered talented.
"They thought Watergate was business as usual," Mr. Eisendrath said. "Now we're getting world-weary like them."
The only thing likely to shake the country from its torpor, said Mr. Teeter, the campaign consultant, is something similar to the Ervin committee hearings at the time of the Watergate affair -- perhaps the hearings that are to be held this spring by Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee.
"Two or three weeks of televised hearings, witnesses who become personalities the country can identify with, maybe somebody taking the Fifth Amendment -- that could grab people's attention and change their view," Mr. Teeter said, "but I really can't think what else could do that."
Joel Pitcoff, a marketing executive with the Ford Motor Company in Dearborn, agreed.
"Right now," he said, "it looks to a lot of people like reporters making a mountain out of a molehill. But give it time and exposure on television, and molehills can start looking like mountains to those same people."

HEADLINE: 2 Brokerages In Insurance To Join Forces

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Two giant New York insurance brokerages that began doing business more than a century ago, the Marsh & McLennan Companies and Johnson & Higgins, announced yesterday that they were merging. The $1.8 billion deal will make the combined company the world's largest insurance broker.
The merger, which will create a firm with more than $5.3 billion in annual revenue, was the latest in a succession of consolidations that have been sweeping the insurance and financial services industries as companies strain to achieve operating efficiency and command of their markets. 
 More mergers of insurance companies and brokerage firms, which arrange insurance coverage for corporations, are expected. Indeed, with the announcement of Marsh & McLennan's planned acquisition of Johnson & Higgins, investors began speculating that the Chicago insurance brokerage firm Arthur J. Gallagher & Company might soon become a takeover target, and Gallagher's stock jumped $1.375 to close at $33.25.
Marsh & McLennan said it would pay one-third of the $1.8 billion purchase price in cash and the balance in stock.
The market endorsed the merger of Marsh & McLennan with Johnson & Higgins, which was privately held, by bidding up Marsh & McLennan shares $7, to $129. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that a deal was imminent.
Executives of both firms as well as industry analysts said the merger would create substantial savings through the combining of many back-office operations and the elimination of some of the 36,000 jobs in the two companies in New York and at the companies' more than 500 offices throughout the world.
The companies would not say just how many jobs would be lost -- and where -- but analysts said the impact would be spread throughout the world and was unlikely to cause a tremor in the economy of New York.
"This is a worldwide thing, not a New York thing," said Ira L. Zuckerman, an analyst at Nutmeg Securities Inc. in Westport, Conn.
Ultimately the merger is expected to increase revenue at Marsh & McLennan, making it a stronger player in the economy.
"I think there will be some expense savings, but the purpose for doing this is to achieve higher growth," said A. J. C. Smith, the chairman and chief executive officer of Marsh & McLennan, which began doing business in New York in 1871.
Such combinations are increasing. In January, for example, the AON Corporation of Chicago paid $1.23 billion for Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. The AON merger gave the company total revenue of about $5 billion and, until yesterday, made it the largest insurance brokerage in the world, supplanting the longtime leader, Marsh & McLennan.
A big part of the brokerage business involves acting as an intermediary between corporations and property and casualty insurance companies. For nearly a decade, the property and casualty companies have been lowering premiums in a battle for market share, and this has hurt brokers' commissions.
Marsh & McLennan has reported net profits of more than 10 percent for the last five years, but much of its success, company executives say, is attributable to high gains by its investment subsidary as a result of the soaring stock market. Growth has been flat, analysts said, and that provided motivation for the merger.
Johnson & Higgins, founded in 1845 and also looking for growth, had considered going public as a means of raising money for acquisitions. But Ronald W. Frank, an insurance industry analyst for Smith Barney said, "This was certainly not a distress sale."
Mr. Smith estimated that savings of as much as $150 million a year could result from the merger. He estimated that several hundred people might lose their jobs, adding that much of the savings would come through consolidating offices in cities where both firms now operate. But analysts said they thought the savings were likely to be higher and that the estimate on eliminated jobs seemed conservative.
Total revenue for Marsh & McLennan last year was $4.1 billion, compared with $1.2 billion for Johnson & Higgins. While much of Marsh & McLennan's revenue came from its consulting business, the Mercer Consulting Group Inc., and its money management firm, Putnam Investments Inc., its insurance operations yielded $1.9 billion -- almost twice the revenue that Johnson & Higgins collected from insurance. About $110 million of Johnson & Higgins's revenue came from consulting.
Even though Marsh & McLennan is much larger in the insurance field, Mr. Smith said, Johnson & Higgins has the edge in several regions including the Western and the Midwestern United States. Johnson & Higgins has also been stronger in the Netherlands, and has been "a little more adventurous than we have been" in Asia, he said.
The parent company will continue to be called Marsh & McLennan, but the insurance operations of both organizations will be combined in a subsidiary to be known as J&H Marsh & McLennan Inc. Mr. Smith will retain his title and will take the same titles at the new subsidiary. David A. Olsen, the chairman and chief executive of Johnson & Higgins will become a vice chariman of Marsh & McLennan.
As the merger was being announced yesterday, Mr. Smith said, talks were continuing, in an attempt to obtain further growth through acquistion with the purchase by Marsh & McLennan of the Minet Group brokerage in London, a unit of the St. Paul Companies in Minnesota that specializes in liability insurance for professionals. The unit had revenues of $300 million from fees and commissions last year.
Some industry executives have speculated that Marsh & McLennan might be interested in selling all or part of Putnam Investments to concentrate on its core businesses. Not so, Mr. Smith said yesterday.
"We like owning it," he said of Putnam, "and we plan to continue owning all of it."

HEADLINE: Big Realty Trust to Take Over 7 Manhattan Office Towers, Long a Family's Domain

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
For decades, much of New York's vast thicket of skyscrapers, apartment houses and industrial buildings from Wall Street to midtown have been owned by a small group of family dynasties with names like Durst, Helmsley, Rudin and Mendik.
That may be starting to change. 
 Bernard Mendik, a landlord active in New York for 40 years, announced yesterday that he would merge his company and seven Manhattan office towers with Steven Roth's publicly traded Vornado Realty Trust, one of the largest shopping center owners in the country. The $437 million deal would give Mr. Roth's Vornado control of 4 million square feet of valuable Manhattan office space, including Two and 11 Penn Plaza, the giant towers standing over Pennsylvania Station, 330 Madison Avenue, 866 United Nations Plaza and 2 Park Avenue.
Mr. Roth, who built his company by buying and closing the Two Guys and Alexander's department store chains and turning the properties into lucrative real estate operations, has told friends privately that he "intends to become the largest owner of commercial real estate in New York," according to one person who has talked with him.
An analyst with Cohen & Steers Capital Management, Steven Brown, said: "This is a very focused portfolio and Mendik is strong in leasing and management. We like the focus on Manhattan where we think there's a lot of economic strength. This gives them a great platform from which to go after family- or institutionally owned property."
Mr. Roth's decision to merge his company with Mr. Mendik's should smooth Vornado's shift from shopping centers to office buildings. The company also said it would convert Vornado to an "umbrella partnership." That financial structure could prove enticing for real estate families, who would be able to trade their holdings for interests in the partnership through tax-deferred transactions.
Until recently, the New York real estate families and owners had little interest in selling out to publicly traded real estate companies. But the spiraling costs of real estate development and the aging of the families have many real estate moguls considering conversion to publicly traded real estate trusts because of the financial and tax benefits. Last year, Mr. Roth hired Michael Fascitelli, a partner at Goldman Sachs, paying him a compensation package worth an estimated $70 million to take Vornado in new directions. Recently, Mr. Roth and Mr. Fascitelli have pursued a number of properties, including Manhattan Mall, 572 Madison Avenue, 685 Third Avenue and parts of the Helmsley empire. He also is one of nine bidders for the Coliseum site at the southwest corner of Central Park.
"The financial strength of our combined companies will enable us to capitalize on opportunities, including those in the Manhattan office market," Mr. Roth said in a statement released yesterday. Mr. Mendik, who will become co-chairman of Vornado, declined to comment.
But the combination of Mr. Mendik, known as a relatively quick deal maker, and Mr. Roth, a shrewd if sometimes unpredictable negotiator, may prove difficult. Vornado, which owns 56 shopping centers in seven states, controls one of the most valuable development sites in Manhattan, the former Alexander's department store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue. But over the past several years, Mr. Roth's constantly changing negotiating terms for a tower on the Alexander's site have infuriated some prospective prime tenants, including Sotheby's and Christie's, both of which walked away from a deal.
Mr. Brown said that Mr. Roth had been criticized for "his reluctance to pull the trigger. But he has a very good track record for doing high-return deals for" Vornado. In the past year, Vornado shares have soared to more than $61, from a low of $37.125.
The deal is considered good for Mr. Mendik, who had built a large commercial real estate empire with a reputation as a savvy landlord with a talent for rehabilitating office buildings. But like many property owners during the recession in the early 1990's, Mr. Mendik came under financial pressure. He lost control of several buildings, including 260 and 261 Madison Avenue. In December, Mr. Mendik announced a plan to raise as much as $220 million through an initial public offering, a move that would have created the first publicly traded company to own office buildings in Manhattan.
That project came under some criticism from Mr. Mendik's limited partners and from analysts. Recently, Mr. Roth and Mr. Mendik opened negotiations. According to the terms of the proposed deal, which includes Mr. Mendik's management and leasing business, Vornado will pay $269 million in cash, issue $168 million in partnership units, or shares, and assume $217 million in debt. Mr. Mendik and his limited partners would get a 9 percent interest in Vornado.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Court Rejects Domestic Partner Benefits

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
A state appeals panel in New Jersey has ruled that Rutgers University does not have to provide health benefits to the domestic partners of five homosexual employees, saying that the benefits plan for state workers extends only to legal husbands and wives.
In a unanimous decision issued Tuesday, the panel of three Superior Court judges said that health benefits extend only to people defined as "dependents" under the law that established the benefits plan for state employees in 1961. Although the definition included spouses, the judges all agreed that same-sex domestic partners cannot technically be considered spouses. 
 The decision, which could ultimately affect all of the state's 60,000 employees, comes at a time when the State Legislature is considering two bills that would ban same-sex marriage in New Jersey. Both proposals have strong support in the Republican-dominated Legislature, which is expected to pass a law this year.
But lawyers for the plaintiffs said yesterday that a ban on same-sex marriages would not necessarily dim the prospects for future challenges, because New Jersey's anti-discrimination law prohibits discrimination based on marital status and sexual orientation. Lenora Lapidus, the legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union in New Jersey, said the ruling had clearly overlooked the anti-discrimination law.
"We think it is totally wrong," Ms. Lapidus, who argued the plaintiffs' case with three other lawyers, said of the ruling. "The court had every authority to say the state's interpretation of the benefits law was too narrow and that employees' families clearly encompass lesbian and gay partners."
The ruling came five years after the five employees -- four professors and a dean -- asked Rutgers, a public university, to provide health benefits for their longtime partners. Rutgers forwarded their applications to the State Division of Pensions and Benefits, which rejected them. In 1993, the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the state and the university in the law division of State Superior Court, which quickly turned it over to the appellate division.
Since the decision was unanimous, the State Supreme Court is not required to take the case. But the plaintiffs can petition the Supreme Court to review the appellate judges' decision, and they said yesterday that they would probably do so. They said they hoped the court would take up the case and rule in their favor, especially since two of the appellate judges expressed misgivings about the ruling in their written opinions.
"Of course I am disappointed, but I look at this as a waystop," said William E. Mayo, a ceramics professor at the Rutgers College of Engineering, who is among the plaintiffs. "The judges' opinions give me hope."
The other plaintiffs were three professors, William W. Derbyshire, Louie Crew and S. Schurman, and the associate dean of the School of Communication, Information and Library Studies, James D. Anderson.
Although all three judges agreed that the law that provides benefits for state employees does not extend those benefits to domestic partners, two of them said they were philosophically in favor of granting the benefits, and they suggested in their opinions that the state should reconsider its decades-old definition of "dependents."
"Times have changed," Judge Paul G. Levy wrote in his opinion. "Domestic partners and spouses and children are more and more becoming extended families with interwoven economic dependencies."
A number of public and private universities around the nation, including Princeton, Yale and the City University of New York, have extended health benefits to domestic partners of their employees in recent years. Vermont now grants benefits to the partners of its state employees, as do a number of cities, including New York.
Although Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has said she is opposed to same-sex marriages, her spokeswoman said yesterday that the Governor would not necessarily fight a law that would provide the benefits.
"She thinks it is reasonable that people should be able to assign their benefits to partners of their choice," said the spokeswoman, Becky Taylor.
But Sue Kleinberg, the Deputy Attorney General who argued the state's case, said it would be impossible to grant benefits to domestic partners of state employees in a fair and objective manner.
"What are the factors we should use to determine if domestic partners meet the definition of a spouse?" she said. "They can give us a list, but other people are going to come along with other factors they believe are significant, and the definition would just keep growing."
Ms. Kleinberg said the state believed that "any kind of plain reading of the definition has to mean a married partner."

HEADLINE: Clinton Proposes Increases In Spending on Highways

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today announced a six-year transportation plan that would sharply increase maintenance money for Interstates and other major highways.
The plan would also provide more money for enforcing truck safety laws and for arresting those driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
 In addition, the President's proposal would provide $600 million to help people on welfare get to work, including financing van pools, and increase spending on vehicle safety studies and on computerized "intelligent" road and vehicle systems to reduce traffic. It would eliminate Federal subsidies for mass transit operations, but increase the amount of money under the control of state and local governments.
Over all, the plan would authorize $175 billion in spending, about $17 billion more than the last six-year plan, which was approved by Congress in 1991. But actual spending under the old plan did not reach the authorized levels, and it is unclear whether Congress will fully fund this plan if it is adopted.
Like the plans of previous administrations, this one contains no "demonstration projects," or money earmarked for specific roads or bridges -- but Congress has always added them.
"Today, we're taking the next big step to maintain and modernize our transportation system and to make sure it is the best in the world," said President Clinton, announcing the plan at the White House today.
Later at a news conference, Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater said that with the Interstate highway system complete "the great majority of the dollars will go to preserving the system that we have, and that could include some enhancement expenditures."
As calculated by the Administration, spending for maintenance of the Interstates and other major routes would increase by 30 percent but mass transit investments would be maintained "at high levels."
Asked if this was a shift toward highways, Mr. Slater said the plan was "clearly about more than highways."
"We will continue a sustained record level of transit investment because of this bill," he said.
The proposal would also let the states charge tolls on Interstate highways. Mortimer L. Downey, the deputy secretary, called this "a minor suggestion."
"We do not believe that a lot of states will take advantage of the opportunity," Mr. Downey said. The Transportation Department would have no authority over the tolls charged, he said, but the courts have determined that the fees must be "just and reasonable."
The new plan, the National Economic Crossroads Transportation Efficiency Act, would replace the the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991, which allowed states more power to make spending choices, including those between highways and other transportation systems.
Dennis M. Kouba, a spokesman for the American Public Transit Association, offered this view of the new plan: "We're not completely happy with the transit authorization levels proposed, but at the same time, the flexible fund programs beneficial to transit are proposed to have a large increase in authorization."
In addition, he noted, the plan would let transit authorities use capital for repairs, the sort of flexibility he said highway departments had had for years. "We are pleased with the overall direction" of the President's proposal, he said.
The Administration's proposal comes as a major battle is developing in Congress over whether the highway financing system, largely financed by the gasoline tax, is a mechanism for unfair subsidies among the states. Officials in some Eastern states say they get back less than 70 cents for each dollar they pay in taxes. And some Plains states say their roads are used mainly for long-haul transportation across their borders, for which residents should not have to pay.
The Administration's plan calls for a guarantee that each state will receive at least 90 percent of what it pays. It was not clear whether Congress would accept that compromise.
The authorization bills sometimes have an air of unreality, even as they are passed. Mr. Downey said that under the current plan authorization in the first five years was kept low because it came under an overall national budget plan passed earlier. But in the final year, which ends on Sept. 30, a larger amount of money was authorized for transportation -- but the money was never appropriated at the higher level.
Under today's proposal, New York State would receive an average of $1.159 billion, or 5.78 percent of the national pie, up from $994.9 million or 5.47 percent; New Jersey 578.4 million, or 2.88 percent, up from $488.7 million, or 2.83 percent, and Connecticut $375 million, or 1.87 percent. Connecticut's dollar amount would be higher than the previous $340.5 million, but the percentage would decline from 1.97 percent. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Key West Journal;
Finding Toil and Sweat Instead of a Spring Break

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla., March 8

 BODY:
Michael Morton had expected three days of spring break bliss -- meeting girls on the beach, watching the sunset, cruising the bars -- but his plans went terribly awry. On the second day, he spent eight hours picking up trash.
The tumble from vacation to forced labor began at a bar only hours after Mr. Morton drove into town this week. Looking at a driver's license with the picture of Mr. Morton's 26-year-old brother, the doorman waved over a police officer from across the street. In no time, Mr. Morton, who is 20, was handcuffed, booked and ordered to show up in court at 8 A.M. the next day for violating under-age-drinking laws. 
 Mr. Morton, a sophomore at Appalachian State University in North Carolina, was told he could wipe out any record of the charge by paying a $175 fine or picking up after fellow spring-break students on the beaches and in the parks.
Mr. Morton was among the first college students this year detailed to what students call Key West's "spring break chain gang" by a special court that convenes only in the March-April vacation weeks.
Last year the court sentenced 191 students to work details in the orange jail shirts of Monroe County for flouting drinking laws. The work includes pulling weeds, painting government buildings and straightening files in the county jail.
The hundreds of students who have come before what is known as Spring Break Court have been given the option of a day of community service, a $175 fine or a trial.
The court is a way to relieve clogging of the jails and courtrooms from arrests on spring break, usually for the use of false identification. Law-enforcement officials say that 30,000 to 45,000 students descend on this island in the Florida Keys in March. On any given night 10,000 of them can be hanging out on Duval Street, the main commercial strip, looking for a good time.
The law-enforcement program also underscores the love-hate relationship between spring-break students and regions whose economies depend on tourism. In Florida, a spring-break mecca, municipalities like Fort Lauderdale have all but banned the students, through crackdowns on public drinking and advertisements intended to attract older tourists and families.
Even in Key West, where officials still welcome students, some hotels screen them out or require a $500 deposit to cover possible damage.
"They'll yank the commode and throw it into the pool," said Roger Comegys, an information consultant with the Key West Information Center.
But bar owners and employees say that most students behave.
"Most of the trouble is not spring-breakers," said Mitchell Hein, a chef at the Barefoot Bob's bar-restaurant, but "people in their 30's reliving their childhood."
Florida tourism officials do not keep track of students separately from the 43 million visitors who come to the state each year, but Key West's court numbers show a downward trend in arrests.
Mr. Morton and four other students said they had used false I.D. cards because there was little else to do at night here other than hang out in the watering holes, which remain open until 4 A.M. and entice customers with live music and wet T-shirt contests.
"What are you going to do?" Mr. Morton asked. "Walk around?"
The students also contended that the enforcement crackdown on under-age drinkers was too harsh. In some cities, they said, a bouncer would just confiscate their cards.
Several students called the SpringBreak Court just a way for Key West to make money and save on trash collection, at their expense. On the day the five chose to work, most of them for lack of money for the fine, two others chose to pay.
"I have the money and I don't feel like being degraded on the beach," said Jonathan Meyer, 20, a psychology major at Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton.
Law-enforcement officials say the students should be thankful. Before the advent of the court, they said, students who broke the law would typically spend the night in jail and still face fines and convictions on their record.
That was not obviously apparent to the students as they bent under a stinging sun to collect trash, receiving stares from joggers and taunts from passing cars.
Judge Wayne M. Miller of Monroe County Circuit Court, however, functioned more like a school principal than a criminal court officer as he took the students' pleas and admonished them to have fun "within the law," respect the crew leaders from the city's Department of Public Works and behave. That means, Judge Miller said, that "if you happen to see a woman in a bikini while you're wearing that orange shirt you keep your mouth shut."
By the end of the day, after collecting about 3,000 pounds of trash, the students' mortification had dissolved into "thank you's" and handshakes with their crew leaders and each other.
Did they learn a lesson?
"The only lesson I learned was trying to get a better I.D.," Mr. Morton said before his 14-hour drive back to North Carolina.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Justin Higgins, 19, of Appalachian State University, who has been on work details in Key West, Fla., for breaking the law on under-age drinking. (Andrew Itkoff for The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Congress Seeks to Assess Mexico's Anti-Drug Efforts
Congress, bending to Administration pressure, sought to find a way to criticize Mexico over drugs without harming its economy. A bill under consideration in the House would revoke President Clinton's certification of Mexico as fully cooperating in fighting drug trafficking. But the White House threatened a veto, even though the bill would allow Mr. Clinton to waive the legal effects of the decertification, and the likelihood that it would pass appeared to be dwindling. A1
 
Key Testimony in Drug Case
A former Mexican police officer, testifying in a civil trial in Houston, identified a former deputy attorney general of Mexico to whom he said he delivered narcotics protection money in 1994. It was the most important testimony to date in the case, in which United States prosecutors have been constructing an image of systematic narcotics corruption, showing Mexico's law enforcement officials as being in the pay of drug traffickers. A12
 
Rebels Near Albanian Capital
Rebel gunfire pressed closer to the Albanian capital, Tirana, where gangs carried off weapons from two military sites and Western embassies organized evacuations. Looters also stormed an arms depot near Elbasan, 22 miles southeast of Tirana. In the oil refining center of Ballsh, 50 miles from the capital, insurgents plundered an armory and took control over a main highway through southern Albania. A5
 
Nigeria Charges Dissidents
Nigeria's military Government charged a Nobel laureate, Wole Soyinka, and 11 other dissidents with treason in connection with a series of bombings of army installations. The charge against Mr. Soyinka carries a potential death penalty, though he fled Nigeria in November 1994 and lives abroad. A6
 
Peru Talks Deadlock
Talks to bring a peaceful end to the hostage crisis in Peru broke down, with both sides saying they had failed to agree on important points. While the discussions had been expected to produce the outlines of an agreement toward ending the crisis, the meeting ended with no progress. It was the first meeting since talks broke down over rebel allegations that the Government was building tunnels to attack them. A13
 
Israeli Premier 'Fed Up'
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel declared he was "fed up" with charges that his actions had violated the Israeli-Palestinian peace accords. The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, who has apparently refused to talk to Mr. Netanyahu, prepared to convene a meeting in Gaza to discuss the peace agreements; Israel was not invited. A10
 
The United Nations Palestinian observer opened a General Assembly debate on the Israeli Government's plan to build a Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem by condemning the plan as illegal. A11
 
NATIONAL A16-24, B9-11
 
President Shelves Plan For Price Index Commission
Administration officials said President Clinton had decided to shelve the idea of establishing a commission to look into recalculating the cost-of-living adjustments in the consumer price index, which studies said was overstating inflation. A1
 
U.S. Tipped on Lobbying Plan
The Government began to investigate China's lobbying efforts early last year after the National Security Agency picked up hints about China's effort, including its willingness to funnel money to American politicians, law enforcement officials said. They said the hints were discovered while eavesdropping on conversations between Beijing and Chinese officials in the United States. A1

Transportation Plan Announced
The Clinton Administration announced a six-year transportation plan that would raise the amount of money available for maintaining major highways, including interstates. Other elements of the proposal would increase money for enforcing truck safety and drunken driving laws. Overall, it would increase spending on transportation by $17 billion from the amount in the previous six-year plan. A16

Republicans Seek New Budget
The Republican majority in the House endorsed a nonbinding resolution to require the White House to submit a second budget for the coming year. Congressional analysts have described the first one as flawed by overly optimistic assumptions about the economy. The White House said it had no intention of offering a new budget and called on the Republicans to propose their own alternative. B11

Philadelphia Worries Over Trial
Testimony concluded in the trial of two men in the killing of a 26-year-old jogger in Center City Philadelphia in November 1995. The defense focused on allegations of misdeeds by the police, leaving some Philadelphians worried that the guilty would go free and others fearing that the real killer was still at large. A16
 
Restraint Urged on Cloning Ban
Scientists and ethicists testifying before a Senate panel urged Congress not to rush to ban research on the cloning of human beings. The specialists, including Dr. Ian Wilmut, the Scottish scientist who announced the first cloning of a mammal, said there was no immediate crisis because the methods for sheep would have to be made much more efficient before being used with humans. B11
 
High Court Rebuffs Muslims
The Supreme Court rejected a Muslim group's request that it remove a 66-year-old marble depiction of the prophet Mohammed from its courtroom. Islamic tradition discourages artistic renderings of people, especially Mohammed. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said he had decided against removing the work but would change the Court's literature describing it. (Reuters)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Albany Democrats Propose Big Rise in School Spending
The Democratic leaders of the New York Assembly proposed increasing school spending by more than 50 percent over five years. The proposal, using money from an unexpected boom in income tax receipts, would make preschool available for all 4-year-olds in the state. Governor Pataki and the Republican-controlled Senate want to use the money for property tax relief instead. B1

Gay Partners' Benefits Denied
An appeals panel ruled that Rutgers University did not have to provide health benefits to the domestic partners of five gay employees. The ruling, which ultimately could affect all New Jersey state employees, said the benefits plan for state workers extended only to legal spouses. B4

New Charges for Nightclub King
Peter Gatien, whose Manhattan nightclub empire was partly shut down after his indictment on Federal drug charges, was arrested again. State prosecutors said he had cheated New York City and State out of more than $1.3 million in taxes. Mr. Gatien's lawyer said there was a legitimate explanation. B2

Protest Over AIDS Classes
Students and their advocates passed out condoms and demonstrated in front of more than 30 New York City high schools. The students said many of their peers do not receive mandated health classes on AIDS. B3

Plan Announced for Airport Link
The Port Authority said it expected to start construction this summer on a rail line to Kennedy International Airport. The Giuliani administration, which also wants a link to La Guardia Airport and can stall the plan if it chooses to, complained. B7

HEADLINE: Confronting Medicare

 BODY:
To The Home Section:
It is no wonder that Medicare expenses continue to grow at double the inflation rate, when nonessential health problems like erectile dysfunction (impotence) are covered ("How One Man Confronted and Conquered Impotence," Feb. 6). The evaluation of impotence is very expensive (more than $5,000 in many cases) and rarely changes the therapy. The therapies are expensive (penile prosthesis is $3,000, not including the fees for the surgeon, anesthesiology and hospitalization) and injections or urethral instillations are $25 to $50 a dose. 
 The diversion of scarce health-care dollars to nonessential health problems is wrong. Impotence, prostate ultrasonography, urine flow rates and urodynamics represent a waste of health dollars as they are unnecessary, inaccurate and expensive. Eliminating nonessential services will correct a great deal of Medicare's financial problems.
 
W. REID PITTS JR., M.D.
New York
 
Associate Professor of
Urology, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College

HEADLINE: Republican Demand: A Realistic Budget

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Trying to turn up the public and political pressure on President Clinton over budget negotiations, House Republicans today approved a nonbinding resolution that would require the White House to submit a second budget to replace one that Congressional analysts say is flawed.
The budget resolution passed on a vote of 231 to 197. 
 Democrats called the vote "a cynical attempt to make the President look bad."
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the Republican majority leader, said he hoped Mr. Clinton would accept the resolution as "as an invitation and an encouragement."
The Administration insisted again today that it would not send a new budget to Congress. Instead, it renewed calls for the Republican majority to offer its alternative.
"I think the resolution is totally unhelpful," said Franklin D. Raines, the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget. "It is a diversion from the real work and is a weak effort to try to disguise the fact that the President has the only detailed budget before the nation."
The resolution carries no legal weight and does not require matching action in the Senate, but House Republicans used the debate today to set their benchmark in the budget negotiations.
"While we, as the Congress, are committed to negotiating a balanced budget agreement with the White House, there is one non-negotiable item determined by the American taxpayer," said Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, the Republican of upstate New York who heads the Rules Committee. "Any budget agreement must achieve balance in 2002 by using Congressional Budget Office scoring."
A recent analysis of the Clinton plan by the Congressional Budget Office found that it had used overly optimistic assumptions about the performance of the economy and would actually leave a $69 billion deficit in 2002.
Unless the White House agrees to a budget that balances by Congressional Budget Office calculations, Mr. Solomon vowed today that he would use his position as rules chairman to block the Clinton plan.
"Actually achieving balance through real and significant spending cuts is the whole ball game," he said.
Republicans also complained that the Clinton budget put off a major part of its deficit reduction until two years after Mr. Clinton's second term has expired; does not save Medicare from bankruptcy, and provides no permanent tax break.
Even as Mr. Armey was affirming the Republicans' commitment to tax cuts, however, another senior House Republican leader, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, was questioning that strategy.
"We might find ourselves in a position where we are better served fighting over spending first and then going after tax cuts," Mr. DeLay said in an interview with The Associated Press.
Mr. DeLay is the House majority whip, the No. 3 Republican leader, but his idea is likely to be unpopular with Mr. Armey and many other Republicans who have made tax cuts the centerpiece of their politics.
Mr. Delay's spokesman, John Feehery, said the majority whip was not backing away from his commitment to tax cuts, but was suggesting that the issue be taken up later in the year.
"The idea is to get the spending cuts done and signed by the President and then later on get a tax cut that might be even more substantial," Mr. Feehery said.
The resolution that passed the House today requests that the President submit to Congress "a detailed plan that balances the budget" by April 7, eight days before the statutory deadline for completion of the Federal spending plan.
Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the Budget Committee, called the resolution "pointless."
"The President has already sent us a budget that fully complies with the budget act," Mr. Spratt said.
The Congressional Budget Act requires the House and the Senate to agree on a budget by April 15.

HEADLINE: Congress Seeks Ways to Chastise Mexico on Drugs

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Bending to Clinton Administration pressure, Congress began struggling today for a way to criticize Mexico over its lapses in fighting drugs without disrupting the Mexican economy.
The White House warned today that President Clinton might veto a House bill that would overturn his recent finding that Mexico was "fully cooperating" with the United States in fighting drug trafficking, even though the measure would permit the President to spare Mexico the economic sanctions imposed on countries that are designated as not cooperating. A vote on the bill is scheduled for Thursday. 
 There seemed little likelihood that Congress would approve such a bill, at least not soon. Committees in both houses are seeking milder expressions of unhappiness after Administration officials and business executives warned that "decertifying" Mexico -- labeling the country uncooperative -- ran the risk of undermining foreign investors' confidence.
Administration officials, including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, have warned that the bill, if it becomes law, could deal a blow to the Mexican economy comparable to the sudden devaluation of the peso two years ago; that led to a financial crisis that forced the Administration to stitch together a bailout plan, though Mexico has repaid the $12.5 billion in United States loans.
Officials have also said they fear that a Congressional condemnation would lead to a political backlash in Mexico that would reduce its efforts to combat drugs, not increase them.
As senior officials sought to reassure Congress today about Mexican efforts to fight drugs, prosecutors at a civil trial in Houston were painting a picture of pervasive corruption in Mexico: A former police agent testified that he had delivered suitcases full of cash to Mexico's top drug official. [Page A12.]
The first Congressional effort to find a way out of the certification quandary without appearing indifferent toward narcotics corruption will be a House proposal to leave the certification in place if President Clinton, within 90 days, reports he has received "reliable assurance of substantial progress" toward a variety of anti-drug goals.
Such assurances would include commitments to extradite Mexicans indicted for crimes, to allow United States drug agents to carry handguns in Mexico and to develop a radar net to track drug traffickers' planes.
The Administration took no position on that proposal, put forward today by House Republican leaders, but Democrats warned that it too might invite a veto. Lesser proposals being debated include a "sense of Congress" resolution that would urge both the United States and Mexican Governments to make progress on fighting drugs.
The legal effect of labeling Mexico uncooperative would be to bar foreign aid to Mexico, of which there is very little, and to require the United States to vote against loans by international lending institutions.
Administration witnesses warned again today that grave results would follow. Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee that the "true damage would come from undercutting our support for those in Mexico committed to reform, and from undermining investor confidence in the close cooperation between our countries and in the strength of our American commitment to work with Mexico."
Barry R. McCaffrey, director of the White House office of National Drug Control Policy, told the Senators that decertification "would impair our ability to effect cooperative counter-drug efforts."
He said that the current situation was "extremely explosive" and that the Mexican Government had already been harshly criticized for "excessive deference of their sovereignty to the United States."
Their testimony seemed to have an impact but left some Senators plainly frustrated. Senator Paul Coverdell, the Georgia Republican who heads the Western Hemisphere subcommittee, repeatedly told Administration witnesses that while he did not want to inflame Mexican opinion, "the status quo will not do."
Other senators were blunter. Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat, said, "I did not agree with anything that Mr. Summers said about how things could get worse."
She also praised today's testimony by Thomas A. Constantine, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, whose description of Mexican corruption and the influence of narcotics cartels appeared grimmer than the accounts by other Administration witnesses.
Mr. Constantine said he was taking no position on whether Mexico should be certified as cooperative. But he said the Administration's finding that Colombia was not fully cooperating had spurred anti-drug efforts there, and some Senators took that as an argument for the same step toward Mexico.
One advocate of that view, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, complained that too much concern was being offered about Mexico's hurt feelings. "We're getting window dressing," he said.
In the House, Republican leaders swung behind the 90-day extension today, saying it was intended to focus attention on the Administration's failure to win important Mexican cooperation. That proposal would also allow certification only if the President obtained "assurances of substantial progress by, and commitments from" Mexico to take "concrete measures to find and eliminate law enforcement corruption" and to "cooperate fully with United States law enforcement personnel on narcotics control."
