HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

President Postpones Plan To Set Up Inflation Panel
President Clinton has shelved for now the idea of establishing a commission to recalculate the way in which Social Security and other benefit payments are adjusted for inflation, Administration officials said.
The officials said talks with members of Congress suggested the issue of creating the panel was so divisive that it might poison the entire budget-making process. But they said the idea may be revived later. [Page A1.]
 
Fed Reports Moderate Wage Gains
Despite a persistently low unemployment rate, American workers have generally been unable to win significantly higher pay, while improved productivity has enabled companies to keep costs in check, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of economic conditions suggested. As a result, the economy is making only moderate gains that would not seem to press the Fed to raise interest rates. [D4.] 

BankAmerica Fills Key Job
BankAmerica, filling one of the most prominent open jobs in banking, chose Eugene Lockhart, left, the chief executive of Mastercard International, as president of its consumer banking division. Mastercard, in turn, named Robert Selander, who had run its European operations, to replace Mr. Lockhart. [D4.]
 
G.E. Paid Welch $6.3 Million
John F. Welch Jr., the chairman and chief executive of General Electric, was paid $6.3 million in salary and bonus last year, an 18.4 percent increase over 1995. [D4.]
 
Sylvan Learning Plans Acquisition
Sylvan Learning Systems agreed to buy the once-troubled National Education Corporation for about $750 million in stock. [D6.]
 
Two Retailers Report Profits
Toys "R" Us reported a fourfold rise in earnings, after charges, while Woolworth moved onto profitable ground. [D19.]
 
General Mills Posts 5.6% Gain
General Mills, in line with forecasts, reported a 5.6 percent earnings gain, despite drops in sales and domestic cereal volume. [D21.]
 
Smith Barney and Lehman Fined
Several thousand account holders at Smith Barney and Lehman Brothers who were overcharged when they sold mutual funds, will receive $5.6 million in refunds, regulators said. The firms were fined $250,000 each. [D2.]
 
G.M. Parts' Profits Prop Up Cars
G.M., after decades of secrecy, broke out financial information on its sprawling auto parts operations. It confirmed what analysts had long suspected: profits from the auto parts division, Delphi Automotive Systems, were propping up otherwise weak results in the car-building business. [D6.]
 
Real Estate Companies to Merge
Bernard Mendik, a New York landlord, plans to a merge his company and seven Manhattan office towers with Steven Roth's Vornado Realty Trust, a big owner of shopping centers, in a $437 million deal. [B8.]
 
Murdoch's Plans Pose Challenge
By going from being a media mogul to a multimedia mogul, Rupert Murdoch seems to be threatening several industries all at once. His plans to invest $1 billion in a satellite television service to be called Sky have made him an ominous figure to people in both the cable and broadcasting industries. News Analysis. [D21.]

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO DEFER PLANS FOR PANEL ON A PRICE INDEX

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to shelve for now the idea of establishing a commission to recalculate cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other benefit payments that are tied to an index that many economists say overstates inflation, Administration officials said today.
The officials said the Administration was not ruling out reopening the issue later, perhaps even in time to use it as part of any agreement between the White House and Congress this year to balance the Federal budget by 2002. 
 Reacting to studies saying that the Government's current inflation gauge, the Consumer Price Index, overstates inflation, some members of both parties have been seeking to reduce cost-of-living payments to help insure the long-term viability of the Social Security program and to help eliminate the Federal deficit.
For the last several weeks Mr. Clinton has been studying whether to support the creation of a commission of economists that would set a more accurate -- and presumably lower -- cost-of-living adjustment than the price index provides.
But after extensive talks with members of Congress and others, Administration officials said they had determined that there would be such strong opposition to setting up a panel now to deal with the issue that it would set off a political hue and cry sufficient to poison the entire budget process, perhaps fatally.
The decision, which was first reported by The Washington Post in its Thursday issue, is almost certain to provoke criticism of Mr. Clinton from proponents of the idea in both parties, particularly Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader. Mr. Lott has been publicly pushing for a commission to deal with the issue and last week said that only Mr. Clinton's leadership could overcome the political obstacles to making it happen.
But other Republicans were cool to the proposal, in part because they feared being attacked by Democrats as shortchanging the elderly to pay for the tax cut proposals being pushed by the Republican leadership. And indeed many Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, came out staunchly against the idea of a commission.
At the same time, influential pressure groups like the American Association of Retired Persons and a number of labor organizations made clear that they would go all-out to fight the idea of a commission, saying any improvements to the price index should be made by the experts within the Bureau of Labor Statistics and not by a politically appointed panel.
Opponents of a commission made clear to the White House that any downward adjustment in cost-of-living payments could not be seen as even indirectly paying for tax cuts, especially the capital gains tax cut proposed by the Republicans to trim the tax rate on investment profits.
"The goal of doing a cost-of-living commission at this moment was to take the issue out of politics and to make it an issue of technical accuracy only," a senior Administration official said tonight. "There was a large, significant reaction from all sides that doing a commission at this moment, in this context, might have the opposite reaction and serve to politicize the issue."
But the official said the White House wanted to leave open the possibility of finding a less politically explosive way of dealing with the issue, perhaps by postponing consideration of it until after Congress and the Administration reach a broad agreement on balancing the budget.
"We are not ruling in or out whether it could be done at other times or in other contexts," the official said.
Reducing the cost-of-living formula, even slightly, could save tens of billions of dollars in the next five years, making it much easier for Congressional Republicans and the White House to agree on a budget deal. Given the differences between the Administration and the Republican leadership on taxes and spending, some members of Congress had said the only way to get a budget agreement was to have a bipartisan agreement on the cost-of-living issue.
Efforts to negotiate a budget deal have been stalled for weeks. Republicans have been lambasting the Administration's budget proposal as built on unrealistic assumptions, and today the House passed a resolution asking the White House to submit a new budget.
Administration officials responded by noting that the Republicans have yet to make a proposal of their own and that any Republican proposal would have to include such deep spending cuts to pay for the party's proposed tax cuts that it would subject the Republicans to a painful political backlash. To some extent, both parties have been waiting for a resolution of the cost-of-living issue before determining how to proceed on budget negotiations.
Whether Mr. Clinton's decision today accelerates the budget process or derails it could depend on how much Republican criticism is generated. With relations between the parties already strained by revelations about possible campaign finance abuses by the Administration, some Democrats have said in recent days that the budget process could be imperiled by any return to the intense partisanship that surrounded budget talks over the past few years.

HEADLINE: Capital Gains Taxpayers Get No Free Loan;
Risk Deserves Reward

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "No Change in Capital Gains" (editorial, March 10): You would do well to return to Econ 101. A capital investment incurs a risk of loss as well as profit. Wages and other income are essentially risk-free. In a capitalistic world, it is important that capital risks be taken to create economic growth. To tax gains on capital investment at close to the same rate as other income reduces incentives to risk capital, reducing economic growth.
 
CHARLES J. PRIZER
Longboat Key, Fla., March 10, 1997

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Serious Side of an Infatuation With Fashion

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Maybe even important artists can miss their true calling. This idea may cross the mind more than once during "Art/Fashion," a sometimes wonderful, spiffily turned-out exhibition of art-related fashion and fashion-related art at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo.
The notion registers in the show's first gallery, where a bright, dynamic vest designed by the Futurist Giacomo Balla may strike some as more appealing, in a Paul Smith sort of way, than his paintings. It pops up again in a gallery dominated by the boldly geometric clothing and designs of the painter Sonia Delaunay. It is stunning to see Delaunay transpose the ideas of modernist abstraction onto women's backs; a similar translation occurs in the emblematic, paper-doll-like fashion drawings of the Russian Constructivist Varvara Stepanova. 
 The show has been organized by Germano Celant, a curator at the Guggenheim; Ingrid Sischy, editor of Interview magazine, and Pandora Asbaghi Tabatabai, an independent curator and director of the Prada Foundation, and its beginning is thrilling. Designed by Arata Isozaki, who has credibly broken up the monotonous rectilinearity of the Guggenheim's SoHo galleries, it recalls a time when modernist artists and designers alike sometimes saw garments as just another surface for painting or carving.
It can make fashion design seem as vital and creative as any art form, and both an expression of and vehicle for social change. It continues the reshuffling of the art-media hierarchy that started in earnest with the Museum of Modern Art's "High and Low" exhibition. And it infuses some welcome seriousness into the season's most prominent craze: the mutual infatuation of art and fashion.
Last fall, that infatuation spawned the first Biennale di Firenze, subtitled "Looking at Fashion." The Florence show seems to have been a three-ring circus of six or seven exhibitions -- including ones devoted to Bruce Weber's photographs and Elton John's costumes -- plus 18 installations by big-name fashion designers who were set loose in some of the city's most venerable museums and buildings. (Valentino, for example, surrounded Michelangelo's "David" with five mannequins in red dresses.) "Art/Fashion" is a condensed version of what was probably the most restrained and thoughtful segment of the Florentine extravaganza. In its first half, it surveys the interaction between art and fashion down through the 20th century, although it has (understandably) a bit of an Italian bias, and is hardly exhaustive. (Exhaustive would require something like the Fashion Institute of Technology's superb "Fashion and Surrealism" exhibition of 1987 applied to the last 97 years.)
There is a crisply Minimalist dress designed in 1952 by Ellsworth Kelly, and two "slit" ones by Lucio Fontana seen beside three of his paintings. Andy Warhol does Pop, making a dress printed with "Fragile/Handle With Care" labels, while Getulio Alviani does Op stripes. Elsa Schiaparelli of course does Surrealism: her famous "Tear Dress" of 1937, made with fabric by Salvador Dali printed with trompe l'oeil rips, is on loan from the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Certain moments in performance art are recaptured: by Nam June Paik's "TV Bra," worn by the cellist Charlotte Moorman, and, more obscurely, by three found-object hats made by the Pattern painter Robert Kushner in the mid-1970's. The Camille-like sensibility of Colette is summed up by a nearly picture-perfect mannequin of the artist swathed in satin flounces. Displayed publicly for the first time in years are drawings proposing "wrapped" dresses and jump suits by Christo; also on view is his "Wedding Dress," a highly symbolic tableau that consists mostly of a large wrapped bundle pulled by a female mannequin.
As the exhibition moves into the present, further away from wearable garments and closer to art, it gets weaker and weaker. Sparsely installed, it maintains its elegant store-window look but barely scratches the surface of a very robust trend in current art. A tired Surrealism alternates with an equally empty formalism: Jana Sterbak's organza "Nightgown," which has a patch of curling chest hair, and Wiebke Siem's geometric hats; Jan Fabre's sinister suspended gowns made of real scarabs, and Judith Shea's sculptures of simplified pants. In front of works like these, one longs for something by Issey Miyake, Rei Kawakubo or Martin Margiela, designers whose idiosyncratic garments may vary in wearability but usually bristle with artistic ambition.
Only Charles LeDray's strange little groupings of miniature clothes, magazines and accessories achieves real emotional resonance. Laid out on the floor like stolen goods displayed for sale on an East Village sidewalk in Barbieland, its compressed panorama makes one think of fashion's changeability, of economic desperation and of the artist's own compulsive love of sewing. Mr. LeDray made every last tiny item in the piece, which bears the title "Workworkworkworkwork."
The show ends with a gallery documenting six collaborations between artists and designers seen in Florence, including Miuccia Prada and Damien Hirst, Helmut Lang and Jenny Holzer, and Azzedine Alaia and Julian Schnabel. These are conveyed by big, backlighted color transparencies placed in reduced replicas of the one-room wood buildings that Mr. Isozaki designed for the Biennale. Maybe one had to be there. Here, these concoctions form a vapid, frivolous final note that contradicts most of the exhibition by suggesting that art and fashion should be kept as far apart as possible.
"Art/Fashion" remains at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, 575 Broadway, at Prince Street, through June 8.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Rises on U.S. Data Favorable to a Rate Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday, in a rally driven by new evidence of American economic health suggesting that the Federal Reserve might indeed raise interest rates late this month. Demand for the dollar overcame the depressing effects of sharp declines in stock and bond markets.
"Today was a pure dollar move, about as pure as you get," said Ben Strauss, a senior foreign-exchange trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York. "We'd be considerably higher if it weren't for the stock and bond markets. It's remarkable we've been able to hold on to our gains." 
 The dollar traded as high as 1.7064 marks before settling in New York at 1.7056 marks, up from 1.6932 marks on Wednesday. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar closed at its highest level since Feb. 19 -- 123.41 yen, up from 122.34 on Wednesday. The British pound eased to $1.5974 from $1.5992.
The catalyst for the dollar's strength was a Commerce Department report showing a surprising surge in February retail sales and a strong upward revision for January. In addition, the Labor Department's weekly report on jobless claims, which had been expected to show a moderate increase, fell instead.
The data came a day after the Fed's survey of regional business conditions, known as the beige book, suggested that the economy was growing mildly with little inflation. This was taken as meaning that the Fed would refrain from raising interest rates at its meeting on March 25.
"What we had today was an exact reversal of yesterday," said Earl I. Johnson, foreign-exchange economist at the Bank of Montreal in Chicago.
Some traders said the dollar was also helped by reports that Guntram Palm, a senior member of the German central bank's rate-setting council, was not concerned about the dollar's strength. Other bank officials, including the president, Hans Tietmeyer, have been saying that the dollar's two-year rebound from postwar lows against the mark is now complete, which hurt the dollar on Wednesday.
"Palm's comments that we've got no problem with the dollar being up here made it go right back up," said Jesse Torres, chief dealer at the New York branch of Bank Austria.

HEADLINE: FINANCE BRIEFS

 BODY:

Debt
 
* Chase Manhattan Corp., New York, is selling $250 million of zero-coupon subordinated medium-term notes due in 2027 through Paine Webber Inc. The notes, which are callable in 10 years, pay no quarterly interest. At maturity the notes will yield 8.25 percent. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service, A- by Standard & Poor's and A by Duff & Phelps. 

* Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2004 through Lehman Brothers. The notes, which are callable in three years, carry an interest rate of 7.11 percent and are priced at par.
 
* Federal National Mortgage Association is selling $100 million of medium-term step-up notes due in 2000 through Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. The notes, which have a one-time call on April 6, 1998, carry a 6.14 percent coupon and are priced at par. If the notes are not called, the coupon increases, or steps up, to 7 percent.
 
* Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, is selling $500 million of debentures due in 2002 through Lehman Brothers and J. P. Morgan Securities. The debentures, which are callable in a year, carry an interest rate of 7.08 percent and are priced at par.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Decline on Solid Retail Sales Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities tumbled in heavy trading yesterday after the Commerce Department reported stronger-than-expected retail sales for February, feeding investor concern that the economy is growing fast enough to accelerate inflation and cause the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates.
The Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee is set to meet on March 25, and the chances of a rate increase seem to be improving. 
 Maureen Mooney, an analyst with Govpx Inc., a bond pricing service, said the value of securities traded went above $100 billion for only the fifth time this year. Yesterday's selloff sent the price of the benchmark 30-year bond, by which many lending rates are set, down 30/32, to 95 29/32, pushing its yield up to 6.95 percent, from 6.88 percent on Wednesday. That was the highest level since 6.98 percent on Sept. 24, a result of the market building in an expected quarter-point rate rise.
The Commerce Department said retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, exceeding the seven-tenths of 1 percent gain expected by analysts. Excluding autos, sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent. Sales in January were revised to reflect a gain of 1.5 percent, the biggest in more than a year.
Adding to concerns about growth and bolstering the case for a Fed rate increase was a separate report that first-time claims for unemployment insurance fell by 5,000 in the week ended March 8 to 307,000; analysts had expected a drop of 2,000.
One report that did not point to robust growth was the Atlanta Fed's survey of business activity, which showed a nationwide business slip for manufacturers based in the Southeast. The survey's index fell to a reading of 7.0 in February from a revised 13.8 in January.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said: "The unusually strong retail sales statistics this morning most certainly caught the attention of the F.O.M.C. Strength was very much in evidence in durable goods spending, particularly the automotive sector and department stores sales."
While a strong February number was expected, Mr. Fine said, it was the size of the January revision that surprised market participants. Soon afterward, gross domestic product and consumption forecasts for the first quarter were revised upward, adding to the pressure on the market. At the same time, the latest figures for initial jobless claims confirmed the continuing tightness in the labor market: The four-week moving average reached an eight-year low at 310,250.
"Indeed, since Greenspan first delivered his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony on Feb. 26, virtually every economic statistic has been on the upside, and in some cases dramatically so," Mr. Fine said. "As a result, with the passage of each day and the release of each number, more and more market observers are coming to the view that the F.O.M.C. is more likely than not to tighten monetary policy at its upcoming meeting on March 25."
Although the Producer Price Index today and the Consumer Price Index Wednesday are expected to be market friendly, he added, "It must be remembered that Greenspan specifically said that given the lags with which monetary policy affects the economy, we cannot rule out a situation in which a pre-emptive policy tightening may become appropriate before any sign of actual higher inflation becomes evident."
Traders say the bond market was certainly adjusting for a possible tightening, helped in part by an apparent stall in budget negotiations.
Elsewhere, Michael Moskow, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago and a voting member of the F.O.M.C., raised investor anxiety another notch. Speaking to the Industrial Relations Research Association in Chicago, he said, "It's necessary to stay ahead of the curve." Citing the experience of the 1970's, he added, "If we don't react until a serious problem shows up, we're too late."

HEADLINE: Living at the Office

BYLINE: By Michael Pollan; Michael Pollan is the author, most recently, of "A Place of My Own: The Education of an Amateur Builder."

DATELINE: CORNWALL BRIDGE, Conn.

 BODY:
I was tapping away at my computer on a bright summer morning when I first heard, or felt, the sound: a series of distant, muffled explosions, followed by a low rumble that seemed to roll across the ground and rock the foundations of my office.
Were I still living in my apartment on upper Broadway, almost directly above the IRT, I might not even have noticed it. But I'd recently moved to northwestern Connecticut, a hundred miles from the sounds of a subway, and I was at that very moment working in a tiny cabin in the woods behind my house -- my home office. 
 I followed the noise east into the woods and eventually found its source. A contractor was dynamiting ledge rock to make room for a new building at the end of a long dirt road in the middle of nowhere. We got to chatting, and I learned that the building was going to be a trading room. Here in this quiet second-growth forest where I now went to work every day, writing my articles and books, I was about to be joined by a risk arbitrageur from New York City.
In the days to follow I watched as a crew from the phone company unscrolled a new wire along my road (which is dirt for most of its length). The guys on the crew said they were running an ISDN line -- a high-speed data connection that would allow the trader to be in constant, real-time contact with Wall Street. It seems that the true currency of risk arbitrage is timely information; even the tiny lag-time it takes news and market data to squeeze through an ordinary twisted-pair phone line would put a trader at an unacceptable competitive disadvantage. But an ISDN line changes all that.
That wire and the rumble that preceded it were auguries of a new world, and a new landscape. In the same way that the Long Island Expressway transformed the lapsed potato field where I grew up into a suburb, the telephone line (along with the computer, modem, fax and Internet) is helping to transform the rural countryside where I now live into something new: an exurb. If the rows of split-levels with their stamps of lawn out front became the architectural embodiment of the postwar bedroom community, the symbol of the new landscape now taking shape out beyond the suburban fringe, in places like Litchfield, Conn., and Sonoma, Calif., and southern New Hampshire, is the on-line home office.
Since the dawn of the industrial revolution, the realms of work and family life have been steadily drifting apart. As workers began commuting to their jobs, they reconceived their homes as strictly private spheres from which all traces of economic activity should be banished. Historically this was a novel idea -- home had been the site of work for centuries -- yet by the time John Cheever wrote his chronicles of postwar suburbia, the new arrangement seemed perfectly natural, even God-given. We will soon recognize it for the aberration it is, for work is rapidly returning to the home, under the spur of economic necessity and technological opportunity.
In recent years, corporate down-sizing and "outsourcing" -- the farming out of work once performed within the company -- have spawned millions of new home-based businesses: The in-house publicist or systems analyst is now working freelance in her own house, often for the same corporation. At the same time, the computer and modem have made many jobs in the information sector more or less portable.
According to the Regional Plan Association, 98 percent of the work force in the New York metropolitan region commutes to work each day; on any given day in the year 2010, 10 percent will "commute" by wire. Nationwide, 30 million of us are expected to be working at home by the year 2000, more than a fifth of the labor force. Welcome to the Staples economy.
What will the landscape, and the life style, generated by these new forces look like? In the case of the landscape, probably not all that different. That's the good news about the changes under way around me: Nowadays you can build a trading room in the middle of a New England forest and leave only the faintest of environmental footprints. The new technologies make it possible to draw large stretches of rural America onto the grid of the modern economy without sacrificing its beauty in the way that the highways that drove the last wave of development invariably did. Today the economic centers can release their centrifugal energies without necessarily having to sprawl.
That's not to say the countryside isn't changing. As traders and architects, accountants and software developers take to the hills around here, you may not be able to see our offices from the road (and that road may not need to be widened), but we do leave our telltale marks on the land all the same. There's that new Staples superstore in Torrington, for example, and in Litchfield, a picture-book white-clapboard New England village, the old pharmacy with its zinc soda fountain has given way to a coffee bar where you can pay $3.75 for an iced latte. The new exurb might look a lot like the old countryside, but in truth it is as urban an artifact as Central Park.
But it is the life style, more than the landscape, that the home office economy will transfigure, as the man in the gray flannel suit is replaced by the man (and woman) in the gray flannel sweatshirt and slippers, padding up, or out, to the home office. (Shlubbiness is definitely an occupational hazard: Jackets, skirts, even the morning shave and shower are strictly optional.)
If you've visited a model home recently, you know that the American house is changing, as it sprouts new office rooms (often replacing the old "den" or "sewing room") and sometimes whole outbuildings to accommodate work best done out of range of the kids. And it is the kids who surely stand to benefit: One of the great advantages of working at home is the added time with one's family it affords, once you realize how much day is left after you've lopped off those hours for commuting and water cooler schmoozing.
The loss of this ritual is often cited as a drawback of working at home, and isolation (social and office-political) is certainly a problem. Yet I've discovered that the lack of society during the day whets one's appetite for social activity at night -- going out, having people over, even getting involved politically.
The rap on bedroom communities has always been that a society of commuters, with one foot in the city and the other in bed, had no time or energy left for local politics and community activities; the commuter's sense of attachment to a place was attenuated. I find that after a day spent in the solitude of my hut, the prospect of a P.T.A. or zoning board meeting begins to look pretty exciting. A society of home-office workers could wind up actually revitalizing our communities. What might look like a formula for social atomization could prove precisely the opposite. At least that's what my own experience suggests. Is it representative? I'd be the last person to tell you a writer's life is typical of anything. And yet maybe in this one case it is. For in a way, the writer's existence is a model for the life style now emerging.
Long before the trader and the accountant and the software developer pulled up stakes to move to the woods, the writers were already here, tapping away in the solitude of their attics and cabins. Writers have always had the freedom to live out beyond the reach of the expressway, to map their day, to figure out how to make something of their isolation and the gift of all that time. For better or worse, millions of us are writers now, freelance souls set loose by the American centrifuge, making our own way across territory that only looks familiar, building something new.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Philippe Weisbecker)

HEADLINE: Monaco Journal;
The Heir Won't Marry, the Croupier's on Trial . . .

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: MONACO, March 7

 BODY:
The hair and the brush mustache are white with age, the face worn with care.
Prince Rainier III has carried the burdens of this tiny Mediterranean principality, smaller than Central Park in New York, for 47 years, one of the longest reigns since his ancestor Francois Grimaldi the Cunning laid claim to Monaco 700 years ago. 
 Burdens? Sleek yachts still nestle in the harbors on either side of the Prince's yellow fairy-tale castle, and Mercedes limousines line up in front of the turrets of the Monte Carlo Casino, where gamblers from all over the world pay no tax on winnings.
But the state-owned gambling enterprise, once the principality's prime source of revenue and still its biggest drawing card, lost $30 million last year and expects to lose $16 million this year.
Rainier, 73, also worries that his designated heir, Prince Albert, has not yet married, though he turns 39 on March 14; Monaco's Constitution enshrines the principle of a direct male line of succession.
And last year Albert's younger sister, Princess Stephanie, 32, divorced her husband and former bodyguard, Daniel Ducruet, after celebrity-chasing Italian photographers caught him embracing a former Miss Bare Breasts of Belgium in a pool at a rented villa on the French Riviera.
The oldest of Rainier's three children, Princess Caroline, 40, has two sons and a daughter from her marriage to her second husband, an Italian who was killed in a speedboat accident in 1990. They could also succeed to the Grimaldi throne if Albert produced no heir, but his father seemed preoccupied nonetheless.
"I think it's mostly behind us now," Rainier said, speaking of the wave of unwanted publicity generated by the often intrusive photographers, and drawing nervously on a filter cigarette in an interview in his office in the castle.
"You can't take them to court, and I understand they have to do their job," he said. "But it's become a sort of hunt, and they sell their scoops for so much money it's ridiculous."
The paparazzi reportedly got $1.5 million for the swimming pool photographs, but, the Prince said, "I think the best thing is just to ignore it."
Prince Rainier's troubles began with the death of his American-born wife, Grace Kelly, the former actress, who died after a car accident in 1982.
For almost 10 years he has been denying rumors that he would step down in favor of his son, an Amherst graduate whom his father recently named to head Monaco's delegation to the United Nations.
"I've talked about the succession at length with Albert," Rainier said. "But it has to be something gradual, and it's also a question of marriage. He has to pick a wife and settle down and establish a family."
What does Albert have to say to that? "He gets very cross with me," Rainier acknowledged. "He says, 'I've seen enough disasters around me with people who've married too quickly.' "
Most of Rainier's subjects seem to sympathize with the family, and several thousand turned out in the rain on Jan. 8 for the start of 700th-anniversary celebrations that will continue throughout the year.
"They're regular people," said the owner of an Italian cafe near the casino, "and they've been good to us."
The Prince guarantees all his 5,000 subjects lifetime employment. But over the years his highly publicized family has had almost as many ups and downs as Monaco itself, a palmy, clean place that W. Somerset Maugham once described as "a sunny spot for shady people." Today there are television surveillance cameras at every big intersection and in every gambling room, and 498 police officers for 25,000 residents.
Still, four years ago, after a complaint by an Italian industrialist about strong-arm tactics used to recover loans to gamblers at the casinos, Rainier ordered an investigation of the Societe des Bains de Mer, the state-owned company set up in 1866 to provide an economic base.
The inquiry revealed that an affiliate of the company was paying commissions to strong-arm agents to lend gambling money to customers who were threatened and beaten to pay it back if they lost. Two company officials and three recruiters were arrested in that scandal.
More recently, the company suspended 14 more employees, including a chief croupier, on suspicion of helping certain customers at the Cafe de Paris make big winnings in exchange for kickbacks. Ten were tried on various charges last month, with the prosecutors requesting an eight-month jail sentence and a heavy fine for the chief croupier.
The Prince is the principal stockholder in the company, which appointed a new director general, Michel G. Novatin, a French citizen, late last year.
"No doubt about it, we had to stop using banking agents," Mr. Novatin said. The Monte Carlo casinos, like American ones, still use recruiting agents to bring in paying customers. Here, most of them have traditionally come from nearby Italy.
"Everybody sees the Mafia in things like this," Mr. Novatin said, "but I have never seen a problem with organized crime in seven years in this business."
With gambling far behind tourism, light industry, banking and other services as a source of income, Monaco is counting on things like a new convention center under construction on the Mediterranean to keep the Grimaldi family business going strong into the 21st century.
"The miracle that after 700 years the family is still there," Prince Rainier said, "shows that there's been unity between my family and the population."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Monaco, which celebrates the 700th anniversary of Grimaldi rule this year, faces economic change, inquiries into casino practices, relentless publicity about the royal family and strong public concern about succession. (Associated Press); Prince Rainier III, 73, ascended to Monaco's throne 47 years ago. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: House Panel Praises Endowment for the Arts

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Members of a House subcommittee that appropriates money for the National Endowment for the Arts praised the embattled endowment in hearings today, amid signs that House Republicans may lack sufficient support to end Federal financing of the agency this fall as they had vowed to do.
Representative Ralph Regula, the Ohio Republican who is the chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on the Interior, said after hearing testimony from Jane Alexander, the chairwoman of the endowment, that most members of his subcommittee now seemed satisfied with Ms. Alexander's changes and her management of the downsized agency. 
 But it was still unclear whether the endowment would survive, he said, adding, "The mood of this committee may not reflect that of the Rules Committee, or that of the House."
In 1995 the Republican-controlled Congress slashed the endowment's budget by more than 40 percent, to $99 million, and pledged to stop all financing by the next fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. But the House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, a longtime opponent of the endowment, was quoted today in Congressional Quarterly Monitor as saying he doubted that Republicans had the votes to kill the agency any time soon.
"The way you live up to the deal is to get 218 votes," Mr. Armey was quoted as saying, referring to the "gentlemen's agreement" struck by the House leadership to kill the endowment. "I'm not sure that the most ardent supporters of eliminating the N.E.A. believe we can get that."
Optimism about the agency's prospects was also the prevailing mood this week among champions of more Federal support for the arts and the endowment. Grass-roots lobbyists flooded Congress earlier this week to press for Federal financing, telling undecided lawmakers that Federal financing of the arts generates far more revenue for the Government and prosperity in the economy than the money appropriated. Arts financing, the advocates said, was good for tourism, for the development of creativity in business and for the nation's balance of trade.
While few wished to be identified, several arts champions at the hearing today expressed confidence that the endowment would survive, even if Congress refused to appropriate the $136 million for the fiscal year 1998 that President Clinton has requested for the agency.
"Our worst-case scenario," said one Congressional lobbyist, "is that the agency will limp along on the $99 million it got for this year."
Representative Sidney R. Yates, an Illinois Democrat who is the most ardent champion of Federal financing for the arts, called the endowment one of the Government's "shining agencies," and added, "I feel quite sure that Congress in its wisdom will continue it not only this year but in the years to come."
Even committee opponents of the agency like Representative Zach Wamp, a Republican from Chattanooga, Tenn., who said he had supported a phase out of the endowment, expressed concern that reduced corporate support for the arts, coupled with reduced Federal support, was causing arts groups in his district and state to suffer. While Federal support for science, technology and other recipients of taxpayer dollars was important, he said, "now that the cold war is over, we may want to revisit our priorities" to explore whether the Government is spending enough to support culture.
"Wow," Ms. Alexander replied.
In her testimony, Ms. Alexander described the effects of the restructuring mandated by Congressional budget cuts. Stressing that the endowment was now a "tiny agency which accounts for less than one one-hundreths of 1 percent of the total Federal budget," it is expected to award about 1,000 grants this year, compared with 4,000 before 1995.
She said her staff had been cut by about 45 percent, and grants to most individual artists, except writers, had been eliminated. In the last 32 years, the endowment has made some 110,000 grants, only 45 or 50 of which had generated controversy.
But attacks on the endowment continue. Representative John T. Doolittle, Republican of California, has circulated a "Dear Colleague" letter objecting to Federal sponsorship of culture. And Representative Peter Hoekstra, the Michigan Republican who is chairman of the House Education Committee's Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee, says he intends to hold hearings on the endowment this spring.

HEADLINE: Economist Wins Top Medal for Pay Study

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Kevin M. Murphy, a 39-year-old professor of business economics at the University of Chicago, has been chosen as the winner of the John Bates Clark Medal from the American Economic Association, economists on the awards panel said yesterday.
Though the Clark Medal, awarded every other year to an outstanding American economist under age 40, is little known to the public, it carries as much prestige among American economists as the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. 
 Mr. Murphy, according to the citation prepared by the awards committee, is being honored for his "extraordinarily original" study of "wages, wage inequality and the relationship between wages and labor force participation."
Dale W. Jorgenson, an economist at Harvard and a member of the seven-member committee that selected the winner, said that Mr. Murphy's work was central to the way economists now think about the causes of widening inequality. "Kevin Murphy is the father, son and holy ghost of income distribution," he exclaimed.
The John Bates Clark Medal was created in 1947 and named for a specialist in capital theory at Columbia University in the late 19th century who was the first American economist to gain an international reputation. A second award, for "lifetime achievement," was abandoned after the Nobel award was created in 1969, leaving the Clark Medal as the single prize awarded by the association.
Paul A. Samuelson, the Harvard professor who pioneered Keynesian economics in the United States and wrote the textbook relied upon by generations of college students, was the first winner as well as the youngest. Since then, the list of recipients has read like a who's who of economics. Five of the next six winners -- Milton Friedman, James Tobin, Kenneth Arrow and Robert M. Solow -- later went on to win Nobel awards.
Martin S. Feldstein, who won in 1977, and Joseph E. Stiglitz (1979) served as chairmen of the White House Council of Economic Advisers. Lawrence H. Summers (1993) is now the Under Secretary of the Treasury. And the others, from Gary S. Becker of the University of Chicago (1967) to Paul R. Krugman of M.I.T. (1991), are academic giants.
"It's a window on where the profession is at," said Orley Ashenfelter, a Princeton economist who edits the American Economic Review, the profession's top journal.
This year's winner -- not to be confused with another distinguished economist, Kevin J. Murphy at the University of Southern California -- graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles. He earned a Ph.D. at the University of Chicago, known for its distinctive brand of conservative, staunchly free market economics. Once in Hyde Park, Mr. Murphy never left.
Like most ambitious academic economists, Mr. Murphy sports a list of publications so long that one has to wonder when he found time to see "Star Wars." But the work for which he is being honored is found in 18 articles on the causes of growing income inequality in America.
This is a well-trod subject. What distinguishes Mr. Murphy's contribution is his careful collection of data, mastery of statistical methods and disarmingly straightforward use of basic economics. "A lot of what we've seen in the past two decades comes right out of Econ. 101," he said in a telephone interview.
From the rubble of conflicting analyses, Mr. Murphy has clearly identified the growth in demand for skilled labor -- as opposed to the rise in supply or decline in demand for unskilled labor -- as the principal cause of the widening gap in wages between blue- and white-collar workers. His work also suggests that the market for skills is functioning the way it is supposed to: Americans have responded by staying in school longer, a trend that should eventually narrow the gap or at least prevent it from widening much further.
Mr. Murphy is now training his sights on the underlying causes, which surely include both technological change and globalization of the labor market. "We've identified the suspects, but don't have anyone in custody," he reports.
Unlike the Nobel, the Clark Medal does not come with a fat check, or any check at all. Mr. Murphy says he is thrilled to be its 25th recipient. "But like any good economist," he jokes, "I'd rather have the money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kevin M. Murphy of the University of Chicago is being honored for his work on wage inequalities. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Taiwan Keeps a Step Ahead of China in U.S. Lobbying

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Last month, President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and their wives dropped in on a party at a restaurant in Chinatown here to help usher in the Chinese Year of the Ox. Among the cheering crowd that greeted them was Jason Hu, Taiwan's unofficial ambassador to the United States.
While Mr. Hu did not talk to the President or the Vice President that night, and the White House said this week that Mr. Clinton was not aware that Mr. Hu was at the restaurant, the fact that the three of them were briefly in the same room was a diplomatic coup for Taiwan, which is not officially recognized by Washington. 
 The symbolism was not lost on China, which considers Taiwan to be a wayward province and has long viewed it as its chief rival for influence in Washington.
"Why didn't the President come to our party?" asked an exasperated Chinese Embassy official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
China's efforts to match the intricate network of supporters that has made Taiwan one of the most effective lobbies in Washington is central to the expanding controversy surrounding illegal campaign donations to Democrats in the last election.
Federal officials said they began investigating whether China was making covert efforts to influence American politicians early last year after the National Security Agency overheard Chinese officials expressing their desire to counter Taiwan's influence. Earlier this week, several Democrats in Congress said the Federal Bureau of Investigation warned them in June that the Chinese Government might try to funnel illegal donations to their campaigns.
Chinese officials have strongly disputed the accusations that they made illegal contributions, calling them "groundless." But there is no doubt that the Chinese Embassy here has increased its lobbying efforts in recent years.
The need for a more aggressive effort was driven home in June 1995, when Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-Hui, was allowed to attend his class reunion at Cornell University, the first time a Taiwanese President had visited the United States since the latter broke off relations with Taiwan in 1979 and recognized China. Although the White House had assured China that Mr. Lee would not be issued a visa, it was forced to change course after Congress overwhelmingly passed a resolution urging Mr. Clinton to allow the visit.
The Chinese Embassy has since increased the number of people who lobby Congress and appointed Shao Wenguang, an urbane graduate of both Oxford University and the Fletcher School of Diplomacy at Tufts University, as its new head of Congressional liaison.
James Lilley, a former American Ambassador in Beijing and a veteran of 27 years at the Central Intelligence Agency, said China had a long record of interfering in the affairs of other countries.
"They've been kicked out of more countries in Africa than we have," Mr. Lilley said. "They've been at it all the time, influencing people with guns, politics and money."
But many China watchers find the current focus on Beijing's activities curious, given Taiwan's long history of aggressive and sometimes questionable lobbying activities. Some suggest that Federal agencies may look the other way at Taiwan's efforts to influence American policy.
Taiwan regards American domestic politics as a question of national security and has done so for years. It studies the United States intensively and has brought hundreds of American politicians, journalists, academics and other opinion leaders to Taiwan on free visits. As an indication of the broad sweep of Taiwan's effort, a young Arkansas Governor, Bill Clinton, visited Taiwan four times but never once went to China.
"The Chinese are the weakest embassy in Washington," said one industry representative who requested anonymity. "That is why it is so laughable that they are orchestrating some elaborate campaign."
Even before the Taiwan President's visit, China's supporters here and abroad had been urging Beijing to beef up its lobbying. Unlike Taiwan and many other countries, China has been reluctant to hire professional lobbyists to promote its interests. But as a nuclear power, home to one-fifth of the world's people, and the world's fastest-growing economy, China has won many friends in Washington in recent years.
On major economic issues, like China's trading privileges with the United States, there has been little need for Chinese officials to lobby because their cause has been championed by a broad network of large corporations, including Boeing, International Business Machines and Motorola, that do business in China. In addition, Hong Kong Chinese tycoons and even Hong Kong's colonial government, have lobbied on behalf of China because much of Hong Kong's wealth is derived from China's rapidly expanding exports.
China also has a network of former high-ranking American officials, including former Secretaries of State Henry A. Kissinger, Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who act as unofficial lobbyists and then parlay their China connections as private consultants to businesses and foreign governments.
But despite its rising influence in Washington, China has been irritated by the fact that Taiwan's influence in the capital has not diminished in equal measure.
Taiwan has been adroit at making its voice heard, despite being hobbled by its lack of official recognition. The report about allegations of Chinese influence buying, which first appeared in The Washington Post, put the total amount at about $2 million. That is less than half what the Taiwan Research Institute, a private organization closely allied with Taiwan's governing party, is paying Cassidy & Associates, a Washington lobbying firm that has been widely credited with getting Mr. Lee his visa.
Taiwan also employs numerous other lobbyists and knows the legal ways to curry favor with influential members of Congress. In 1993, for example, Taiwan donated $225,000 to a foundation that supports a museum dedicated to the career of Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Earlier this month, an official in Taiwan told The Los Angeles Times that the island's unofficial embassy in Washington helped its friends in Congress by supplying them with lists of Taiwanese-Americans in their districts whom they could target for fund-raising. The Taiwan Economic and Cultural Representative Office denied that it was engaged in such activities, which in any case would be legal if the contributors were legal United States residents.
The only overseas fund-raising trip made by John Huang, the former Commerce Department and Democratic National Committee official now at the center of the campaign fund-raising furor, was to Taiwan last May.
Because of Washington's long history of support for the Chinese Nationalist Party during World War II and the cold war, the F.B.I and American counterintelligence agencies do not scrutinize Taiwan's activities here, said Roger Sullivan, who was a China specialist on the National Security Council in the Carter Administration.
"There are all sorts of guys in the military and at the bureau who think they are the good guys," Mr. Sullivan said, referring to Taiwan. "In my time it was very difficult to get anyone to focus on what they were doing. How much is anyone watching them even now? Probably not that much."

HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Expanded At 3.9% Rate in 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 13

 BODY:
With exports starting to surge again, Japan's economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the fourth quarter, capping a year in which the nation emerged, at least partly, from an extended economic slump, the Government said today.
Still, economists cautioned that growth was likely to slow again this year as tax increases, to take effect in April, dampen consumption. 
 Adjusted for inflation and seasonal factors, gross domestic product grew 1 percent in the fourth quarter from the prior three months, or at a 3.9 percent annual pace. In the third quarter, gross domestic product, which measures the nation's output of goods and services but does not include income from abroad, had expanded at an annual rate of only 1.3 percent.
In all of 1996, economic output rose an inflation-adjusted 3.6 percent, the strongest expansion since 3.8 percent in 1991 and the highest growth rate among the world's industrialized countries. The United States, by contrast, grew 2.4 percent last year, although at a 3.9 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter.
About 40 percent of the fourth quarter's growth in Japan came from an increase in net exports, raising the prospect that as in the past the nation is exporting its way out of a recession. Over all, exports rose 4.3 percent in the fourth quarter. The other 60 percent came from growth in domestic consumption, capital spending and housing investment.
Exports, particularly of automobiles, have been surging as the yen has weakened against the dollar by about 50 percent over the last two years, making Japanese products less expensive in terms of other currencies.
That has prompted recent warnings from American officials, most prominently Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, that Japan should work for a recovery led by domestic demand and avoid a sharp rise in its trade surplus. On Wednesday, Shinji Sato, Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, gathered top executives of the nation's auto makers and warned them to try to avoid reigniting trade tensions with the United States.
Jesper Koll, an economist with J. P. Morgan Securities Asia in Tokyo, said the fourth-quarter figures showed that Japan's economy was undergoing a recovery similar to those in the past. "The traditional growth engines are capital expenditures and net exports, and that's exactly what's driving the recovery," he said.
For much of the last few years, as the yen was rising, import growth exceeded export growth, and trade was a drag on the economic expansion. The economy -- which grew only 1.4 percent in 1995, six-tenths of 1 percent in 1994 and three-tenths of 1 percent in 1993 -- was kept afloat by huge fiscal stimulus, such as spending on public works projects.
But in the fourth quarter of 1996, many of the fiscal stimulus programs had run their course and public investment shrank sharply, detracting from growth.
Many economists say that the relatively robust growth for the year was partly the result of a statistical aberration in the first quarter and of a rush by consumers to make purchases before the consumption tax, essentially a sales tax, is raised to 5 percent from 3 percent on April 1.
"There's a wide discrepancy between these numbers and how average citizens are feeling about the security of their jobs and their standards of living," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, chief economist in the Tokyo office of Credit Suisse First Boston. She said the economy was still plagued by industrial overcapacity and a financial sector hobbled by bad debts.
Most economists think consumer spending will drop off substantially and the economy will shrink in the quarter that begins in April -- after the tax increase takes effect. A rise in income taxes scheduled for this year will also hurt spending.
Ms. Sasaki-Smith said she expected the economy to grow only 1.2 percent this year. But Mr. Koll of J. P. Morgan expected the economy to weather the tax increases fairly well and expand by 2.1 percent.
Despite the recent strong growth, many analysts do not expect the Bank of Japan to immediately raise interest rates.

HEADLINE: Zaire Rebel Leader's Big Test: Saving the Economy

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: GOMA, Zaire

 BODY:
Ten years ago, Sylvia Kazuba worked as a teacher. Then the Zairian Government stopped paying civil servants, and her husband asked her to sell goods in a local market to make ends meet.
Now she spends all day squatting on a filthy street, selling cassava flour to scrape together $20 a month. It is just enough to feed, clothe and educate her seven children. Her husband still teaches, relying on occasional charity from parents. 
 "With the small money I get here, I'm able to feed the children," said the merchant, 38. "But it's difficult."
More than anything else, the rebellion sweeping eastern Zaire has been fueled by economic hardship. Throughout this vast and resource-rich land, people are furious with President Mobutu Sese Seko for driving what should be a prosperous nation into abject poverty.
While rebel forces have racked up a string of military successes and are threatening Kisangani, Zaire's third largest city, the real test for the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, will be how he administers the government and handles the economy in the long run, many Zairians here say.
Judging by their few months in power so far, it appears Mr. Kabila is serious about overhauling the civil service, stamping out corruption and inviting investment from abroad. In Goma, the rebel headquarters, his administration has fixed roads, restored electricity and lowered duties on most imports and exports in the last three months. The rebel government has also arrested several customs officials and one doctor on charges of soliciting bribes.
Banks are open in rebel-held cities for the first time since 1991, thanks to deposits in dollars from the rebel treasury, officials say. Ports have been reopened on Lake Tanganyika, and most days the border posts with Uganda and Rwanda are thronged with importers and exporters.
Some foreign-owned businesses have returned after fleeing in October: the Heineken brewery in Bukavu, the coffee and lumber mill in Beni, the sugar refinery in Uvira, and a Belgian shipping company in Goma.
The Finance Minister, Mwana Mawampanga, a former economist at the University of Kentucky, said the rebels plan in the coming months to cut the public workforce by 10 percent, eliminate hundreds of no-show jobs, raise salaries and begin paying public servants.
As for the runaway inflation that has impoverished everyone here, Mr. Mawampanga said the solution is simple: "We have to stop printing money and to manage whatever we have more efficiently.
"All we need to do is impose on ourselves a strict discipline in terms of how we manage the public funds," he said. "The first thing is to restore the confidence in the monetary policy and the banks."
That may be easier said than done. Mr. Kabila inherited a fiscal disaster. Under Mr. Mobutu, corruption was the rule. Officials collected taxes on just about everything and extorted bribes from anyone who needed government services, but none of the money was put in the treasury. Instead, it went into the pockets of Mr. Mobutu's ruling class, usually ending up in foreign bank accounts.
Government salaries, usually amounting to less than a dollar a month, were not paid for years at a time, forcing employees from customs officers to doctors to survive on whatever they could extort from people who needed their services.
Jean-Luis Paluku, a 26-year-old teacher, has not been paid in three years. "I don't even have any shoes," he said. "We want a government that can give us jobs because to stay in the world without a job is horrible. So many are in the streets."
Ranking members of the ruling party were seldom short of cash.
Mr. Mobutu's treasury printed tons of worthless currency and distributed it through local political officials, who used it to buy whatever they wanted. "It was a very organized form of thievery," said a local missionary, insisting on anonymity. "They printed money and handed it out to party officials."
The result was rampant inflation. By the time the new notes trickled down to the average Zairian, they were worth next to nothing. In 1967, 1 Zaire was worth $2. By 1993, when the Government introduced a new currency, $1 was worth 9 million Zaire. Today it takes 90,000 of the new Zaires to buy a single dollar.
"This is a Government that has driven people into absolute poverty," the missionary said. "They don't pay people. They steal everything."
Perhaps Mr. Mobutu's greatest folly was not paying his soldiers. The army went on looting binges as a result, nearly bringing the Government to the point of collapse in 1991.
The failure to pay the military has been the chief reason Government forces have put up so little resistance in towns the rebels hold. Two weeks before the rebels captured Kindu in late February, the 3,000 soldiers garrisoned there marched through the streets, chanting: "We won't die for 100,000 Zaires a month." They pulled out three days before the rebels arrived.
Mr. Mobutu also spent so little on infrastructure that most of the country's roads are nearly impassable. Its rail lines, airports and ferries are outdated, overloaded and decrepit.
"We inherited a catastrophe," said Valentine Balumetussi, the vice governor of North Kivu, a former pastor. "The main problem is to organize a big country which was abandoned for a long time. We have to begin again from the beginning."
Despite the rebel administration's efforts, the life of Mrs. Kazuba and others has not changed much since the rebellion began last October. If anything, the crackdown on official corruption has meant people have less money in the marketplaces.
The Government runs almost entirely on volunteer labor, local officials say, and many of the civil servants are the same ones who in the past lived on bribery. They are being kept in line by their zeal to help the rebellion and by the threat of prison.
"Everyone, even the Governor and the director of the province, are volunteers," Mr. Balumetussi said. "The soldiers are not paid. They are volunteers. You can't have everything at the same time."
Yet Mr. Kabila's popularity is rising. That may be because many people in Zaire were used to living with little or no money. Now, at least, they dream of a time when Mr. Kabila will reignite the economy.
"We have hope," said Athanase Kahanya, the provincial director of North Kivu.
Another challenge for Mr. Kabila is to change the culture of corruption, Mr. Balumetussi said. To do that, the rebel alliance has begun holding ideological seminars for people who want to join the movement.
After taking 10 classes on topics like "the roots of the rebellion" and "civil liberties," people who attend the seminars are given a certificate proclaiming them members of the alliance.
Last Sunday, about 400 people crowded outside a Catholic school to attend the first seminar.
Mobokani Kambale, a 50-year-old lecturer at North Kivu Central University, said Mr. Kabila would have to deliver on his promise of better wages within the next two years.
"What's most important is not just to get a job but to get a job that is better paid," he said. "I have a job and I'm more miserable than a jobless person. I have a very irregular and miserable salary, three years without getting paid, and once one gets paid, one gets less than $1."
Other Zairians say they are prepared to give Mr. Kabila a chance. For Mrs. Kazuga and her husband, Thomas Samvura, the question is not whether Mr. Kabila will create jobs and pay workers, but when. Like many in Goma, they believe that once Kisangani falls, the rebels will have won the war.
"We are still waiting," said Mr. Samvura, 45. "After the liberation of Kisangani, things will be very good. They are going to pay us maybe."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Soar, Making a Rate Rise by the Fed More Likely

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Americans shopped at a brisk pace last month after a surprisingly strong surge in retail sales in January, Commerce Department figures showed today, making it more likely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in the near future.
"We've got consumers on a tear," said L. Douglas Lee, economist at HSBC Securities in Washington. "They're spending what they're earning." 
 The latest evidence of an economic upswing -- and the fears it stimulated that the Fed will tighten credit in a bid to keep inflation firmly capped -- sent tremors through Wall Street. Bond prices tumbled early in the morning and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 160 points.
After shrugging off a strong jobs report on Friday, a lot of investors now appear to be having second thoughts. There is a growing consensus that the Fed now has enough evidence of a robust economy to move as early as its March 25 policy meeting to lift short-term interest rates. Investors may also be somewhat concerned by the discord in Washington and fear that prospects for achieving a balanced budget and a cut in capital gains taxes are dimming.
Consumers pushed a total of $213.2 billion across retail counters in February, an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent, the department's preliminary estimate showed. The rise was slightly more than expected but the impact was hugely magnified because it came on top of an upward revision for January that transformed a six-tenths of 1 percent gain into a 1.5 percent boom.
The free-spending habits of consumers, while good for economic growth, put an increasing number of people into financial trouble for living beyond their means. Late payments on credit cards, the American Bankers Association reported today, jumped in the fourth quarter of 1996 to 3.72 percent of accounts, the highest proportion since 1980, when the trade group began to monitor delinquencies.
A top banking regulator described the trend in charge-offs and delinquencies as "worrisome" and urged in an appearance before a meeting of the New York State Bankers Association here that issuers of credit cards be more cautious. Many have already tightened standards and some have also raised interest rates.
"It is worrisome to consider that there was a 44 percent growth in credit card losses and a 50 percent increase in credit card delinquencies during the past year," Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, told his banker constituents.
"Growth is far more than people thought," said Debbie Jansen, senior economist at Stein Roe & Farnham in Chicago. This will make the Fed "more nervous," she added, and therefore "raises the odds that they're going to tighten" monetary policy to keep inflation under control.
The consumer accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, half in retail spending and the other half in housing, car insurance, medical care and the like.
The economy, now six years from the end of the latest recession, has recently been growing faster than what most experts believe is its long-term potential. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has warned that he is prepared to move pre-emptively against an inflation threat.
Economists generally maintained today that the burst of spending this winter reflected such traditional factors as solid job growth, a modest rise in wages and record levels of consumer confidence.
But some, including David Levy, director of research at the Levy Economic Institute in Mount Kisco, N.Y., contended that a stock market that has delivered outsized gains for more than two years is a significant, not a minor, contributor.
"There's been a much stronger tendency of consumers to splurge" because of the bull market, he argued.
As evidence, Mr. Levy cited robust total spending by consumers at a time of high credit card delinquency. What is happening, he said, is that well-to-do stockholders who do not need credit cards are spending aggressively while others cut back -- voluntarily or under duress.
The retail sales gain last month was concentrated in big-ticket durable goods, with automotive dealers posting a 1.7 percent gain and merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes enjoying a 2.2 percent spurt. Part of the latter activity came from recovery from floods in the Northwest. Sales of furniture and other equipment for the home rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
As for nondurables, the strength was mostly from a 1.8 percent surge at department stores and other purveyors of general merchandise. Drugstores and clothing stores posted gains of six-tenths of 1 percent and four-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, while restaurants and bars, gasoline service stations and food stores had fractional sales declines.
Retail transactions last month were 5.1 percent ahead of the February 1996 level but that does not allow for inflation, which ran at a 3 percent pace for the latest 12 months.
The revision for January doubled the gain for durables and tripled it for the larger nondurables category.
Still other reports today showed that first-time applications for unemployment insurance fell an additional 5,000 last week, to 307,000, reflecting a very strong job market.
The Government also put the nation's international deficit on current account at $165.1 billion last year, up 11.4 percent and just shy of the record set in 1984. This measure includes investment flows and foreign aid as well as trade in goods and services.

HEADLINE: House Votes To Punish Mexico Over Drugs

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
The House voted today to impose sanctions on Mexico for its failures in the war on drugs, while senators and the Clinton Administration worked to reach agreement on a Congressional statement that would call for progress by the Mexicans but carry no threats or penalties.
The House measure would impose sanctions on Mexico after 90 days unless President Clinton reported substantial progress by the Mexican Government on various aspects of the drug war, from extraditions to "concrete measures to find and eliminate law enforcement corruption." 
 But the 251-to-175 vote to adopt it fell 33 votes short of the two-thirds majority required to override an almost certain Presidential veto, and attention quickly turned to the Senate.
There, five members offered a nonbinding "sense of the Senate" resolution as an alternative to efforts to reverse Mr. Clinton's finding on Feb. 28 that Mexico had "cooperated fully" with United States efforts in fighting drugs. The Administration must certify each year that nations receiving American drug aid are fully cooperating or they can face economic sanctions.
Conceding the scope of the American drug habit and the role of this country as a primary consumer of narcotics, the Senate statement expresses "concern about ineffective and insufficient progress by Mexico" in halting the production and shipment of narcotics.
The Mexican Foreign Ministry sharply criticized the House vote, saying it "sends a wrong signal to Mexico and the world." In a statement quoted by Reuters, the ministry added, "The resolution damages international cooperation in the fight against drugs and benefits our common enemy: drug trafficking."
The five sponsors of the Senate statement and the Administration were at work today trying to enlist other supporters. One Republican sponsor, John McCain of Arizona, said he thought chances of success were "pretty good." He said the group was "trying to send a message without provoking a wave of anti-Americanism."
The other sponsors are Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, Republicans, and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, Democrats.
Their task was eased by the vote in the House, which made it clear that decertification of Mexico could not become law over a Presidential veto.
That result was engineered by a group of nine Democrats with Hispanic districts who stood by as a Republican amendment denouncing the Government's drug program under President Clinton passed by 212 votes to 205.
The group, led by Representative Xavier Becerra of California, who heads the Hispanic caucus, abstained, though several stood by the Speaker's rostrum ready to vote for the amendment if their votes were needed. They believed that if the partisan criticism of the Clinton Administration was added to the measure, many Democrats who otherwise favored decertification, like Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, would vote against it.
They were right. Mr. Gephardt, who had spoken in favor of decertification because "what we are doing is not working," was among the 154 Democrats and 21 Republicans, mostly moderates, who voted against the entire package. It was favored by 204 Republicans, 46 Democrats and one independent.
Withdrawing certification from Mexico would reduce American foreign aid, already minuscule, and require the United States to vote against international loans for Mexico, two largely symbolic steps.
But the Administration has argued that it would also threaten confidence in Mexico's economy. The opposition's emphasis today, however, was on the argument that the effort would hinder, not enhance, anti-drug efforts by provoking what Representative David Dreier, a California Republican who opposed the legislation, called "anti-gringo sentiment."
Speaker Newt Gingrich sought to put a very different emphasis on the measure. "No American," he said, "can look at the Mexican prosecutors, the Mexican police who have died risking their lives to try to free their countries from the scourge of drug dealers and then talk in a self-satisfied manner." He said he wanted members to discuss the issue "in a positive effort to create a spirit across the Americas of defeating the drug dealers as allies together for civilization."
In today's debate, critics of Mexico frequently quoted Thomas A. Constantine, head of the Drug Enforcement Agency, as saying that he could trust none of Mexico's four major law enforcement agencies to be free of corruption by drug cartels.
But Representative Silvestre Reyes, a Texas Democrat, said Mexicans would be correct in seeing the vote as "an affront to them and to the price they have paid."

HEADLINE: Officials Say Long Island Isn't the Place For Casinos

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: WOODBURY, L.I., March 13

 BODY:
Casino gambling might be a way to boost tourism in the Catskills, but it is not welcome on Long Island, top Suffolk and Nassau County officials said today at a forum on the Island's economy.
"I'm not a supporter of casino gambling in Suffolk," said the County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney. "It might be the answer to the dying economy in Sullivan County and other counties in that area. It might also be of enormous value in parts of New York City, but not of Long Island." 
 He said the most likely location for casinos on Long Island would be the East End, where the greatest number of tourists gather. "But I think it would be counterproductive to the way in which we are trying to maintain the quality of life on the East End," he said.
Business leaders in the Catskills were disappointed in late January when lawmakers from Long Island and New York City formed a bipartisan bloc in Albany and voted down a measure that would have permitted a referendum on casino gambling.
Bruce Blakeman, the presiding officer of the County Legislature, said he had "great reservations" about casino gambling as a way to solve an area's economic problems.
"But I also recognize," he said, "that there is a large amount of dollars flowing out of the state into casinos in New Jersey and Connecticut, so maybe we should be part of the action. So, I would keep an open mind to it in Sullivan County, but my mind is absolutely closed to casino gambling in Nassau County."
Mr. Gaffney and Mr. Blakeman were among the speakers at a forum sponsored by the Long Island Association, the Island's largest business and civic organization.
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, used the occasion to announce a new workfare initiative. He called on each employer in the county to pledge one job to help move county welfare recipients into the work place. Mr. Gulotta said that over the last six months the county had provided job training for hundreds of welfare recipients.
To start the program, Mr. Gulotta distributed registration participation pledge forms to the more than 1,000 business owners attending the meeting.
Mr. Gaffney and Mr. Gulotta also called on the State Legislature to repeal the sales tax on clothing. "Recently we completed a very successful experimental week during which sales tax was not collected on clothing and shoe purchases," Mr. Gulotta said.
