HEADLINE: Even a Big Donor Can Find Political Dividends Elusive

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Few have spread money around this city like Carl H. Lindner, the man behind Chiquita Bananas. He let Bob Dole fly around on jets that belong to his family's financial empire. He and his company, American Financial Corporation, donated more than $400,000 to the Democrats since 1993, enough to insure that he got both coffee at the White House and a night in the Lincoln Bedroom.
Along with his checks, Mr. Lindner delivered the message that Europe has visited many injustices on the banana business -- and on Chiquita. He has pressed for ways to punish the Europeans for their arcane banana restrictions, which favor bananas grown in Europe and its former colonies. Those rules make it enormously difficult to sell bananas grown in Latin America -- including hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of Chiquitas -- to European consumers. 
 Next week, Mr. Lindner will probably learn whether the huge investment he has made in Washington will bring any returns. The World Trade Organization is expected to hand down its first decision on Europe's banana rules, in a case that the Clinton Administration has pressed on Chiquita's behalf.
But by most accounts, Mr. Lindner, who virtually never grants interviews and would not comment for this article, is not a happy man. He wanted decisive, swift action from Washington. He got something well short of that.
Mr. Lindner's tale, in fact, is a cautionary one to big contributors. Buying influence is harder than it looks these days, especially when your problems involve multibillion-dollar disputes over international trade. In the old days, a loud enough complaint -- and nothing speaks louder than big donations -- often resulted in trade sanctions against the offending government. Now it ends up in the court of world trade, which moves at the speed of a banana boat and rarely results in a truly satisfying victory.
That point is often made these days by Clinton Administration officials, who are a bit touchy about the fact that Mr. Lindner's company, American Financial Corporation, made some of its generous contributions to the Democratic National Committee just as the Administration was trying to decide how to handle the banana problem.
"My impression at the time was that Chiquita was quite disappointed that U.S.T.R. did not opt for imposing sanctions," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative, who was in the No. 2 trade post for most of Mr. Clinton's first term. "Instead, we brought the case to a W.T.O. dispute body."
Mr. Lindner's aides say that he has given to both parties for decades and that his political contributions are a fraction of his charitable contributions. Federal records show that since 1993, Mr. Linder and American Financial have given $648,000 to various Republican causes at the Federal level and $460,000 to the Democrats.
In 1995, Mr. Dole was enthusiastic about solving the banana problem. Before he resigned as Senate majority leader, Mr. Dole tried to introduce amendments to budget bills that would have imposed sharp sanctions on Costa Rica and Colombia for going along with the European banana-trade system. He also criticized the Clinton Administration on the issue. But the amendments all failed.
But even while Mr. Dole was flying around on jets provided by Lindner family interests, Mr. Lindner was sipping coffee with the President, on Feb. 21, 1995. And he shows up on the list of Clinton "friends" who slept at the White House.
American Financial gave $100,000 to the Democrats on Aug. 4, 1995. A month later, on Sept. 28, the Administration asked Europe for trade "consultations," the first step toward filing a case. American Financial gave $15,000 on Feb. 29, 1996, and the formal case was filed April 11. Some European officials are hinting that the donations and the filing were closely related.
But it is difficult to establish that link. Career officials at the United States trade representative's office say they felt no pressure on how to handle the case, and Mr. Lindner apparently attended only one formal meeting on the subject, with Mickey Kantor, Ms. Barshefsky's predecessor. The decision Mr. Kantor made -- to take the case to the World Trade Organization, along with Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras and Ecuador -- was the route recommended by career staff officials at the trade representative's office. It is a sensitive issue because Caribbean nations that live off the banana trade complain that the United States' actions threaten to destroy their deals with Europe, and thus their economies.
Mr. Lindner's problem, though, is that this is not the kind of case that gets American workers exercised because any jobs that would be saved would be in Latin America.
The problem could still be around for the next big campaign. Even if the United States wins, the Europeans could drag out the process by changing only some of the rules and playing for time. They could avoid changing their system altogether if they chose to pay compensation to the countries that brought the case.

HEADLINE: Canberra Journal;
Where Australia's Chief Just Won't Hang His Hat

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: CANBERRA, Australia

 BODY:
This totally planned inland capital was designed early in this century to look a little like Washington.
Floral drives wind along an area that resembles the Tidal Basin. Marvelous vistas open up from wide avenues that radiate from the Senate and the House of Representatives. Cyclists and joggers move through stately parks and malls graced by majestic monuments. Suburbs drape the undulating hills between the city and grazing land dotted with cattle, sheep and an occasional kangaroo. 
 Canberra even has something close to the White House, a lovely eucalyptus-shaded mansion known as the Lodge, blending Colonial Revival and American Mission styles and sitting grandly behind cream-colored stucco walls a five-minute drive from the House and the Senate.
Prime Ministers have proudly lived in the Lodge since its completion in 1927. But the tradition has been shattered by Australia's newest leader, John Howard, who refuses to move his family to the bush capital, as Canberra is commonly called, from cosmopolitan Sydney, Australia's largest city.
Sydney is where Mr. Howard was born and grew up and where two of his children are in college and the third is in preparatory school. His family has moved into Kirribilli House, a Gothic-style manor above the harbor usually reserved for official entertaining and distinguished foreign visitors.
Canberrans are fuming. Residence in the Lodge, many feel, signals commitment to the city.
The local view is that Mr. Howard is apathetic to the capital's growing problems, which include rising unemployment from cutbacks in the Civil Service and a generally depressed business climate. In distancing himself, Canberrans say, the Prime Minister may be making conditions worse.
"The implications are very far-reaching and enormously damaging for Canberra," said Kate Carnell, Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory, roughly equivalent to the District of Columbia.
"Government isn't exactly the flavor of the month around here," she said. "It's hard enough to get over the negative sides of a place that people say is full of a lot of jolly politicians, and the P.M. deciding not to live here just adds to that attitude."
Many Canberrans believe that residence in the Lodge is one of the job requirements for a Prime Minister.
"If he wants the job, he should take the Lodge," said Jane Bennett, a Canberra market researcher. "If he doesn't like the heat, . . ." She smiled.
Once rolling sheep country given to bush fires during the searing heat of summer, the Capital Territory was selected in 1911 to end bickering between Sydney and Melbourne. Canberra is between the two cities, about 140 miles to the southwest of Sydney.
Walter Burley Griffin, an associate of Frank Lloyd Wright, submitted the prize-winning plan for the city, influenced by Pierre L'Enfant's layout for Washington.
The compromise between Sydney and Melbourne is being undermined, many fear, by the Prime Minister's refusal to live here.
Historically the rivalry has been sharp and at times bitter between the more protectionist-minded southern manufacturing state of Victoria, whose principal city is Melbourne, and the more free-trade-minded northern agricultural state of New South Wales, represented by Sydney.
A theme of conversations here was that the Prime Minister might be making Canberra irrelevant.
More Cabinet meetings than ever are now held in Sydney. Business lobbyists come here less, because the movers and shakers are all in Sydney.
Mr. Howard, 57, who has just completed his first year in office, leads the Liberal Party, which is business-oriented and conservative compared with the other main party, Labor.
In defense of his decision he cites his desire not only to keep his family together but also to stay tuned to opinion outside the capital.
"Mixing with the same group of people, reinforcing one particular view of life, however well intentioned you may be and the people with whom you converse may be, it is possible to end up being a little out of touch with views in other parts of Australia," he said.
When not traveling to other parts of Australia or abroad, he said, he spends 60 percent of his nights in Sydney and 40 percent in Canberra.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Canberra has a lovely mansion akin to the White House, known as the Lodge, where Prime Ministers have lived since 1927. Until now, that is. The newest leader, John Howard, prefers to live in Sydney, his hometown. (Elisavietta Richie for The New York Times)
 
Map of Australia highlighting Canberra: Australia's Prime Minister refuses to move to Canberra, the capital.

HEADLINE: State Will Buy Old Shipyard For Oyster Bay Waterfront

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 14

 BODY:
Using funds allocated 25 years ago, the state is providing $5 million to buy a crumbling shipyard that dominates the waterfront of Oyster Bay, a sheltered haven that yields 90 percent of the oysters harvested in New York State.
The 5.2-acre site at the southern end of the bay is bordered by beaches and public parkland. Much of the bay has been designated a National Wildlife Refuge and is home to the Pine Island oyster. 
 The Town of Oyster Bay board is to vote on Tuesday on a proposal to provide an additional $1 million for the purchase.
In a statement announcing the land purchase, Gov. George E. Pataki said, "This cooperative purchase will recapture an important part of Oyster Bay's waterfront and the area's unique maritime character."
He added, "It will allow for redevelopment that will turn a dilapidated eyesore into a vibrant economic and recreational resource."
The $5 million will come from the state's 1972 Environmental Quality Bond Act. Previously, the money was designated for a solid waste incinerator on Long Island that was never built, according to a statement from the Governor's office.
State Senator Carl L. Marcellino of Oyster Bay said he worked closely with the Governor and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, to secure the funds to buy the site, the Jakobson Shipyard, which was listed on the state's open-space plan as a priority acquisition.
The shipyard opened in 1938 and once employed as many as 600 workers who built tugboats. It was removed from the state's hazardous waste site list in 1995 after a voluntary cleanup by the current owner, Moran Towing.
The grant was a long-sought victory for Friends of the Bay, a group dedicated to the preservation and protection of Oyster Bay and Cold Spring Harbor, estuaries on the North Shore of Long Island about 35 miles east of Manhattan.
"We see this property as the centerpiece of a new waterfront," said Michael Deering, executive director of Friends of the Bay.
The Oyster Bay Supervisor, Lewis J. Yevoli, also welcomed the news.
He said that the town would be seeking more money, perhaps from the state's recently approved environmental bond act, to improve the site with features including a marine museum and education center.
Governor Pataki on Thursday announced that the state had bought 267 acres in Hampton Bays in Suffolk County, using $1.9 million in state funds set aside to help preserve the Long Island Pine Barrens.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Decline Again, With Inflation Still a No-Show

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The economy displayed almost no signs of inflation on the producer level last month, the Labor Department reported today, further straining the view that strong growth and low unemployment lead inexorably to rising wages and prices.
The Labor Department said that the Producer Price Index for finished goods, which tracks the prices paid to manufacturers, farmers and other producers, declined four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the steepest fall since October 1994 and the second consecutive sharp monthly drop. 
 Excluding food and energy prices, which tend to jump around independently of broader inflationary pressures, the index fell by one-tenth of a percent, the third decline in five months. Prices paid to producers of consumer goods fell five-tenths of a percent after a drop of three-tenths of a percent in January.
Figures for retail price inflation will not be released until next week, but today's report suggested that there was little upward pressure anywhere in the economy. Prices paid for intermediate goods like parts and components were unchanged last month even after excluding falling food and energy prices. And prices for crude goods inched up just 1 percent, mostly because of rising prices for scrap metals.
"It's a picture of virtual price stability at the wholesale level," said Stuart Hoffman, the chief economist at the PNC Corporation in Pittsburgh.
The notion that the economy remains well balanced was reinforced by other indicators released today. The Federal Reserve reported that industrial production rose five-tenths of a percent last month, its biggest jump in three months, but that industries were operating at 83.3 percent of capacity, below the level at which pre-inflationary bottlenecks typically appear.
The Commerce Department said business inventories increased just a tenth of a percent in January, suggesting that factories could count on steady orders as long as demand remained strong.
The figures helped spur a recovery in stock and bond prices, which had tumbled on Thursday when reports that the economy was growing at a surprisingly fast pace increased investors' fears that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates later this month to forestall a buildup in inflationary pressures.
Today's producer price report, however, again seemed to reduce the chances that the Fed would tighten monetary policy when it meets on March 25. But the report left many economists struggling to explain why price pressures remain so contained despite the strong economic growth and low unemployment. Economists have long assumed that tight labor markets inevitably lead to higher wages, which companies then pass on to consumers in the form of higher prices.
"It certainly raises questions about the way we view the economy in terms of looking at pressure points," Mr. Hoffman said.
After watching for the last year as growth has repeatedly accelerated and slowed, all without significantly upsetting the balance between a strong labor market and relative price stability, economists are divided over how fundamental a change the economy has undergone.
On one side are those who are confident that current growth rates, which have been running around 3 percent annually, are perfectly compatible with the current low unemployment rate of 5.3 percent as long as the economy's productive capacity and productivity improvements dampen the need and ability of companies to raise prices.
"I've been arguing strenuously for several years that inflation would remain low regardless of economic growth, and we just got more evidence of that today," said Mickey D. Levy, the chief economist at Nationsbanc Capital Markets.
Mr. Levy said the Fed had been pushing growth in nominal gross domestic product -- growth before it is adjusted for inflation -- gradually down to far lower levels than it did in the last period of rampant wage-price inflation, in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
In Mr. Levy's view, high levels of nominal growth -- 11.5 percent from 1978 through 1980 -- created excess demand in the economy. Workers demanded higher wages and got them. Companies then passed the wage increases along to consumers in the form of higher prices, and got away with it without losing market share because competitors were doing the same thing.
But now, with nominal growth running around 5 percent, there is no excess demand because growth is roughly equal to -- or even less than -- increases in capacity and productivity. Mr. Levy said that companies could no longer raise prices because competitors, who have excess capacity, would keep their prices down to gain market share. Companies in turn are holding the line on wages.
"There's certainly room for debate over when the Fed needs to tighten, but the debate should not be in the standard notion that low unemployment rates drive up wages, which drive up inflation," Mr. Levy said. "The Fed has changed the whole macroeconomic environment for wage negotiations, for the way companies conduct their business and for spending growth."
But other economists remain convinced that the old pattern will sooner or later reassert itself: companies will bid up wages as they compete for workers in a fast-growing economy with a tight labor market, and they will raise their prices to compensate for their rising costs.
"Are we in a high-growth, low-inflation new era? My conclusion is no," said Kenneth Mayland, the chief economist at Keycorp, the banking company in Cleveland.

HEADLINE: Albania Chief's Associates Flee; Gunfire Halts Evacuation by U.S.

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, March 14

 BODY:
The collapse of authority in Albania worsened today, as close confidants of the President fled the country and the Government failed in its effort to seize weapons from roving bands of thugs.
The United States suspended efforts to evacuate Americans after gunmen fired at two helicopter gunships waiting to pick up families who had gathered in a large field at the diplomatic compound here. About 2,000 Americans are in Albania, according to the State Department. 
 Only 408 people had been lifted out at the time of the suspension, the Pentagon said, leaving nervous Americans to spend another night in a city racked by indiscriminate gunfire and widespread looting. Italy also mounted an evacuation operation by helicopter at a sports field in the center of town and by landing craft at the chaotic port of Durres, in central Albania, where gunmen fired into the air. One Italian helicopter was hit by gunfire but not seriously damaged.
Mobs of desperate Albanians wanting to flee pushed themselves onto the Italian landing craft and had to be pushed off by Italian soldiers, a Western diplomat said.
In the capital, the coalition Government that President Sali Berisha was forced to appoint this week tried unsuccessfully to contain the chaos. Kalashnikov-toting secret policemen tried to set up checkpoints, demanding that motorists give up weapons. But there appeared to be only a few checkpoints, and there were no signs of confiscated weapons.
On Thursday, the authorities had flung open weapons warehouses, apparently hoping to supply guns to its backers.
The new Government also asked police and military officers, many of whom have deserted and some of whom have been looting, to return to their posts. Their calls appeared to have gone largely unheeded.
Despite Mr. Berisha's appeals for help from other nations, it seemed highly unlikely that European countries would send troops or police support. Jamie Shea, a NATO spokesman, rejected Mr. Berisha's call for troops, saying, "The main problem is that there is lack of trust in the Government."
But if Mr. Berisha resigned, he would leave a power vacuum. There are no clear leaders in the opposition parties, and any successor would face the daunting task of rescuing an economically devastated country as well as trying to restore order to a nation of armed camps.
This afternoon two battered armored personnel carriers, with the symbol of the police written on the front, paraded up and down Tirana's main tree-lined street and around the central Skanderbeg Square. On board, eight gunmen in tattered clothes brandished automatic weapons, firing off shots. It was impossible to tell whether the men supported the President or the new Government, or whether they were part of the rabble.
The anarchy reached the previously calm eastern part of the country near the Macedonian border, where a $10 million cigarette plant, one of the biggest new investments in Albania, was burned to the ground after looters took all they could carry.
"They took doors, toilets, everything," said Vebi Velija, the owner of the plant, at Prenjas, and one of the most prominent businessmen in Albania. Mr. Velija, who has been a critic of Mr. Berisha, said he was concerned that his recently built four-story business center in the heart of Tirana would also be looted.
In Shkoder, 56 miles north of Tirana, a center of culture and education, all Government institutions were set on fire and the armory emptied. The headquarters of the secret police was destroyed as well as the local bank. On a historic street dating from the Middle Ages, buildings considered national treasures were also burned, according to Elsa Ballauri, a head of a human rights group in Tirana who spoke to residents there by telephone.
The new coalition Government today forced the resignation of the unpopular head of the secret police, Bashkim Gazidede. Mr. Gazidede had presided over the state of emergency that Mr. Berisha imposed nearly two weeks ago.
As his country descended into nightmarish chaos, a defiant Mr. Berisha appeared to be standing firm, ignoring demands from the people and politicians that he resign.
He sent his 25-year-old son, Shkelzen, and 18-year-old daughter, Argita, to Italy on the last ferry from Durres to Bari on Thursday night, Italian officials said.
Today, the recently replaced Defense Minister, Safet Zhulali, his wife and 14-year-old daughter escaped to Italy on a boat that arrived in Brindisi, the Italian Government said.
Several national guardsmen, members of the elite unit that protects the President, said they were preparing to flee.
A guardsman from Mr. Berisha's hometown of Tropoje, in northern Albania, said he had already sent his wife and child to Greece and would follow this week, using his diplomatic passport.
But Mr. Berisha has no intention of leaving, his press office said, according to a report on Italian television. He was invited to attend diplomatic negotiations held today on board an Italian frigate moored off Durres but apparently did not want to venture even that far out of the country, a diplomat said.
Instead the new Prime Minister, Bashkim Fino, a 35-year-old member of the Socialist Party, headed the Government's delegation at a meeting with the former Austrian Chancellor, Franz Vranitzky.
Mr. Vranitzky, representing the Organization for Cooperation and Security in Europe, said after the meeting that European countries should consider sending military or police assistance to Albania to curb the violence. He said Albanians had made it clear that they were incapable of restoring order themselves.
But NATO diplomats said they would be unwilling to send help unless an organization like Mr. Vranitzky's could help broker a political solution.
"If the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe worked out a credible framework for a political solution to the crisis and made a specific request to NATO to do something like monitor the collection of weapons, then we'd take another look," a NATO official said.
Whether Mr. Berisha actually understood how dark the situation was in his country was open to question.
A Western diplomat who visited Mr. Berisha, a tall, 51-year-old with a ruddy face and a booming, agitated voice, described a bizarre scene at the Presidential Palace on Thursday.
As weapons depots were being ransacked and the city was exploding with gunfire, the President was all alone in his suite of offices in a dilapidated white two-story building, the diplomat said. Mr. Berisha's staff had abandoned him.
Mr. Berisha's first concern, the diplomat said, was to get foreign troops to help him put down the violence that had ruined one of Albania's most precious assets: "We have to get action because they have burned the Coca-Cola plant," the diplomat quoted Mr. Berisha as saying. The bottling plant on the outskirts of Tirana is one of the few multinational investments in Albania and close to the heart of Mr. Berisha, a former Communist turned capitalist.
In fact, the Coca-Cola plant was still intact today and had survived four attempts by gunmen to storm the gates, according to men guarding the plant.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Gains 56.57, But Nasdaq Slips 0.31
Blue-chip stocks rebounded after prices were pummeled on Thursday. An unexpected drop in the Producer Price Index gave investors hope the Federal Reserve might not have to push up rates to avert inflation. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 56.57 points, to close at 6,935.46, and the S.& P. 500 index gained 3.61 points, to 793.17. Both have risen more than 7 percent this year. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite lost 0.31 of a point, closing at 1,292.97, and leaving it up less than a quarter of a point for the year. [Page 42.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities also rose as a Fed rate rise looked less certain. The 30-year bond rose 5/32 , to 962/32 , with its yield slipping one basis point to 6.94 percent. [42.]
 
Applied Magnetics Withdraws Bid
Applied Magnetics said it was withdrawing its unsolicited offer, made in February, to buy the Read-Rite Corporation, a larger rival supplier of components to makers of disk drives, because recent declines in Applied's shares had trimmed the value of the proposed stock swap to $1.06 billion from $1.76 billion. [40.]
 
Anti-AIDS Drugs for Children
Children infected with the virus that causes AIDS became eligible to receive a potent new class of drugs that has sharply reduced the level of the viral infection in adults. The F.D.A. approved for pediatric use two anti-AIDS drugs known as protease inhibitors -- nelfinavir, to be sold by Agouron Pharmaceuticals under the brand name Viracept, and Abbott Laboratories' ritonavir, sold under the brand name Norvir. [9.]
 
World Bank Head Trims Plan
James Wolfensohn, the president of the World Bank, faced with criticism from other nations and Congress, proposed trimming $122 million from the budget for his plan to reorganize the bank and said that he would more closely supervise the buyouts to be made to the 500 to 700 employees who would leave voluntarily. Proposed payments averaging $200,000 have been criticized as excessive. Board members of the 180-nation organization are to consider the proposed changes on Thursday. [40.]
 
G.M. Plant in Indiana Is Struck
Members of a United Automobile Workers local struck a General Motors plant in Fort Wayne, Ind., that makes pickup trucks. The union wants G.M. to hire more workers at the plant to cut down on overtime and to address health and safety issues. It was the first local contract dispute since the auto maker reached a new national pact last fall. G.M. said talks were to resume today and that it hoped for a resolution. [40.]
 
Less Powerful Air Bags Endorsed
The Federal Government told car makers that they could make air bags that opened with 35 percent less force, following reports of air bag-related fatalities in 62 car crashes. The manufacturers, endorsing the change, said it would be made in the 1998 model year. But some safety advocates were critical. [11.]
 
Dollar Off Against Mark and Yen
Depressed by the producer price report, the dollar lost ground on foreign-exchange markets. It settled in New York at 1.6935 marks, down from 1.7056 marks on Thursday, and at 123.38 yen, down from 123.41 yen Thursday. The pound cost $1.6010, up from $1.5974. [38.]
 
Soybean Futures Prices Surge
Soybean prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade, with beans for May delivery up 21 cents, to $8.495 a bushel, after a report showed domestic demand at a record pace on rising consumption of livestock feed. Coffee prices recovered, with May coffee up 4.10 cents, to $1.8635 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York. [38.]
 
Pressing the Case for Bananas
Carl Lindner, the man behind Chiquita Bananas, is known for spreading money around Washington, to leading politicians of both parties. And next week he is likely to learn whether his investment has paid off. The World Trade Organization is expected to hand down its first decision on Europe's banana rules, in a case that the Clinton Administration pressed on Chiquita's behalf. Mr. Lindner contends Europeans favor bananas grown in Europe or former colonies over Latin American-grown competitors. [10.]

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-7

U.S. Suspends Evacuations Under Hostile Albanian Fire
A United States military effort to evacuate Americans from Albania was suspended after gunmen fired at two helicopter gunships involved in the operation. Only 408 of the 2,000 Americans in Albania had been lifted out. Gunmen fired into the air during Italy's evacuation, hitting one helicopter but not seriously damaging it. 1
 
Refugees from the chaos in Albania have been reaching Italian shores, some flying the white flag of surrender. But the Italians, worried that they are about to face a recurrence of the Albanian exodus of 1991, have been keeping close track of them. 6
 
Israel to Start Housing Project
The Israeli Cabinet resolved to go ahead with construction of a Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem despite warnings of potential Palestinian resistance. The Cabinet reaffirmed its decision as the nation mourned seven schoolgirls killed by a Jordanian soldier. The attacker remained in custody, and no new information emerged about his motives. 4
 
The attacker's family said he had psychological problems but no history of violence or ties to militant groups. King Hussein appointed a former intelligence chief to head the investigation, raising speculation about possible political motives for the attack. 4
 
No New NATO Forces in East
NATO made a new concession to Russian concerns about its expansion. The alliance said it had no intention of stationing permanent foreign forces for ground combat in countries that did not already have them. NATO officials hoped the concession would serve as an olive branch in advance of next week's Russian-American summit talks in Helsinki. 6
 
Zaire Rebels Attack Kisangani
Zairian rebels launched an attack on Zaire's third-largest city, Kisangani, creating panic among Government troops and civilians. Western diplomats said the assault began with a mortar barrage, followed by shooting inside the city and a convergence of rebel fighters. Kisangani, the unofficial capital of northeast Zaire, is the biggest strategic target so far in the rebels' campaign. 7
 
Mexican Defends Bank Deposit
Mario Ruiz Massieu, who deposited $9 million in a Texas bank while he was a deputy attorney general in Mexico, told a Federal court that he shipped the money out of the country for fear that Mexico was sliding into chaos. Narcotics corruption in Mexico and the country's political crisis dominated testimony at a civil trial focusing on whether Mr. Ruiz Massieu can legally keep the money. 7
 
80 Feared Dead in Iran Crash
A military cargo plane crashed in the mountains of northeastern Iran, killing the 80 or more people aboard, the Government news media said. The American-built C-130 crashed near Mashhad, a city holy to Shiite Muslims that is more than 400 miles northeast of Teheran. (AP)
 
NATIONAL 8-11
 
Surgeons Reattach Tendon In Clinton's Knee
Surgeons reattached a tendon to President Clinton's right knee. He had torn it when he stumbled on steps at the golfer Greg Norman's house in Florida. Mr. Clinton said he would attend next week's summit meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia as planned. Doctors said he would have to wear a leg brace and use crutches. 1

X Chromosome Is Mapped
Researchers completed a high-resolution map of the X chromosome, one of the pair that determines whether a human is male or female. The map took 10 years and the work of 25 biologists to complete. 1
 
2 Acquitted in Jogger Killing
A jury acquitted two men in the November 1995 rape and killing of a jogger, Kimberly Ernest, near one of Philadelphia's most prestigious areas. The men had contended that the police had forced them to sign confessions. The verdict struck another blow against a police department that has seen 12 officers charged with corruption and 283 criminal cases dismissed. 8
 
F.B.I. Finds 7 in Atlanta
The F.B.I. in Atlanta said it had located seven of the nine people whose images it had released less than 24 hours previously as part of the investigation into the bombing during the Olympics. None of the seven were considered suspects, but they might be able to provide information about the bombing, the bureau said. 8
 
AIDS Drug Approved for Young
The Government approved the use of new AIDS drugs for children. The drugs, called protease inhibitors, have been successful in reducing the levels of the AIDS virus in adults. They are being used in combination with older antiviral drugs like AZT to transform AIDS treatment. 9
 
Herman Aided Her Firm's Buyer
The White House said President Clinton's nominee to be Labor Secretary, Alexis M. Herman, had helped a woman who had bought her consulting firm obtain a spot on a Commerce Department trade mission last year. The White House defended the help as proper and said it was not related to contributions to the Democratic Party by the woman and her sister. 10
 
Less Forceful Air Bags Allowed
The Government told automobile manufacturers they could make air bags that open with less force than had previously been required. The manufacturers said they would make the change on all cars by the end of the 1998 model year. The change would reduce the danger to children and small adults, some of whom have been killed by the more powerful air bags. 11
 
Suspect Called Unremarkable
The teen-age Ukrainian immigrant accused of killing Ennis Cosby seemed so quiet and polite to most people with whom he came in contact that, they said, he seemed to escape notice and memory. 11

Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew urged the Justice Department not to keep a hard-won reorganization of New York City's schools from taking effect on April 1. The Government is examining whether the plan, by giving the Chancellor more powers, violates minority voters' rights. 1

The judge in the bribery trial of a former top Newark official dismissed a juror who had been sleeping. A heated argument over race erupted as the defense noted that several jurors had fallen asleep but that the only one dismissed for it was black. 25

An artist who kills frogs and electrically stimulates their muscles to create moving sculptures said he would withdraw from a show opening next month in Soho. But the artist, David Arnold, said he would complete his series of sculptures despite criticism from animal-rights groups. 25

New York State's tax amnesty program has not lived up to expectations, Comptroller H. Carl McCall said. The amnesty was expected to bring in $450 million but has reaped only $256 million so far, he said. 29

HEADLINE: EUROPE '97: FESTIVALS;
A Taste of The Zeitgeist

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER; HOLLAND COTTER writes about art for The New York Times.

 BODY:
ART LOVERS can do triple duty in Europe this spring and summer. They can play catch-up with major shows they missed at home, see others not due in New York for months (including a spectacular display of Cambodian sculpture), and experience a major dose of the contemporary Zeitgeist in two biennial extravaganzas that don't travel.
Of several shows that debuted in the United States and are moving on to Europe, at least two are outstanding: the retrospectives of the American modernist painters Ellsworth Kelly (at the Tate Gallery, London, beginning June 12) and Jasper Johns (at the Ludwig Museum, Cologne, beginning Aug. 3). Both career surveys looked impressive in New York; it will be fascinating to see how they shape up elsewhere. 
 For devotees of up-to-the-minute art, though, the summer of '97 is one of Those Summers, when Europe's two sprawling expositions, the Venice Biennale and Documenta in Kassel, Germany, roll into view. Neither show is a known quantity at this point, but both are famous for being famous, and, at least for the opening week or two, they draw art world cognoscenti like moths to a flame.
More often than not that flame is a dim one, but there's always the chance it will set off larger sparks. Documenta this year is in the capable curatorial hands of Catherine David, a former director of the Pompidou Center in Paris. The trumpeting of the end of the millennium in the press material is already sounding tired, and the promise of a program in which "every day, at an appointed hour, between 21 June and 28 September, one or more intellectuals or cultural protagonists will initiate a debate on the economic, political and cultural aspects of globalization" is enough to send anyone to the nearest art-free zone. Still, Ms. David could pull off something memorable from a basically unorganizable event.
The Biennale (June 15 to Nov. 9), with the veteran Italian curator Germano Celant at the helm, promises less. Again, the official statements of intent are hot-airish. (The show's theme is said to be "the flux that is born of the dialect between continuity and discontinuity.") But as always, the choice of the artist to represent the United States at the show generates some interest on this side of the Atlantic.
This time the nod has gone to the painter Robert Colescott, best known for his reworking of canonical masterpieces -- Jan van Eyck's "Arnolfini Wedding," Leutze's "Washington Crossing the Delaware" -- by inserting caricatured figures of blacks. Mr. Colescott's bad-taste work is funny, angry, and sure to send some viewers steaming out of the show. It should provide at least a mild buzz to an event that tends to doze its way through the summer months.
Taste of a different kind (the very kind Mr. Colescott burlesques, as it happens) may be sampled in "Van Dyck in Genoa: Grand Paintings and Collections," on view at the Palazzo Ducale in Genoa through July 13. The great Flemish artist lived in the city from 1621 to 1927, painting the rich and famous with matchless panache. In addition to 41 paintings by Van Dyck himself, the show includes others by Titian, Rubens, and Caravaggio, in the grand setting where many of the works originally hung.
Elsewhere in Europe, major retrospectives of modern artists crop up. A retrospective of the French modernist Fernand Leger (1881-1955) will air at the Pompidou Center from May 29 to Sept. 28. (It arrives at the Museum of Modern Art in New York next February.) The show will afford the first opportunity in some 30 years to take a sweeping look at an early Cubist who went on to restyle the human figure as a set of interlocking machinelike tubes and pipes.
A modernist painter of lesser stature, the Belgian Paul Delvaux (1897-1996), will be given a full-dress retrospective in Brussels. His surrealistic concoctions of meticulously painted nude women fitted out with bows and wandering across empty piazzas no doubt has an ardent audience out there somewhere and fans will find much to savor at the Royal Museums of Fine Arts (March 21 to July 27).
Definitely worth catching at the Tate Gallery in London, through May 4, is a retrospective of the German painter Lovis Corinth (1858-1925), which has previously been seen in Munich, Berlin and St. Louis. Corinth can be a scary, overbearing artist -- his work helped inspire early 20th century German Expressionism -- but his depictions of his family and his series of Rembrandtesque self-portraits documenting his own physical decline are extremely moving.
London also offers other tantalizing exhibitions. Spring travelers will find very English fare in "Hogarth the Painter" at the Tate through June 8, one of several events celebrating the 300th anniversary of the artist's birth. Closer to the present is "Modern Art in Britain 1910-1914" through May 26 at the Barbican Gallery, which sets Continental artists (Cezanne, Gauguin, Matisse and Picasso) beside British artists whom they "inspired" (Vanessa Bell, David Bomberg, Roger Fry and Augustus Johns).
Perhaps this lineup of modernists will shed some light on contemporary British art, which is a hot item on the international market these days.
Anyone visiting London before April 6 should trot over to the Saatchi Collection to see work by two fine young painters, Fiona Rae and Gary Hume, then move on to "Material Culture: The Object in British Art of the 1980's and 90's" at the Hayward Gallery, through May 18, which includes work by such young artists as Mona Hatoum, Damien Hirst, Shirazeh Houshiary, Sarah Lucas and Rachel Whiteread. (An exhibition of Ms. Whiteread's work is also appearing at the Reina Sofia in Madrid until April 21.)
London also offers something special in non-Western art, with a show at the Queen's Gallery, Buckingham Palace, titled "The King of the World." It consists of a single, magnificent album of miniatures from 17th-century Mughal India known as the "Padshahnama" now owned by the Royal Library, Windsor Castle. Ordinarily the book can be exhibited only two pages at a time, but it has recently been unbound for conservation and all 44 pages are on view until April 27. (The book will also appear at the Sackler Gallery in Washington, May 18 to Oct. 13, and then at the Met from Nov. 20 to Feb. 8.)
 AND Paris, with the blockbuster "Angkor and Ten Centuries of Khmer Art" at the Grand Palais through May 26, will be a must-see site on the Asian art pilgrimage route. There is no more glorious sculptural tradition on earth than Cambodia's, nor any that has suffered more devastating pillage and poaching, a fact that inevitably lends this dreamy exhibition a bitter extra-esthetic edge.
"Angkor" will travel to the National Gallery of Art in Washington this summer (June 29 to Sept. 28), but visitors to the show at its Paris venue can be ahead of the game. But while in Europe, why not catch some small, easy-to-miss exhibitions that are unlikely to be seen here?
For those who think old art is the best art, for example, there will be portraits by Sir Henry Raeburn (1756-1823) at the Royal Scottish Academy in Edinburgh, beginning Aug. 8. Raeburn was, you might say, the Scottish Herb Ritts, except he was a real artist, who by making pink cheeks pinker and hairdos higher had a very successful career.
And finally, there are two amorphous gatherings of modern art. One of them is a display at the Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow of Russian avant-garde work from the legendary collection of George Costakis (March 18 to May 5). The other is the long-promised blockbuster titled "The Age of Modernism: Art in the 20th Century," at the Martin-Gropius-Bau in Berlin (May 7 to July 27). With splashy international loans and artists ranging from Kasimir Malevich to Cindy Sherman, it may not tell a coherent story but it's bound to have wonderful things.

PUB-DATE: March 16, 1997

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2292 words

HEADLINE: Photos That Lie -- and Tell the Truth

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
WHAT'S GOING ON IN THIS photograph? Two girls on the edge of puberty are wading a stream. One is pensive, turned inward. The other looks around and stops in mid-action, spying something that frightens her in the darkness of a tunnel. What a decisive moment, and how fraught with sexual symbolism! Jeff Wall, the photographer, must have been poised to take the picture at the second the revelation occurred.
He was. He staged it. 
 A funny thing happened to reality on the way to the photograph. The camera, true to its calling, registered what was before it, which was real enough, if a little too perfect, but not what it seemed to be. The picture comes close enough to traditional documentary photographs to look like a lucky grab-shot, at least on first inspection, but is instead a performance disguised as a snapshot. Manufacturing a reality that has the effrontery to look real, Mr. Wall thrusts the camera's vaunted documentary powers into the realm of fiction.
In the region between illusion and reality, Mr. Wall has a lot of contemporary company. Right now, "Jeff Wall," an exhibit of 30 transparencies mounted in light boxes, is at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, while work by 30 more photographers who concoct edgy alliances between fact and fiction are at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn., in a show ironically titled "Making It Real." At the Aldrich, toy figures perform like actors in out-of-focus movies, realistic landscapes shimmer in Day-Glo colors, and waxworks stand still for portraits from life. It's as if these photographers had decided that if everyone thinks the camera lies, they might as well prove them right.
Actually, the crucial issue may not be the camera but a gnawing sense that the world itself, knowable only through imprecise perceptions, is a tissue of uncertainties, ambiguities, fictions masquerading as facts and facts as tenuous as clouds. Life today resembles a fictional paradigm more and more and sometimes even outdoes the movie version. O. J. Simpson's ride in a white Bronco might well have been an improbable episode on a television cop series; the televised Simpson and Menendez trials so convincingly melded the forms of "L.A. Law," "All My Children" and "Oprah" that talk show and soap opera ratings fell off. Small wonder if photographers, who traditionally pay close attention to the world, are making story boards for an equivocal universe.
Jeff Wall decided some time ago that the idea of the document was too predominant in photography, and that cinema, where the artificial and the real coexist without either taking precedence, was a better model. "Every picture I've made is an experiment in the gray area between the theatrical and the real," he said recently. He goes to enormous lengths to dwell in this area, hiring actors and coaching them until they're so exhausted they underact like "real" folks. Once he spent 26 weeks waiting for the right weather and hired a helicopter to stir up wind when nature would not oblige.
THE HIRSHHORN RETROSPECTIVE, a big show of big work -- one photograph, "Eviction Struggle," measures 90 inches by 163 inches -- is the most comprehensive of this Canadian artist's 20-year career. Organized for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles by one of its curators, Kerry Brougher, the show remains on view through May 11, then travels to Los Angeles and the city of Mito in Japan. "Making It Real," organized by Independent Curators, is on view in Ridgefield until April 20 and then travels.
As it happens, photography has been dallying with fiction since its invention, when reality still knew its place. Nineteenth-century photographers staged tableaux and patched together composite photographs for artistic purposes, a style that pretty much went out of favor in America when straight photography, documentary and 35-millimeter candid photographs moved to the forefront in the 1930's and after. Theatrics returned several decades ago, and more recently art photographers have developed a taste for performances that look like the unrehearsed course of life passing by, a newly popular form of trompe l'oeil.
Advertisements have done something like this for ages -- all those grumpy men being served coffee by smiling wives and achieving nirvana -- but no one claimed those were documents. In Mr. Wall's case, the light box display technique is directly borrowed from advertising, hinting that for some reason it has become necessary to market the real world.
Other art photographers imply that lives measured out with coffee spoons are, after all, constructions, a fact that might as well be acknowledged. Tina Barney and Philip-Lorca diCorcia, for instance: Ms. Barney's photographs look like large blowups of snapshots that calmly and subversively capture the persistent disconnections in upper-crust lives -- family members standing at cautious distances from one another, making no eye contact, in elegant chintz-covered rooms. In Mr. diCorcia's domestic documents, minor, offbeat incidents assume intense and puzzling significance, as when a man stares into a refrigerator that to judge from the aggressive light it casts on him, may be staring back.
Both photographers' work is as carefully scripted and directed as "Citizen Kane," though Mr. diCorcia recently showed dramatically stage-lighted but unposed street photographs. Some photographers, like Collier Schorr, simply direct their subjects to re-enact something that happened a while ago, then photograph people playing their own lives.
Something is odd here. Why would anyone use the little reality machine to record performances painstakingly choreographed to seem casual, offhand, even insignificant? Isn't casual, offhand -- maybe even insignificant -- what photography already does best?
Perhaps it can no longer do what it does best so readily. With life looking like the movies and everyone leery of photographs, visual documents have fallen into disrepute. At least since the late 1960's it has been clear that the belief in photographs was hostage to opinion and prejudice. Pictures of Vietnamese civilians massacred by American soldiers at My Lai were declared fakes by a number of staunch patriots who were certain that Americans were incapable of such atrocities. Whatever fabric of belief in photographic observation that still remained surely unraveled with the first trial in the Rodney King case in 1992, in which four officers accused in the beating were acquitted. What the jurors saw may have had as much to do with racial prejudice as with optics, but what they said was that the tape of Mr. King's beating by the police after a high-speed chase told a different story when seen frame by frame than it did at normal speed.
This kind of wavering credibility fit right in with the warnings that pundits, deconstructionists and post-modernists had been issuing for a couple of decades. There was no absolute truth and not much fixed reality to hang on to, and we would have to make do with little more than shifting individual interpretations. Popular culture, which may not have been entirely up-to-date on the latest academic philosophies, nonetheless seemed to bear them out.
Television docudramas played fast and loose with history, claiming dramatic license. Just last month, George C. Wallace, former Governor of Alabama, denounced a forthcoming television movie about his life for including two scenes invented from whole cloth. Critics have complained that the movie "The People vs. Larry Flynt" effectively trashes history by omitting the bad news about Hustler magazine.
In 1991, Oliver Stone mixed fact and fiction in a Waring blender in his film "J.F.K."; all the ingredients, whether frames from the Zapruder film or secret informants who never existed, had the same consistency and seemed equally authentic. Last year, Russ Hexter's movie "Dadetown" took this approach to its logical conclusion. The film unrolled like an as-it-happened documentary of a small town where the factory economy was dying and giving way to the software business. Not until the credits rolled was it revealed that the town, the citizens and the upheaval were entirely fictional. Any critic who raced out at the close of the final scene reviewed a documentary they only thought they saw.
Even the news occasionally plays around with re-enactment or staged events, as when a gas tank was primed to explode in a report on alleged dangers in pickup trucks.
FINALLY, ENTER THE COMPUTER, which makes performing seals of documents. Forrest Gump consorts with dead presidents; the moon is moved to the wrong part of the sky to improve a composition; newscasters appear to be somewhere they are not. Reality has not actually disappeared; it has merely turned into Houdini on weeknights and a master of disguise at matinees.
With faith in the stability of the material world dissolving under the pressure of doubts, digitization and special effects even as we watch, reality is declared unreliable, unprovable and, when convenience dictates, disposable. In come the art photographers, flaunting the untrustworthy nature of appearances and of photography itself. Some of them have decided that since our environment is a construct of imagination and perception, they might as well remake it themselves.
Thomas Demand, a German artist whose work was recently seen at the Museum of Modern Art, makes pictures of empty interiors that are, in fact, scale models replicating photographs from magazines and newspapers. Jerald Frampton photographs tableaux he constructs from cut-out photographs, clay and plaster, each scene inhabited by what at first seem to be actual people but are in fact photographs stuck on pins. Joan Fontcuberta constructs impossible flora from bits of vegetable matter and photographs them as if he were a plant biologist. All or part of these photographs look, at first glance, "real."
Photographers who make use of computers sometimes mess with the eternal verities. Nancy Burson combines Reagan and Gorbachev, while the team of Aziz and Cucher photograph nudes who have no genitals, nipples or navels. One way or another, the photographic medium is busy destabilizing the very nature of existence. A medium intent on such subversion just might have more power as fiction than fact. Maybe its lies are what count.
Some of its fictions are attempts to outwit photography's limitations. Cameras cannot see through walls or into people's souls. Tina Barney complains that she got so tired of looking for actual instances of the complex relationships she knew were there and getting people to display emotion that she finally asked actors to play out her scenarios. Jeff Wall, too, expresses a "wish to be able to get closer into situations which usually happen in the absence of a photographer rather than in his presence." The still camera is ordinarily stymied by its dependence on what is visible here and now. The most direct route to the invisible is to make it up.
After all, everyone knows by now that photographs lie. But maybe, just maybe, everyone is wrong. After all is said and done, we still believe in photographs. If the Derby is won by a nose, a photograph proves which nose. If a camera shows dead bodies in Zaire, if an X-ray reveals a tumor, no one flippantly says these are lies made by photographs. In the first Simpson trial, the defense lawyers cast doubt on the police, the experts, the DNA evidence, the glove, the socks, even the jurors' ethics, but no one has questioned the authenticity of the grisly photographs of the dead.
DESPITE ALL THE ATTACKS on the medium's virtue, both artists and photographers are fully aware that it has an uncanny power to convince, and none of us can easily keep ourselves from succumbing to its wiles for an instant or two. When Tony Oursler stretched a rag-doll dummy along the floor and stuck its head, a circular pillow, partway under a mattress, no one was expected to believe this was a person. But projected onto the head was a video of a woman's face, slightly squashed (no doubt by a mattress).
She grimaced, sighed and snarled, "What are you looking at? Get out of here! Hey, you!" It was impossible not to feel both intrusive and assaulted, though she was but a bag of clothes. There was a real woman lurking there somewhere in the projector; we humans are programmed to respond. The mere fact that a photograph is at work will lend even dummies and staged performances at least a moment of our belief.
We have our reasons for credulity. Seeing is believing, and our lives are organized around visual clues: A car is coming. It looks like rain. My hair's too long. "I couldn't believe my eyes!" means that I did -- but I never would have, had my eyes not offered proof.
If the media and the computer have thrown even the evidence of our eyes into doubt, their timing has been astute, for the pattern of our lives is in a peculiar state of flux. Gender identities and role identities, no longer quite fixed in stone, are entirely fluid on the Internet. Neither a job nor a marriage necessarily lasts much longer than it takes to change the station. News slides into entertainment every night at 7. An entire industry is busy devising virtual realities that promise the intense pleasure of experiencing life at one remove.
Perhaps photographers who manufacture ambiguous facts and fictions disguised as truths have got it exactly right; perhaps they are telling it the way it really is. Maybe photographs are not lying even when they skitter along the thin edge between real life and theater. Rather, they uncover the secret stories, mythic constructions and uncertainties that constitute our lives.

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Taking Control of Old Demons By Forcing Them Into the Light

BYLINE: By E. R. Shipp; E. R. Shipp, a professor of journalism at Columbia University, is working on a history of her Southern family.

 BODY:
NEITHER Esther Allison Brown nor Johnnie Will Shipp Sr., my father, would have been comfortable with John Singleton's new film, "Rosewood" -- and that has nothing to do with esthetics or accuracy.
"What is all this digging up?" Miss Esther, who was then 85, challenged me a few years ago after I pumped her about the Allison plantation near Statesville, N.C., and what became of the former slaves who were her kinsmen and mine. As one of her granddaughters and I headed out to roam through the old cemetery in search of my missing past, Miss Esther added: "I don't know what y'all hunting them old dry bones for." 
 My father, who died in 1993 at the age of 70, was less perplexed than close-mouthed. He initially denied having known his paternal grandfather, Shelton Shipp, a former slave who died when my father was about 8. And he refused to say anything about his World War II experience of battling Nazis as well as racist white Americans until I finally dragged out of him this simple declaration: "It was rough."
Even after "Roots" -- the book and the television mini-series that came out in the 70's -- Miss Esther and my father stood as fortresses to protect their progeny from the painful, though rich, African-American heritage. So did others of their generation, as had their parents and their grandparents. Blacks were not alone, however, in wanting to keep closed the doors to the truth.
"Ours is a morbid history," Mr. Singleton said in an introduction to the book "Rosewood: Like Judgment Day" by Michael D'Orso (originally published as "Like Judgment Day: The Ruin and Redemption of a Town Called Rosewood").
"Most of us try to avoid it," he said. "Black people don't want to remember having been the victims of lynchings and rapes. We don't want to linger on the separation of our families, living under Jim Crow and all the horrors that kind of life entailed. And white folk don't want to remember perpetrating that kind of persecution."
With the unfettered hubris of youth, a degree of revisionism and the detachment that comes from growing up outside the South, Mr. Singleton, a 29-year-old Californian, has tackled a long-lost episode of American history and claimed it for his generation as a metaphor for racism. With a few differences.
The story he tells -- with obvious homage to westerns, action movies and "Schindler's List" -- is the massacre of an unknown number of blacks by an angry white mob and the annihilation of their nearly all-black town, Rosewood, Fla. But Mr. Singleton has conveyed that sad tale in a way that allows his contemporaries to see possibilities of heroism amid the victimization.
Survivors lived in fear that if they talked of what they saw during those hellish days in January 1923, members of the mob would track them down and resume the bloodletting. "My grandma told me not to say a word," Robie Mortin, who was 8 in 1923, recalled last year in The New York Times. "My grandma said never to look back. We weren't supposed to talk about Rosewood."

Breaking the Silence
In the early 1980's, some of them broke the silence and talked to journalists. As they found their voices, the story of unimaginable horror was recounted in newspapers, in magazines, on "60 Minutes" and in "Like Judgment Day."
While "Rosewood" the film may be breaking new ground with its big-budget backing by Warner Brothers, stories like Rosewood's -- of black settlements destroyed and blacks forced into exile -- are not unique. They are merely hidden, only rarely even the stuff of whispers and legends retold at family reunions.
"Earlier generations didn't want to talk about slavery or deal with the kind of pogroms or whatever you want to call it that white people carried out in places like Rosewood," said the essayist Gerald Early, director of African and Afro-American studies at Washington University in St. Louis. But now, he suggests, blacks are interested in creating "an epic narrative of what their experience means in the Western world."
Among recent works in this category are these:
* 'Malcolm X," in which Spike Lee angered purists with the liberties he took in his 1992 account of the life of the black nationalist leader who was assassinated in 1965.
* "Daughters of the Dust," Julie Dash's elegiac 1992 film about the last days of a Gullah family on the Sea Islands off South Carolina and Georgia. In choosing greater economic opportunity on the mainland, the family left behind an African heritage few other black Americans could lay claim to.
* "Posse," in which the actor-director Mario Van Peebles focused on blacks who populated a West usually depicted as white, Mexican and American Indian. The 1993 film was shaped as much by the Rodney King episode as by 19th-century history.
* "Panther," Mr. Van Peebles's 1995 movie about the Black Panther Party, which was formed by young blacks in Oakland, Calif., in the 1960's and spread across the country before it was destroyed by its leaders' criminality and self-destructive tendencies and a relentless campaign by J. Edgar Hoover.
* "Tuskegee Airmen," a 1995 HBO movie with an all-star cast of young black actors told the story of World War II fighter pilots who were never properly honored as heroes.
* "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," in which the theater wizard George C. Wolfe and the tap dance kid Savion Glover use dance to trace the American history of blacks, from slave ship to the Million Man March.
* "A Huey P. Newton Story," Roger Guenveur Smith's one-man show at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, touted in press releases as "the mythic rise and tragic fall" of the co-founder of the Black Panther Party.
* "Miss Evers' Boys," an HBO film, shown last month, that is a fictionalized account of how for 40 years more than 400 black men were used like guinea pigs so scientists could observe the effects of untreated syphilis.

Alternative Narratives
All these stories are shaped by a present largely depicted in the popular culture and by news media as marked by racism, violence, police brutality, welfare dependency, broken families, drug abuse and alarming rates of incarceration. The artists whose work has pierced mainstream consciousness this decade offer an alternative narrative.
"They want to understand their American experience on their own terms," Professor Early said. "All of that adds up to me to be a very important exercise -- an emotional, psychological and intellectual exercise -- for black people as they begin to exert some degree of control over how they wish to be interpreted in the culture."
Control is key. The director Melvin Van Peebles insists that historically, most black artists have sought to define the African-American experience; the difference now, he says, is access to a mass market available to directors like Mr. Singleton, Spike Lee and his son, Mario.
"I've seen many scripts that told these stories," said Mr. Van Peebles, "but those scripts were not given the opportunities they're being given today. It's like saying, when the barn door opens and horses are stampeding out: have horses suddenly taken to running?"
Malik Yoba, a member of the emerging generation of artists, echoes that sentiment: "The lack of pertinent stories regarding our history is directly attributable to the fact that we are not power brokers in this industry," he said, noting that fewer than 2 percent of the members of the Directors Guild of America are people of color.
Some black creative artists -- the painter Jacob Lawrence, the playwright Amiri Baraka and the actor-film makers Ivan Dixon and Ossie Davis -- have always made the past the foundation of their work. In the 70's, Mr. Dixon and Mr. Davis tried to bring the Malcolm X story to the big screen but were unable to muster the Hollywood backing that Spike Lee eventually received.
Mr. Singleton, whose debut film was the acclaimed "Boyz N the Hood" in 1991, has acknowledged of "Rosewood" that "no black man has had the opportunity before to direct a film like this in this context and on so wide a canvas."

The Legacy of 'Roots'
Like millions of people, in ways obvious and not so, Mr. Singleton is a beneficiary of "Roots" which 20 years ago brought history alive for Americans of all origins, while especially imbuing blacks with a sense of what Robin D. G. Kelley, a professor of history at New York University, calls "peoplehood."
Ever since, the visual arts, film and theater have drawn on the 'Roots' metaphor, he said. "A lot of the work from that point on took for granted the African past."
That alone distinguishes Mr. Singleton and his cohort from my own: we, who celebrated the rare appearances of blacks on television in the 50's and 60's in roles other than the half-naked primitives who populated "Tarzan," needed "Roots" to explain to us that we had a past worth acknowledging. Mr. Singleton's generation of film makers and playwrights can take that for granted.
And thus, "Negro psychology," as Mr. Wolfe calls it, can fall by the wayside because this new generation is not trying to redeem the image of blacks as maids, mammies, mamas, buffoons, butlers and Buckwheat.
In this era, he says, they are less interested in "telling stories that only show nobility and strength and courage" than in showing the "complexity of human behavior." They can concentrate on "going after the story as opposed to going after the image."
That means having the freedom to bring to the screen and to the stage flawed heroes like Huey Newton, love stories unconstrained by the fear of stereotyping blacks as sex machines and rhapsodies about black life before the civil rights movement.
Even as they pursue a bolder and more complex depiction of African-American life, the new kids on the block are undergoing the rite of passage required of every generation of black artists and intellectuals: wrestling with the enormity of racism and struggling to carve out an identity for themselves as African-Americans.
"People of John Singleton's generation are trying to figure out how to be black in a society where everything seems so hybrid and mixed," Professor Kelley said. "Some are Princeton and Yale grads; some grew up in suburbs. They know a lot, and they are also trying to be black. They're trying to figure out how to negotiate that blackness. Part of that exploration involves history."
In "Rosewood," Mr. Singleton responds to the facts of life in the 1990's and offers his generation an idyllic past in which black families are intact, loving and prosperous, and a black superhero who changes the course of history when he escapes the noose, takes on the mob with double-barreled ferocity and saves many women and children from death. The director tops it off with a tender romance, a war hero and the possibility of a happy ending.

A History Out of Shards
Mr. Singleton defies the image of blacks as mere victims even in retelling this dark hour of African-American history; with an eye on current racial conflicts and the rash of church burnings that made headlines last year, he conjures up black heroes standing tall -- perhaps the only way to attract his contemporaries to a historic episode that on the surface is solely about black victimization.
His film may be stereotypical and cliche-ridden to audiences accustomed to seeing their stories rendered on screen, but many black moviegoers are entranced by this tale that has its roots in a past about which they know very little.
The film is inaccurate only if one expects it to be a documentary. It is not. What it is, however, is disturbing, especially to some white moviegoers in whom it stirs feelings of guilt.
Some critics of "Rosewood" take issue with Mr. Singleton's embellishment of the facts and the creation of Mann, the reluctant hero. Indeed, a reviewer for The Houston Chronicle, typical among the critics, regretted that the movie "assumes a lot and then makes up a lot more."
One response is this: When a people's history has been deliberately obliterated, how can anyone question attempts to piece together that history from the shards that remain, using artistic license to fill the gaps?
As Henry Louis Gates Jr., the author and chairman of the Afro-American studies department at Harvard University, makes clear in regard to black artistic endeavors rooted in African-American history: "To reassemble fragments, of course, is to engage in an act of speculation, to attempt to weave a fiction of origins and subgeneration. It is to render the implicit as explicit, and at times to imagine the whole from the part."
But there is another response to the charge that Mr. Singleton "assumes a lot and then makes up a lot more." He didn't stray too far from the truth. The basic story of "Rosewood" hews closely to the facts set out in a 1993 report prepared by researchers from three Florida universities and titled "A Documented History Of The Incident Which Occurred At Rosewood, Florida, In January 1923."
The characters in the film bear the names of people who lived in Rosewood, Sumner and surrounding hamlets. Some are clearly composites; for instance, John Wright, the white store owner in the film, is credited with saving (and in one instance betraying) black neighbors when, his was among several families that did so. But even the heroic Mann, who was created for the film, bears some history and traits of the real Sylvester Carrier, whose nickname was Man. Like Carrier, Mann was a World War I veteran and, by most accounts, fearless.
Indeed, the story told by Mr. Singleton and the screenwriter Gregory Poirier resonates not solely because so much of it is verifiable as having taken place in Rosewood in January 1923, but because events like it most certainly took place elsewhere in that area and in that era.
The report prepared by the Florida academics in 1993 notes: "From Chicago to Tulsa, to Omaha, East St. Louis, and many communities in between, and finally to Rosewood, white mobs pursued what can only be described as a reign of terror against African Americans during the period from 1917 to 1923."
For all these reasons it is nearly impossible for blacks familiar with that history to view "Rosewood," flaws and all, with dispassion.

Wrestling With Demons
When a white man in the movie callously tosses Mann's World War I discharge papers to the floor, I can't help thinking of my 93-year-old grandmother's uncle Jodie Aiken, whose service has been similarly diminished. As best as I can tell from family stories and meager courthouse documents, he died in the Army in France in 1919. But the United States Government has no record of him.
When the sheriff on the screen tells Sylvester Carrier to get out of town if he knows what's good for him, I hear whispers in my family about my paternal grandfather's brothers, who, early in this century, were likewise told to leave. What became of Will Shipp is still a mystery; John Shipp was killed in Gary, Ind., in 1931.
And when the movie mob takes as trophies body parts sliced off blacks who are lynched, I can't help thinking of the experience of the scholar-activist W. E. B. DuBois, as recounted recently in the PBS documentary "W. E. B. DuBois: A Biography in Four Voices."
In 1899 a black man was lynched in a town not too far from Atlanta, where DuBois was on the faculty of Atlanta University. Recalling how the incident affected DuBois, the historian Herbert Aptheker said:
"He was going to the newspaper, The Atlanta Constitution, to register some kind of a complaint. Walking down the main street of Atlanta, he passed a butcher shop and on display with a label were the knees of the victim -- next to the pigs and the pork. He saw that, and didn't go to the newspaper. He went back and wept."
A tally kept by the Tuskegee Institute (now University) between 1882 and 1964 records 4,752 lynchings. Nearly all of them occurred in the South; practically all the victims were black -- and, yes, some of them were occasions for parades and picnics, as depicted in "Rosewood."
The drumbeat for a Federal anti-lynching law, led by the N.A.A.C.P., reached a peak in 1946, after the widely publicized lynching of two black couples by a score of white men in the Georgia county of my roots. One victim, George Dorsey, had recently returned home from fighting in the Pacific in World War II.
That story, like Rosewood's, was buried for nearly half a century until a man came forward to tell what he had witnessed as a 10-year-old. Until then, neither blacks nor whites who knew what had happened to George and Mae Dorsey and Roger and Dorothy Malcom ever talked about it. As in Rosewood, many blacks moved away and started new lives.
"There were four shooters initially," Clinton Adams told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution in 1992. "Then, when they fell to the ground, these men just stood over them, shooting into the bodies and up in the trees. Everybody was shooting. Everywhere." That's not unlike a scene in "Rosewood."
Responding to this story, the son of a man who had been sheriff at the time of the murders questioned the value of recalling what happened at Moore's Ford, Ga., in 1946. "If all it's going to do is stir up old memories, it can't do anything but hurt folks," said Judge Marvin Sorrells. "Who wants to talk about Nagasaki and Hiroshima? Who wants to talk about Dachau? Well, probably those things need to be kept alive, but this thing, I don't see anything positive to come from it."
The judge and my older relatives are not alone in questioning the value of delving into African-Americans' tragic history. On the eve of the premiere last month of "Miss Evers' Boys," some health-care workers worried that by dredging up the past, the film would reinforce a distrust of government -- and deter blacks from participating in experimental AIDS treatments.
But there is a need to wrestle with and even tame the demons of African-American history for reasons that go beyond the Singleton generation's way of explaining the present.
"All the things that happened in the past have a bearing on the present,' says Professor Kelley of N.Y.U.
"When you erase these memories, you have white people thinking that African-Americans have always had it easy and that affirmative action has been around since Abraham Lincoln. A lot of white people need to know this. They don't have to feel responsible, but they do have to understand it and work toward recreating the world."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk
