HEADLINE: Deadline Nears for States To Develop Antismog Plan

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
After two years of studies, the Eastern states are facing Federal pressure to solve air pollution problems that transcend regional boundaries. If they do not soon agree on a coordinated solution, the Government is expected to require costly new rules affecting many states.
Environmental agencies from the 36 easternmost states, in an extraordinary collaboration involving hundreds of participants from government, industry, academia and environmental advocacy groups, have been trying to devise a transregional approach to help the dirtiest areas, which are mostly in the Northeast, achieve the Clean Air Act's limits on ozone, the main ingredient in smog. 
 The plan could impose new controls on industrial polluters in the Middle Western and Southern states, thought to be the source of much of the smog in cities like New York, Washington and Boston.
But deciding how to proceed is proving elusive, and the technical work by the federally sponsored coalition known as the Ozone Transport Assessment Group, or OTAG, is behind the schedule originally set by the Environmental Protection Agency. The E.P.A., increasing pressure on the states, has said that it intends to propose the tougher pollution limits on many of them this spring, even though the group is not likely to complete its work before June.
Already, schisms are appearing between the various states and interest groups involved in the ozone group's deliberations.
"The tensions are going to get very high," said Mary Gade, the Illinois environmental commissioner and chairman of the ozone transport group's policy committee. "The stakes are high, politically, economically and in terms of public health."
On Friday in Philadelphia, the group presented the final computer analysis on how to deal with the drifting smog.
Specialists described how they believe smog travels from region to region and how various schemes could change the pattern. In the most ambitious scenario, pollution across the 36 states could be cut almost 40 percent, with power plant emissions reduced as much as 85 percent.
"It is extremely unlikely that any of the most aggressive control strategies will be adopted by this group," said David Hawkins, a senior attorney at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "E.P.A. will have to use its authority."
Even some participants who say they favor giving more authority to the states in carrying out environmental laws, like David Struhs, the Commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection, are counting on the Federal Government to back them up if the states fail to reach consensus.
"If nothing else, what we gain from this is a solid, comprehensive set of evidence that, in a worst-case scenario, we can use in court," Mr. Struhs said. But he called himself "an optimist by nature: I continue to be optimistic that OTAG will surprise everyone in the end and reach some kind of consensus."
Gov. Angus King of Maine, a state that suffers chronically from smog blowing across its borders, said: "There is going to be a certain amount of bashing into each other, inevitably. But at some point there has to be a collaborative resolution."
The discussions over how to control the long-distance movements of smog are especially important because the E.P.A. is simultaneously proposing more stringent national standards for ozone pollution, and the Federal agency believes that a transregional solution is essential if states with the worst smog problems are to have any hope of reaching the new goals.
In addition, the prospect of deregulating interstate sales of electricity means that unless environmental rules are changed, relatively low-cost and high-polluting power plants in the Middle West might in the future export more smog along with cheap power to other states.
To bolster their case for far-flung solutions to their local problems, Maine and the seven other Northeastern states this week issued a study of weather and pollution data; they said the study proves beyond a reasonable doubt that the solution to their problem lies among the smokestacks and boiler rooms of the industrial Middle West.
The report, written by the Northeastern States for Coordinated Air Use Management, says that by the year 2007 smokestacks in Ohio alone are likely to produce more oxides of nitrogen, or NOx, than those in all eight Northeastern states combined. NOx is changed to ozone, an irritating gas, forming smog that can travel for hundreds of miles.
In the meantime, industry groups and state officials in the Middle west and South have already begun to argue that ozone pollution may not travel far enough to justify transregional controls.
"Although not complete, the OTAG modeling analyses are changing common perceptions of the transport issue," said Gov. Don Sundquist of Tennessee, in a letter to the E.P.A. in January. "Contrary to expectations, the modeling is not showing significant long-range interstate ozone transport."
"The science so far shows ozone stays close to its sources," argued the Midwest Ozone Group, a coalition of power companies, in a recent report analyzing OTAG's preliminary work. Using environmental jargon for meeting or not meeting air-quality goals, the report said, "Science shows reducing ozone locally in non-attainment areas continues to be the most effective way to attain standard. Costly controls on Midwest sources don't appear to help Northeastern states."
In their report this week, though, the Northeastern states reached exactly the opposite conclusion from the same data produced by the ozone group.
"The OTAG modeling shows that broad-based regional NOx reductions will have significant air quality benefits throughout the eastern United States," the report said.
Governor King of Maine said that it was practically self-evident that his state's worst pollution blew in from elsewhere and must be controlled in other states.
"You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows," he said, quoting Bob Dylan.
But judging by the prevailing political winds, he may need a lawyer. Last year Maine sued the E.P.A. to require the agency, under the Clean Air Act, to control pollution in upwind states. But to give the ozone transport group time to reach its recommendations, his suit did not call for the E.P.A. to act immediately.
Past efforts to devise transregional smog controls have not gone smoothly.
On Tuesday, Virginia won its own lawsuit against the E.P.A. when a Federal appeals court overturned the agency's proposal to require new cars sold in 12 states, from Virginia northeast to Maine, to meet more stringent pollution standards.
The agency had issued the rule at the request of the Ozone Transport Commission, a body established by the Clean Air Act to address Northeastern smog. The commission wanted all 12 member states to abide by the same automobile regulations.
The work of the broader, 36-member OTAG could potentially have far greater ramifications than the proposals by the Northeastern states to require cleaner cars.
Smog comes not only from vehicle exhaust but also from factory and power plant smokestacks and from emissions of volatile organic compounds, like fuel vapors. Dealing with long-distance smog could involve complex decisions over which sources to control.
The diverse states may not agree that transregional controls are needed, but if they do, there appears to be a broad consensus over how to go about the process.
Under a market-based approach being designed by the ozone transport group, the Government would put caps on emissions of oxides of nitrogen at much lower levels than at present and would allow the sources of pollution to buy and sell the right to emit the chemicals. That way, in theory, the cheapest controls would be put into place first.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Expecting a Flood of Network Cash, N.F.L. Plans for Drought

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

DATELINE: PALM DESERT, Calif.

 BODY:
When your league is flush with $4.4 billion in television money, and it stands to increase that take by 50 percent or more, must you worry about bad times ahead? If you're the National Football League you do, even if your TV money will soon approximate the annual compensation paid by the Walt Disney Company to Michael Eisner, its chairman.
So, in very preliminary talks, N.F.L. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and Gene Upshaw, the leader of the players' union, have discussed setting aside a so-far unspecified chunk of future TV money for the days when -- who knows? -- there aren't enough takers for $250,000 luxury suites, $45 seats or $8.50 beers, and offensive linemen's salaries are greater than the gross domestic product of Finland. 
 "With enough money, we might want to negotiate with the union," Tagliabue said here last week. "I've broached it with the union. We have a healthy economy. Six straight years of growth. And we have prospects for substantial revenue increases from television. In a rainy-day fund, you'd maybe defer some TV money the first year, and then if you need it, you have it, and if not, it would be redistributed to the players," as an increase to the pension fund, or in lump-sum payments to players. "Right now, it's just a concept."
As the largest source of money that flows into the N.F.L., television revenues have the greatest impact on the income that flows out to players, and on setting the salary cap. The amount of money that would be diverted into any possible fund could slow salary growth.
Tagliabue did not specify which woes would trigger the need to dip into such an account. The informal Tagliabue-Upshaw chats have spread to a few owners, who whispered about the rainy-day fund concept during the league's annual meetings. But while the league may want to do it, it clearly can't be done without the union.
"Gene thinks it's intelligent, but it's premature to discuss numbers," Tagliabue said.
Doug Allen, the assistant executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, said that Upshaw had not briefed him on the embryonic idea. "We haven't agreed to anything that would treat television money differently than it is now," he said.
That television rights money isn't all the networks pay for the N.F.L. In this peculiar world, the networks spent lavishly at the Marriott Desert Springs Hotel on parties to amuse and feed team owners, coaches and executives. Paying for the privilege to pay: it sounds like those wacky personal seat licenses that fans are required to buy in order to own the rights to buy season tickets.
At these parties, Fox and N.F.L. executives gleefully blew smoke at each other from the respective ends of foot-long Dominican cigars; NBC's Greg Gumbel and ESPN's Chris Berman swapped bawdy tales; ABC's Dan Dierdorf showed off the mobility an artificial hip has given him; the Baltimore Ravens owner Art Modell joked that he never really had a bodyguard during the nasty brouhaha over moving the Cleveland Browns, "just a driver with an Uzi," and many people paid obeisance to Eisner during his ABC party cameo.
Within all this fun was the posturing and positioning that goes with the months-long lead-up to new contract talks between the league and the networks.
"We're looking forward to it," said David Hill, the president of Fox Sports, whose company's $1.58 billion investment in the N.F.L. roiled the industry in 1993.
"We didn't come this far to bow out at this point," said Robert Wright, president of NBC, whose $868 million rights fee will rise by leaps and maybe bounds. "We're in it."
An interesting perspective comes from Dennis Swanson, the president of ABC Sports until last spring, who is now the president of NBC-owned WNBC-TV.
In 1993, Swanson came away from his N.F.L. talks with a bargain for ABC: $920 million through 1997.
Nearly four years later, Swanson is thrilled to be gone from ABC Sports and running the local TV home of the Jets. After making that ABC-N.F.L. deal, he said, "I didn't want to renew against that number" -- reasoning that the N.F.L. will pinch ABC for gobs more cash to renew its "Monday Night Football" package.
Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, said he fully expects to have to pay heavily to keep the American Football Conference package.
"Every one of us has to be extra alert, except Fox because they are up so high," he said. "They have a right to be a tad relaxed."
A few N.F.L. owners insist that doubling their TV cash is possible (largely because CBS is the odd network out, and is looking to pay to get back in). But Modell, the former head of the league's broadcast committee, said of the potential increase: "They don't know what they're talking about. I'd say 35 percent on the low side, 50 to 60 percent on the high side."
Al Davis, the Oakland Raiders' chieftain, recently predicted a doubling. When asked to reiterate his claim, he asked, "What's it going to cost me to say that?"
Nothing, Al. It's on the networks' tab.

HEADLINE: Russian Media, Free of One Master, Greet Another

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 15

 BODY:
Every Sunday evening, Russia's most influential television news program unveils a new tale of intrigue and corruption.
The targets are President Boris N. Yeltsin's old cronies and new political foes. The anchorman is Yevgeny Kiselyov, a dapper correspondent for NTV, who is Russia's Peter Jennings, Dan Rather and Tom Brokaw rolled into one. 
 Mr. Kiselyov and his colleagues at NTV, Russia's independent television network, wear the mantle of crusading journalists determined to ferret out the links between former Kremlin aides and multimillion-dollar crimes.
"We are basically anti-Communist, pro-reform and pro-democracy," Mr. Kiselyov said proudly.
But others say that the reports also appear aimed at settling old political scores on behalf of the Government and its supporters in the business community.
"The program is excessively politicized," said Mikhail Berger, the respected economics editor for the daily Izvestia.
With the collapse of the Soviet Union, many of Russia's news media have wrenched themselves free from Government control. At the same time, the lines between information and business are becoming increasingly blurred.
Russia's largest television stations and newspapers are owned by energy companies, large banks and entrepreneurs like Boris A. Berezovksy, the tycoon who became Mr. Yeltsin's deputy national security adviser.
Mr. Kiselyov himself is the public face of Media-Most, the communications empire of Vladimir Gusinsky, a theatrical producer turned banker.
The concentration of power in the hands of a relative few -- along with the linking of big money, big media and government power -- has raised searching questions about Russia's young democracy.
The new media czars insist that they are simply copying the American model, in which private ownership is a mark of independence and a barrier against government censorship.
But critics say some media barons are out to protect their business interests and unfairly influence people.
"This is not real journalism," said Boris G. Fyodorov, a pro-reform former Finance Minister. "This is political games."
By all accounts, Mr. Gusinsky is Russia's most powerful and sophisticated media mogul. At 44, he has already made a fortune as head of Most Bank. But he left it in January to establish Media-Most, saying he wanted to avoid a conflict of interest with the bank and focus on his media holdings.
His is a vast and variegated empire, which includes NTV, the newspaper Segodyna, Ekho Moskvy radio, the publishing house Sem Dnei and the magazine Itogi, a joint venture with Newsweek.
As a young man, Mr. Gusinsky was denounced as "anti-Soviet" for staging a play by Mikhail Bulgakov in Tula, an industrial town near Moscow. (Mr. Bulgakov fought a lifelong battle with Soviet censors, and many of his key works were not published until decades after his death.)
An active member of Russia's Jewish community, Mr. Gusinsky describes himself as a builder of a new Russia.
"I have a dream," he recalled in a recent interview in his office, where a caged boa constrictor was on display. "When I am not in this world anymore or am very old, they will remember the name Gusinsky just as they recall the name of the family who started The New York Times."
But Mr. Gusinsky's media ventures, including his four-channel satellite broadcast system, NTV Plus, have also drawn him into the lucrative area of entertainment.
One of the television personalities he most admires, he said, is Dr. Ruth Westheimer, the sex therapist. He still marvels at how the heads of passers-by turned when he and she walked down the street in New York City.
He has powerful rivals, particularly Mr. Berezovsky, 50, a wheeler-dealer who used his Logovaz car sales network to launch a business empire and a government career.
Mr. Berezovsky has served as deputy chairman of the board at ORT, which is 51 percent owned by the Government, and has invested heavily in the TV-6 television network. He has also reached into his deep pockets to rescue the newspaper Nezavisimaya Gazeta and acquire an interest in the weekly magazine Ogonyok.
Russia's nascent corporate sector has dived into the media market as well. Gazprom, the huge natural-gas monopoly, has a 30 percent stake in NTV and substantial interests in two papers, Trud and Komsomolskaya Pravda, the latter one of Moscow's most popular.
Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, has a 20 percent share of Izvestia. Powerful banks have invested in the weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta and the newspaper Vek.
Even some Government-controlled media companies have become increasingly dependent on the private sector. The RTR television channel, although owned by the Government, relies on commercials to supplement its meager subsidies.
Experts say the problem is not private ownership, which acts as a balance to the Government. (In any case, they point out, some of the media owners have conflicting economic interests, which would make it hard for one of them to monopolize the news.)
"The problem," Mr. Berger said, "is when the shares are in the hand of one company. Gazprom is investing in one of the most popular papers so that at the right moment it can resist efforts by the Government or the Parliament to withdraw its privileges." He was referring to Komsomolskaya Pravda.
As for political bias, critics see it in some of the most effective and professionally run organizations, like Mr. Gusinsky's NTV.
During the war in Chechnya, NTV acquired a reputation for independence, with graphic reports that poked holes in the Kremlin's claims. The authoritarian President of Belarus, Aleksandr Lukashenko, was so infuriated recently by NTV's reports on events in Minsk that he threatened to block its broadcasts.
But the network was also accused of siding with President Yeltsin during his re-election campaign. NTV's managing director, Igor Malashenko, advised the Yeltsin team on image-making during the campaign.
Mr. Malashenko, who is in the process of launching a political consulting company, said NTV reporters did not take their cue from Mr. Gusinsky. But he acknowledged that his network's journalists believed their profession to be threatened by the Communists.
"There is a liberal bias in NTV," he said. "We have a bias against a politician who will reintroduce censorship or government control."
Critics say the network was repaid for its loyalty to Mr. Yeltsin when, after the election, it no longer had to cede air time for educational programming.
NTV's Sunday news program, "Itogi," which is anchored by Mr. Kiselyov, has continued to pound away at the Kremlin's enemies. In a series of reports, it has detailed corruption in the aluminum industry, which it has linked with Oleg N. Soskovets, a man ousted from the post of First Deputy Prime Minister last year.
Yeltsin supporters have been concerned that proceeds from the highly lucrative aluminum industry will be used to finance the presidential ambitions of Aleksander I. Lebed. Their fear is that Mr. Lebed will join forces with Mr. Soskovets and Aleksandr V. Korshakov, the President's former bodyguard and a staunch enemy of Mr. Gusinsky.
Mr. Kiselyov said that although he and Mr. Gusinsky often talked on political subjects, Mr. Gusinsky did not interfere with news decisions. Mr. Gusinsky, for his part, said his job at Media-Most was more about making money than making news.
"To influence editorial policy is not my profession," he said.
But he confessed with a smile that his idea of business was all-embracing. "Whatever is good for business in Russia is good for Russia," he said.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 43; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 822 words

HEADLINE: After Pay Freeze, a Plan to Increase Union Dues 30% Angers City Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Stanley Hill, executive director of the largest union of New York City municipal employees, has created a storm among the union's 120,000 members by proposing a hefty dues increase while they are still under a 27-month pay freeze.
Many workers in District Council 37 assert that before the union's top officials push to raise dues by almost 30 percent, the leaders' pay should be cut, including that of Mr. Hill, who makes $257,000 a year. 
 "At a time when economic times are difficult and members are living paycheck to paycheck, the timing is horrible," said Frank Jerez, an emergency medical technician who confronted Mr. Hill about the increase. "If we're in trying times, everyone has to give a little back. I told Stanley he ought to take a $100,000 pay cut. He'd still live much better than most of the people he represents."
Mr. Hill is urgently campaigning for a dues increase because the union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, is facing a $5.4 million annual deficit. Nonetheless, of the 56 union locals in the council, 3 prominent ones are on record against the increase: those representing 15,000 social workers, 1,800 library workers and 2,300 accountants and statisticians.
Upset that Mr. Hill accepted a contract with a 27-month pay freeze, Raymond Markey, president of the librarians' local, said: "We oppose the increase because our members can't afford it. I think any dues increase should be tied to what the union produces. If the union doesn't negotiate a contract with money in it, you can't expect the members to be happy about a dues increase."
Actually, the district council's leadership is proposing that the increase begin April 1, the same time that the workers receive their first raise in 27 months. But many union members -- whose salaries average under $25,000 -- say they are insulted that the union wants to take more money as soon as they receive their long-awaited 3 percent raise. The leaders of the union, which has a $29 million budget, are seeking $2.50 more a month now and $5.50 more a month on Jan. 1.
Mr. Hill defended the increase as necessary to close a budget deficit caused largely by a decline of 11,000 in the union's membership brought about by the city's shrinking of its work force.
"Either we cut back drastically and lay off people or we continue the services we've done for years," he said. "We have to handle thousands and thousands of grievances. We help educate people. We're expanding our citizenship classes. We have to go to the Governor's office, City Hall, the State Legislature. And now we have to organize workfare people. All that costs money."
Mr. Hill voiced confidence that the union's 24-member executive board and 325-member delegate assembly would approve the increase. But some union members assert that the increase will be rejected in a rank-and-file vote.
For many workers, the opposition is visceral, focusing on union leaders' salaries and their winter retreats in Florida and the Bahamas -- trips that union officials say they have stopped.
"This increase is outrageous, coming after 27 months without a raise," said Carol Thomas, an administrator at the Andrew Heiskell Library for the Blind in Manhattan. "I understand D.C. 37 has a big deficit, but it didn't seem to bother Stanley Hill and the other top people when they set their own salaries."
Mr. Hill's annual pay is higher than that of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ($165,000); John Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. ($192,500); Dennis Rivera, president of the 117,000-member National Health and Human Service Employees Union ($96,000); Sandra Feldman, president of the 90,000-member United Federation of Teachers ($157,000), and Jay Mazur, president of the 300,000-member Union of Needletrades ($165,000).
Defending his pay, Mr. Hill said: "If you compare me with Dennis Rivera or Sandy Feldman, I have to represent this whole city. I don't represent just one title. I have to be an expert in administration and on the work of 56 different locals, representing social workers, engineers and school lunch workers, you name it. I can pick up the phone and speak to the Governor or the Mayor. I can have my international president talk to the President. That's what you call value."
Mr. Hill noted that he works seven days a week and that the union's executive board unanimously set his salary. Some critics, however, say that board members are simply backscratching when they approve high salaries for one another.
These critics question the $188,000 in pay for Robert F. Myers Jr., the union's treasurer; the $174,000 received by Al Diop, president of the 22,000-member clerical local, and the $224,000 by Charles Hughes, whose local represents 19,000 cafeteria workers and other part-time board of education workers.
Mr. Hill insisted that his staff was the best union staff in the city and was not overpaid.

HEADLINE: Hot Issue in Lilco Takeover Talks: Who Pays for Shoreham?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: SHOREHAM, L.I.

 BODY:
Standing like a bulky gray sentinel on the coastline here, the Shoreham power plant soars more than 200 feet high. If it had windows, they would offer a commanding view of Long Island Sound.
The main tower is a pillar of concrete -- enough, it is said, to pave a road to Florida. Inside is a high-tech labyrinth of chambers, pipes, cables and turbines. It produced electricity just once -- for a one-day, low-level test in the 1980's. 
 Now, with current negotiations for a partial state takeover of its owner, the Long Island Lighting Company, reaching the final stage, the true cost of Shoreham and who should pay for it are a main issue of debate.
For more than three decades, the Shoreham project has cast a long shadow over Long Island. The Lilco takeover is part of Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut local electric bills, the highest in North America.
"If Shoreham had never been built, we wouldn't be where we are today," said Jonathan Sinnreich, a member of the state's Long Island Power Authority.
Without Shoreham, Lilco's rates would be a third to a fourth lower, experts say. The power authority itself, created to deal with the island's energy problem, would not exist. And Lilco, long wounded by Shoreham, would probably not be merging with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.
Critics say that unless something is done now, Shoreham's debt will ultimately cost Lilco customers $20 billion or more. To avoid that, the critics insist that Lilco absorb a big part of the loss, a demand the company had opposed.
Even based on lower cost figures from the past, experts say the 800-megawatt plant may be the most expensive thing ever built and then abandoned. It was closed because of public concerns over safety, the environment and costs.
The ill-fated plant has been a drag on the local economy as high electric rates drove away thousands of jobs. The Shoreham issue made and broke local political careers, entangled governors and even drew White House concern when President George Bush met with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and urged opening the plant.
When first proposed 32 years ago, the plant was to cost $65 million to $75 million and be finished in 1973. But when completed in the mid-1980's and licensed in 1989, the plant had cost $6.5 billion.
In 1989, Governor Cuomo closed the unpopular plant, giving it to the power authority. In return, Lilco was allowed to recover the costs over 40 years in its billing. So far, Lilco has charged customers $5.6 billion for Shoreham costs and interest.
In one critic's study, Harry Davitian, president of the Entek energy consulting company, projected that customers would pay $14.3 billion more to retire the debt by the year 2030, for a total of $20 billion. Gregory Palast, an economist who directed a Suffolk County investigation of Shoreham, put the cost at $25 billion.
Another utility consultant, James A. Rothschild, said those numbers "are in the ball park."
Most of the projected cost is interest. "When you're looking at Shoreham, you're looking at a mega-pile of interest," Mr. Palast said. "It's a Carl Sagan number -- billions and billions."
Peter Quinn of the Long Island Progressive Coalition, an alliance of environmental, business and civic groups, said the state takeover of some of Lilco's assets -- particularly the Shoreham debt -- amounted to a bailout of Lilco.
"Here's a company that's been ill managed at ratepayers' expense," he said, "and we want the investors to share the debt."
Governor Pataki's appointees on the power authority say they want a fair settlement that will reduce rates, and they warn that an obsession with Shoreham and the Shoreham debt could thwart a solution.
"Much of what happened should not have happened, but we are where we are," the authority's chairman, Frank G. Zarb, said of Lilco's history. Long Island will suffer if it misses this chance to solve its energy crisis, he said.
But decades of resentment against Shoreham are bubbling over. This week, the Suffolk County Legislature will vote on a bipartisan bill calling on Lilco to write down the debt.
"This is all about the Shoreham debt -- the merger is kind of a sideshow," said Ashok Gupta, an analyst for the National Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. "The underlying issue is do we have to pay for Shoreham or not? People are still fighting the old fight. It's like Bosnia; they have long memories."
Could the Shoreham issue scuttle the prospective deal?
"Absolutely," Mr. Sinnreich said. "Any bailout of Lilco on Shoreham is a hurdle to a deal. People are still mad about Shoreham. There is no good answer to the problem -- only better bad answers. We can't make history go away and unspend billions of dollars."
Under the state takeover plan, interest on the Shoreham debt could be cut by refinancing with tax-exempt bonds issued by the power authority -- this would require the largest such bond issue in the nation's history. The basic debt could also be shrunk by forcing Lilco to absorb a loss.
Lilco contends that it already wrote off $1.7 billion in the 1980's, a penalty imposed by state regulators for the company's bad judgment on Shoreham.
But critics say the vast competitive changes under energy deregulation in recent years have prompted other utilities to accept losses on so-called stranded assets like Shoreham. They say the 40-year repayment is not binding, and Lilco should bend with the times.
When Shoreham was conceived, energy use was rising, Long Island was growing and Lilco warned of brownouts and blackouts.
But unforeseen events intervened: the environmental movement that started with Earth Day in 1971, the 1973 oil embargo that fostered conservation and 1979's "China Syndrome" disaster film and the subsequent Three Mile Island meltdown.
Confidence in Lilco's nuclear capability was undermined with the breakdown of conventional diesel engines at Shoreham in 1983 (cynics nicknamed them Snap, Crackle and Pop). And then delays, overruns, double-digit inflation and tougher regulations all pushed up Shoreham's costs.
"Certainly, Lilco bullheadedly pushed Shoreham far longer" than made sense, said a former Public Service Commission chairman, Peter A. Bradford
Shoreham's originators are mostly gone. "This goes back such a long time that many of our executives, myself included, were in grammar school at the time," said Dr. Joseph McDonnell, a Lilco senior vice president. "As you look back, mistakes were made by everyone it touched, both inside the company and in the political arena."
Shoreham still has defenders. William K. Schneider, a steamfitter on its construction who now oversees the property, said "it breaks my heart" that the plant closed. Shaking his head, he said, "I've been involved in two major things in my life -- Vietnam and Shoreham."
And what if Shoreham had been allowed to open? "If Shoreham had been turned on, things would be pretty much the same as they are now," said one energy economist, Charles Komanoff. "Nuclear operating costs, exclusive of construction, are about the same as buying power from the grid, about 3 cents a kilowatt hour. Over all, it's a big fat wash."
The plant is not suitable for conversion to oil or gas, and demolishing it would be a major expense.
Irving Like, a lawyer for the first Shoreham opponents in the 1960's, said, "Some suggested alternative uses are as a monument to man's technological stupidity or as a rest home for all the politicians either elected or defeated because of it."

HEADLINE: Irish President's Decision Not to Run Again Unsettles Politicians

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, March 15

 BODY:
President Mary Robinson's decision not to seek a second seven-year term has thrown Irish politics into turmoil.
Politicians, who face a parliamentary election this year, are now wondering anxiously whom they should back in a presidential election, also to be held this year. 
 Ms. Robinson, 52, who in 1990 became the first woman elected President in the Irish Republic's 74-year history, said on Wednesday that she would not seek a new term and indicated that she would like to be considered for the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.
While her announcement was not a complete surprise, it has created a new urgency among political leaders, including Prime Minister John Bruton, to start looking for a successor. The main question is whether the candidate for what is largely a ceremonial post should be a person not directly involved in Irish Republic politics or whether there should be competing candidates from Mr. Bruton's Fine Gael party, and from the largest opposition party, Fianna Fail, led by Bertie Ahern.
The nation's largest bookmaker, Paddy Power, has already established John Hume, the prominent moderate Roman Catholic leader in Northern Ireland, as a 4-to-1 favorite. Also mentioned is another northerner, the poet Seamus Heaney, the Nobel Prize winner in literature in 1995.
Although both men were born in the British province, they are eligible to become President under Irish law.
The Irish Times reported from Washington that Mr. Hume was not now considering campaigning. But a poll in The Sunday Independent showed Mr. Hume was first preference of those surveyed.
Mr. Heaney has not commented.
Aides to Mr. Bruton said that he was likely to meet Mr. Hume at the White House in Washington on Monday -- St. Patrick's Day -- and that the presidency would be a likely topic of conversation.
If no prominent outsider comes forward, the political parties will choose from among their own members. Mr. Bruton will decide whether to hold the parliamentary and presidential elections on the same day, in November, or whether to hold the parliamentary election first.
Before the presidential vacancy became certain, Mr. Bruton was believed to favor holding the parliamentary election in June. But if he had a strong presidential candidate to head the ticket, he might hold both elections the same day.
On Thursday he seemed to equivocate, saying the elections should probably be separate, but added that having them on the same day would save millions of dollars.
Political analysts and politicians say Fine Gael is short of strong presidential candidates. Former Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald is not believed to be interested. Peter Sutherland, a former Irish Commissioner at the European Union and head of GATT, the former international trade organization, has not commented on his availability.
Fianna Fail has several possible candidates. Former Prime Minister Albert Reynolds, who gained wide popularity for his peace efforts in Northern Ireland, has indicated that he would like the job, but he has many enemies in his own party. David Andrews, a former Foreign Minister, is expected to announce his candidacy in a few weeks.
Both parties have prominent women who might run. Fianna Fail has a former Justice Minister, Maire Geoghegan-Quinn, and Mary O'Rourke, her party's expert on unemployment and education. Fine Gael has the present Justice Minister, Nora Owen, and a long shot, Frances Fitzgerald, a member of Parliament and former head of the National Women's Council.

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Administration Proposes Charging for Clearing Ice

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is causing alarm at ports on the Great Lakes by proposing to charge for clearing ice from shipping lanes.
The fee could raise $25 million a year, but the area's lawmakers are mobilizing to head it off in Congress. 
 "Despite the apparent short-term attractiveness of fee-for-service, the economic consequences of an ice-breaking fee would be widespread and severe," Representative James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, wrote in a letter he is planning to send to the Administration.
Various ports are clogged with ice from December into April. Mr. Oberstar said the fee would force shippers to move grain, coal and iron ore through other routes, "further undermining the regional economy."
But Lawrence Haas of the White House budget office called the proposed fee "prudent management."
The ice-breaking fee could add $45,000 to the cost of a single trip by a lake freighter, said Davis Helberg, the port director for Duluth, Minn.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Through the Wronger

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
"IT IS WRONG," I wrote in medium dudgeon (as opposed to high dudgeon, in which I would have written, "It is morally corrupt" -- a dudgen or dudgeon is an archaic word for a wood-handled dagger, and nobody knows how it came to mean "a fit of indignation," with its first citation in 1573), and what kind of tangent am I off on? Begin again.
"It is wrong to use tax-exempt money to support political activity," wrote the moralizing vituperator. "It is wronger for a lawyer paid by the people to use the claim of 'executive privilege.' " 
 "Say it ain't so!" writes Kenneth Palmer of Kannapolis, N.C. "Our search of the American Heritage Dictionary failed to turn up such a word. . . . One of us is wrong."
The question is: Should it be more wrong or wronger? In his "Syntactic Phenomena of English," which I carry around in my pocket, Prof. James McCawley of the University of Chicago department of linguistics writes that comparatives are formed with "long adjectives and adverbs generally demanding more and short ones demanding -er, subject to some exceptions such as more right and more wrong that are preferred to righter and wronger." Robert Burchfield's edition of Fowler's Modern English Usage agrees.
Gee. Even E. Ward Gilman, editor of Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage, who is no prescriptivist, holds that "although such writers as George Bernard Shaw used wronger, it is an infrequent use of the comparative of wrong." He has on file a New York Times headline from 1987 -- "Longer and Wronger" -- but that was apparently chosen because of the rhyme.
The Oxford English Dictionary offers me no succor; the only use of wronger is as a noun, "one who wrongs another," its first use in 1449 as "Defenders agens wrongers and diffamers of the . . . wickid world," now a self-description of the White House special counsel Lanny Davis.
I could claim that more wrong, to my ear, is not as strong a comparative as wronger, but as Richard Nixon never said, that would be wronger. I erred, Mr. Palmer, and would now rather be more right than President.
 
Covering Charlie
In the scandal some have given the dysphemistic headline "The Asian Connection" (based on the 1971 movie "The French Connection"), which other journalists slug "Lippogate" or "Indogate" (based on the Lippo Banking group in Indonesia), and which the most euphemistic call "the campaign fund-raising mess," one unfamiliar character keeps popping up: an entrepreneur in Little Rock whose Chinese restaurant was frequented by Gov. Bill Clinton.
His name is variously reported as Charlie Trie, Charles Yah Lin Trie and plain Yah Lin Trie. Reporters are uncomfortable with the nickname Charlie, as it seems to be an ethnic half-slur based on the title character in the Charlie Chan movie series of 1926 to 1944. Hence, the discordant Charles is fixed at the beginning of a Chinese name, which can't be right.
We may be reading a lot about Mr. Trie in coming months, because he was a big fund-raiser who took an arms dealer from Beijing into the White House to see Mr. Clinton at a "coffee" that some have suggested might have been related to campaign fund-raising. How to refer to Mr. Trie in first reference?
To solve this linguistic puzzle, I obtained a photocopy of a letter he wrote in Chinese to a prospective client or donor. The signature is in Chinese, and underneath its characters is the translation, presumably written by the man himself: "Yah Lin 'Charlie' Trie." He treats his English appellation as a nickname, not to be escalated to be a formal part of his name, and -- on the theory that a person is the best judge of his own name -- that's how to refer to him. Drop the Charles; infix Charlie.
 
Dissing Dysfunction
Hardly anybody says "I can't stand him" anymore. Nor do we hear "She makes my skin crawl" or "I despise him with every fiber of my being." Instead, the same feeling is expressed in the coolly clinical "We have a dysfunctional relationship."
When the pseudonymous Mom Kallikak goes off on a toot and Pop tries to get his clutches on the cleaning lady, and as Junior blames parental neglect and sibling ribaldry for his drug-cultural descent, molested Sis sells the story to a publisher as "the saga of a dysfunctional family."
The prefix dys- is always bad news. From Greek, Gothic, Old English, Indo-European, Sanskrit, any root you like -- a dys- is "bad, difficult, impaired," the opposite of the prefix eu-, which always provides a nice day. Doctors picked up dys- in 1916 and married it to function, and then sociologists and psychologists glommed onto it in a big way.
The dysfunctional family was a coinage of the psychiatric social worker Virginia M. Satir in her book "Conjoint Family Therapy" (1964). It became such a cliche that when Wendy Kaminer wanted to parody Thomas A. Harris's book "I'm O.K., You're O.K." (1967), she titled her book "I'm Dysfunctional, You're Dysfunctional" (1992).
Politics was next. John Broder, investigating the archaic modernization at the Internal Revenue Service, used the vogue word to describe many of the agency's computers.
And on NBC's "Meet the Press" last month, the District of Columbia's Mayor, Marion Barry, wedded the economist's 1932 structural unemployment to the dysfunctional family to come up with the reason D.C. government does not work: it is "structurally dysfunctional."
As Bert Lance might now say, "If it ain't dysfunctional, don't fix it."

HEADLINE: Communities And Police Strengthen Local Bonds

BYLINE: By RAMIN P. JALESHGARI 

 BODY:
ON Officer Brett Carlson's beat, there are no backroads of a poor neighborhood. There are no abandoned cars or graffiti-ridden walls. Officer Carlson patrols Strathmore Ridge, a standard, suburban condo complexwith six-to-eight unit dwellings, lawns, entrance gates and playgrounds.
Built in the 1960's, the community offered affordable dwellings for retirees and young families. But within the last few years it has provided something different: in this wooded section of Ridge, drug pushers and buyers operate under a cloak of near-invisibility. 
 Overrun by criminal activity, the residential area became a community of organized fear. Often, residents failed to notice drug deals until after they happened, so police responding to 911 calls arrived too late. Strathmore Ridge worsened, until Officer Carlson and his Sixth Police Precinct Community Oriented Police Enforcement unit stepped in.
The task force, called COPE in Suffolk County and Problem Oriented Policing in Nassau, is a method of law enforcement that takes officers out of cars and places them in long-term, one-on-one relationships with the local population. Rather than cruising the streets and answering 911 calls, COPE officers work with the public to research crimes or potential crimes and then apply extended intervention.
"COPE complements the daily activities of the various departments in a precinct and vice versa," said Capt. Robert Moore, former leader of the Sixth Precinct's two COPE units. "Sector cars are absolutely crucial to answer 911 calls, but, once the emergency has been alleviated, they move on; they respond rather than prevent. COPE units are able to spend time attacking crises in depth, trying to avert future problems."
COPE solutions might include regular patrols by car, foot or bike, educational seminars for residents, using plainclothes officers to observe a questionable location or organizing responses from other departments in the precinct like the narcotics or detective bureaus.
"Suffolk is one of the 50 largest police districts in the country," said Police Commissioner John Gallagher, "and the Island as a whole is one of the densest population areas in the state, outside of New York City. As such, we are in need of multiple strategy policing; that's why COPE is so necessary."
COPE was started under the Public Safety Partnership and Community Policing Act of 1994. The law provided money to put more officers on the nation's streets; stipulating they be in a community oriented capacity. Under two headings, COPS FAST for smaller areas and COPS AHEAD for larger, municipal precincts were given financing to hire more police officers. Within the Sixth Precinct, which covers the biggest section of Suffolk County -- from the Smithaven Mall to the Riverhead Town line and from the Long Island Rail Road tracks south of the expressway to Long Island Sound -- 65 officers were hired with $4.875of Federal funds. In 1995, with $1.875 million, 25 more officers were hired, and another 25 were hired in 1996 at the same amount. For 1997, 38 more officers have been requested.
In most precincts there are two units of COPE officers consisting of 10 or more individuals and operating day/night shifts. For Strathmore Ridge, the additional police manpower has made a difference.
"There were numerous disturbance calls through the front desk and 911 from Strathmore Ridge, but most responses didn't result in arrests," said Officer Carlson, who has been the main liaison for the homeowners in the development. "These crimes were drug-related and a drug deal is by its nature a fast transaction. Usually the exchange had already taken place before the sector car arrived. Because of these factors, and desperate requests from the residents, COPE stepped in and began preliminary canvassing of the area."
Their research showed that, during the 1980's, housing prices in Strathmore Ridge had, like all of Long Island, risen dramatically. Later, the early 1990's economic recession found homeowners paying high interest on high mortgages they could ill afford.
Many attempted to sell their homes, but could not earn back their expenditures. The result was that a number of owners rented their condos and sought cheaper dwellings elsewhere. Some homes were subject to foreclosure and others complete abandonment.
The surplus of available housing at Strathmore Ridge attracted the attention of the County Department of Social Services. Purchasing foreclosure properties outright or renting from absentee landlords, the agency placed clients, many of them homeless ex-convicts, into the complex.
"I lived in Strathmore Ridge for many years," said Doris Ann Brennan, vice president of the Strathmore Ridge Homeowners Association. "Up until the last few, I never felt that I couldn't go out alone. Then, between the strange cars coming in and out to buy drugs, the break-ins and vandalism, I became afraid to even walk my dog."
A Police Department survey indicated that criminal disturbance in Strathmore Ridge was disproportionately high -- increasing steadily from 1994 to 1996.
"The community became so desperate, we called the commander of the Sixth Precinct, Inspector Robillotto; he referred us to the COPE unit," said Chris Sosik, president of the Ridge Civic Association, "Brett came down and spoke to us. Together we formulated a plan where we worked with the police to take back our community."
The plan they put together initially included increased police pressure in the neighborhood, with foot and bicycle patrols into inaccessible woods and back lots. Plainclothes officers were stationed strategically to observe drug transactions and make arrests. The next step was educating residents.
"We sent officers to Ridge Civic Association meetings who helped organize neighborhood watches and taught crime prevention seminars," said Sgt. Tom Brady, team leader of COPE Unit 1. "On the more extreme side, we worked with the narcotics bureau to organize raids when necessary."
No aspect of the Strathmore Ridge cleanup was too small for the unit's attention. Officers advised residents on everything from obtaining fencing to proper lighting to removing trees and shrubs -- ideal covers for illicit activity. Within a year, children reappeared at the complex's playground.
"A year ago we would see drug paraphernalia all over the ground, related to everything from marijuana to crack cocaine." said John Polsunas, president of the Strathmore Ridge Homeowners Association. Mr. Polsunas has lived in the development since it first opened more than 20 years ago. "But, when COPE showed up, the drug culture went underground."
In Setauket, the precinct's COPE Unit 2 addressed a different kind of residential problem: trucks illegally making use of residential routes. "We got a complaint from a Setauket woman who said that commercial vehicles were using Upper Sheep Pasture as a short cut to Terminal Road -- an industrial area," said the team's sergeant, Mark Maieli.
"On the surface this seems like a simple traffic problem, but it was much more than that. Upper Sheep Pasture is a country road, very residential. Yards abut narrow streets and there are children everywhere."
More than 200 commercial vehicles were roaring through the area in a single day. The approved route for high load vehicles is twice as long and forces trucks to make use of the traffic-light laden Nesconset Highway (State Route 347.)
The Setauket woman, a mother of six, made initial complaints to the precinct. "Sector cars would arrive promptly," she said, "but not always during high traffic periods. Also, one ticket to one truck doesn't make a difference."
She finally called COPE for help. "The kids couldn't go out to play because of the noise and also because they were afraid," she said, "If a ball or toy flew into the street, the constant truck flow made it dangerous for them to retrieve it."
Determining the source of the problem was the first item on Sergeant Maieli's agenda. Following culprits to their location, he found they were loading and unloading materials at businesses on Terminal Road. The next step was to give business owners warnings.
"I approached business owners suggesting they put the word out on their CB's to the truckers that Upper Sheep Pasture was off-limits and we were going to start cracking down," said Sergeant Maieli. "It's a better use of police time and taxpayer money -- to put in an afternoon getting people to stop breaking the law rather than spending days enforcing it."
Within two days of the warnings, the sergeant and three patrol cars set up road blocks at each end of Upper Sheep Pasture. Only two trucks came through.
Sean Grennan, a criminal-justice professor at C. W. Post,. likes the idea of community-oriented policing but questions if it is being administered most effectively on Long Island.
"A lot of officers would like to see their COPE counterparts on the streets instead of attending civic meetings and doing school talks," said Dr. Grennan, a retired New York City homicide detective. "There's a disparity in the fact that the officers that residents see at special assemblies are not likely to be the ones that will answer their 911 calls."
"When I was on the force," said Dr. Grennan, "we created satellite stations in high-risk neighborhoods, from which a full team of officers operated. We had foot patrol, anticrime, narcotics and detective units. It was like a mini-police force, and people got to know and trust us because we were always there -- not because we came to conferences. They had the satisfaction of seeing us where they needed us most -- on the street."
Commissioner Gallagher said that he knew community oriented policing was not perfect but believed that most officers felt better about their job when they interact with the community on a positive level. He also pointed out that COPE officers do answer 911 calls when necessary and always respond to calls for back-up.
Additionally, every COPE unit in the county was taken off scheduled duties to respond to the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.
While there are no quantitative figures proving the effectiveness of COPE-type units, crime has decreased in Suffolk, a fact Commissioner Gallagher says is due in large part to the increased response that community-oriented policing makes possible. The Sixth Precinct, for example, achieved the highest number of driving under the influence arrests in the county -- second only to the highway patrol.
"I think this achievement has a lot to do with the precinct's COPE unit," said Commissioner Gallagher. "They have the luxury to study charts and trends of DWI accidents, their patterns, locations, etc., and then station themselves at critical sites -- all because they are not constantly answering 911 calls."
In Brentwood, a Third Precinct COPE Officer, Wanda Levista, works at solving local problems both during and after work. One of the few Spanish-speaking officers in her department, Officer Levista was assigned to COPE after her superiors noticed that, as a sector officer, she was constantly requested for back-up to calls involving Hispanic individuals.
"I was always answering domestic disturbances involving Hispanic people or asked to interview non-English speakers taken into custody after committing a crime," said Officer Levista, who has been on the force for nine years. "I still do some of that, but I also teach Spanish-speaking immigrants about their rights, counsel drug prevention and help residents understand that, unlike in some of their native countries, the police are not 'out to get them.' "
"Some of the Brentwood Hispanic population are illegal aliens and are fearful of the police," said Miriam Garcia, executive director of Adelante, a cultural/civic association that provides services from housing for the homeless to scholarships to health screenings for the Hispanic community. "Officer Levista has tried particularly hard to let them know that the police are not immigration officials."
Last Christmas, Officer Levista led a precinct-wide drive to raise funds for a needy family from St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Brentwood. Each officer donated $5, and $1,500 was raised.
"The COPE unit, and Officer Levista in particular, have been very good to us," said the Rev. Tom St. Pierre, co-pastor of St. Ann's. "Wanda comes to masses to talk to parishioners about special programs her unit is sponsoring." While off-duty, Officer Levista attends Brentwood Lions meetings -- she says it's another "in" into the community.
Community Oriented Policing runs in the Levista family. Her husband, Tony, is a COPE officer with the First Precinct, which includes the higher crime areas of Wyandanch and North Amityville. He patrols residential neighborhoods in Babylon with his partner, Vincent Callahan. There, the two officers are involved in preventing robberies and attempting to close down a local crack house.
"People are much more responsive to me as a COPE officer than when I was in a sector car," Officer Tony Levista said. "There's more trust there because I'm usually not dealing with them in a high-stress environment when things aren't going well. Now, I don't have to rush off and do other things so I can take time to speak with them on human basis. I think they really appreciate that."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Gilt-Edged Hotel for Investors And Guests

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRUSH 

 BODY:
FOR $490 before tax, you can spend a night in the least expensive double room at the Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan. Pretty pricey, true, but you can get your suit pressed in one hour, sleep on a custom-made mattress and enjoy countless other luxuries. After all, this is the Four Seasons, rivaled for poshness only by the Ritz-Carlton and maybe a few other chains. At some of its resorts, sun-baking guests can even get a personal water spritzing once an hour.
But now that the Four Seasons company, based in Toronto, is selling its stock here -- it was listed on the Big Board last month -- you might want to spend that $490 on the 19 or so shares you would get at Friday's closing price of $25.25. While the company would suffer in an economic downturn, just as other peddlers of luxury would do, the shares look very attractive. But be aware of one thing: like the hotelier's rooms, the equity is far from cheap. 
 Four Seasons Hotels has come a long way. Like a lot of real estate companies in the early 1990's, it was burdened by high debt and occasional losses. (It also used some clever accounting techniques that put its performance in the best possible light.) But over the last three years, it has sold off its stake in properties in London; Toronto; Santa Barbara, Calif., and elsewhere, and turned itself into a relatively debt-free manager of properties owned by others.
To be sure, Four Seasons still holds minority interests in many of the hotels it runs. But the new emphasis on management means the company will most likely enjoy a better and more steady return on its investments, analysts say.
"They have gone from being a company with a huge amount of capital earning low returns to a company with a fraction of that capital earning high returns," said Joe Little, a portfolio manager for Duncan Ross Associates, which owns Four Seasons shares and is based in Vancouver, British Columbia. "And that is what the company will look like going forward."
THE company's well-known name is also an asset, and not just because it translates into above-average occupancy and room rates. The brand name helps the firm negotiate favorable long-term management contracts, said Neil Barsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, which helped underwrite Four Seasons in its United States offering. While the typical hotel management contract lasts 5 to 10 years, the average Four Seasons deal runs for 50 years, he said.
(Under its agreements, Four Seasons normally gets about 3 percent of gross revenue and in some cases an "incentive fee" of 5 percent to 20 percent of operating profits.)
The industry's prospects are bright, too. Luxury hotel bookings are up because of solid economic growth. What's more, many aging baby boomers are choosing better lodging, and a trend toward shorter vacations means that people are willing to spend more per night on accommodations.
On the supply side, few new luxury hotels are going up in the United States because it costs at least 30 percent more to build them than to buy them. Stephen Rushmore of HVS International, a consulting firm in Mineola, L.I., said that while luxury hotels will soon open in Asia and the Middle East, it will be several years before new ones open here. That means "a good long run for five-star hotels" now in operation, he said.
This demand-supply imbalance allowed luxury hotels here to increase room rates by 7 percent in 1996, said Frank Nardozza, the director for the national hospitality industry at KPMG Peat Marwick. He expects domestic rates to rise by at least 5 percent to 7 percent annually over the next two years. "In places like London, Paris, Hong Kong and other gateway destinations, there have been double-digit growth rates," he added.
If Four Seasons has its way, however, its earnings growth will not depend only on these economic conditions. The company, which now owns or manages 39 properties, has an ambitious plan to take on three to five new management contracts annually over the next several years. Because the company is small -- 1996 revenues were just $121 million -- each new contract may have a big impact on earnings, Mr. Barsky said.
In 1997, for example, Four Seasons will bring its version of luxury to Atlanta; Goa, India; Paris (the Hotel George V), and Bali. In 1998 it will start managing hotels or resorts in Cairo; Caracas, Venezuela; Las Vegas, Nev., and Scottsdale, Ariz.
"Within two years, George V and the Four Seasons Las Vegas alone will generate $7 million a year in management fees," Mr. Little said.
Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, who bought a 25 percent stake in the company in 1994 when it was on the ropes, has been solidly behind the company's expansion plan. Using his own funds, Prince Walid often provides a good chunk of the money needed to either buy or build a luxury hotel, attracting other investors, and then usually arranging for Four Seasons to manage the property. Prince Walid has a stake in properties to be run by Four Seasons in Cairo and Scottsdale, for example, and he owns outright the George V.
Unfortunately, many Wall Streeters agree that Four Seasons is strong, a belief that is reflected in its stock price. Since the start of last year, for example, the Canadian shares are up 90 percent. And at Friday's close, the new American stock was trading at 20 times next year's estimated earnings, at the upper end of the 15 percent to 20 percent by which many analysts believe the company's annual earnings will grow. (The Canadian and American stocks are not exchangeable, although both are of the same class of common share.)
Although some fans of the Four Seasons think its famed name should add a premium to its stock, many investors believe that shares are fully valued when they trade at multiples that are at or above their earnings-growth rates.
"I might be accumulating at this price, but I would not be aggressively picking up the stock," said Barbara Belch, a portfolio manager at Laketon Investment Management in Edmonton, Alberta. Ms. Belch is one of the analysts who believes that earnings may grow at 15 percent to 20 percent a year.
Moreover, three important management contracts are up for renewal within the next several years -- in Hong Kong; Taipei, Taiwan, and Bangkok, Thailand. No one is suggesting that Four Seasons will lose them, but the expirations point up a broader danger in the company's new role as manager: If a hotel's owners don't get the results they want from Four Seasons -- if its lavish approach, say, just is not working -- they may jettison the company. Management contracts often have cancellation clauses that take effect when business is bad.
And just as the hotelier's small size means that one new management contract may greatly improve earnings, one lost contract can similarly hurt earnings.
Also, an economic downturn would certainly cut into bookings at luxury hotels. While Four Seasons is diversified, with properties in 16 countries, any sharp regional decline would reduce its earnings.
And keep in mind that, while Four Seasons Hotels rolls out the red carpet for guests, it may be less hospitable to activist shareholders: Isadore Sharp, the company's chairman and co-founder, has locked up 67 percent of the voting power in his 15 percent of the company's shares.
 
Want Your Daiquiris Really Fresh?
How do high-end hotels, like the Four Seasons, try to lure you into the lap of luxury? Here is a sampling of their sometimes-odd efforts:

* Hotel Inter-Continental, London. The master bed of the Royal Suite can accommodate 13 people.
 
* Ritz-Carlton, Cancun, Mexico. It offers 120 varieties of tequila, served by a staff that takes a weeklong course in the liquor.
 
* Victoria Jungfrau Grand Hotel, Interlaken, Switzerland. Guests have free use of a Jaguar, BMW or Range Rover for a day.
 
* Ritz-Carlton, St. Thomas, V.I. Daiquiris are made from mangoes and bananas plucked from the hotel's trees shortly before preparation.
 
* Hyatt Regency Cerromar, Dorado, P.R. At 1,776 feet -- 526 feet longer than the Empire State Building is high -- its freshwater swimming pool is the world's longest.
 
* Millenium Hilton, New York. It not only has one of the city's few hotel indoor swimming pools, but its locker room offers guests a "suitmate" machine that dries swimsuits in seven seconds.

An article on March 16 about investing in Four Seasons Hotels misstated the number of hotels managed by the company worldwide. It is 38, not 39. The article also misstated the role of Isadore Sharp, the company's chairman,in starting the company. He was the founder, not a co-founder.

HEADLINE: Peer Pressure

BYLINE: By Steven R. Weisman; Steven R. Weisman, who writes editorials for The New York Times, was the paper's Tokyo bureau chief from 1989 to 1992.

 BODY:

Inside the Kaisha
 Demystifying Japanese Business Behavior.
 By Noboru Yoshimura and Philip Anderson.
 288 pp. Boston:
 Harvard Business School Press. $24.95.
 
 An Empire of Schools
 Japan's Universities and the Molding
 of a National Power Elite.
 By Robert L. Cutts.
 268 pp. Armonk, N.Y.:
 An East Gate Book/M. E. Sharpe. $29.95. 
 Like their counterparts across the corporate landscape of Japan, the hard-working employees of Shiseido, the nation's biggest cosmetics company, live in a world of slogans. Shiseido's motto is "For beautiful human life." Seminars for middle managers focus on topics like "Body and Soul" and "Beauty and Truth." These catch phrases may perplex the outsider, but according to the authors of "Inside the Kaisha" they are actually a method of enforcing strict standards of performance. When combined with other subtle forms of coercion, they convey the message that employees will be ostracized if they fail to devote themselves to the good of the corporation.
Though the Japanese economy is no longer riding as high as a few years ago, American companies continue to be fascinated by the success of the Japanese corporation, or kaisha, in achieving team spirit. Noboru Yoshimura, a vice president of Bankers Trust, Tokyo, and Philip Anderson, who teaches at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth, provide a healthy antidote to much of the mumbo jumbo about Japanese business practices perpetrated by journalists, businesspeople and management consultants. Basing their findings on hundreds of hours of interviews with Japanese middle managers, they argue that the Japanese company is hardly a place of harmony, egalitarianism, farsighted leadership and benevolent concern for workers. Rather, it abounds with social control, internal conflicts, shortsighted thinking, rigid and dominating hierarchies and exploited labor.
"Inside the Kaisha" is intended mainly as a guide for Americans working for or negotiating with a Japanese company. Its writing is dry and bloodless, but it has a certain understated passion reflecting the authors' awareness that they are demolishing stereotypes.
Both "Inside the Kaisha" and "An Empire of Schools," by Robert L. Cutts, which deals with the leading Japanese institution of higher learning, the University of Tokyo, are part of what has come to be called the revisionist school of Japanese studies. Until the last decade or so, books about contemporary Japanese society tended to stress its egalitarian and democratic aspects. Now the emphasis is more on Japan's unstated system of social engineering and elitism.
Mr. Yoshimura and Mr. Anderson focus on Japan's legendary "salaryman" system, and their portrait will be familiar to students of Japan. But they take it further than most other commentators, describing how the fear of embarrassment and letting down the group inspires hard work even as it stifles innovation and initiative. They also challenge the widely accepted notion that the Japanese regard themselves as happy and productive.
Most everyone knows, for example, that the Japanese work long hours and attend corporate outings on weekends. "Does this reflect the fabled company loyalty of the Japanese worker?" Mr. Yoshimura and Mr. Anderson ask. "Hardly; although such activities are formally voluntary, everyone knows that failure to participate is socially unacceptable. Only a complete idiot would make such a blunder. . . . Deviation from the appropriate model is accompanied by penalties that most Japanese are unwilling to endure." It is anxiety that compels employees to work even when sick, or during a child's graduation. Many American companies have tried to borrow the notion of team spirit from Japan without realizing the system of social controls at work underneath the surface.
Another insight that may surprise readers is that Japanese workers would rather conform to accepted procedures than achieve a favorable outcome. This trait has been remarked on before, most notably by historians of World War II, who found that the Japanese military continued to make the same mistake over and over again rather than deviate from accepted strategies. Too much can be made of the point, of course. The Japanese have adjusted brilliantly to crises, as they did during the oil shocks of the 1970's. But to a remarkable extent, many Japanese companies today prefer to continue in their niches than to beat the competition by trying something new.
Still another cliche blasted by Mr. Anderson and Mr. Yoshimura is that Japanese businesses pursue long-term investment strategies, not the short-term quarterly profits demanded by shareholders in the United States. When the Japanese economy was booming, this notion was the accepted wisdom. In fact, the authors point out, Japanese companies would not be in so much trouble in this current downturn if they had been more careful about speculating during the real-estate and stock-market booms of the 1980's.
If there is one institution that instills the spirit of social pressure outlined by "Inside the Kaisha," it is the University of Tokyo. As described by Mr. Cutts, a freelance journalist who writes frequently on Asia, the school is an "ivory basement," a place of little intellectual inquiry, and it is driving the entire country to ruin. It suffers from an ossified faculty structure and from students who arrive exhausted after their grueling studies in high school. "The system of higher education is going increasingly awry," Mr. Cutts says. "It is failing in providing society with the enlightenment, knowledge and energy it will need to meet internal and external hazards that loom."
Much of "An Empire of Schools" is written in that sort of overheated style, and Mr. Cutts has a habit of making sweeping generalizations without backing them up with evidence. Moreover, his descriptions of the university are drawn almost entirely from secondary sources: nowhere is there much of a feel of what it is like to be at the school or even to wander through its buildings and talk with its students and teachers. Without any kind of personal leavening, "An Empire of Schools" comes across as a diatribe reinforcing the stereotype of the Japanese as soulless automatons. Mr. Yoshimura and Mr. Anderson offer a far more persuasive picture of a people caught up in a system that has brought them success -- and a lot of problems to go with it.
With the Kunsthaus on Lake Lucerne being replaced by a new Culture and Congress Center and Hotel Schweizerhof Hall undergoing reconstruction, many concerts, under the theme "Nostalgia, a Retrospective," are taking place in the Von Moos Steel Hall in nearby Emmenbrucke. Schubert's complete piano sonatas will be played by Andras Schiff, and the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter devotes an Aug. 27 recital to Brahms. On Aug. 25, the tenor and conductor Peter Schreier sings Schubert's "Schwanen gesang," and on Aug. 27 he conducts the C. P. E. Bach Orchestra of Berlin and the Lucerne Festival Chorus in Schubert's Mass No. 5 in A flat major.
Celebrating his 80th year on Aug. 31, Rudolf Baumgartner conducts the Lucerne Festival Strings in works by Vivaldi, Penderecki and Bruckner, then adds Bach's "Musikalisches Opfer" and Violin Concerto in A Minor on Sept. 6. The London Mozart Players and the soprano Edith Mathis offer serenades at the Lions Monument, and Mendelssohn is remembered with his "Midsummer Night's Dream" Suite and Fourth Symphony, "Italian," on Aug. 31, in a performance by the Berlin Philharmonic and the Slovakian Philharmonic Chorus, conducted by Claudio Abbado.
On Aug. 23, a study of works by the composer-in-residence Wolfgang Rihm includes the premiere of his chamber opera "Jakob Lenz," and on Sept. 6 the Arditti Quartet offers an all-Rihm program.
Charles Dutoit conducts the Montreal Symphony in Debussy's "Images" and Ravel's "Bolero," and Martha Argerich plays Liszt's Second Piano Concerto. The nostalgia theme is prevalent in works by the American composers Roy Harris, Samuel Barber and George Gershwin with Andrew Litton conducting the Dallas Symphony.
Carlo Maria Giulini closes the festival, leading the Vienna Philharmonic in Schubert's Fourth Symphony and Brahms's Second Symphony.
Tickets: $14 to $122.
Box Office: International Festival of Music Lucerne, P. O. Box 3842, CH-6002 Lucerne, Switzerland; fax 41-210 94 64.
 
Turkey
 
Istanbul International Festival
June 15 to July 8
For centuries Istanbul has been a bridge between Europe and Asia, and its 25th festival presents four Turkish premieres of European works.
On July 1 the BBC Symphony and Chorus under Leonard Slatkin play Elgar's "Dream of Gerontius" and on July 2 Walton's "Belshazzar's Feast," both for the first time in Turkey. Marking the 125th birthday of the English composer Ralph Vaughan Williams, Mr. Slatkin offers "The Lark Ascending" along with Britten's Sinfonia da Requiem and Second Symphony on July 3.
The third Turkish premiere, "A Venetian Coronation" by the 16th-century Italian composer Giovanni Gabrieli, takes place on June 25, and the fourth premiere, "Mass With Instrumental Music" by the 16th-century Spanish composer Cristobal de Morales, is heard on June 26. Both are played by the Gabrieli Consort and Players, directed by Paul McCreesh.
Wolfgang Sawallisch conducts the Royal Concertgebouw in Brahms's Fourth Symphony and Richard Strauss's "Don Quixote" on June 19 and Hindemith's Symphonic Metamorphoses, Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto, with Frank Peter Zimmermann as soloist, and Beethoven's Seventh Symphony on June 20. The four hands of Katia and Marielle Labeque perform Mozart's Piano Sonata in F major and the Debussy nocturnes "Nuages" and "Fetes" on June 25. Peter Schreier leads the Academica Salzburg with Alexander Janiczek, violinist, and Till Fellner, pianist, in two all-Schubert concerts on June 17 and 18.
More Schubert and Brahms is played by the Allegri String Quartet, with James Champbell as soloist in Schubert's Arpeggione for Clarinet and String Quartet and Brahms's Clarinet Quintet in B minor on June 23, and the Accademia Bizantina offers a mixture of early music, Vivaldi, Biagio Marini and Handel, with the contemporary composer Luciano Berio's "Sequenze VIII for Violin," with Francesco D'Orazio, soloist, on June 20.
The Chamber Orchestra of the Kremlin plays Rossini, Stravinsky, Stamitz and Tchaikovsky, and the violinist Gidon Kremer performs "Le Grand Tango -- Homage to Piazzola."
The King's Singers combine works by Purcell and the 15th-century Flemish composer Adrian Willaert with those by the contemporary Gyorgy Ligeti, including "Two Dreams and Little Bat," "A Long, Sad Tale" and "The Lobster Quadrille."
Tickets: $15 to $60.
