HEADLINE: Rate Cut Questions

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has offered a set of bold changes that he says will lead to deep reductions in New Yorkers' electric bills, which are the highest in the continental United States.
But consumer advocates and industry analysts contend that, while large businesses may see deep cuts in their electric rates, most residential customers are unlikely to see significant savings for many years. And even if the administration achieves all the savings it has outlined, the price that New Yorkers pay to turn on their lights will remain far above the national average. 
 "Getting 10 percent across-the-board reductions, in my view, is extremely unlikely," said Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council who is closely following the overhaul of the industry. "People are confusing competition with lowering rates, and they're two different things."
State officials base their hopes for lower rates on three major initiatives: First, they plan to simply order utilities to cut costs and drop prices over the next five years. Second, they want to help utilities borrow billions of dollars at low interest rates to refinance old debts and buy out over-priced energy contracts, passing on the savings to consumers. And third, they intend to replace the current system of utility monopolies with competition, believing that will lead to lower prices.
That combination, administration officials say, should lower residential rates 10 percent or more.
But many independent experts said the same factors that led to today's high electric rates will continue to hinder efforts to lower them. And it appears likely that, due to market factors and proposed state policies, any savings will largely benefit big commercial customers rather than residential users.
"There are a lot of reasons to doubt whether this wonderful new market we're supposed to be getting will actually save ordinary New Yorkers much money," said Susan Weinstock, who analyzes state policies for the American Association of Retired Persons, in Washington.
A milestone in the Governor's plan to overhaul the electric industry was reached Thursday, as the staff of the state's Public Service Commission and Consolidated Edison agreed on a restructuring of the giant utility. The pact, expected to set the tone for a revamping of all seven of the state's power companies, would break Con Edison into separate power generating, retailing and distribution companies, under a single holding company, and would require the distribution arm to deliver electricity sold by competing companies.
The accord would also lower electric rates for manufacturers by 25 percent over five years, by 10 percent for other large commercial users like hospitals or department stores, and 3.3 percent for residences and small businesses. Commission officials said they planned to apply the same formula statewide, which has brought loud protests from consumer groups, and from Democrats in state government.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said the Governor had not taken a position on the pact, which must still be voted on by the commission. Further, she said, complaining about the amount of savings missed the larger point.
"This is the first time that there is a reversal, cutting rates, not increasing rates," she said. "At least this Governor has taken an interest in the process, instead of the historical trend of just letting them keep raising rates. This may not be enough, but at least it's a first step."
Business executives insist that favoring industry is a matter of economic survival, because employers are lured from New York to states with cheap power. And even if the savings in the Con Edison deal were spread evenly, they would average only about 5 percent, analysts say.
Nationally, several states are giving consumers freedom to choose among several power retailers, much as they do with long distance telephone companies. New York plans to introduce competition gradually over the next five years. But consumer advocates warn that once competition begins, the electric companies will see big commercial users like hospitals and factories as more desirable than residences, so large consumers will get the lowest rates.
While retailers in the future will be able to buy more cheap power from out of state, there is limited line capacity to carry it into New York City and Long Island. About one-third of the power used in New York City and on Long Island will still be produced locally, at relatively high cost.
New Yorkers would seem to have much to gain from restructuring the electric industry. The average price for electricity nationwide is 6.9 cents per kilowatt/hour, but in New York State it is 10.7 cents, and it is far higher in the metropolitan area.
In the 1970's and 80's, the state ordered New York's utilities to enter into decades-long contracts to buy power from in-state generators -- from major gas-fired plants to Mom-and-Pop dams -- often at above-market rates.
New York utilities pay $1.4 billion a year more for that power than they would if they bought it on the open market, the state estimates. They can either continue to overpay, or they can buy out the overpriced contracts, at a price the Public Service Commission estimates at $10.6 billion. Either way, consumers will foot the bill for years.
Utilities also have heavy debts from construction projects, often undertaken at the state's urging, like the never-used Shoreham nuclear plant. All told, the utilities estimate that they have more than $20 billion in obligations, like the overpriced power contracts and old debts, that they would be unable to recover in a purely competitive market.
The agreement with Con Edison lets the company recover 90 to 100 percent of such costs from its customers. Some consumer advocates and Democratic officials, like Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, say that the power companies and their shareholders must absorb a larger share of the expenses. But it is not clear whether they have the clout to take control of the restructuring.
Mr. Pataki's plan for dealing with those expenses is to help utilities borrow money through the sale of bonds at low interest rates, to refinance old debts and buy out overpriced power contracts. The low interest payments would save money, which administration officials said would be passed on to residents and small businesses as lower rates.
The new debts would be repaid over as much as 30 years through charges assessed on all customers.
While some administration officials say the bond sales could lower residential rates by 10 percent, securities industry analysts say the true figure is closer to 5 percent.

HEADLINE: Culture and Irony

BYLINE: By James R. Kincaid; James R. Kincaid is the Aerol Arnold Professor of English at the University of Southern California. His most recent books are "Annoying the Victorians" and the forthcoming "Manufacturing Virtue: The Culture of Child Molesting."

 BODY:

A LIFE OF
 MATTHEW ARNOLD
 By Nicholas Murray.
 Illustrated. 400 pp. New York:
 A Thomas Dunne Book/
 St. Martin's Press. $27.95. 
 Imagine Matthew Arnold emerging from one of the most strenuously upright homes in England, presided over by the Earnestness King (Thomas Arnold of Rugby), and becoming a Victorian Groucho Marx/Jacques Derrida. Imagine what it would take to persuade us that this is what happened. Well, "A Life of Matthew Arnold," by Nicholas Murray, isn't quite set on doing that -- I am -- but does certainly give us the finest picture yet of Arnold as a playful and poised ironist, against-the-grain social critic, mocker of the knowing and the smug. Even more important, he gives us Arnold as a quick-fingered unraveler of deep-woven cultural patterns, as deft as any of today's politicized deconstructionists -- and much funnier.
That we've not exactly been longing for such a make-over of Arnold is true. His status as major, ignored poet seems secure, and we've been satisfied boxing him into simple categories: "a sort of easy shorthand," Mr. Murray points out, for what the drearily moralizing academic left loves to drone against -- cultural elitism, remote estheticism, the status quo -- while the even drearier cultural right welcomes this same version of him into their virtue club. But Mr. Murray's Arnold hops free of these nets, stealthily peddling his idea of "culture" as an agile and open habit of mind, a way of being in the world rather than a static view that comes with a set of oppressive nostrums laid on to enforce that view. Culture was, for Arnold, a tactic, an active agency that worked by being fast on its feet, resistant to self-congratulations, subversive of our sustaining (and damaging) myths.
Arnold's voice is familiar to us, though we find ways to evade its radical power, the truly revolutionary force of his ironic method. His battle against "machinery," the steady grinding of habitual social and intellectual engines, was carried on as if little were at stake, precisely because everything was at stake. He always felt, for instance, that Protestant zeal, laudable as it was in some ways, carried with it a fanatical narrowness so self-satisfied and inflexible as to starve the soul it meant to feed, and it bored us to death too: "Notwithstanding the mighty results of the Pilgrim Fathers' voyage," he wrote about the settling of New England, "they and their standard of perfection are rightly judged when we figure to ourselves Shakespeare or Virgil -- souls in whom sweetness and light, and all that in human nature is most humane, were eminent -- accompanying them on their voyage, and think what intolerable company Shakespeare and Virgil would have found them!" Against the moral power of our founders and the pride we can (and do) take in their sea-to-shining-sea success, Arnold asks us to think of being stuck next to one of these pious mountains at dinner, many dinners.
Puritan virtue was by no means a safe target then (or now), but it was even riskier to mock the fetish of personal freedom, a freedom worshiped especially by those jealous of their right to be sublimely stupid and, when they liked, to carry that stupidity into action. To suggest that the determination to speak one's mind does not always secure for us the free play of the finest ideas, Arnold opens his pages to some wonderful roarers -- a Mr. Murphy, for instance, exercising his rights in some Birmingham lectures devoted to the designs he suspects the Roman Catholic Church of having on Mrs. Murphy: "If mayors and magistrates do not care for their wives and daughters, he does. But, above all, he is doing as he likes; or, in worthier language, asserting his personal liberty. 'I will carry out my lectures if they walk over my body as a dead corpse. . . .' Touching and beautiful words, which find a sympathetic chord in every British bosom!"
This is Arnold at his best, sure to be caricatured by people unwilling to develop the elasticity he asks for and employs. Mr. Murray, a poet in Wales, is especially fine at showing how Arnold has been reduced to a few misunderstood phrases, phrases like "getting to know . . . the best which has been thought and said in the world." Arnold often fired this slogan at the British philistine's steady, dimwitted devotion to a supply of "stock notions and habits." His emphasis, however, was never on a static "best" but on the process, the "getting." It was a mental activity, quick and skeptical, that he wanted to nourish. Even his famous touchstones -- examples of terrific writing employed to remind oneself of how awful writing usually is -- were not litmus tests but referents one would use to escape vulgar insularity, along with the brute knowingness that supported it.
Mr. Murray is, of course (though you wouldn't know it from what I've said so far), giving us the story of a life, in this case of a man scratching for some money and some time to write in the midst of a hectic (if deliriously happy) domestic scene and a voraciously demanding (and not deliriously happy) career as an Inspector of Schools. The Arnold here is also a surprisingly consistent, harmonious man, delighting as much in mocking himself as in taking after the British philistine. Mr. Murray clearly feels as much affection for his subject as Arnold did for so many of those around him, even his father, a dragon Mr. Murray manages to domesticate. The severe Thomas Arnold was also a romping, high-spirited man, permeated with right thinking, surely, but also with fun and with a soft, easy love for the son he called "my own Crabby."
Crabby's triumphant social career at school (and his entirely mediocre academic one), his dandyism and love of parties, fishing and good times were, Mr. Murray shows, something other than a pose, though they certainly took everyone in. This biography convinces us that Arnold really was that amiable, that able to swim in his own stream. Mr. Murray does get a little distracted by what Cecil Y. Lang, editor of the new and impressive first volume of "The Letters of Matthew Arnold" (University Press of Virginia, $60), calls "the Marguerite cottage industry." "Marguerite" is the subject of a series of poems so fascinating that a fair number of scholars, finding themselves sucked into a tabloid mentality, have gone in search of the real Marguerite, of whom we know, Mr. Murray candidly admits, "little" -- make that "nothing at all." Arnold later said bluntly there was no such person, and the evidence for her existence is so slim even the prosecutors of Mr. Pickwick wouldn't have used it. But it's the absence of any reason to suppose Marguerite existed that makes such a supposition irresistible, I suppose, and it's a minor weakness in an otherwise poised and witty biography, one so soaked in Arnoldian virtues of balance and liberality it sometimes seems deliberately to grant too much to Arnold's critics simply to keep our view from closing tight around admiration.
All the same, this is an admirable man, one who, irony restored, is far more dynamic and modern than those who criticize him for sponsoring a retrograde humanism. Arnold's generosity and ability to double back on himself are stunning and should work as rebukes to our own complacency. Here's one in- stance, a series of references to the philosopher and social reformer Margaret Fuller, whose work he had purchased because it was cheap, she was pretty and he had heard she was "brazen," a quality he had always found attractive. At first, the ignorant hokum she spouted repelled him, but he soon began reading through what he called "the screen" of the book to "her exquisite intelligence," marveling that she could develop it in a Boston "where everybody knows that the earth is an oblate spheroid and nobody knows anything worth knowing." A few months later he was reading her again and with a heart even more open, "greatly struck with her sincere striving to be good and helpful," especially in "her address to the poor women in the penitentiary."
Arnold's attraction to such feeling for "poor women in the penitentiary" reminds us of that side of him we have most shamefully occluded in our desire to use him to our own ends. Arnold was a lifelong liberal, so liberal that he gave great pain to the Liberal Party by his egalitarian and powerful ironies. His 35 years as Inspector of Schools were spent in close contact with the teachers and children, often poor children in nonconformist schools, and in very edgy contact with his superiors. He risked his career and sacrificed all chance of promotion by vigorously championing mandatory and free public education. He opposed the payment-by-results schemes for financing the schools on the grounds that they penalized the poor, and he did all he could to support teachers and teachers' unions, admiring a profession he said did more and worthier work than he, and for less pay.
But it was the poor children who most caught his sympathies. Some of his most telling social criticism works by juxtaposing aloof blather against the material lives of working-class children. For example, he reproduces, deadpan, Mr. Robert Buchanan's enthusiasm for God's population plans -- "There are never enough. Life, life, life. . . . The whole earth breeds, and God glories" -- and allows it to join hands with The Times of London's "finest economical doctrine" (which "I always carry . . . about with me"), to the effect that poverty is part of the simple and inexorable supply-and-demand law. He then confronts us with a picture of the East End London children he knew so very well, "children eaten up with disease, half-sized, half-fed, half-clothed, neglected by their parents, without health, without home, without hope."
Arnold died in 1888 at the age of 65. At his funeral, resting amid all the formal tributes from dignitaries was a small wreath that Mr. Murray rightly calls "the most moving tribute": "From St. Stephen's School, Westminster, where Matthew Arnold's annual presence, genial, kindly, encouraging, discriminating in sympathy, was welcomed as sunshine in the monotony of school life."
Arnold brought to all his countrymen an ironic sunshine meant to penetrate a self-satisfied reliance on instinct and tradition that was often not less vicious for being silly. Take, for instance, Sir Charles Adderley in a speech to the Warwickshire farmers -- "Talk of the improvement of breed! Why, the race we ourselves represent, the men and women, the old Anglo-Saxon race, are the best breed in the whole world" -- and Mr. Roebuck to the Sheffield cutlers: "I look about me and ask what is the state of England? Is not property safe? Is not every man able to say what he likes? Can you not walk from one end of England to the other in perfect security? I ask you whether, the world over or in past history, there is anything like it? Nothing."
Against this Arnold reprints a paragraph he stumbled on in a newspaper "immediately after reading Mr. Roebuck": "A shocking child murder has just been committed at Nottingham. A girl named Wragg left the workhouse there on Saturday morning with her young illegitimate child. The child was soon afterwards found dead on Mapperly Hills, having been strangled. Wragg is in custody."
Arnold proceeds by throwing platitudes and images together: "our old Anglo-Saxon breed," "Wragg!," "our unrivaled happiness," "the strangled illegitimate child." To "defiant songs of triumph," he says, the alert soul will murmur under his breath, "Wragg is in custody." Why? "There is profit for the spirit in such contrasts," in "eluding sterile conflict, by refusing to remain in the sphere where alone narrow and relative conceptions have any worth and validity."
Mr. Murray's biography gives us new access to this spirit and to Arnold's lifelong attempt to move us to other spheres, to teach us, even through his melancholy poetry, that sweetness and light are not sterile elitist attitudes but tools for confronting cheap contentment, heedlessness and bigotry. In offering us ironies as challenging as they are rich, Arnold took the risk that we might refuse his gifts. And we have: Wragg is in custody.

HEADLINE: To Find Favorable Farm Climate, a World Map on the Web

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Researchers have developed a database encompassing decades of information on water, temperature and climate for every square mile of land on Earth, a tool that could benefit farmers, scientists and policymakers worldwide.
Establishment of the database, the World Water and Climate Atlas for Agriculture, was announced today by scientists at the International Irrigation Management Institute and Utah State University. 
 Users of the atlas, which will be available on CD-ROM and free of charge on a Utah State Internet, will be able to extract moisture and temperature data for an area as small as one square mile. The first segment, covering Asia, is to be available by June, the entire database by the end of the year.
"This is a unique resource that should benefit agriculture everywhere," Dr. David Seckler, director of the institute, said.
The institute, a research center based in Colombo, Sri Lanka, is one of 16 centers supported by the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research, an association of nations and private organizations fostering food and crop science.
Members include the World Bank and the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations. The project, which researchers estimate will cost less than $1 million, is being financed by the Japanese Government.
"The atlas integrates the available agricultural climate data into one computer program and represents the most comprehensive, quality-controlled climatic data set in existence," said Ismail Serageldin, chairman of the international group.
Donald T. Jensen, director of the Utah Climate Center at Utah State, said he and Andy Keller of the irrigation institute developed the atlas from data received from 56,000 weather stations around the world. The information, covering 1961 to 1990, came from combining data gathered by the United States, Canada, United Nations organizations and military sources worldwide.
The atlas includes 10-day, monthly and annual summaries of average, maximum and minimum temperatures, rainfall and other forms of moisture, and precipitation probabilities. It also includes data on evaporation, which is compared to precipitation figures to estimate moisture availability for crops and to help locate areas needing irrigation.
"The information in this database is a vast improvement over what we've had before," Dr. Seckler said, "It will make us a little smarter in how we use water, especially as it becomes scarcer in the future."
Dr. Seckler said 70 percent of all water used each year goes for irrigation, which produces between 30 to 40 percent of the world's food on just 17 percent of all arable land.
Using this information, the scientists said, engineers can develop better plans for irrigation and water conservation. In addition, agronomists should be able to identify areas where new types of crops might be introduced.
The scientists said the database is designed to be expanded. So far it contains no information from weather and sensing satellites in space, which could add data on seasonal crop growth, among other things.
The Food and Agricultural Organization has drawn a map of the soils of the world, Dr. Seckler said, and this information will be combined with the water atlas to help determine the best conditions for particular crops.

HEADLINE: Squaring Off Over Future Of Coliseum

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The latest effort to redevelop Columbus Circle, a morsel of land as valuable as it is star-crossed, is running into some of the same civic turbulence that doomed its forebears. Officials, developers, advocacy groups -- all are again warning that the attempt to revitalize this scorned crossroads is in danger of repeating the missteps of the past.
The effort is entering a crucial stage because the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will soon choose three or four finalists in the search for a developer to construct a building to replace the dowdy New York Coliseum, the circle's most prominent structure. 
 Though the authority may eventually settle on a winner without altering the process, if people vehemently object to the proposal that is selected, they might sue, a strategy that tied up earlier Coliseum projects.
In fact, the Municipal Art Society of New York, an advocacy group that was instrumental in using the courts to help defeat the last Coliseum project, said last week that it had become so disappointed with the selection process that it had asked Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to revamp it.
The two officials declined to do so, and the society said it would sue again if it opposed the final plan for the Coliseum site, which will not be announced for several months.
The society and other critics complain that the neither the M.T.A. nor any other government agency has put together a master plan for Columbus Circle that takes a broad view of what is needed to create a glorious public space.
They note that at least six government agencies are planning work on various parts of the circle, adding that it does not appear that those endeavors are being adequately coordinated.
For example, the M.T.A., a state agency, is handling the Coliseum, while two city agencies are trying to reconfigure the circle's tortuous roadways, which have long been something of an obstacle course for pedestrians and drivers.
The fear is that the various projects will not mesh, leaving Columbus Circle as dysfunctional as it has been for decades.
"They have to get some other larger sense of the urban environment into the decision-making process," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society, an influential nonprofit group that often lobbies on planning and zoning issues.
"This is the last time in our lifetime that such an important chunk of Manhattan is going to be up for redesign and rebuilding," Mr. Sexton said. "This one has got to be done right. It can't be just another development. This is going to be part of the mental picture that visitors to New York are going to have, just like Rockefeller Center."
Even Giuliani administration officials, who have tried to avoid publicly differing with the M.T.A. over the Coliseum sale, said the authority had to do a better job of examining the ramifications of the Coliseum plan for the rest of the circle.
In February, the administration attacked a study by the authority of those effects, saying that it did not include enough information about the roadways, sidewalks and subway and park entrances.
"They are not looking at it, or they have not yet determined that these are anything but minor issues," Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said at the time. "We disagree."
Some of this bickering is to be expected. The development of large projects in New York City is almost always a tempestuous affair, a process that often moves from the boardroom to the drafting room to the courtroom.
And even the staunchest opponents of the authority give it credit for seeking input from civic and community organizations, in an attempt to insure that the Coliseum plan does not fail, as it did once before.
The previous attempt to rejuvenate the area was led by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publisher and real estate magnate, who had won the rights from the M.T.A. to build on the Coliseum site.
In 1985, Mr. Zuckerman originally proposed two towers rising 68 stories, but those would have cast such long shadows over Central Park that advocacy groups successfully fought them. The plan was repeatedly scaled back before it collapsed in 1994, a victim of the neighborhood opposition and a slumping real estate market.
E. Virgil Conway, the authority's chairman, said the agency had learned from its mistakes. Mr. Conway acknowledged that the authority had not drawn up a master plan for Columbus Circle, but he said he realized that the Coliseum site set the tone for the area, adding that he would coordinate the final proposal with those of other agencies.
"The process has been very open, and we plan to keep it that way," he said.
Underlying some of the criticism of the M.T.A. is a belief that the authority has no long-term stake in Columbus Circle. Once it sells the Coliseum, which includes 10 Columbus Circle, the agency will have few commitments in the area, raising questions about whether it will simply pick the developer who makes the highest bid, without focusing much on architecture.
Nine developers have submitted plans for the site, each of which includes both a bid and a proposed design. (The bids are believed to range from $150 million to $275 million.) Only one of the nine criteria in the M.T.A.'s application involves the artistic or civic merits of the designs; the rest discuss financial, legal or development considerations.
Mr. Giuliani has veto power over the winner of the Coliseum competition, and his aides have said he wants to make sure the winning design not only generates immediate dollars for the state and city, but also acts as an economic engine for the neighborhood in the coming decades.
The Municipal Art Society and three community boards in the area have said that before the authority selects a developer, it should expand the list of criteria to include more design considerations, and should set up an advisory panel with architects and other experts to help make the decision. The authority has declined to do that.
There are at least six state and city agencies drafting plans for Columbus Circle. Besides the M.T.A., another state agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, has also worked on the Coliseum proposal.
A city agency, the Economic Development Corporation, is selling 2 Columbus Circle, which was formerly the Huntington Hartford Gallery of Modern Art. The corporation has said it will delay choosing a developer until it has a better idea of what is planned for the Coliseum site.
Three other city agencies -- Planning, Transportation and Parks -- are trying to overhaul the roadways, sidewalks and park entrances.
The Planning Department, for one, is updating a proposal for the roadways from the late 1980's that calls for the city to turn the byways of the circle into a true traffic circle.
Amid these arguments about the future of Columbus Circle, the developers have remained largely on the sidelines, awaiting decisions about the Coliseum and 2 Columbus Circle. An exception is Donald J. Trump, who has bid for both of the properties and has threatened to sue if he loses and the resulting plans hurt the value of Trump International, his nearby condominium.
Another developer vying for the Coliseum site, Richard S. LeFrak, said there seemed to be little information about how the M.T.A. was conducting its selection process.
"I would be happier if we knew what criteria they are using, other than this vague list that they have given us," Mr. LeFrak said. "But apart from that, I guess they are trying to keep everybody as far removed as possible, and maybe that is the right way to do it."
Mr. LeFrak added that when it comes to Columbus Circle, "you can't keep all of the people happy any of the time."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "A CLOSER LOOK: Improving a Crossroads"
Several state and city agencies are working on improving Columbus Circle, which has long been one of the most poorly developed crossroads in New York City.
 
Coliseum and 10 Columbus Circle
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency, will soon choose three or four finalists from a group of nine developers vying to build here. The proposals include plans for offices, hotels, condominiums apartments, cinemas, department stores and television studios.
 
2 Columbus Circle
The Economic Development Corporation, a city agency, is selling this 10-story structure, which is also known as the Huntington Hartford building. Among the seven proposals are plans for a spiritual retreat and conference center, as well as for a headquarters for Spanish-language radio stations.
 
Entrance to Central Park
Earlier proposals for towers on the Coliseum site drew stiff opposition because they would have cast shadows on the park. Advocacy groups say a revamped circle should be more friendly to pedestrians, who would then be more willing to use this park entrance.
 
Traffic and Sidewalk Changes
Several proposals have been floated for overhauling the circle, which now has so many traffic islands and byways that it is dangerous for pedestrians to cross and confusing for motorists. At left is the layout from a 1987 proposal by a consulting firm that essentially creates a genuine traffic circle. City officials are now updating this design. Another proposal calls for the statue to be elevated, allowing Broadway to continue under the statue.

HEADLINE: In Manhattan's Big Race, Task Is to Become Known

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
They are already spending their days and nights crisscrossing Manhattan, appearing before everything from block associations and tenant groups to senior citizens and labor audiences.
Though the Democratic primary for Manhattan borough president is six months away, the campaign is moving ever so gradually from preseason to the main event. And as the candidates immerse themselves in the campaign, their most formidable challenge is simply to be recognized by an electorate that knows little about them or the office they seek. 
 The task is doubly difficult because their views on issues are strikingly similar and they often describe themselves in the same terms, as independent or progressive.
For now, their energies seem to be focused on striking chords they hope will appeal to voters beyond their home areas.
The candidates seeking to succeed Borough President Ruth W. Messinger are Deborah J. Glick, an Assemblywoman from Greenwich Village, and three members of the City Council: C. Virginia Fields, who represents central Harlem and the Upper West Side; Antonio Pagan, who represents the Lower East Side, and Adam Clayton Powell 4th, who represents East Harlem and portions of the Upper West Side.
"For these candidates, becoming well known is a task of herculean proportion," said Hank Morris, a political consultant who works with Democratic candidates.
"They are in the most information clogged area in the world, campaigning for an office that most people don't really understand," Mr. Morris said. "The person who wins will be the person who figures out a way to communicate outside of their base."
That mission, the candidates agree, will be particularly difficult. The borough president, who is now widely characterized as half figurehead, half ombudsman, is far less powerful than presidents were before 1990, when the position meant having a seat on the Board of Estimate and, with it, significant influence over the budget and land use in New York City. The Board of Estimate was abolished in 1990.
But the borough presidency is still seen as a stepping stone for officials with mayoral aspirations, like Ms. Messinger, who is seeking to challenge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
At a forum for Democratic candidates for borough president last week, sponsored by two political clubs on the Upper West Side, all of the candidates stressed an ability to collaborate with groups outside their political bases and to champion issues that are not often associated with them.
Ms. Fields, a former social worker who has been a Councilwoman for eight years, focused on economic and development issues rather than some of the social service issues for which she is well known. She says she aims to woo voters from the Upper East Side and the Upper West Side.
Ms. Glick, the first openly lesbian member of the Assembly, reminded the audience that she had been an advocate of tenant rights and abortion rights as well as gay rights, and an opponent of overdevelopment on Manhattan's West Side.
"I have not been a single-issue legislator," she said, explaining that she had been able to forge strong political alliances outside her Greenwich Village district. "I have always been involved in progressive struggles."
Mr. Powell sought to counter speculation, rampant in political circles, that he was not seeking to become borough president so much as trying to enhance his name recognition and campaign contributions for another City Council race. "Many people thought I wasn't very serious and I was just putting my name out there," Mr. Powell said. "But I have made my decision."
Mr. Pagan, too, emphasized that he could appeal to voters outside his Council district on the Lower East Side.
Each candidate is allowed to spend $1 million on the race, and most have suggested that they need at least half that much to conduct a viable campaign. So far, Ms. Glick is leading the group in contributions, having collected nearly $200,000. Next is Ms. Fields, who has raised $170,000, followed by Mr. Pagan, who has raised $150,000. Mr. Powell has raised $50,000.
Much of the attention paid to the race has been devoted to which candidates would remain in it. Last week, David A. Paterson, a State Senator from Harlem, announced that he was no longer a candidate, a move that was widely seen as assisting Ms. Fields, since it would most likely lessen the splitting of the Harlem vote.
Because many Manhattan politicians cast the race as a contest between Ms. Glick and Ms. Fields, Mr. Powell and Mr. Pagan are busy assuring audiences that they are serious about the campaign.
Mr. Powell, in an effort to show that his campaign is in earnest, often brandishes a poll that he commissioned. In the poll, conducted by Zogby Group International, Mr. Powell said he placed first, the choice of 20.2 percent of the 461 respondents. Ms. Glick was next, with 12.1 percent, followed by Ms. Fields, with 9.6 percent. Mr. Pagan was the choice of 6.3 percent. More than half of those surveyed said they had no opinion.

HEADLINE: Fund-Raising Furor: Clinton Agenda Is Hindered

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Like a contagion, the campaign finance controversy is hobbling an array of Government agencies and starting to change the political calculus of President Clinton's second term.
From the White House to the Commerce Department to the State Department Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, Government offices are tied up in document searches that Administration officials say are likely to become even more time consuming as Congressional investigations move into high gear. 
 In a host of other areas, the controversy is raising all kinds of new political considerations.
For example, Vice President Al Gore's coming trip to China was once viewed as high-profile diplomacy. But Administration officials are fretting that Mr. Gore's every action will be viewed through the prism of accusations that the Chinese Government and Asian business interests were trying to buy political influence through campaign donations.
For Mr. Clinton, naming three people to a new commission to study gambling's effects on the country should have been a simple task. But the appointments are months overdue as the White House considers how to avoid any appearance that Mr. Clinton was influenced by donations from supporters of gambling.
At the State Department, nominations of ambassadors and assistant secretaries are backed up at least in part, officials say, because the current climate has made the Administration extremely cautious in its background checks of candidates.
And the fallout from the campaign finance controversy may also be starting to affect the negotiations over a balanced budget plan -- for a continuing Republican assault on Democratic fund-raising has left Mr. Clinton more dependent on Congressional Democrats than he might have been otherwise, some Administration officials and members of Congress say.
"They are driving him into the arms of the Democrats who least want to deal," said George R. Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's former senior adviser.
Indeed, the mood in Washington has changed sharply since Mr. Clinton was re-elected and promised to govern from the "vital center."
For months, Mr. Clinton had tried to set the stage for a season of cooperation with the Republican-led Congress. He particularly had appeared poised to separate himself from the liberal wing of his own party as he had done on issues like welfare and trade.
He named a Republican, William S. Cohen, as Defense Secretary in an effort to reach out to the Republicans. Later, furthering the impression that he was a conciliating force, Mr. Clinton appeared with former President George Bush and Gen. Colin L. Powell to say he would hold a three-day conference on community service this spring.
Such gestures were to pave the way for Mr. Clinton and Congressional Republicans to reach an agreement early this year on a plan to balance the budget by 2002.
But with questions about White House and Democratic fund-raising dominating Washington, partisanship is on the rise once more. Congressional Republicans have demanded that Mr. Clinton produce a new budget plan. Many are calling for an independent counsel. And one Georgia Republican, Representative Bob Barr, went so far last week as to call for impeachment proceedings against Mr. Clinton.
In such a climate, Congressional Democrats say, White House officials have been working to push more allies out in public to defend the President and to stop members of his own party from undercutting him by adding their own voices to the criticism of his fund-raising practices. But such tactics make it more difficult for Mr. Clinton to oppose liberal Democrats and core Democratic constituency groups.
"He is much more dependent on Democrats in Congress than he might have been otherwise," a Democratic strategist said. "He needs people up there to fight his fight. He can't afford to turn them all off."
Thus some on Capitol Hill considered it a telling moment last week when budget talks stalled after President Clinton shelved the idea of establishing an independent commission to devise a new way to calculate cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other Federal benefits.
Such a change would save billions of dollars, making a budget deal easier and potentially freeing up money to meet Republican demands for further tax cuts. But it was highly unpopular with traditional Democratic allies like labor and the elderly and was opposed by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, who is expected to challenge Mr. Gore from the left for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000.
Mr. Clinton's negotiators said that the decision had nothing to do with campaign finance considerations -- and that they had simply found opposition among some Republicans and among all factions of the Democratic party. Even conservative Democrats, they said, were unwilling to make changes in Social Security payments if the move could be viewed as paving the way for tax cuts.
But as a result of the President's action, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, whom Mr. Clinton had been courting as a negotiating partner, condemned the President as lacking leadership and Mr. Gephardt praised the President as "politically courageous."
Without progress on the budget, there is little on the horizon despite forays into foreign policy -- like the President's trip to Helsinki, Finland, later this week -- to dilute the focus on fund-raising and help Mr. Clinton change the subject.
Mr. Clinton himself ran in 1996 on a scaled-back domestic program and his most major proposals -- tax relief for higher education and additional money for work programs for welfare recipients -- are contingent on the budget talks.
The Republicans, meanwhile, came out of the election fractured over whether to return to their 1995 agenda or to seek more moderate areas of cooperation with the President. Speaker Newt Gingrich, who led them on their charge, has been weakened by his own ethics problems and unpopularity. And Mr. Lott has recently suffered several leadership setbacks.
One result is a vacuum that only means fund-raising questions will continue to grip policy-makers.
William Kristol, the editor of The Weekly Standard, a conservative magazine, gave this assessment of the situation: "If Clinton had announced a health care plan like his original one in the State of the Union message, or if the Republicans had come out of the box with something like the Contract With America, the scandals wouldn't be nearly as prominent. The economy is good. The country's at peace and neither party has an agenda."

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Gap Grows, Breaking Trend

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, March 17

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose in February for the first time in 27 months, as the weakening yen helped increase exports, the Finance Ministry said today.
The surplus rose 6.5 percent from February 1996 to 686.72 billion yen, or about $5.56 billion, the Japanese Government said. Still, that increase was within expectations; economists in a survey had projected a surplus of about 699 billion yen. 
 Japan's trade surplus with the United States in February rose 12.3 percent, to 407.35 billion yen, the ministry said, for the fifth consecutive monthly increase.
Financial markets showed little early reaction today to the first increase in Japan's trade surplus since November 1994. In afternoon trading, the dollar was quoted at 123.67 yen, up from 123.38 yen late Friday. Japanese stocks were relatively stable, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues trading up 129.86 points, at 18,053.50, at the close.
The yen's 16.3 percent decline between August and February fueled much of the increase in Japanese exports, particularly of automobiles and machinery. Automobile exports to the United States rose 15.4 percent in February.
Global imports to Japan rose 10.8 percent in February, to 3.302 trillion yen, while exports rose 10 percent to 3.989 trillion yen, the ministry said.

HEADLINE: 1997 N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;
Four-Year Mission Ends for Wake Star

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND 

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz., March 16

 BODY:
He came back for this?
Tim Duncan chose the dorms over an N.B.A. per diem, but he did not want to hear today that college is the greatest time of your life. He could have millions of dollars in annuities by now, but instead he spent this afternoon being pushed on his empty wallet by a group of Stanford econ majors. 
 Their names are Mark Madsen, Peter Sauer, Pete Van Elswyk, Mark Seaton and Tim Young, and, although they could all use a student loan from Duncan next year, Stanford's big men were superior to him today in the aggregate. Duncan, certain to be college basketball's player of the year, did not have a field goal in the final 14 minutes, and he was nowhere to be found when the offensive rebound of Stanford's life fell into the lap of a 6-foot guard.
Arthur Lee's look-what-I-found rebound basket with 29 seconds remaining was the insurance bucket that sixth-seeded Stanford needed, and Duncan's remarkable career at Wake Forest ended with a 72-66 loss in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.
"I didn't know we could do this, to be honest with you," said the Cardinal coach, Mike Montgomery.
Stanford had not won two games in an N.C.A.A. tournament since it won the championship in 1942, and its archrivals at California like to say that the Stanford men cannot even beat the Stanford women's team. But Brevin Knight, a point guard who almost attended Manhattan College, controlled the tempo today, and Stanford's five post players pitched the perfect makeshift tent around the 6-foot-10-inch Duncan.
Stanford (22-7) is not only the record fourth Pacific 10 team in this year's round of 16 -- hence its band chanting, "Pac 10, Pac 10" -- but on Thursday it will get to play its West Regional semifinal 20 minutes from campus at San Jose (Calif.) Arena. "It will be very, very loud," Knight said. The opponent will be Utah, which dismantled North Carolina-Charlotte, 77-58, in today's early game, but the truth is, this regional was supposed to be a pro scouting combine.
Duncan was supposed to be there, along with Utah's Keith Van Horn and Kentucky's Ron Mercer -- possibly the first three picks in the National Basketball Association draft -- but Stanford's upset of the third-seeded Demon Deacons (24-7) means Duncan can start talking to agents.
"I couldn't sit here and tell you what I got out of staying," said Duncan, a senior, who possibly could have been the first pick in either of the last two N.B.A. drafts had he chosen to leave school early. "I had a great time. I have no regrets. I'll never look back and say I should have done that or should have done this."
His crime today was not finishing what he started. Wake Forest was the nation's No. 2 team in late January, but its guards stopped shooting like marksmen, and defenses were free to sag back and swallow Duncan. His numbers today were reputable -- 18 points, 20 rebounds, 3 blocks -- but he had 6 turnovers amid all of the Stanford commotion and his erratic guards not only failed to get him the ball, they waited 35 minutes to warm up.
Stanford's center, Young -- its only big man to choose English over economics -- played only five minutes of the first half after fouling Duncan twice, while his backup, Madsen, picked up three similar fouls in a mere six minutes. But the Cardinal still led by 25-19 at halftime, scored the first 7 points of the second half and held an improbable 40-24 lead with 15 minutes left.
Wake Forest's guards, Tony Rutland and Jerry Braswell, began to ignore Duncan -- because of the Stanford forest around him -- and they hoisted enough 3-pointers that some were bound to drop. By the three-minute mark, the Cardinal's lead was a mere 60-55, and Stanford decided to put the game in Knight's itchy hands.
Knight, a senior who attended Seton Hall Prep in East Orange, N.J., and who chose Stanford over Manhattan because his parents told him to, finished with 19 points and 5 assists, and gave all the credit to the bruisers who backed up Young.
Sauer, in particular, drilled two jump shots (set up by Knight) in the final two minutes to give the Cardinal a 66-59 lead, and then Lee's heaven-sent rebound and basket made it 68-62.
"When I got the rebound and put it in," said Lee, who was not boxed out by Ricky Peral, "it was like a dream."
In the earlier game, the Charlotte box-and-one defense that warped Victor Page's shot in a first-round victory over Georgetown did nothing of the sort to Van Horn. The Utah senior may have been 1 of 6 from 3-point range, but there is always the alley-oop. Van Horn had more than his share of dunks and two-foot shots on his way to a game-high 27 points, and Utah suffered only minor perspiration in its victory.
"Actually, I think Keith is pressing a bit," said his coach, Rick Majerus. "The reason, and this is why I like the boy, is when he misses, he gets mad."
Meanwhile, Sean Colson, the North Carolina-Charlotte guard who had tortured Page, was experiencing double vision -- as in two Utes everywhere he looked. Colson may have head-bobbed his way to 24 points against the Hoyas, but Majerus implored his defense not to fall for Colson's Academy Award-worthy head-and-shoulder move. The result was Colson's 3-point, 1-for-13 shooting day that left Charlotte in an unenviable hole. Utah's lead was actually as little as 47-40 with 14 minutes left, but -- with Van Horn resting on the bench -- center Michael Doleac (18 points, 7 rebounds) scored 4 straight to end it.
A Utah-Wake Forest matchup would have been a rematch of their New Year's Eve game earlier this season -- the night Duncan clinched the player of the year award over Van Horn -- but now the two all-Americans will not meet again until the next level.
Wake Forest Coach Dave Odom was near tears about it. He remembers when Duncan, who is still a month from his 21st birthday, arrived as a rail-thin 17-year-old from St. Croix. He stayed four years, is on a first-name basis with his professors and was even brave enough this year to get two tattoos: a wizard on his chest and a joker (winking) on his back.
"Tim leaves us after four years of absolute great performances -- one monster game after another," Odom said. "More than any other player I've been around, he's exercised the joy of the moment. I have no remorse at all with him. He's leaving; he's ready.
"I'm sad to see him go, but it's his time, and he's earned it. And as he walks out that door the last time, there will be no tears. Well, O.K., there will be tears."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wake Forest's Tim Duncan, right, set to block a shot by Stanford's Arthur Lee yesterday. (Todd Warshaw/Allsport, for The New York Times)(pg. C4)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2520 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE: New England;
For Chilly New England Economy, Spring

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass.

 BODY:
The towers rose almost overnight in this former textile city in the early 1980's, concrete and glass headquarters for the Wang Laboratories computer giant and a symbol of the boom known as the Massachusetts Miracle.
But when Wang missed the personal computer revolution and went bankrupt in the early 1990's, laying off thousands of workers, the nearly empty buildings loomed as a grim reminder of the recession that lasted longer in New England than in any other region of the country. The three towers, built for an estimated $80 million, were sold to a pair of developers in 1994 for a pittance: $525,000, or 35 cents per square foot. 
 Today, the towers, which have been rechristened Cross Point, are once again a hot property. They are almost fully occupied, with 22 new businesses that provide services like health care, banking, telecommunications and Internet access. The towers stand as a symbol of Lowell's, and New England's, economic rebound.
Time and again, this region has transformed itself through pluck and brains, from a mid-19th-century agriculture and textile center to a great maritime power, then to a defense and high-technology magnet. So the region has responded to its latest slump by reinventing its economy once more. No miracle of growth this time, this economy has weaned itself from an overdependence on Pentagon money, outmoded mainframe computers and real estate dollars. Instead, it is developing as a mix of entrepreneurial high-technology start-ups and services, much like the mix of companies drawn to the former Wang towers.
Just as Lowell is a metaphor for New England's recovery, so does the region mirror in many ways the rest of America, where the economy has diversified and where rising fortunes have helped keep both inflation and unemployment low, fueling investor and consumer confidence.
Here in Massachusetts, the latest unemployment figure was 3.7 percent, below the national average, which was 5.3 percent in February, and it is even lower in the area along Route 128, the highway circling Boston. During the recession, offices emptied out in that area, known as the Silicon Valley of the Northeast. But competition for high-technology workers is so intense now that some companies have been reported to be offering signing bonuses of $100,000.
"It has taken us nine years to dig our way out," said Ira Jackson, an executive vice president at BankBoston, who described the Massachusetts Miracle as "overheated, giddy, greedy," a wave of growth that seemed to defy market logic before it went bust.
"We're like the guy in the Mennen commercial who gets slapped, and says, 'Thanks, I needed that.' " Mr. Jackson said. "We're much more diversified. We're lighter and quicker on our feet, much more competitive, more market-oriented. We're certainly more humble. Our long extended winter of discontent is behind us."
The Massachusetts Miracle, its name notwithstanding, took hold primarily in Boston and eastern Massachusetts, and the recovery is also concentrated there. It is spotty in some other parts of New England, like western Massachusetts, where manufacturing jobs continue to decline, and Rhode Island, which, because of a reliance on military manufacturing rather than research and development, has been less able to cope with Pentagon cutbacks than Massachusetts.
In northern Maine, in many ways a separate state from southern Maine, the decades-long decline in logging and paper-mill jobs continues. The state has an unemployment rate, about 8 percent, that is higher than the rate for the rest of the nation.
While the nation has more than recovered the jobs lost in the recession, New England has regained only 73 percent of the 650,000 jobs lost between late 1988 and 1991, said Wayne M. Ayers, the chief economist for BankBoston. The region has been losing manufacturing jobs steadily since 1984, and those losses have begun to bottom out only in the past year.
"It's a bona fide recovery, but it's very uneven," Mr. Ayers said.
The economy of Vermont, the most rural of the New England states, depends on dairy farming, tourism and manufacturing, and it was not hurt as badly by the recession as the rest of the region. Some people give credit for that to the state's strict environmental laws, which curbed development.
"We didn't come to the peaking crescendo the other states did and then crash," said Tom Pelham, the state's commissioner of finance and management.
But areas that are strongly tied to the Massachusetts economy, like southern New Hampshire and southern Maine, are bubbling again with new jobs in high technology, telecommunications and financial and business services. New Hampshire, in fact, had the highest job growth from 1994 to 1995 of any New England state.
Many of New Hampshire's new jobs, in retail and service, pay considerably less than the construction and manufacturing jobs that have disappeared, said Russ Thibeault, an economic consultant in Laconia. "The good news is we added all the jobs we lost," he said. "The bad news is the kind of jobs we're adding is lousy."
Maine may still be known for lobsters and potato farming, but it is computer chips, telemarketing and biotechnology that are driving the new economy, said Gov. Angus King, a political independent and self-made millionaire businessman. Mr. King, who was elected in 1994 after promising to bring jobs to Maine, persuaded National Semiconductor last summer to commit to a $900 million expansion of its South Portland plant.
 The energy is being felt here in Lowell, a city of 100,000 people that in the mid-19th century reigned as the country's largest manufacturing center, only to endure a bust and boom and a bust again as the mills moved south, and as Wang drove an economic revival in the 1980's and a collapse in 1992.
In the wake of its fall, Wang, which employed 5,500 workers in the towers at its peak, has moved to nearby Billerica and transformed itself into a computer integration and support company with fewer than 1,000 employees.
The Boston Globe is thick with Help Wanted advertisements on Sundays. The sleek office parks along Route 128 are humming once again, their corridors bustling with 30-and-under graduates of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and software engineers.

Roots of a Revival
New Enterprises On Broader Base
The spirit of New England's revival can be found at all hours in a two-room, ground-floor office in Cambridge, Mass. There, Steve Levy, a 56-year-old former chief executive of BBN, the Internet giant based in Cambridge, founded an Internet game start-up company with his partner, Al Stevens, 47.
"Five people, 800 square feet and an idea," Mr. Levy said, describing the company, called Kaon. "Our idea was that we could create virtual communities focused around a game."
Kaon has already outgrown its space and is looking for larger quarters.
While the boom of the 80's was driven by Federal military dollars, real estate and a handful of high-technology superstars like Wang, the Digital Equipment Corporation and Data General, the new economy, as shown by Cross Point's success in Lowell, is more diversified. It draws on mainstays like the defense giant Raytheon and the consumer products maker Gillette but also on financial services, health care, telecommunications and a new generation of biotechnology and other high-technology companies. The new names include Genzyme, Cascade, Parametric Technology, Security Dynamics and Bay Networks.
The hardest-driving pistons in this economic engine are found in Cambridge and the areas around Route 128 and, farther west, Route 495, the other highway that rings Boston.
Cambridge has become a boom town, with a 4.6 percent commercial vacancy rate. High-technology start-ups share the narrow streets of the industrial section with pipe factories, auto repair shops and the New England Confectionary Company's Necco candy factory.
Roy Hirshland, a vice president with Spaulding & Slye, a commercial real estate firm, was driving along Route 128 the other day, past the huge office complexes where high-technology companies are competing for space.
"These were empty buildings in the 1990's," Mr. Hirshland said. "You couldn't give space away. Now it's tight as a drum. Rents go up almost monthly."

The Labor Force
Opportunities Depend on Skills
For all the venture capital pouring into places like Cambridge and along Route 128, Mr. Ayers, the BankBoston economist, cautions that there are threats to the recovery. The low unemployment rate, for example, in part reflects the smaller labor force; the number of highly skilled workers shrank during the recession.
There is a risk, Mr. Ayers said, that if Massachusetts continues to lose skilled workers, "the industries that we have identified as being the drivers of the New England economy will look to grow elsewhere, where the labor force is growing more rapidly."
Housing is still expensive. Boston's housing market is still the fifth most costly in the country, and labor and utility costs make it more expensive to do business in the region than in, say, the Research Triangle, between Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill in North Carolina.
"It's not a slam-dunk, rosy future for anybody," said Jerold S. Kayden, an associate professor of urban planning at Harvard's Graduate School of Design. "This is a wiser Massachusetts that needs to look over its shoulder and look ahead at the same time. Everybody is competing with everyone else."
It takes a college education, computer experience and a car to get to a job along Route 128. Peggy Lai, 41, and Kit Chung, 46, lack all three things. They belong to the ever-increasing ranks of Americans trying to catch up in the new economy.
Last November, Ms. Lai and Ms. Chung were laid off from their jobs stitching bras at the Goddess lingerie factory in Watertown, Mass. Now they spend their days at computers in a classroom in downtown Boston, learning data entry and basic computer skills.
Their classes are part of a retraining program offered by Action for Boston Community Development.
"We have to be computerized," Ms. Lai said. "We have to catch up." The two women earned $5.85 an hour at the lingerie factory, with extra piecework bringing the wage up to as much as $10 an hour. They expect to find $8-an-hour jobs when they complete the training program, perhaps as data entry clerks in a bank or as temporary workers.
For 30 years, Frederick J. Grafton has earned his living as a boilermaker, building and maintaining power plants. In 1990, his best year, he earned $70,000. He has not found work in his trade since November, when he had a two-day job in New Hampshire.
Now he picks up odd jobs where he can, with a recent stint as an $8-an-hour driver for a Starbucks coffee truck. The bank foreclosed on Mr. Grafton's house two years ago. He and his wife have separated, in part because of his financial difficulties, Mr. Grafton said.
Mr. Grafton is studying computer-aided design at the same center as Ms. Lai and Ms. Chung. Jack Cumisky, who heads the program, said Mr. Grafton could expect to find a $10-an-hour entry-level position when he completed the 18-week course.
"I'm looking forward to it," Mr. Grafton said. "I'm optimistic. I've hit rock bottom."

New Attitudes
Warmer Welcome For Businesses
Economists say there is no single reason for the recovery. The region has benefited from the upturn across the country, and it has put behind it the credit crunch and real estate crisis -- in particular, a glut of unsold commercial property -- of the recession.
In addition, Massachusetts is no longer Taxachusetts. Cushioned by tax increases pushed through by his predecessor, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican who took office in 1992, has pushed into law several tax cuts and other measures intended to reduce the cost of doing business in the state.
Some people say the state is becoming downright business-friendly. When Raytheon threatened to leave last year, the Legislature, which is overwhelmingly Democratic, gave the company breaks on its corporate income tax.
In a 1991 survey of 200 chief executives who are members of the Massachusetts High Technology Council, 77 percent rated the Massachusetts business climate as fair or poor, while 92 percent said it would hold steady or worsen. In a 1997 survey, 88 percent called the business climate good or outstanding, while 99 percent said it would hold steady or improve.
Economists say the region is doing better because of growth in banking and financial services, particularly for mutual fund companies. With Boston home to Fidelity Investments, the country's largest financial services company, the city has in the last decade risen to become a financial services capital second only to New York.
In fact, despite Fidelity's highly publicized problems, including lagging mutual fund returns and the defection of many top managers, the company continues to grow.
Its Boston work force has more than doubled in the past six years, to 8,900 from 4,325. It opened a new office in New Hampshire last year and has announced plans to open one in Rhode Island in 1998.
Another key to the recovery is Boston's wealth of top educational institutions, which continue to produce the intellectual capital for the region's economy.
"What's interesting about the recovery in Massachusetts is that it's very difficult to pin it on a particular sector," said Lynn Brown, a senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston. "I think probably what is driving it is people with ingenuity who are well educated and have developed lots of contacts and have continued to be able to come up with new ideas."
Just as Massachusetts has reinvented itself to survive in the new economy, so has Christopher Jenkins. Mr. Jenkins, a graduate of the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., is the chief financial officer of Ziplink, a start-up Internet service provider that moved its 30 employees onto the fifth floor of one of the former towers of Wang Laboratories last July.
Eight months later, Ziplink has 97 employees, with plans to add 100 to 150 jobs in the next 18 months.
Ten years ago, Mr. Jenkins became one of the statistics of the recession when he bought a small paging company two weeks before the stock market crashed.
The nadir came one day in 1991, when his car had been towed from a temporary no-parking zone and he and his wife were walking along Boston's Southeast Expressway in the rain.
"I thought State Street Bank was going to take my house," Mr. Jenkins said. "I was way, way in debt. People were threatening to put me in bankruptcy. I started laughing. I said to my wife, 'It can't get any worse than this.' "
In 1995, with the Northeast economy improving, one of the Bell Company spinoffs bought what was left of Mr. Jenkins's paging business. That gave him the cash to help start Ziplink.
Mr. Jenkins said he and his wife, Julia Nord, had learned a lesson: "We know that things don't just always continue to go up. They can go back down."

HEADLINE: Feeling Insecure, Are We?;
Go Ahead, Be Paranoid. Hackers Are Out to Get You.

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
In a chilly, windowless room in a New York suburb, four men are tapping furiously at their laptop computers. Their mission: crack into the computer system of a major American corporation.
Things seem to be going well, for them. "All right, we're through the firewall," announced one bearded hacker. A few moments later, a second practitioner of high-tech mischief pronounced himself pleased by what he saw inside -- a digital picture of vulnerability rendered by the lines of computer code dancing across his screen. "Looks like we can toast it," he said. 
 Charles Palmer, a slender, bearded 40-year-old computer scientist, looked on with pride at the members of his team. Skilled hackers, Mr. Palmer noted, are scarce these days, at least ones that he will hire.
"It's hard to find good people in this field who do not have criminal records," he explained.
Mr. Palmer and his team work for the International Business Machines Corporation, and their brand of computer hacking is legal. Companies pay the I.B.M. squad to attack their computer systems to test how well they can stand up to the increasing assaults by real hackers. The growing ranks of cyberintruders are engaged in everything from snooping around to "parking" pornography and pirated software on unsuspecting corporate machines to computer-assisted fraud and theft.
White-hat hackers, like those at I.B.M., are only one kind of computer-security professional whose skills are much in demand today. Once an arcane specialty, computer security has moved into the mainstream. As companies rush onto the Internet, they benefit from improved communication with customers, suppliers and far-flung employees, but they also take on far greater risk that their corporate computer systems will be breached by outsiders with malicious intent.
The dangers of a networked world have created boom times for computer security consultants, auditors, cryptographers and others. Lately, they must contend with pushy headhunters as well as hackers. Five years ago, six-figure salaries were rare in the security field. Today, it is not uncommon for skilled computer-security veterans to be making $200,000 a year or more.
Recognizing a sellers' market for computer-security expertise, Wietse Venema has come to America, and he's selling. A computer scientist from the University of Eindhoven in the Netherlands, Mr. Venema is the co-author of Satan, a sophisticated software program intended to find security flaws in any computer system linked to the Internet. The 45-year-old Dutch researcher is considering offers from I.B.M. and other leading American computer companies. "Many people are interested in my capabilties now," he observed cheerfully.
Experts, like Mr. Venema, are suddenly stars because corporations are spending more on computer security. This year, companies worldwide are expected to spend $6.3 billion on security for their computer networks, estimates Dataquest, a market research firm. Within three years, the security price tag is projected to more than double to nearly $12.9 billion -- a figure that is only for services supplied by outside contractors, so it excludes spending on in-house staff, security software or hardware products.
The industry in America, the world leader in computer security, comprises hundreds of companies. They run the gamut from large companies with worldwide computer consulting practices, like I.B.M., the Science Applications International Corporation and Perot Systems, and Big Six accounting firms, like Coopers & Lybrand, Ernst & Young and Deloitte & Touche, down to one-man independent consultants, like Mr. Seiden.
Fueling the surge in computer-security spending is fear. The corporate concerns are heightened with every report of hackers defacing well-known World Wide Web sites, like the recent attacks on the sites of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Justice Department. The Federal Bureau of Investigation says few intrusions into corporate computer systems -- 15 percent at most -- are ever reported to law enforcement agencies. But the handful that are reported, like the 1994 case of Russian hackers who tapped into Citibank and made $10 million in illegal funds transfers (all but $400,000 was recovered), tend to cause alarm.
"The business is not so much network security as it is network insecurity," noted Alice Murphy, an analyst at Dataquest. "There's so much anxiety out there now."
Just how great the threat is to corporate computer systems is a matter of debate. The Internet, observes Peter Neumann, a computer scientist at SRI International, a research group in Menlo Park, Calif., was never really designed to be secure. Once the bailiwick of a small community of researchers, it is starting to be used as a freeway of commerce. "The infrastructure is vulnerable," Mr. Neumann said. "From that larger perspective, the risks are enormous."
Dan Farmer, the co-author of Satan with the Dutch researcher Mr. Venema, did a survey of 1,700 corporate and government Web sites late last year and found that more than 60 percent of them had "serious potential security vulnerabilities." Mr. Farmer, a programmer at Sun Microsystems Inc., did not break into the computer systems, but he said they were open to attack and often could be severely damaged. (His survey results are posted on the Web, at www.trouble.org.)
Yet there is a significant difference, some analysts say, between potential vulnerability and the actual business risk to corporate computer systems. "There is risk, but the threat tends to be vastly overstated," said George Colony, president of Forrester Research Inc., a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass.
Forrester estimates that losses from fraud in Internet commerce are likely to be roughly $1 for every $1,000 of business. To put the matter into perspective, the fraud losses in cellular phone service are $20 for every $1,000, according to Forrester, while the losses on credit card transactions are nearly $2 for every $1,000 of goods charged.
Still, even skeptics, like Forrester's Mr. Colony, agree that computer security requires continuous attention. "It is a manageable risk, and it should not deter companies from jumping into Internet commerce," Mr. Colony said. "But I also tell our clients that they should think of computer security as a guerrilla war that will last forever."
The F.B.I. is treating the battle against computer crime as a long-running campaign. All new agents are now trained in cyberspace investigations as part of the curriculum at the F.B.I. Academy in Quantico, Va. And last year, the bureau established three computer crime squads in San Francisco, New York and Washington, to pursue cybercrime more aggressively.
"We're really on the cusp of this becoming a major problem," said James Kallstrom, head of the F.B.I. office in New York. "As more and more of the economy goes digital, there are huge incentives for criminal attacks on American corporations."
Computer crime, of course, comes in many forms. An employee with a grudge and access to a company's computer network may well be far more dangerous, and costly, than even the most artful hacker.
A survey released two weeks ago by the Computer Security Institute, and conducted on behalf of the F.B.I.'s computer crime unit, estimated computer security losses last year at $100 million -- a total only among some 250 companies and organizations that would place dollar figures on their losses from fraud, theft of trade secrets and other breaches.
The criminal hackers have long been engaged in a kind of cat-and-mouse game with law enforcement agencies and private computer security experts. And that game is increasingly being played at a higher level, with greater skill and new tools.
The cell-phone hackers of the past, who electronically jimmied phones for the thrill and free phone service, have graduated to Web site hacking. Today, there are an estimated 440 hacker bulletin boards, 1,900 Web sites purveying hacking tips and tools, and 30 hackers publications like "Phrack" and "2600: The Hacker Quarterly." There are readily available software programs for hacking tactics like "war dialing," "sniffing" and "fingering" -- all used to exploit security weaknesses in computer systems.
"As the stakes become higher, the technical sophistication of the people doing this kind of illegal activity is increasing," said Edward Hart, a senior vice president of Science Applications International.
Today, there is a brisk, illicit market in hacking, according to security experts, with the street price for breaking into a corporate Web site typically in the $8,000-to-$10,000 range. Bonus payments are usually demanded for trade secrets pilfered or damage inflicted on a competitor's computer system.
Limiting the risk, and damage, to corporate computer systems is the goal of Mr. Palmer and the other security specialists at I.B.M. The test hacking done by his team is mainly a fact-finding tool, and only one of many. The authorized break-ins by these groups, called "tiger teams," is often more valuable as a marketing tactic than as a research tool. Thick and exhaustive studies of a company's computer security can be met with yawning indifference by top executives, but a break-in gets their attention.
Mundane rules, not high-tech wizardry, are crucial to reducing security risks. A robust firewall to filter what electronic traffic gets into a company's computer system is helpful, but it can be a Maginot Line approach to security -- the real weaknesses are elsewhere.
To work from home, employees may have dial-up modems at their desks, unprotected by firewalls or even passwords. Employees, security experts warn, must be told to give their passwords to no one; one scam is for hackers to call new employees, pretending to be members of the corporate technology staff doing a check of passwords. Another frequent weakness is simple physical security, watching who goes in or out of the building.
These are hectic times for security consultants like I.B.M.'s Nick Simicich, a 44-year-old self-taught programmer. He works from his home in Boca Raton, Fla., equipped with powerful computers running Linux, a shareware program that is the operating system of choice for hackers.
Mostly, though, Mr. Simicich is on the road, 85 percent of the time, he estimates, logging perhaps 150,000 air miles a year. Continental, the airline he flies most regularly, invited Mr. Simicich to a company parade last year.
He proudly calls himself a "paid professional paranoid." His goal, he says, is not to make corporate computer systems immune to hackers. "That's impossible," he explained. "Our real goal is to raise the bar. First, we do want to make it harder for them to break in, so the average hacker moves to an easier target. Second, when they do get in, we want to insure that the damage is limited."

DO:
 
CAUTION WORKERS about choosing passwords wisely. Passwords should be at least six to eight characters long, and be a mix of letters and numerals. Passwords should be changed every six months or so.
 
EDUCATE WORKERS about the "social engineering" tactics used by criminals. Hackers will call workers, pretending to be members on the technology department and ask for passwords or what software workers use. Any knowledge of a company's computer system can aid a skilled criminal.
 
TEST THE COMPUTER SYSTEM REGULARLY FOR SECURITY HOLES. Keep up with security bug fixes. The Government-backed Computer Emergency Response Team posts security fixes on the Web, at www.cert.org.
 
ASSUME THE SYSTEM WILL BE BROKEN INTO. Design the company network and computer-use policies to limit the damage. Corporate data, for example, should be classified as "public" or "proprietary," with the two sets of information segregated.
 
DO NOT:
 
USE REAL ENGLISH-LANGUAGE WORDS AS PASSWORDS. Passwords cracking software tries words from a dictionary list. Urge employees to memorize their passwords. If they write them down, passwords should not be displayed anywhere near a user's machine. Workers hould not give out passwords to anyone, inside or outside the company.
 
SEND SENSITIVE CORPORATE INFORMATION over computer networks without using encryption software.
 
ALLOW EMPLOYEES TRAVELING OR WORKING FROM HOME ACCESS TO THE NETWORK THROUGH AN UNPROTECTED DIAL-UP MODEM. Workers should only be able to tap into the network by going through a firewall into a secure connection. Getting into the network should require the user to perform identification and authentication.
