HEADLINE: Museum Innovator Delights in Bringing Science to the Public

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
AS an audience of wide-eyed children watched, a young woman wearing safety glasses and a laboratory coat decanted fuming liquid nitrogen from a thermos flask and demonstrated some of the startling things that happen to rubber balls, balloons and other objects chilled to 320 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.
Liquids like mercury freeze as hard as lead, balloons shrivel to small prunes and rubber balls shatter when dropped. Watching from the sidelines, her boss at the New York Hall of Science, Dr. Alan J. Friedman, nodded approvingly and recalled some of his own experiences with extreme cold. 
 "For my doctoral thesis at Florida State, I investigated magnetic transitions that occur at the temperature of liquid helium," Dr. Friedman said. "It was fun. I loved the adventure of discovery."
"Later, as I began specializing in the communication of science to nonscientists, I worried that by giving up research in physics, and the opportunity to be first to know new truths about nature, I would lose something important. But I gained something just as important: the satisfaction of helping people to know some of the pleasures of science. I'm speaking not just of children, but of their teachers and everyone else in whom the spark of curiosity is kindled."
Behind his graying beard, Dr. Friedman exudes boyish delight as he explains to museum visitors how things work and imagines new ways to depict scientific subtleties to nonscientists. He has succeeded so well that last month the American Association for the Advancement of Science, America's premier society of professional scientists, presented him with its Award for Public Understanding of Science and Technology.
Dr. Friedman calls his brand of teaching "informal science education," and what it lacks in hard mathematics and the rigors of testing, it makes up in appeal, he believes. Its main object at the New York Hall of Science in Flushing Meadows, Queens, is to lure young minds from inner-city populations.
Most of the children visiting the museum on an average day are black or of Hispanic descent, as are about 80 percent of the museum's young assistants and red-coated "explainers" -- high school or college students recruited for a museum program called the Science Career Ladder. As they learn to explain to visitors the science underlying museum exhibits, the explainers, more than half of whom are girls, must master some of the science themselves. For their services, they are paid small stipends and are given a variety of educational perquisites, which Dr. Friedman believes have paid off.
A recent survey of 91 alumni of the program, the museum reported, showed that 34 percent had gone on to become professional teachers, 15 percent were in science-related careers, and 9 percent were full-time museum employees. Only 2 percent were unemployed.
The museum has been a learning experience for Dr. Friedman himself.
"It's impossible to know what goes on in a child's head, so you just have to keep experimenting with the exhibits, just as you would in any other research project," he said. "As a matter of fact, there is a great need for more formal academic study of what works and what doesn't in informal science education."
In 1984, at the age of 42, Dr. Friedman became director of the moribund New York Hall of Science, which has since enjoyed phenomenal success under his stewardship, particularly in innovative display.
For instance, it had long troubled Dr. Friedman that the atom was generally depicted in museums, on television and in the popular press as a miniature planetary system, in which the atomic nucleus occupied the place of the Sun, with little electron balls circling in neat orbits like those of planets. But with the advent of quantum physics in the 1920's and 1930's, scientists learned that real atoms are not like that at all. An atom's electron shells are actually diffuse probability clouds that abruptly change shape and size, absorbing or emitting light as they are excited to higher energies or fall to lower ones.
Representing such an object in a realistic way was a staggering challenge, but in 1988 Dr. Friedman's technical team succeeded. Starting with a darkened room for the exhibit, the team rigged up a gadget that jiggles a small projection screen up and down. The motion is linked to a computer-driven laser system. With the screen moving rapidly and a dot of laser light speeding over it faster than the eye can perceive, the illusion of a giant, three-dimensional quantum atom of hydrogen leaps out at a viewer. A visitor, moreover, can add "energy" and watch the atom sprout lobes and change shape, or emit a photon of light when it loses energy.
(The museum's quantum atom performed impeccably for nearly a decade but is undergoing some repairs and maintenance.)
Another museum innovation, the creation of an inventor, Budd Wentz, was a new type of microscope equipped with a special light system and a large frosted-glass viewing screen. The microscope is powerful enough to view the activity of paramecia and other microorganisms, but because of its novel design, a half-dozen children at a time can watch the action. The microscope became so popular with museum visitors that Mr. Wentz has since manufactured them for some 60 institutions around the world.
Yet another product of the museum's inventors was a portable canvas planetarium equipped with a small star projector, an air lock and a blower to keep the dome inflated. Easily transported from one school to another, these little planetariums can accommodate about 30 children seated on the ground. Thirteen New York Hall of Science planetarium kits are circulating in the New York City area, and many others have been sold or leased abroad, including to India.
Born in Brooklyn on Nov. 15, 1942, the future museum director moved at the age of 5 to Carrolton, Ga., where his father managed a plant manufacturing bedspreads. Educated in the Georgia school system, he went on to the Georgia Institute of Technology. At first he majored in electrical engineering, but soon realized that his real interest was "in discovering how things worked, not just how they were hooked together." In 1964 he was awarded a bachelor's degree in physics and went on to Florida State University to pursue a doctorate.
The New York Hall of Science is not Dr. Friedman's first creation. He started the physics and astronomy education program at the Lawrence Hall of Science in Berkeley, Calif., in 1973. From 1982 to 1984, the University of California lent Dr. Friedman to France, to oversee the creation of a vast new Museum of Science and Industry in Paris -- Cite des Sciences et de l'Industrie -- which is now the largest museum of its kind in the world. Many of the ideas he carried out in the French museum were later developed for the New York Hall of Science.
Although Dr. Friedman delights in the technical tools of pedagogy, he is not personally addicted to mechanical gadgetry; he seems more at home thinking and writing about the philosophy of science and the literature and art it has inspired.
In 1969, a year before he was awarded his Ph.D. in physics by Florida State, he joined the faculty of Hiram College in Hiram, Ohio, where he was granted a fellowship by the National Endowment for the Humanities. With his future wife, Michaele Thompson, who recently published her seventh mystery novel under the name Mickey Friedman, Dr. Friedman taught a course exploring the profound influence of new scientific thinking on contemporary literature.
From that time on, Dr. Friedman has been a frequent contributor to learned publications on the impact of the sciences, particularly relativity and quantum theory, on contemporary literature.
Among his many literary dissertations is an analysis of "Gravity's Rainbow," the enigmatic but enormously popular 1973 novel by Thomas Pynchon. Dr. Friedman shows in detail how the novel's thread is consciously shaped by such calculus concepts as infinitesimals and their approach to a limiting value of zero. Thermodynamic theory and the decay of certainty into chaos, important scientific notions, also mold the novel, Dr. Friedman shows. An element of the wartime plot is an accurate mathematical analysis of the probability of a Nazi V-2 rocket's hitting any given place within a target area.
Among the many modern books in which Dr. Friedman has perceived important scientific content is Lawrence Durrell's tetralogy, "The Alexandria Quartet," which the physicist describes as "a relativistic study of modern love." As in relativistic space-time, the first three novels of the collection deal with locations in space, while the fourth moves the reader back and forth in time -- the fourth dimension.
Dr. Friedman hardly expects museum visitors to read his literary papers, but he hopes that the New York Hall of Science at least offers alternatives to the cruel environments of poor people.
As the Hall of Science began construction of a new wing and an outdoor Science Playground during the past year, this hands-on museum played host to some 250,000 visitors, most of them children from minority populations brought to the museum each day in an armada of schoolbuses.
Some get more out of the visit then others. "A lot depends on the involvement of the teachers who accompany their classes to the museum," Dr. Friedman said. "In some groups, you can see that the teacher has prepared her students by assigning individual students to concentrate on specific exhibits, so that back in the classroom each student can brief the others on what he or she learned.
"But other teachers retreat to the cafeteria to drink coffee while their students wander around. You can easily imagine the effect on the students."
And if the museum could "get more parents to come to the museum and participate in science learning, we could make much more progress," he said. "Encouragement at home is crucial. Still, I think we're moving along."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark On Hints of Delay in the Euro

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the mark and ended mixed in other currency dealings yesterday after a number of senior German officials hinted that Europe's plans for monetary union might be delayed.
The remarks by the Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, and three members of Germany's Bundesbank aroused a broad rally in marks by compounding fears in the foreign-exchange market that the debut of a single European currency in January 1999 would be postponed. That would leave the mark as the predominant currency in Europe. 
 A report in Der Spiegel magazine also intensified doubts about the Euro's debut, asserting that Mr. Waigel's own internal calculations suggested Germany's Government deficit would total 4.15 percent of gross domestic product this year.
Such a ratio would be far higher than the currency plan's requirement that the deficit of any participating country total 3 percent or less of G.D.P.
Although Germany's finance ministry denied the report in Der Spiegel, the market still focused on the new speculation that the timetable for the single currency is unrealistic because Europe remains besieged by economic sluggishness and high unemployment.
In New York, the dollar settled at 1.6894 marks, down from 1.6935 marks Friday. The dollar was at 123.66 yen, up from 123.38 yen, due partly to the yen's weakness against the mark.
The demand for marks had the worst effect on the British pound, which tumbled against most currencies and hit the lowest level against the dollar since mid-October. In late New York trading, the pound cost $1.5888, down from $1.6010.
Traders said the demand for marks intensified as word spread of an interview with Mr. Waigel published yesterday in Germany's Bild Zeitung newspaper, which quoted him as saying strict adherence to the union's criteria was more important than a punctual start-up of the Euro.
The impact of Mr. Waigel's interview was reinforced by Edgar Meister and Franz-Christoph Zeitler, who are both members of the Bundesbank's policy-making council. They said it was premature to say whether Germany would qualify for monetary union participation. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Tyrant's Crisis in Zaire

 BODY:
For more than 30 years Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, made himself one of Africa's richest and most powerful men by relying on a simple, cynical formula. He crushed, corrupted or co-opted domestic dissent, made sure his army was too weak to threaten his rule and cultivated the West with a militantly anti-Communist foreign policy, thereby insuring outside military help to put down the occasional armed revolt.
Now, however, Mr. Mobutu's regime is in serious military trouble, and no foreign friends are rushing to bail it out. That is for the best.
With the cold war over, former foreign allies like the United States and France did nothing in recent days to stop rebel troops from marching virtually unopposed into Zaire's third-largest city, Kisangani. Serbian mercenaries whom Mr. Mobutu had recruited to defend the city fled after Zairian Army units began defecting to the rebel side. 
 Kisangani gives the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, substantial control over Zaire's mineral wealth. He can now consolidate his rule over the gold-producing eastern third of the country while commanding river access to the rich copper and cobalt deposits of the south.
The corruption, negligence and brutality of the Mobutu era have been an economic as well as a political disaster for Zaire. There is a chance, however, that the untested Mr. Kabila, who has spent much of his life trying to mount an armed rebellion, is better. He has reportedly reined in corruption and brought a measure of economic revival to the rebel-ruled east. But he has yet to commit himself firmly to democratic rule.
At this point, it is not even certain that the ethnically divided, politically demoralized country can remain united. It was Mr. Mobutu who created a unified country out of the secession-riven ruins of the former Belgian Congo in the mid-1960's, renamed it Zaire and has dominated it ever since.
In those early days, Washington supported Mr. Mobutu as a preferable alternative to leftist rivals who declared their admiration for Russia or China. American policy makers also hoped, in vain it turned out, that he would follow economic policies favorable to Western business.
Long after his domestic misrule became evident, Mr. Mobutu capitalized on his anti-Communist foreign policies to win renewed Western support. Zaire became a key ally in America's proxy war against a pro-Soviet regime in Angola and a useful partner to French foreign policy ventures in Africa. Most recently, he provided sanctuary and weapons to France's former Rwandan Hutu militia allies who fled their own country after organizing the mass murder of Rwandan Tutsi.
That last adventure contributed to Mr. Mobutu's current plight. To push marauding Hutu militias farther from their border, Rwanda's present Tutsi Government lent crucial early support to Mr. Kabila's rebellion.
America's interest in the present crisis is primarily humanitarian. Washington should work diplomatically for an early cease-fire to spare innocent civilians and allow the repatriation of tens of thousands of unarmed Hutu refugees trapped by the fighting. It has no interest in prolonging for a single day Mr. Mobutu's disastrous misrule.

HEADLINE: In German Big Steel, a Surprise Hostile Bid

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 17

 BODY:
Germany's largest steel producer said today that it was the target of a hostile takeover attempt by a rival steelmaker, an almost unheard-of act here that appears driven by the growing competitive pressures that have hammered profits at both companies.
A spokesman for Thyssen A.G. said that the Krupp-Hoesch group was planning a hostile takeover and that Thyssen would fight it by all means possible. Krupp refused to comment, but said it would issue a statement on the matter Tuesday morning. 
 A deal for Thyssen would be worth at least $6.4 billion based on its closing stock price today.
A merger of the two companies would create a conglomerate with $38 billion in sales and a work force of 183,000. Analysts said a merger could easily lead to job cuts of anywhere from 10,000 to 30,000 workers, that it would also almost certainly accelerate plans at the two companies to sell off noncore businesses.
"You need economies of scale, and, physically, their locations are good for consolidation," said Terrence Sinclair, a steel industry analyst at Salomon Brothers in London.
American-style hostile takeovers are extremely rare in Germany, in part because big companies here frequently own each other's stock or share common institutional investors such as the major commercial banks. But any merger between this country's two biggest steel manufacturers would immediately set off alarms among both unions and politicians here, as well as with Europe's antitrust regulators.
Both Krupp-Hoesch and Thyssen have been struggling in the last several years, weighed down by brutal competition in the worldwide steel market and lackluster profits at scores of ancillary businesses.
Thyssen, with $24 billion in sales, saw its income plunge by more than half in 1996 to $208 million. But the company has embarked on a sweeping program to sell billions of dollars worth of properties and severely prune its thicket of 336 separate businesses. Its stock has recently climbed on the basis of hopes for the revamping as well as on expected gains from a stronger dollar, which makes German exports to the United States cheaper.
The Krupp group, known formally as Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp, has worldwide sales of $14 billion and saw its net income decline by about 59 percent in 1996 to $122 million. Krupp and Hoesch merged in a friendly deal in 1992.
Thyssen and Krupp-Hoesch are similar in many ways, according to Mr. Sinclair of Salomon. They both derive about one-third of the revenues and, in good years, as much as two-thirds of their profits, from steel. Both have also plunged heavily into the production of auto parts, an area where Krupp may be expecting to reap the benefit of consolidating customer bases.
There has been repeated speculation in recent months about a possible merger between two steel operations, though both companies have denied those rumors on several occasions. Indeed, the two companies already have a big joint venture in stainless steel production called Krupp Thyssen Nirosta, which is the largest single stainless steel manufacturer in the world.
But executives at Thyssen immediately denounced any attempt by Krupp to take over their company. The apparent attempt "can only be an attempt by the Krupp enterprise to solve its own considerable problems through the reserves of Thyssen," said Reiner Hochscheid, a spokesman for the company, this evening.
The announcement by Thyssen was made after trading ended on the Frankfurt stock exchange. Earlier, shares of Thyssen closed at 346 marks, down from 354 marks on Friday, but up about 17 percent since the beginning of the year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Pearson's New Chief Discloses Big Plans for Financial Times

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 17

 BODY:
Marjorie M. Scardino, the chief executive of Pearson P.L.C., the British media and entertainment company, announced plans today to invest $160 million over the next five years in The Financial Times, one of the company's prized possessions, to bolster its circulation and brand name in the United States and Asia.
Mrs. Scardino also pledged sweeping changes in the culture of the company, which also owns Penguin publishing, Madame Tussaud's wax museum and several broadcasting stakes. She said she had put in place a new management team and instituted a rewards and accountability system to increase profits and cut costs. "The major immediate changes under new management at Pearson will be the ones of style and focus on performance," she told reporters at the company's headquarters here today. 
 The moves today were the first by Mrs. Scardino since she took the helm on Jan. 1. Mrs. Scardino, a Texas native, is the first woman to head a leading British company, and her appointment had raised eyebrows in the City, London's male-dominated financial center.
While analysts had awaited her comments for clues on the direction of Pearson, she declined to offer details on any sales or reorganizations.
"As time goes on, we may change the business we're in, too, as we work toward being first in a few important markets," she said. "But we won't be selling things just to be tidy. We'll be selling things where the move will make the company more valuable for our shareholders, of today and tomorrow."
Mrs. Scardino spoke after Pearson reported earnings for the year. Before a 100 million charge for improper accounting practices at its Penguin unit in the United States, which Pearson disclosed in February, Pearson said operating profits rose 8 percent, to 281 million, or $447 million, from 260 million in 1995.
After the charge, operating profit fell 30 percent in 1996, to 181 million. After gains and charges, profit was 356.8 million, down 2 percent. Sales rose 20 percent, to 2.19 billion.
Analysts said there were few surprises in the earnings report.
"It looks good so far, but it is early days," said Caroline Slater, a media analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson in London, reflecting a general sentiment of welcoming the new management but refraining from early expressions of optimism .
Pearson shares fell 14.5 pence today, to 7.565, amid a broad decline in prices on the London Stock Exchange. The stock had climbed to a 52-week high of 7.975 in January.
Pearson's new push will initially focus on The Financial Times. The company said new printing sites for the newspaper would be established in Italy and Singapore to expand its reach.
And the editor of The Financial Times, Richard Lambert, will move to New York City for a year, where he will oversee the expansion of the paper's presence in the United States. Mrs. Scardino told the Dow Jones News Service that Pearson would seek to more than double The Financial Times's current North American circulation of 35,000 copies daily over five years.
Pearson owns a 50 percent stake in the Economist magazine and a London investment bank, Lazard Brothers. Its entertainment division includes the software publisher Mindscape and Pearson Television, which is starting a new channel in Britain, and Madame Tussaud's, a big tourist attraction. Its educational division includes HarperCollins Educational Publishing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Ease on New Talk Of an Interest-Rate Increase

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday, as investors worried that the Federal Reserve would pre-emptively raise rates and the dollar eased in trading against the German mark.
When the dollar weakens, it makes dollar-denominated investments like United States Government debt less attractive to foreign investors. But market participants' biggest concern is that strong economic growth could lead to inflation and higher interest rates. 
 Yesterday the National Association of Home Builders reported that its market index reached 58 in March, up from 54 in February, a sign of continued strength in housing. And that fanned investor fears of a rate rise at the March 25 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's rate-setting arm.
Also heightening such fears were comments by the president of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, Robert Perry, a voting member of the F.O.M.C., who said in Munich that "we must be ready to act to head off increases in inflation before they begin to show up in the inflation data." Bonds later cut their losses when Mr. Perry added that the Federal funds rate was not far from where it should be.
In trading, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond slipped 5/32, to a price of 95 29/32, to yield 6.95 percent, up from 6.94 percent on Friday.
Despite what analysts called tame producer price figures last week, traders remain apprehensive about interest rates and on whether the Consumer Price Index tomorrow will confirm what producer prices suggested last week -- that the economy is growing and inflation is being contained. A tightening of rates by the Fed committee next week is not a given; the central bank could hold off until May.
Jack Regan, chief derivatives strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, commenting on investors' skittishness yesterday, said, "The economic centipede continues to drop one economic shoe after another."
Each piece of data, Mr. Regan said, would be scrutinized by the central bank right up until the morning of its rate meeting.
And the market will be listening, too, as the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, returns to Capitol Hill this week, to a House Banking subcommittee and the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
"The yield on the long bond did rise to 7 percent today," Mr. Regan noted, "but without more convincing data to support that yield level, it will be difficult to maintain."
Market analysts suggest that if forthcoming data show economic growth outpacing the expectations of traders and of the Federal Reserve, the yield on the 30-year bond could go as high as 7.25 percent.
The Commerce Department today is to release its report on housing starts in February, along with two private weekly retail sales reports, followed by the Consumer Price Index figures tomorrow. On Thursday, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia is to report the results of its business survey; also, January trade data and weekly jobless claims will be released.
The supply of debt may also weigh on the market since the Treasury will announce the size of next week's two- and five-year note auctions.
"I'd say the odds for a Fed tightening next Tuesday are 55-45 that they go," Mr. Regan said. "I'd like it to be 100 percent that they go because it clears the air. If they they don't, it will mean at least two more months of turbulence in the financial markets."
At yesterday's regular weekly bill auction, investor demand was moderate, with the three-month maturity offered at an average rate of 5.13 percent, up from 5.06 percent last week. For the six-month bill, the average rate was 5.26 percent, up from 5.18 percent. This week's rates are the highest since 7.02 percent on Sept. 23, the last time the long bond yield was above the 7 percent level.

LENGTH: 1247 words

HEADLINE: YELTSIN SHAKES UP CABINET TO SPEED ECONOMIC CHANGE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 17

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin filled the senior ranks of the Russian Cabinet with economic reformers today, making good on his pledge to overhaul his Government and quicken the pace of economic change.
The shake-up, which gave Russia its most aggressively market-oriented Government since 1992, is aimed primarily at reviving a stalled economic program that has created fertile ground for Mr. Yeltsin's political opponents. 
 But coming three days before a summit meeting with President Clinton in Helsinki, the changes are also likely to enhance Russia's plea for a greater role in international economic affairs.
Mr. Yeltsin's most important move was appointing Boris Y. Nemtsov, 37, the dynamic Governor of a region regarded as a showplace of economic change, to serve as one of two First Deputy Prime Ministers.
Together with the appointment last week of Anatoly B. Chubais, 41, as the chief architect of economic change, the move gives vital responsibilities for economic and social policy to two of the country's most vigorous and most pro-market officials.
It was not the only move to strengthen the reformers' hands. The President elevated other allies of Mr. Chubais, the other First Deputy Prime Minister. Streamlining the hierarchy, he cut the number of Deputy Prime Ministers. And he abolished several ministries, including the Ministry of Industry and Ministry of Defense Industry, which had been obstacles to economic reform.
Today's shake-up somewhat brightens prospects for the summit meeting, which begins on Thursday.
Anxious about the prospect of the NATO alliance expanding into the former Soviet bloc countries of Central and Eastern Europe, Russia has been pushing in recent weeks for a face-saving invitation to join major world economic organizations like the Group of Seven industrial countries. The new reform cast in the Government may strengthen Russia's chances for closer economic integration with the West.
Seeking to project the image of a forceful President, Russian television tonight showed Mr. Yeltsin meeting with the telegenic Mr. Nemtsov, who has often been mentioned as a future presidential candidate.
"Two young men, you and Anatoly Chubais, will set up a young team from scratch in the Government," Mr. Yeltsin said. "All appointments for ministerial positions will be cleared with you."
Mr. Yelstin's moves appear to propel the Government five years back in time, when the reformer Yegor T. Gaidar was the unrivaled economic policy maker.
For the first time since 1992, noted Anders Aslund, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, "you don't have another First Deputy Prime Minister trying to sabotage reform."
There are many reasons why the Yeltsin Government has rediscovered the theme of economic change.
One is the stagnation of the Russian economy. Yeltsin officials worry that the failure to achieve economic growth and pay overdue wages will play into the hands of the Communists and Aleksandr I. Lebed, the President's former national security aide, who yearns to replace his former boss.
As this is not an election year, it is an opportune time to push for wrenching changes that may not pay dividends for several years.
Still another reason lies in the political skill of Mr. Chubais. An ardent capitalist, Mr. Chubais has made a sort of Faustian bargain with the powerful Russian banking and financial community to push ahead with privatization and other market reforms. As head of the privatization program, he was accused of cutting deals favorable to the bankers who later helped finance Mr. Yeltsin's re-election campaign.
It remains to be seen if the new team can overcome the politically well-connected special interests, pleading industrialists, plodding bureaucracy and Communist opposition that have hampered previous reform efforts.
One of Mr. Nemtsov's tasks, for example, is to clamp down on economic abuses by monopolies like the gas and electricity industries. But Gazprom, the huge natural gas monopoly, enjoys close ties to Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who used to head the company.
Even the reformers acknowledge that the economic problems are daunting. And Mr. Nemtsov told reporters today that his decision to join the Government might turn out to be political suicide.
To be sure, the reformers have already accomplished a great deal. Russia has privatized much of the economy. Inflation has been driven down from an annual rate of more than 2,000 percent in 1992 to 22 percent in 1996.
But now the market advocates confront the complex task of establishing new institutions and revamping entrenched social programs.
Reform-minded economists have been urging the development of an effective system of unemployment insurance to make it politically possible to lay off workers. They have urged a reduction in housing subsidies to save money and spur the development of a housing market.
Overhaul of the huge social security system is also high on the agenda of many economists, as is tax reform to encourage investment.
The need for foreign and domestic investment is clear. The World Bank has forcast no economic growth for Russia this year. That would be an improvement compared with years of a declining economy. But it would fall short of the Government's projection that the economy would grow by 5 percent this year.
"For the past year the reform effort has stalled," Lawrence H. Summers, the United States Deputy Treasury Secretary, warned recently.
Under Mr. Yeltsin's reorganization, Prime Minister Chernomyrdin will remain No. 2 in the Government. The stolid Mr. Chernomyrdin is much liked by the United States and also enjoys good ties with industrialists and the Communists. But he accomplished little during Mr. Yeltsin's extended convalescence, prompting calls for his ouster. He appears to have gone along with the Government overhaul to keep his job.
After Mr. Chernomyrdin, the next in rank in the new Cabinet are Mr. Chubais and Mr. Nemtsov.
Besides serving as a First Deputy Prime Minister, Mr. Chubais, the father of privatization, will oversee the Finance Ministry. A man who has been in and out of official favor as his programs have brought great public pain, Mr. Chubais is the clear political victor in today's overhaul.
Mr. Nemtsov will oversee the reform of social programs, regulation of monpolies and relations with regional authorities.
As Governor of the Nizhni Nogorod region 250 miles east of Moscow, Mr. Nemtsov spearheaded land, banking and industrial reforms, making his region one of the most attractive in Russia for foreign investors.
Mr. Nemtsov promptly struck a populist theme today by promising to dispense with fancy limousines, take on the monopolies, insure that wages are paid and narrow the gap between rich and poor.
Under Mr. Chubais and Mr. Nemtsov will be six Deputy Prime Ministers. They include Chubais supporters like Alfred R. Kokh, 35, an economist who served as head of the privatization agency.
Anatoly S. Kulikov, 50, the hard-line Interior Minister, will retain his post as Deputy Prime Minister. Among other duties, he will oversee the tax police.
Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov and Defense Minister Igor N. Rodionov will keep their jobs.
Mr. Nemtsov, for his part, suggested that there might be more changes to come. He told reporters that he thought a conflict among the top officials would be avoided for now.
"A conflict will erupt, but later," he said.

The senior members of President Boris N. Yeltsin's newly overhauled Government:
 
PRIME MINISTER
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, 58
Enjoys good ties with Communists, Russian industrialists and the West. Keeps his post as Prime Minister, but the new appointments are expexted to reduce his influence.
 
FIRST DEPUTY PRIME MINISTERS
Anatoly B. Chubais, 41
Father of Russian privatization. Dismissed by Yeltsin last year when Communists made him a symbol of economic distress in the new Russia, but re-emerged as a mastermind of Yeltsin election campaign and, now, the top figure for economic policy.
 
Boris Y. Nemtsov, 37
Made a reputation as reform-minded Governor of the Nizhny Novgorod region, overhauling land, banking and industrial policies. Will be in charge of reforming social sector and regulating monopolies.
 
DEPUTY PRIME MINISTERS
 
Alfred R. Kokh, 35
Economist and ally of Chubais, he heads privatization program.
 
Yakov M. Yurinson, 52
Another reformer, will also serve as Economics Minister.
 
Oleg N. Sysuyev, 42
Former Mayor of Samara, an aerospace center that has worked hard to attract foreign investment. Will deal with policy toward Russia's regions.
 
Vladimir B. Bulgak, 55
Will be in charge of science policy. Previously served as Minister of Communications and is liked by the Chubais camp.
 
Valery P. Serov, 56
Known as a bureaucrat and not a reformer. Thought to have good relations with Chernomyrdin and will continue to deal with relations with the former Soviet republics and with regional policy.
 
Anatoly S. Kulikov, 50
Has angered reformers by advocating bank nationalization. Will reain his job as Interior Minister, overseeing law-enforcement agencies that deal with economic crime.

HEADLINE: 3 Prime Sites in Times Square Renewal Plan Go Up for Sale

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Development rights to three large parcels in Times Square have been put up for sale, and many real estate experts said yesterday that they expected builders to respond with offers swiftly, providing fresh momentum to development plans that had languished for more than a decade.
Among those who have indicated interest in the sites, according to state officials and real estate industry executives, are the developer Douglas Durst and the Marriott hotel chain. Under one plan, Mr. Durst would build an office tower that would serve as American headquarters for the Reuters news agency. 
 The development rights to the three sites are held by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, a pivotal player in the ambitious Times Square urban-renewal project since the mid-1980's.
Prudential sold its largest parcel -- on the east side of Broadway from 42d Street to 43d -- to Mr. Durst a year ago, and since then there has been intense speculation over whether the company would sell off its other parcels.
"We have been playing with veiled faces, but we are out in the open now," said Dick Riley, a Prudential spokesman, in an interview yesterday. "All our properties are in play."
The remaining sites include large parcels lying on three sides of One Times Square at the south end of the square.
The decision by Prudential to bow out marks a milestone in the tortuous history of the Times Square redevelopment effort. The company joined the project in the boom years of the mid-1980's, but saw its plans for four huge office towers fall victim to a torrent of lawsuits and ultimately a collapse in the office real-estate market.
In selling off the development rights to the sites -- the land remains technically the property of the state, which will grant long-term leases -- Prudential will also transfer to the new developers the lucrative tax breaks offered by the state and city as part of the redevelopment effort.
Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the state's Empire State Development Corporation, said yesterday that Mr. Durst had been negotiating to build an office tower on the west side of Seventh Avenue from 42d Street to 43d Street -- widely regarded as the choicest of the three parcels -- with Reuters as his tenant.
That approach would be similar to the one he employed last April, when he purchased development rights on the east side of Seventh Avenue with Conde Nast, the publishing house, as the major tenant.
Another Times Square suitor, according to the real estate executives, is the Marriott chain, which has approached Prudential about buying rights to the triangular block bounded by 42d Street, 41st Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue. The executives said Marriott wants to build a new hotel, capitalizing on Times Square's growing tourist trade.
That proposal would require state officials to accede to changes in the original terms of the Times Square redevelopment plan, which called for office towers on all three of the sites Prudential now controls. Marriott executives could not be reached by phone last night for comment.
The last of Prudential's parcels -- now dominated by the Disney Store on the west side of Seventh Avenue between 41st Street and 42d Street -- has not yet attracted bids by developers, real estate executives said.
It was not clear what prices Prudential was seeking for the sites. Real estate values in Times Square have risen rapidly in the last few years, and some industry experts speculated yesterday that Prudential might decide to sit on the sites a while longer, to see if prices continued to go up.
But most industry executives said they expected that Prudential's decision to openly seek buyers would lead quickly to the final phase of the Times Square renewal process.
"I would expect these sites to fall like dominos," said Michael R. Laginestra, managing director of Edward S. Gordon Inc., a commercial real estate company. He said the Times Square parcels would attract strong demand because of the area's new found appeal to corporations, and because development sites large enough for major corporate installations are in short supply.
"It won't be immediate," he said. "It took more than 10 years for the first parcel. It might take another year for the second, and the other two should fall within months after that."
If large-scale office or hotel construction begins any time soon, it may take people in the neighborhood off guard because it will displace many new businesses like Ferrara's, Hansen's Brewery and other restaurants that have sprouted up under bright neon signs over the last year.
But the land under the new Times Square businesses is owned by New York State, which has extended them leases that are valid only until someone agrees to break ground for the long delayed high-rises. The only store that is guaranteed a large space in whatever high-rise is built on its site is the Disney Store at the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue.
Since 1990, New York State has condemned Times Square property for the office towers planned by Prudential, and the company has paid $300 million to reimburse the state for its condemnation costs. Prudential will eventually get that money back, but not until the sites are finally developed -- another factor that could push the company to move quickly to sell the parcels.
Mr. Durst has approached Prudential in a partnership with George Klein, a New York City developer who, until a year ago, had been a partner of Prudential's in its Times Square project. The Durst-Klein partnership is considered by some in the industry to have an advantage in the bidding process, mainly because Mr. Durst has already purchased one large parcel from Prudential.
Mr. Durst said yesterday that he hoped to finalize a deal, and begin construction within months.
"I would be able to move quickly," he said, adding that he was prepared to negotiate with Prudential even before he has a firm commitment from Reuters or any other large corporate tenant for the building he has in mind.
Robert Crooke, a vice president of Reuters, said yesterday that Times Square was one of several locations it was considering -- including sites in New Jersey and Connecticut -- for a new North American headquarters. The company's 1,850 New York City employees are now divided between four buildings in Manhattan.
Prudential has retained Lazard Freres, the investment banking concern, and Cushman and Wakefield, the commercial real estate company, as its advisers on what to do with the Times Square sites. Prudential executives declined comment yesterday on the timing of their sale, but said no potential buyers have an inside track.
"No developer is a gatekeeper in this process," Mr. Riley said. "There are lots of players who can bring something to the table, and we are prepared to listen."
